(1	Category:Chad at the Olympics	[[Category:Nations at the Olympics]][[Category:Sport in Chad|Ol]][[Category:Chad at multi-sport events]])
(1	Carolina Thunderbirds	{{for|the team beginning play in 2017|Carolina Thunderbirds (FHL)}}{{Infobox sports team| team          = Carolina Thunderbirds| current       =| color1        =| color2        =| logo          = CarolinaThunderbirds.png| pixels        =| founded       = 1981| league        =| history       =| arena         = Winston-Salem Memorial Coliseum| ballpark      =| stadium       =| city          =| colors        =| colours       =| owner         =| president     =| coach         =| manager       =| championships =| titles        =| cheerleaders  =| dancers       =| mascot        =| broadcasters  =| media         =| website       =| uniforms      =}}The '''Carolina Thunderbirds''' were a professional [[ice hockey]] team located in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]], United States.  The Thunderbirds played their home games at the old [[Winston-Salem Memorial Coliseum]] before the arena was demolished in 1989.  The team played in the [[Atlantic Coast Hockey League (1981–87)|Atlantic Coast Hockey League]] from 1981 to 1987, the [[All-American Hockey League]] during 1987–88 and finally moved into the newly created [[East Coast Hockey League]] in 1988.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=138|isbn=1-894974-21-2}}</ref>The Carolina Thunderbirds were one of five teams that played during the inaugural season of East Coast Hockey League.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=138|isbn=1-894974-21-2}}</ref>  In an effort to protect the league's image, ECHL commissioner [[Patrick J. Kelly|Pat Kelly]] had suspended several of the Thunderbirds' players and, as a result, the Thunderbirds were forced to face the [[Johnstown Chiefs]] for the seventh and deciding game in the league's finals with just 11 skaters.<ref>{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=139|isbn=1-894974-21-2}}</ref>  In spite of this hardship, the Carolina Thunderbirds won the first ever league championship,<ref>http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/echl19891989.html</ref> and were awarded the [[Riley Cup]] for the 1988–89 ECHL season.The team changed its name to the '''Winston-Salem Thunderbirds''' before the start of [[1989–90 ECHL season|1989–90]] season, and the team remained in the ECHL until after the end of the [[1991–92 ECHL season|1991–92]] season when it was announced by Ed Broyhill, Co-Owner, that the Winston-Salem club would be moving to [[West Virginia]] to play as the [[Wheeling Thunderbirds]].<ref>http://www.hockeydb.com/stte/wheeling-thunderbirds-8951.html</ref>== Head coaches ==* [[Rick Dudley]] 1981–86* [[Brendon Watson]] 1988–89== Championships ==*1982–83: [[Atlantic Coast Hockey League (1981–87)|ACHL]] regular season champions*1982–83: ACHL play-off champions*1983–84: ACHL regular season champions*1984–85: ACHL regular season champions*1985–86: ACHL regular season champions*1985–86: ACHL play-off champions*1987–88: [[All-American Hockey League|AAHL]] play-off champions*1988–89: [[East Coast Hockey League|ECHL]] play-off champions ([[Riley Cup]])==Playoffs=====Atlantic Coast Hockey League===*1981–82: Lost to [[Salem Raiders|Salem]] 4-1 in semifinals.*1982–83: Defeated [[Virginia Raiders|Virginia]] 4-0 in semifinals; defeated [[Mohawk Valley Stars|Mohawk Valley]] 4-0 to win championship.*1983–84: Defeated [[Mohawk Valley Stars|Mohawk Valley]] 4-1 in semifinals; lost to [[Erie Golden Blades|Erie]] 4-1 in finals.*1984–85: Defeated [[Virginia Lancers|Virginia]] 4-0 in semifinals; defeated [[Erie Golden Blades|Erie]] 4-2 to win championship.*1985–86: Defeated [[Mohawk Valley Stars|Mohawk Valley]] 4-2 in semifinals; defeated [[Erie Golden Blades|Erie]] 4-1 to win championship.*1986–87: Lost to [[Virginia Lancers|Virginia]] 4-1 in semifinals.===All-American Hockey League===*1987–88: Defeated [[Virginia Lancers|Virginia]] to win championship.===East Coast Hockey League===*1988–89: Defeated [[Erie Panthers|Erie]] 4-0 in semifinals; defeated [[Johnstown Chiefs|Johnstown]] 4-3 to win championship.*1989–90: Defeated [[Nashville Knights|Nashville]] 4-1 in quarterfinals; received semifinal bye; lost to [[Greensboro Monarchs|Greensboro]] 4-1 in finals.*1990–91: Did not qualify.*1991–92: Lost to [[Richmond Renegades|Richmond]] 3-2 in quarterfinals.==Notable players==* [[Doug Smith (author)|Doug Smith]] — A member of that 1988–89 Thunderbirds team, co-wrote the book ''Goon: The True Story of an Unlikely Journey into Minor League Hockey'', which was adapted into the motion picture [[Goon (film)|Goon]], and a sequel, [[Goon: Last of the Enforcers]]. Smith is portrayed in both movies by the actor [[Seann William Scott]] as Doug Glatt.* [[John Torchetti]] — A member of 1988–89 championship squad who became the head coach of the [[National Hockey League|NHL's]] [[Florida Panthers]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=140|isbn=1-894974-21-2}}</ref>{{s-start}}{{succession box | before = Inaugural | title = ECHL [[Kelly Cup|Riley Cup]] Champions | years = 1988–89 | after = [[Greensboro Monarchs]]}}{{s-end}}==References=={{Reflist}}{{ECHLdefunct}}{{Defunct North Carolina sports teams}}[[Category:All-American Hockey League teams]][[Category:Defunct ECHL teams]][[Category:Sports in the Piedmont Triad]][[Category:Ice hockey teams in North Carolina]][[Category:Sports in Winston-Salem, North Carolina]][[Category:Defunct sports teams in North Carolina]])
(1	Vicarage Road	{{for|the planned London Underground station|Watford Vicarage Road tube station}}{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}}{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}{{Infobox venue| stadium_name      = Vicarage Road Stadium| image             =[[File:Vicarage Road 2015.jpg|250px|center|Vicarage Road]]| nickname          = "The Vic"| location          = Vicarage Road, [[Watford]], WD18 0ER| coordinates       = {{Coord|51|38|59.41|N|0|24|5.35|W|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:GB|display=it}}| built             = 1922| opened            = 30 August 1922| renovated         = 2017 ongoing| seating_capacity  = 21,577<ref>[http://nl.soccerway.com/teams/england/watford-football-club/696/venue/ Engeland – Watford – Resultaten, programma's, selectie, foto's, videos en nieuws – Soccerway]. Nl.soccerway.com (2013-01-09). Retrieved on 2016-10-19.</ref>| owner             = [[Watford F.C.]]| tenants           = [[Watford F.C.]] (1922–present)<br>[[Wealdstone F.C.]] (1991–1994)<br> [[Saracens F.C.]] (1997–2012)| dimensions        = 120 x 80 [[yards]] (110 x 73 meters)| surface           = [[Desso GrassMaster]]|}}'''Vicarage Road''', a stadium in [[Watford]], Hertfordshire, England, is the home of the [[association football|football]] club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] of the [[Premier League]]. An all-seater stadium, its current capacity is 23,700 following  the completion of the new Sir Elton John Stand in 2014, and expansion work in 2015 and again throughout 2016 and 2017, this includes the expansion of the football pitch.<ref name=FootballLeague>[http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/watford_2293498_692872 Watford: Club info] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421020630/http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/watford_2293498_692872 |date=21 April 2012 }}. [[The Football League]]. 1 August 2010. Accessed 30 September 2011.</ref><ref name="ground expand 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/150608-vicarage-road-stadium-north-east-corner-2486084.aspx |title=Stadium Update: North-East Corner Transformation To Begin |publisher=Watford F.C. |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref>==History==It has been the home of Watford since 1922, when the club moved from [[Cassio Road]].<ref name=WhosWho>Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 9. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}.</ref> The ground was officially opened by Col. Charles Healey of [[Benskins Brewery]] for the visit of [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on 30 August 1922. In addition to being Watford's home since opening, the stadium was also home to [[Wealdstone F.C.]] between 1991 and 1993,<ref>[http://www.wealdstonefc.co.uk/page.php?history.htm Wealdstone Football Club history]. Wealdstone Football Club Supporters Club. Accessed 2 October 2011.</ref> and to [[rugby union]] side [[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]] from 1997 until they moved to their new home at [[Allianz Park]] in February 2013.<ref>Allnutt, Tom (22 January 2013). [http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/10176843.Saracens___Thank_you_Watford_FC_/ "Saracens: 'Thank you Watford FC'"]. ''Watford Observer''. Retrieved 25 January 2012.</ref>After purchasing the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] of the stadium from Benskins in January 2002, Watford's financial situation forced them to sell and lease back the stadium later that year.<ref>[[David Conn]] (21 September 2002). [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1712032.html New owners of Vicarage Road revealed as Watford wither]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Accessed 2 May 2014.</ref> However, after a campaign entitled 'Let's Buy Back The Vic' with donations coming from fans, as well as celebrity former owner [[Elton John]] donating the entire proceeds of a concert held at the venue, the club was able to repurchase the stadium in September 2004.<ref>[[Graham Simpson (businessman)|Graham Simpson]] (31 March 2005). [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:7wGg07yRZuMJ:www.watfordfc.com/staticFiles/13/7/0,,10400~1811,00.doc+Watford+buy+back+vicarage+road+site:watfordfc.com&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESg11_FMZLJuNOapCZh8zMpuT5gRmuw-ZGB6HIMIMFpo0YzluzqXFuR2rfkciu7HawjCTAItRoqJo3D3_5I1Yo9xuhQSVM5swqxCH_2ujKZ-K2nFYY_VT-_OkXWBJU8pZlmLCxGI&sig=AHIEtbTpXSVL15ZcQJJIzWFq8JoILLW_1A Watford Leisure PLC: Interim Results for the six months ended 31 December 2004]. Watford Leisure PLC. Accessed 30 September 2011.</ref>On 1 September 2011 it hosted [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21’s]] [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 8]] match against [[Azerbaijan national under-21 football team|Azerbaijan under-21’s]]. The hosts thrashed the visitors 6 – 0 with braces from [[Craig Dawson]] and [[Henri Lansbury]] and single goals from [[Jordan Henderson]] and [[Martyn Waghorn]]. There were 7,738 in attendance.==Vicarage Road Stand==[[File:Vicarageroad1.jpg|thumb|left|Rugby game at Vicarage Road, 2005]]The Vicarage Road Stand was built following the conclusion of the 1992–93 season. Previously an open terrace, the all-seater stand was built to comply with the [[Taylor Report]] and raise the standard of the ground. It cost £2.3&nbsp;million to build and had a capacity of 5,800 people. Construction was largely funded by the £1.2m sale of [[Bruce Dyer]] in 1994.<ref name=HarrowTimes/><ref>Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 75. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}.</ref>Originally a mere earth bank when the club moved to the ground, it was gradually transformed into a conventional terrace. In 1978, an electronic scoreboard was put up, which became an iconic symbol of Watford's eighties heyday. In a display of solidarity with the home support, [[Graham Taylor (footballer)|Graham Taylor]] maintained that the benches for the coaching staff and substitute on the side of the pitch would remain exposed to the elements until such time as the home end was covered.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book-->Its final game as a terrace was a 1–0 loss to [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] on 8 May 1993. It opened to the public once more on 18 September 1993, with Watford defeating [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] 3–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wfc.net/stadium.htm|title=The Stadium|publisher=wfc.net|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref>Previously the home stand, it now houses the away support. A partition was subsequently added, meaning that both home and away support could be put in the stand. Half of the stand is given to away fans, and the other half is used as the family area for home fans. It also houses wheelchair supporters of both teams.<!--Sourced to stadium plan--> Since August 2012, the stand has been home to the Hornets Shop<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/120810-hornets-shop-move-305371.aspx|title=RETAIL: New Home For The Hornets Shop|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=10 August 2012|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503045413/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/120810-hornets-shop-move-305371.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>==The Rookery Stand==[[File:Rookery, Vicarage Road.jpg|thumb|alt=Part of a stadium, consisting of yellow and red seats. A grass football pitch is visible to the left.|The Rookery stand]]The Rookery Stand was built over the course of the [[1994-95 in English football|1994–95 season]]. Another former terrace, the all-seater Rookery stand has a capacity of 6,960. Larger than the Vicarage Road stand, it has facilities on two levels and also holds most of the club's administrative areas. The stand cost £1.6&nbsp;million to build, approximately £300,000 of this figure was contributed by the Football Trust, with the remaining money coming from the £2.3m sale of [[Paul Furlong]] by then-owner [[Jack Petchey]] in 1994.<ref name=HarrowTimes>[http://www.harrowtimes.co.uk/news/295444.the_details_are_petchey/ The details are Petchey]. ''Harrow Times''. 7 May 2003. Accessed 2 October 2011.</ref><ref>Trefor Jones (1996). ''The Watford Football Club Illustrated Who's Who.'' T.G. Jones. p. 91. {{ISBN|0-9527458-0-1}}.</ref>When Watford moved from Cassio Road, this end of the ground featured a roof over a cinder bank, and over the years the roof eventually had to be removed for safety reasons. The Supporters' Club eventually raised funds to enable the Rookery End to feature concrete terracing under cover, and this aim was realised in 1959.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book-->The new stand, replacing the 1959 model was used by Watford supporters for the first time on 22 April 1995, for the visit of [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]]. As part of redevelopment work in conjunction with the Watford Health Campus, 164 units of affordable housing, known locally as ''The Wrap'', were built on and around the Rookery end. Construction finished in 2009.<ref>Alex Hill (4 November 2009). [http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/news/4720611.Mayor_Wraps_up_football_club_housing/ Mayor Dorothy Thornhill Wraps up Vicarage Road housing]. ''[[Watford Observer]]''. Accessed 2 October 2011.</ref>The Rookery is the "home end". It lends its name to the Watford fans' podcast, ''From The Rookery End''.<ref>[http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/9171001.Cherished_memories_for_Hornets_fans/ Watford fans podcast "From the Rookery End" call for supporters' memories]. ''Watford Observer''. 1 August 2011. Accessed 1 October 2011.</ref> The stand was known as the ''Rover South'' for Saracens matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saracens.com/news/view.php?Id=4271|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403000600/http://www.saracens.com/news/view.php?Id=4271|archivedate=3 April 2012|title=Changes to the South West turnstiles|publisher=[[Saracens F.C.|Saracens]]|date=10 January 2008|accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref>==The Graham Taylor Stand==[[File:Vicarage Road Rous and SW Corner 2012.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A two-tiered seating area featuring red, yellow and black seats, running along the length of a football pitch.|The Graham Taylor Stand and incomplete south west corner (left), pictured in 2012.]]The Graham Taylor Stand was renamed for the 2014–15 season, taking its name from the club's most successful manager [[Graham Taylor (footballer)|Graham Taylor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-graham-taylor-stand-1520316.aspx|title=GRAHAM TAYLOR OBE: Hornets To Honour Former Manager With Stand Re-Naming|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=1 May 2014|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503044213/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-graham-taylor-stand-1520316.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It was previously named after former [[FIFA]] president Sir [[Stanley Rous]]. The official renaming ceremony took place on 29 November 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/watford-fc-graham-taylor-stand-gallery-2111076.aspx|title=GALLERY: Graham Taylor Stand First Look|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=28 November 2014|accessdate=29 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201051251/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/watford-fc-graham-taylor-stand-gallery-2111076.aspx|archivedate=1 December 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>The stand with its distinctive wavy roof runs along the side of the pitch, on the west side of the ground. It is a two-tiered stand, with executive boxes and a TV&nbsp;camera gantry.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book--> Built in 1986, it replaced the Shrodells Stand. The £3 million development was partly funded via a loan from [[Elton John]]. The upper tier, complete with executive boxes, was constructed first, and temporary seats forming a lower-tier were added later. These were later replaced with permanent seats, first used for a game against [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] on 18 September 1993.<!--First three sentences covered by Phillips book-->When the club moved from [[Cassio Road]] in 1922, the Union Stand was transported and reconstructed on this side of the ground. It was replaced by the Shrodells Stand, which was constructed during the 1930s. It was extended in 1979 with a further 2,200 seats replacing the standing enclosure in front of the stand.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book-->The final match for the Shrodells Stand was a 1–1 draw against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 3 May 1986, the Graham Taylor Stand opened on 23 August 1986, when Oxford United visited Vicarage Road, with Watford coming out 3–0 winners.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book-->==The Sir Elton John Stand==[[File:Main Stand.jpg|thumb|The now demolished Main Stand]]<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Elton John Stand.jpg|thumb|right|The Sir Elton John Stand]] -->The Sir Elton John Stand sits on the east side of the ground, and contains the changing rooms & tunnel. The stand was fully opened on 13 December 2014, in a ceremony attended by [[Sir Elton John]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/141213-gallery-watford-fc-v-wigan-elton-john-2145481.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020005/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/141213-gallery-watford-fc-v-wigan-elton-john-2145481.aspx |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>Prior to the development of the Sir Elton John Stand, the east side of the ground was home to the Main Stand, which was constructed in 1922 following Watford FC's move from Cassio Road. The Main Stand was closed in 2008 due to safety concerns.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordfc.com/page/Stadium/0,,10400~2069271,00.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512044614/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/Stadium/0,,10400~2069271,00.html|archivedate=12 May 2012|title=East stand changes|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=14 June 2010|accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref>Following the acquisition of Watford FC by the Pozzo family in 2012, the club were able to finance the development of a new stand to replace the Main Stand. The redevelopment of the east side of the stadium began in 2013, with the aim of developing a 3,000 seater capacity stand which would also house the players changing rooms, television gantry and tunnel.<ref>[http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/130923-east-stand-contract-1071880.aspx "East Stand IS Happening"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926210503/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/130923-east-stand-contract-1071880.aspx |date=26 September 2013 }}. Watford Football Club. 23 September 2013. Accessed 24 September 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/10811108.East_Stand_images_released/|title=See a number of artist's impressions of Watford's new East Stand here|first=Frank|last=Smith|publisher=''Watford Observer''|date=15 November 2013|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref>In May 2014, it was announced the stand will be known as The Watford FC Community Stand. However the club announced in November 2014 that the new stand would instead be named after former chairman Sir Elton John.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-watford-fc-community-stand-1521713.aspx|title=Name Confirmed: The Watford FC Community Stand|publisher=Watford Football Club|date=1 May 2014|accessdate=3 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503090301/http://www.watfordfc.com/news/article/140501-the-watford-fc-community-stand-1521713.aspx|archivedate=3 May 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The changing rooms were used for the first time in a friendly match between Watford and Udinese on 2 August 2014.On 8 June 2015, the club confirmed that 700 extra seats were being installed in the recently built Sir Elton John Stand.<ref name="ground expand 2"/> This number was revised a day later to around 1000 extra seats, following the announcement of an expansion in the north-east corner.<ref name="ground expand 2"/>==Floodlights==The first game under [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlights]] at Vicarage Road was played in 1953, when lights were installed on top of the Main Stand. These were replaced in 1960, with four pylons being built in the corners of the ground. Currently the floodlights are mounted on the top of the Vicarage Road and Rookery Stands.<!--Paragraph covered by Phillips book-->  New LED floodlights have been added for the 2015/16 season including lights on the top of the Sir Elton John and Graham Taylor stands.==Railway stations==[[File:Croxley rail link stations old and new.png|thumb|The old & new stations on the Croxley Rail Link near Vicarage Road]]In 1982, Vicarage Road Stadium gained its own railway station, {{rws|Watford Stadium Halt}}. It was introduced as a means of [[crowd control|managing the crowds]] attending football matches, providing an alternative to {{rws|Watford High Street}} and {{rws|Watford Junction}}, and was only open on match days. Development of the station was funded jointly by the [[Football Trust]], [[Watford Borough Council]], Watford F.C. and [[British Rail]]. The station was officially opened on 4 December 1982 by Elton John and [[Morys Bruce, 4th Baron Aberdare|Lord Aberdare]], chairman of the Football Trust. The inaugural train rolled into the station five minutes late, bringing away fans of [[Manchester United]] to Vicarage Road; the match that day ended with a 1–0 defeat for Watford.<ref name=WO-station>{{cite news|last=Crozier|first=David|title=Elton rides in to open soccer halt|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/nostalgia/memories/10593045.Elton_rides_in_to_open_soccer_halt/|accessdate=12 August 2013|newspaper=Watford Observer|date=11 January 2015}}</ref>The station fell out of use when [[British Rail]] closed the railway line in 1996 and has remained derelict ever since. A new [[London Underground]] station, {{LUL stations |station=Watford Vicarage Road}}, is due to open in 2020 on the opposite side of the Vicarage Road bridge as part of the [[Croxley Rail Link]] project to extend the [[Metropolitan line]] to [[Watford Junction railway station|Watford Junction]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Croxley Rail Link|url=http://www.croxleyraillink.com/|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> However since March 2017 the project has been in doubt due to a significant shortfall in funding.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/news/transport/metropolitan-line-extension-to-watford-junction-could-be-axed-due-to-funding-gap-a3490276.html|title=Metropolitan line extension could be axed due to £50m funding gap|date=2017-03-15|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-05-13|language=en-GB}}</ref>== Greyhound Racing ==Greyhound racing initially began at Vicarage Road on 20 October 1928. The racing was held under [[National Greyhound Racing Club]] (NGRC) rules and as many as four race nights per week were held every Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 7.45pm. However the provisional NGRC licence was cancelled as early as 1 November 1928, forcing the track to race independently (unaffiliated to a governing body).<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}}</ref>The racing would continue for many years alongside the football team and was still active for the next forty years before a temporary closure on 28 June 1969. On 14 October 1974 racing returned under NGRC rules under the organisation of the industry’s leading promoter the [[Greyhound Racing Association]]. Derby winning trainer Barbara Tompkins was attached to the track and won the Buckinghamshire Cup at [[Slough Stadium]] in 1975 with Houghton Girl.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=NGRC book of Greyhound Racing|year=1990|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}}</ref>The shape of track was very sharp due to the nature of the bend design around the football pitch corners and this led to criticism within the industry that it was not safe enough. Despite this a Bookmakers Afternoon Greyhound Service (BAGS) contract was established at the track. The final race meeting took place on 30 October 1978. The last winner was a greyhound called Chad Supreme.<ref>{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}}</ref>==References==;General* Phillips, Oliver (1991). ''The Official Centenary History of Watford FC 1881–1991.'' [[Watford Football Club]]. {{ISBN|0-9509601-6-0}}.* [https://web.archive.org/web/20140503044757/http://www.watfordfc.com/documents/2013-14-visiting-the-vic286-1100924.pdf#page=5 Vicarage Road stadium layout]. Watford Football Club. Accessed 2 May 2014.* [https://web.archive.org/web/20120531071914/http://www.watfordfc.com/page/History/0,,10400~65929,00.html Ground changes]. Watford Football Club. Accessed 2 October 2011.;Specific{{Reflist|30em}}{{Watford F.C.}}{{Football League Championship Venues}}{{Premier League venues}}{{Watford}}{{2000 RLWC Venues}}{{English greyhound tracks}}[[Category:Buildings and structures in Watford]][[Category:Football venues in England]][[Category:Rugby union stadiums in England]][[Category:Sports venues in Hertfordshire]][[Category:Watford F.C.]][[Category:Premier League venues]][[Category:Defunct rugby league venues in England]][[Category:Rugby League World Cup stadiums]][[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]][[Category:Football League venues]][[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in the United Kingdom]][[Category:Defunct greyhound racing venues in London]])
(1	Pat Nevin	{{Infobox football biography| name          = Pat Nevin| image          =Pat Nevin 2017.jpg| fullname       = Patrick Kevin Francis Michael Nevin| height         = {{height|ft=5|in=6}}| birth_date    = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1963|9|6}}| birth_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland| death_date    =| position       = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]]| youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 =| years1 = 1981–1983 | caps1 = 73  | goals1 = 17 | clubs1 = [[Clyde F.C.|Clyde]]| years2 = 1983–1988 | caps2 = 193 | goals2 = 36 | clubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]| years3 = 1988–1992 | caps3 = 109 | goals3 = 16 | clubs3 = [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]| years4 = 1992–1997 | caps4 = 193 | goals4 = 30 | clubs4 = [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]]| years5 = 1997–1998 | caps5 = 34  | goals5 = 6  | clubs5 = [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]]| years6 = 1998–2000 | caps6 = 58  | goals6 = 2  | clubs6 = [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]]| totalcaps = 660 | totalgoals = 107| nationalyears1 = 1986–1996 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]| nationalcaps1 = 28 | nationalgoals1 = 5| nationalyears2 = 1987–1996 | nationalteam2 = [[Scotland B national football team|Scotland B]]<ref>[http://www.fitbastats.com/scotlandb/player.php?playerid=63 Scotland B Player Pat Nevin Details<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>| nationalcaps2 = 4 | nationalgoals2 = 0}}'''Patrick Kevin Francis Michael''' "'''Pat'''" '''Nevin''' (born 6 September 1963 in [[Glasgow]], Scotland)<ref>[http://www.neilbrown.newcastlefans.com/player/patnevin.html Pat Nevin], Newcastle Fans.</ref> is a retired Scottish [[association football|footballer]]. In a 20-year career, he played for [[Clyde F.C.|Clyde]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] and [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]].<ref name = "bbc bio"/> He won 28 caps for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]], scattered across a ten-year international career, and he was selected for the [[UEFA Euro 1992]] finals squad.<ref name = "bbc bio"/> Since retiring as a player, Nevin has worked as a chief executive of Motherwell and as a football writer and broadcaster.==Professional career=====Clyde===Nevin trained with [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] as a youngster, but was rejected for being too small.<ref name = "tw"/> He was signed by [[Clyde F.C.|Clyde]] in 1981. In his first season, the club were promoted as [[Scottish Football League Division Two|Scottish Second Division]] champions; Nevin scored 14 goals in 30 starts and was voted [[PFA Scotland|SPFA]] Second Division Player of the Year. He scored six goals in 44 starts in his second season with the club.He was inducted into the inaugural [[Clyde F.C.#Hall of Fame|Clyde FC Hall of Fame]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Clyde FC Hall of Fame|url=http://www.clydefc.co.uk/news/2011/09/28/3960/|publisher=clydefc.co.uk|date=28 September 2011|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref>===Chelsea==='Wee Pat' as the Chelsea fans still affectionately call him, arrived at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in mid-1983 for £95,000, joining fellow new recruits [[Kerry Dixon]], [[Nigel Spackman]], [[David Speedie]] and [[Eddie Niedzwiecki]] in manager [[John Neal (footballer, born 1932)|John Neal]]'s new-look Chelsea side. Nevin's skill and pace made him a pivotal player at Chelsea and he very soon became firm favourite with the fans.In [[1983–84 in English football|1983–84]], he scored 14 goals, created numerous others for the likes of Dixon and Speedie and put in some dazzling performances{{cn|date=February 2017}} – during a 4–0 win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], he tormented the opposition defence, leaving five defenders trailing in his wake – as Chelsea won promotion as [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] champions. In the same season he was voted Chelsea's player of the year. Chelsea finished a respectable sixth in the [[Football League First Division|First Division]] the following year and reached the [[Football League Cup|Milk Cup]] (League Cup) semi-final, where Nevin was once again the star turn, setting up three goals in the quarter-final against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] as Chelsea came back from 3–0 down to draw 4–4; he also set up the winner for Speedie in the replay. The club were in the title race for much of the next season, with Nevin scoring a late equaliser against Liverpool at [[Anfield]] and a crucial header against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] to seal a 2–1 win, though a late collapse saw Chelsea finish sixth after being in the title race for most of the [[1985–86 in English football|1985–86 season]]. A year later, the club's performances dropped and they finished 14th, though Nevin was again voted Chelsea player of the year. They were relegated a year later.===Everton===Chelsea were relegated in 1988 and Nevin was sold to Everton for £1.75m. He scored 20 goals in 138 appearances for the club, but struggled to re-capture his previous form with manager [[Colin Harvey]] adopting a far more rigid system. He helped the side reach the [[FA Cup]] final in 1989, scoring the winner against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the semi-final, but they lost 3–2 in the final to arch-rivals [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].[[Howard Kendall]] returned to the club as manager in November 1990; he and Nevin openly disagreed with each other, which reduced Nevin's playing opportunities, as did the arrival of new wingers [[Robert Warzycha]] and [[Mark Ward (footballer born 1962)|Mark Ward]].Nevin was unfortunate to arrive at Everton just after one of the finest spells in their history, when they had collected two league titles, an [[FA Cup]] and the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]]. In contrast, Nevin's four seasons at the club saw a runners-up medal in the [[FA Cup]] (1989) being the closest he came to being part of a trophy winning side, and they never finished higher than sixth in the league (1990).===Tranmere Rovers===Nevin spent time on loan with fellow [[Merseyside]] club [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], then in the second tier of [[Football in England|English football]], before signing permanently in 1992. The club competed in the Division One play-offs in three consecutive seasons (1992–93, 1993–94 and 1994–95) but on each occasion they were eliminated in the semi-final.===Return to Scotland===In 1997, Nevin returned to Scotland and played for [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] and later [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] before retiring in 2000.==International career==In 1982 while playing for Clyde, he travelled to [[Finland]] to play for the [[Scotland national under-19 football team|Scotland U18]] team at the [[1982 UEFA European Under-18 Football Championship|UEFA European Youth Championship]] and was named player of the tournament after helping Scotland win it. The following year, he starred for the [[Scotland national under-20 football team|Scotland U20]] team that reached the quarter-finals of the [[1983 FIFA World Youth Championship|FIFA World Youth Championship]].Nevin won 28 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for the [[Scotland national football team|Scottish national side]], making his debut against [[Romania national football team|Romania]] in 1986. He scored five goals in a ten-year international career and played at [[1992 European Football Championship|Euro 92]], but was not selected in the final squads for the [[FIFA World Cup 1986|1986]] or [[FIFA World Cup 1990|1990]] [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]s. He made his final appearance for Scotland in 1996 but did not appear at the [[Euro 96]] finals.==Career after playing==After retiring as a player, Nevin had a stint as chief executive of Motherwell. He resigned from the position in April 2002 after chairman John Boyle decided to place the club in administration due to serious financial problems.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/1948121.stm |title=Motherwell in turmoil |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=24 April 2002 |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref>He works as a football pundit on television and radio, including for the [[BBC Scotland|BBC's]] ''[[Sportscene]]'' and ''[[Match of the Day 2]]'', for [[Five (TV)|Channel Five]] and [[BBC Radio Five Live]].<ref name = "bbc bio">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/radiofivelive/patnevin.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205151355/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/radiofivelive/patnevin.shtml |archivedate=5 December 2010 |title=Pat Nevin |publisher=[[BBC]] Press Office |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> Nevin co-wrote a book, ''In Ma Head, Son'', with psychologist Dr George Sik that was published in 1997. The book explores Nevin's worries, motivation and troubles during the 1996–97 season at [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] as he neared the end of his playing career.He has an arts [[Academic degree|degree]] from [[Glasgow Caledonian University]]. His interest in literature and the arts and his musical tastes made him stand out from many of his football player peers. He preferred [[The Fall (band)|The Fall]] and [[Joy Division]] to [[Phil Collins]] or [[Lionel Richie]]. Due to his less usual musical taste and prominence as a player he was interviewed by music magazine ''[[NME]]'' and was a guest music presenter on [[Radio City (Liverpool)|Radio City]] during his Everton and Tranmere career. Nevin now lives in [[Duns]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/review/5246174.stm |title=Pat Nevin |publisher=[[Newsnight Review]] |date=4 August 2006 |accessdate=31 October 2010}}</ref> with his wife and two children.At the second [[Bowlie Weekender]], hosted by [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|ATP]] he played a DJ set,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://atpfestival.com/events/bowlie2/news/1012091442.php|title=Bowlie DJ Times / Downloadable Timecards / Twitter - All Tomorrow's Parties|website=All Tomorrow's Parties|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> playing [[Belle & Sebastian]], [[Orange Juice (band)|Orange Juice]] and "My New House" by [[The Fall (band)|The Fall]] while wearing a [[The Pains of Being Pure at Heart]] T-shirt. The following day he slipped an indiepop reference onto 5 Live while talking about the Man Utd vs Arsenal match.<ref>{{Citation|last=makingprogress|title=Pat Nevin slips indiepop reference onto Radio 5 Live|date=2010-12-14|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=seZmnarIj-Y|accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> He has also appeared as a guest DJ at Scared To Dance<ref>{{cite web |title=Pat Nevin to guest DJ |url=http://www.scaredtodance.co.uk/2011/11/16/pat-nevin-to-guest-dj/}}</ref> and [[How Does It Feel To Be Loved?]], which are both indiepop club nights in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://howdoesitfeel.co.uk/patnevin.html|title=how does it feel to be loved? - london club night playing indie pop, northern soul, tamla motown, girl groups, sixties heartbreak|publisher=howdoesitfeel.co.uk}}</ref> He makes a guest appearance on the 1986 Ted Chippington / Vindaloo Summer Special (with Robert Lloyd & The Nightingales and Fuzzbox) video of "Rockin With Rita".<ref>{{cite web |title=Music video guest appearance |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-ZLGY5MrtE/}}</ref>In 2010 Nevin signed as a non-playing substitute for new club [[Chester F.C.|Chester]] after Colin Murray of BBC Radio 5 live offered the new club £2,000 if they named Nevin and [[Perry Groves]] as unused substitutes at every game in the 2010–11 season. This was live on 'Kicking off with Colin Murray', a show Nevin has appeared on every week since the start of the 2009–10 season. Nevin is usually beaten by ex-Arsenal player Perry Groves in the weekly quiz.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/chesterfootballclub/?section=clubnews&news_id=175263|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206043146/http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/chesterfootballclub/news/news-175263.html|archivedate=6 December 2010|title=Chester in the spotlight as BBC Radio 5 visit|date=11 September 2010}}</ref>==Personal life==Nevin grew up supporting [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]],<ref name = "tw">[http://www.toffeeweb.com/fans/interviews/nevin-int.asp Pat Nevin Internet Interview], ''ToffeeWeb''.</ref> but has more recently supported [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]].<ref name = "nevin hibs"/> He has been reported to have switched allegiances for, among other things, feeling that his boyhood heroes had become a large corporate organisation and that [[Celtic Park]] no longer felt like home.<ref name="nevin hibs">[http://www.hibernianfc.co.uk/news/nevin-on-hibernian-20091015_2262950_1826017 Nevin on Hibernian] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130505062725/http://www.hibernianfc.co.uk/news/nevin-on-hibernian-20091015_2262950_1826017 |date=5 May 2013 }}, [[Hibernian F.C.]] official website, 15 October 2009.</ref> Another reason for his switch was reported to be the [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] chanting from Celtic fans in front of his son.<ref name = "nevin hibs2">[http://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/top-stories/celtic-fans-ira-chants-drove-me-away-from-the-club-i-love-says-nevin-1-1830310 Celtic fans' IRA chants drove me away from the club I love, says Pat Nevin], The Scotsman, 7 September 2011.</ref> He also supports his former club Chelsea, and writes a weekly column for the Chelsea website.<ref>[http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1824580 Pat Nevin: All Hands to the Pump] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606200100/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1824580 |date=6 June 2014 }}, Chelsea F.C. official website.</ref> Nevin lives in [[Duns]], a small town in the Scottish Borders with his wife and two children.<ref name = "duns">{{cite news |url=http://www.berwickshirenews.co.uk/news/local/all-news/pundit-pat-enjoys-life-in-the-slow-lane-1-242882 |title=Pundit Pat enjoys life in the slow lane |work=Berwickshire News |publisher= |date=28 January 2009 |accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> His daughter, also a keen sports player, was a Scottish champion in badminton.<ref name = "duns"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/mobile/sport/opinion/interview-pat-nevin-prince-of-football-pundits.20708701?_=83b84c4e157eee972abbaa81a99395c3b7c6d367|title=Interview: Pat Nevin, prince of football pundits|website=HeraldScotland|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>==Honours=====Club===;Clyde*[[Scottish Football League Second Division]]: [[1981–82 Scottish Second Division|1981–82]];Chelsea*[[Football League Second Division]]: [[1983–84 Football League#Second Division|1983–84]]*[[Full Members Cup]] Winner: [[1986 Full Members Cup Final|1986]];Everton*[[FA Cup]] 1981–82<ref>{{cite news|title=Pat Nevin – Hall of Fame|url=http://www.clydefc.co.uk/club/history/hall-of-fame/pat-nevin/|publisher=clydefc.co.uk|accessdate=23 November 2012}}</ref>*[[UEFA Under-18 (1	Sarpsborg 08 FF	{{Infobox football club |clubname = Sarpsborg 08 |image    = [[File:Sarpsborg 08 FF logo.svg|200px]]|fullname = Sarpsborg 08 Fotballforening |current  = 2017 Sarpsborg 08 FF season |founded  = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|2008|1|15}} |ground   = [[Sarpsborg Stadion]]<br/>[[Sarpsborg]]<br/>[[Norway]] |capacity = 4,700<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sarpsborg08.no/stadium |language=Norwegian |title=Stadion |publisher=Sarpsborg 08 FF |accessdate=4 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150506075424/http://www.sarpsborg08.no/stadium |archivedate=6 May 2015 |df= }}</ref> |chairman = Hans Petter Arnesen |coach  = [[Geir Bakke]] |league   = [[Eliteserien (football)|Eliteserien]] |season   = [[2017 Eliteserien|2017]] |position = Eliteserien, 3rd |website  = http://www.sarpsborg08.no// |pattern_la1=_sarpsborg1617h|pattern_b1=_sarpsborg1617h|pattern_ra1=_sarpsborg1617h|leftarm1=0000CC|body1=0000CC|rightarm1=0000CC|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FFFFFF|pattern_la2=_sarpsborg1617a|pattern_b2=_sarpsborg1617a|pattern_ra2=_sarpsborg1617a|leftarm2=660033|body2=660033|rightarm2=660033|shorts2=000000|socks2=000000|}}'''Sarpsborg 08 Fotballforening''', commonly known as '''Sarpsborg 08''' or simply '''Sarpsborg''', is a Norwegian [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Sarpsborg]], currently playing in [[Tippeligaen]]. Sarpsborg 08 played in [[Adeccoligaen]] from 2005 to 2010. In 2010, the club was promoted to the [[Tippeligaen]], the top league in [[Norway]], but finished last and was relegated back to [[Adeccoligaen]] in 2011. In 2012, they were promoted again. They play their home games at [[Sarpsborg Stadion]].==History==Football in [[Sarpsborg]] has traditionally been dominated by [[Sarpsborg FK]] (SFK), which won the [[Norwegian Football Cup|Norwegian Cup]] six times and played 20 seasons in the top division, and to a lesser extent [[IL Sparta]], which won the Norwegian Cup in [[1952 Norwegian Football Cup|1952]] and played nine seasons in the top division. However, after SFK's relegation from the [[1974 Norwegian First Division|1974]], no teams from Sarpsborg played in the top division for the next two decades. In 1999, 16 teams in the Sarpsborg-area joined forces to create a team that could compete in the top divisions of Norwegian football, called '''Sarpsborg Fotball''', which overtook SFK's spot in the league-system. In its first season the team was relegated from the [[2000 Norwegian Second Division|Second Division]], and several clubs including both SFK and Sparta, withdrew from the collaboration.The remaining clubs in the "Sarpsborg Fotball"-project formed a new club called '''Borg Fotball''', which won promotion to the [[Norwegian Second Division|Second Division]] in 2002, but was relegated again in 2003. Meanwhile, Sparta was promoted to the Second Division the same season, and re-entered the collaboration club which now was renamed '''FK Sparta Sarpsborg'''. The club earned promotion to [[Adeccoligaen]] (the second tier of Norwegian football) in 2005.At the end of the 2007 season, the last major club in the district, Sarpsborg FK, joined the collaboration of teams and ended a rather long and hefty rivalry between the two clubs. At the same time, in an effort to unite the different fractions within the collaboration, the jersey was changed and the club renamed itself '''Sarpsborg Sparta FK'''. This name remained a source of contention throughout the 2008 season, however, and a new name, '''Sarpsborg 08 FF''', was adopted in 2009.The 2009 season started badly for Sarpsborg, and it appeared they would be fighting against relegation to the Second Division. The situation worsened when the [[Football Association of Norway]] determined that Sarpsborg 08 had submitted an unrealistic budget when they obtained their license to play in the First Division, and were penalized three points in June, leaving Sarpsborg in a relegation spot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/06/25/sport/fotball/1_divisjon/sarpsborg_08/6895626/|title=Mister tre poeng og havner på nedrykksplass|last=Haraldsen|first=Stian|date=2009-06-25|publisher=Dagbladet|language=Norwegian|accessdate=2009-11-07}}</ref> However, after [[Roar Johansen (football coach)|Roar Johansen]] became coach, the second part of the season went well for the team, which not only climbed out of the relegation spots, but finished fifth, allowing them to participate in the qualification matches for the [[2010 Norwegian Premier League]]. In the semi-final match of the qualification, Sarpsborg defeated local rivals [[Fredrikstad FK]] 2–0 (who were therefore relegated from the Premier League).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fotball.aftenposten.no/forstediv/article155075.ece|title=Har snudd Sarpsborg på hodet|last=Eide|first=Ole Kåre|date=2009-11-07|publisher=Aftenposten|language=Norwegian|accessdate=2009-11-07}}</ref> In the home match of the qualification final, Sarpsborg defeated [[KIL Toppfotball|Kongsvinger]] 3–2,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aftenbladet.no/100Sport/fotball/eliteserien/KIL-fikk-viktige-bortemal_-Sarpsborg-vant-151909_1.snd|title=KIL fikk viktige bortemål, Sarpsborg vant|date=2009-11-09|work=Aftenposten|language=Norwegian|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref> but lost the second leg 3–1 and remained in the First Division.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sa.no/sport/sarpsborg08/article4701512.ece|title=Tapte opprykkskampen|last=Pettersen|first=Gry|date=2009-11-12|publisher=Sarpsborg Arbeiderblad|language=Norwegian|accessdate=2009-11-13}}</ref>The 2010 season ended with a 4–0 home-win against [[Alta IF|Alta]]. This meant that the team ended in second place, after league-winner [[Sogndal Fotball|Sogndal]], and won the right to play in the 2011 edition of the [[Tippeligaen]].The 2011 season started with a surprising 3–0 win against [[Molde FK|Molde]] in [[Ole Gunnar Solskjær]] first match as manager of Molde. But after a good start, Sarpsborg was relegated back to [[Adeccoligaen]] on 23 October 2011, when they lost 3–0 away at [[SK Brann|Brann]] with three rounds left to play.On 3 January 2013, former Sheffield United striker [[Brian Deane]] was appointed as coach.== Recent history ==:{|class="wikitable"|-bgcolor="#efefef"! (1	Abdon Pamich	{{Infobox sportsperson| name = Abdon Pamich| nickname =| image =Abdon Pamich FIDAL.jpg| image_size =| caption =| nationality = [[Italia]]n| sport = [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]| km }}{{MedalGold | [[1965 IAAF World Race Walking Cup|1965 Pescara]] | 50 km }}}}'''Abdon Pamich''' (born 3 October 1933) is a former [[Italy|Italian]] [[race walking|race walker]]. He competed in the [[race walking]] event at the 1956, 1960, 1964, 1968 and 1972 Olympics and won a bronze medal in 1960 and a gold in 1964.<ref name=sr>{{cite Sports-Reference |url=http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/pa/abdon-pamich-1.html |title=Abdon Pamich}}</ref> Pamich was the [[List of flag bearers for Italy at the Olympics|Olympics flag bearer]] for Italy in 1972.==Biography==Pamich was born in Fiume ([[Rijeka]], present-day [[Croatia]]) in 1933, at that time the city was under Italian jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://olimpiadi.blogosfere.it/2007/11/cerchi-azzurri-abdon-pamich-la-scheda.html |title=Cerchi Azzurri: Abdon Pamich, la scheda |publisher=olimpiadi.blogosfere.it |language=italian |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> On 16 October 1960 he set a [[Men's 50 kilometres walk world record progression|world record over 50&nbsp;km]] at 4:03:02 in [[Ponte San Pietro]]. Later he was inducted into the [[FIDAL Hall of Fame]].<ref>[http://www.fidal.it/atleta/Abdon-PAMICH/fKuTlpk%3D Abdon Pamich]. fidal.it</ref>==Achievements=={| class="wikitable" width=50% style="font-size:90%; text-align:center;"|-|colspan=7 bgcolor=lightblue|'''Olympic Games'''|-!Year !!Competition !!Venue !!Position !!Event!!Time !!Notes|-|1956|align=left | [[Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]|align=left | {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Melbourne]]|11th|20 km|[[Athletics at the 1956 Summer Olympics – Men's 20 kilometres walk|1:36:03]]||-|1960|align=left | [[Athletics at the 1960 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]|align=left | {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Rome]]|bgcolor=cc9966 | 3rd|50 km|[[Athletics at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 kilometres walk|4:27:55]]||-|1964|align=left | [[Athletics at the 1964 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]|align=left | {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Tokyo]]|bgcolor=gold|1st|50 km|[[Athletics at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 kilometres walk|4:11:12]]|{{AthAbbr|OR}}|-|1968|align=left | [[Athletics at the 1968 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]|align=left | {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Mexico City]]|{{AthAbbr|DNF}}|50
