(1	Dan Gilbert	{{other people||Daniel Gilbert (disambiguation)}}{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}}{{Infobox person|name        = Daniel Gilbert|image       =Dan Gilbert speaking onstage.jpg|caption =  Dan Gilbert in 2014|birth_date  = {{birth_date and age|1962|1|17}}|birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], U.S.|death_place =|residence   = [[Franklin, Michigan]]|citizenship = United States|alma_mater  = [[Michigan State University]];<br>[[Wayne State University Law School]]|occupation  = Businessman<br>Sports franchise owner<br>Casino owner<br>Attorney|known_for   = Founder/Chairman of [[Quicken Loans]]<br>Owner of the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]]|height     = 5'6"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burke|first1=Monte|title=Net Game|url=https://www.forbes.com/free_forbes/2005/1010/082.html|accessdate=July 21, 2017|publisher=Forbes|date=October 10, 2005}}</ref>|networth    = {{increase}} US$ 5.7 billion (September 2017)<ref name=ForbesBillionaires>{{cite journal| url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/daniel-gilbert/ |work=[[Forbes]]| title=Forbes 400: Daniel Gilbert| accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref>|spouse      = Jennifer Gilbert}}'''Daniel Gilbert''' (born January 17, 1962) is an American businessman. He is the chairman and founder of [[Rock Ventures]]<ref>{{cite news| title=Change quickens: Gilbert's downtown plan| url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20130331/NEWS/303319980/change-quickens-gilberts-downtown-plan#| first1=Kirk| last1=Pinho| first2=Dustin| last2=Walsh| date=March 31, 2013| work=[[Crain Communications|Crain's Detroit Business]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> and [[Quicken Loans]] Inc., the owner of the [[National Basketball Association]]'s [[Cleveland Cavaliers]], the [[American Hockey League]]'s [[Cleveland Monsters]], the [[Arena Football League (2010)|Arena Football League]]'s [[Cleveland Gladiators]] and the [[NBA G League]]'s [[Canton Charge]].  He is also the operator of the [[Quicken Loans Arena]] in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] and chairman of [[JACK Entertainment]] (formerly Rock Gaming), which opened its first [[Horseshoe Casino Cleveland|Horseshoe Casino]] (now JACK Cleveland Casino) in downtown Cleveland in May 2012.<ref name="QLProfiles">{{cite web| title=Quicken Loans Leadership Team: Dan Gilbert| publisher=Quicken Loans| url=http://www.quickenloans.com/press-room/leadership-team-orig/dan-gilbert/| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>==Early life and education==Gilbert was born to a [[Jewish American|Jewish]]<ref name=Guth>{{cite news| title=It's official! Dan Gilbert is Cavaliers' new boss| url=http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/article_2b312bd9-e0d0-5e4b-90bc-a59fa5d3aa46.html| work=[[Cleveland Jewish News]]| first=Douglas J.| last=Guth|| date=March 3, 2005| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Tracy>{{cite journal| work=[[Tablet (magazine)|Tablet]]| url=http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/67693/introducing-%e2%80%a6-the-non-jewish-conspiracy| title=Introducing … The Non-Jewish Conspiracy: NBA Draft lottery produces watershed moment in American Jewish history| first=Marc| last=Tracy| date=May 18, 2011| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name=ForbesIsr>{{cite journal| url=http://www.forbes.co.il/news/new.aspx?0r9VQ=HMGE| work=Forbes Israel| title=Jewish Billionaires: 43 - Daniel Gilbert| date=September 4, 2013| language=Hebrew| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> family in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]].<ref>{{cite journal| url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/12/03/an-interview-with-dan-gilbert-self-made-hometown-billionaire-and-the-leader-of-a-detroit-renaissance/| work=[[Tech Crunch]]| title=An Interview With Dan Gilbert, Self-Made Hometown Billionaire And The Leader Of The Detroit Renaissance| first=Matt| last=Burns| date=December 3, 2012| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> He grew up in [[Southfield, Michigan]], where he attended [[Southfield-Lathrup High School]].<ref name=Davis>{{cite news| title=Dan Gilbert's Rock Gaming partners bound by friendship, desire to build upscale 'urban' casinos| url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2011/10/dan_gilberts_rock_gaming_partn.html| work=The Plain Dealer| first=Dave| last=Davis| date=October 15, 2011| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> He earned his bachelor's degree from [[Michigan State University]] and a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Wayne State University Law School]], and is a member of the [[State Bar of Michigan]].<ref name="QLProfiles"/> While in college he earned a [[Real estate broker|real estate agent]]’s license<ref name=NYTSegal>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/14/business/dan-gilberts-quest-to-remake-downtown-detroit.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0| work=[[The New York Times]]| title=A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City| first=David| last=Segal| date=April 13, 2013| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> and while in law school, he worked part-time at his parents' [[Century 21 Real Estate]] agency.<ref name=Boudway>{{cite journal| url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/10_48/b4205094230553.htm#p3| work=[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]]| title=Left Behind by LeBron| first=Ira| last=Boudway| date=November 18, 2010| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>==Quicken Loans==Gilbert, recognizing that the real potential was in originating mortgages and not in selling homes, founded Rock Financial in 1985, with Ron Berman, his younger brother [[Gary Gilbert]], and his friend Lindsay Gross.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Segal|first1=David|title=A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/14/business/dan-gilberts-quest-to-remake-downtown-detroit.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1|accessdate=September 21, 2017|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|date=April 13, 2013}}</ref> The company grew into one of the largest independent mortgage lenders in the United States and in the late 1990s, launched its internet strategy and quickly positioned itself as the fastest-growing direct mortgage lender online.<ref name="QLProfiles" />In 2000, software maker [[Intuit Inc.]] purchased Rock Financial. It renamed the national web operation ''[[Quicken Loans]]'' and grew substantially as the leading provider of direct-to-consumer home loans on the internet, offering mortgages in all 50 states. Gilbert remained at the company as CEO. In 2002, he led a small group of private investors that purchased Quicken Loans and its affiliated national title company, Title Source, Inc., from Intuit and continues to serve as the chairman of Quicken Loans, Inc.<ref name="QLProfiles"/>In 2010, Quicken Loans moved its headquarters and 1,700 of its employees to downtown [[Detroit]]. After moving all 3,600 Michigan-based team members into Detroit’s urban core by the end of 2010, the company now has approximately 17,000 staff in downtown Detroit and a total of 24,000 nationwide, making the company Detroit’s largest employer, minority employer, and taxpayer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/rock-ventures/|title=Rock Ventures on the Forbes America's Largest Private Companies List|access-date=August 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=R.J.|title=Quicken Loans Family of Companies Surpasses 17K Employees in Detroit, More to Come|url=http://www.dbusiness.com/daily-news/Annual-2017/Quicken-Loans-Family-of-Companies-Surpasses-17K-Employees-in-Detroit-More-to-Come/|accessdate=September 21, 2017|work=D Business|publisher=D Business|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref>==Sports franchise ownership==In 2007, Gilbert bought the dormant [[Utah Grizzlies]] [[American Hockey League]] franchise, moved it to Cleveland and renamed it the [[Lake Erie Monsters]] (now Cleveland Monsters).In early 2012, Gilbert became the new owner of the [[Arena Football League]]'s [[Cleveland Gladiators]].Gilbert became majority owner of the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] in March 2005 and undertook a complete overhaul of the front office, coaching staff, player personnel and game presentation.<ref name="Cavs Front Office">{{cite web| title=Executive Bios and Directory| publisher=NBA.com/Cavaliers| url=http://www.nba.com/cavaliers/team/executives| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> During Gilbert's tenure, the Cavs won five Central Division championships (2009, 2010, 2015, 2016, 2017), four Eastern Conference championships (2007, 2015, 2016, 2017), and one [[NBA championship]] (2016) which ended the 52-year [[Cleveland sports curse]].  Also in 2016, Gilbert's Lake Erie (now Cleveland) Monsters won the AHL's top prize -  the [[Calder Cup]] - giving Gilbert two championships within eight days.In 2011, Gilbert purchased the [[NBADL]]'s [[New Mexico Thunderbirds]], and moved them to [[Canton, Ohio]] (about an hour drive south of Cleveland) renaming them the [[Canton Charge]], and making them the Cavaliers' new D-League affiliate.=== "The Letter" ===Gilbert received national attention July 8, 2010, when [[NBA]] basketball superstar and northeast Ohio native [[LeBron James]] announced that he was leaving the Cavaliers for the [[Miami Heat]] on a highly criticized [[ESPN]] television special dubbed ''[[The Decision (TV special)|The Decision]]''.<ref name=bauder>{{cite news |url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/nba/story/2010-07-09/james-decision-draws-big-ratings-for-espn |title=Was LeBron special ESPN's deal with devil? |first=David |last=Bauder |work=sportingnews.com |agency=Associated Press |date=July 10, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68lgFnX3W?url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/nba/story/2010-07-09/james-decision-draws-big-ratings-for-espn |archivedate=June 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="ESPN Transcript of Decision">{{cite news| title=LeBron James' decision: the transcript| work=ESPN| url=http://espn.go.com/blog/truehoop/post/_/id/17853/lebron-james-decision-the-transcript| accessdate=April 22, 2011}}</ref> Following the special, Gilbert published an [[open letter]] in [[Comic Sans]] font (dubbed nationally as "The Letter" as a counterpoint to ''The Decision'')<ref name=FosterNBC>{{cite web| title=Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert says he doesn’t regret "The Letter"| url=http://probasketballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/02/16/cavaliers-owner-dan-gilbert-says-he-doesnt-regret-the-letter/| last=Foster| first=D J| date=February 16, 2014| publisher=[[NBC Sports]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> to [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] fans in which he strongly criticized how James made his announcement.<ref name="Letter">{{cite news| date=July 9, 2010| last=Lee| first=Michael| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/wizardsinsider/2010/07/cavaliers-owner-dan-gilbert-un.html| work=[[The Washington Post]]| title=Dan Gilbert letter: Cavaliers owner unloads on LeBron James}}</ref> July 12, 2010, [[NBA]] Commissioner [[David Stern]] fined Gilbert $100,000 for his remarks in the letter.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2010/7/12/1566461/cavaliers-dan-gilbert-fined-100k-lebron| title=Cavs Owner Dan Gilbert Fined $100K for LeBron Comments| date=July 12, 2010| work=[[SB Nation]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> Gilbert has since regretted the open letter, which he wrote in 45 minutes when emotions were running high, and it was taken down from the team website after a few weeks but remained widely available on the Internet. Though some members of the media criticized Gilbert for this letter, many [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] fans embraced him for it and even offered to pay the fine. Gilbert instead insisted on donating the money to charity.<ref name="USA Today">{{cite web| last1=Albom| first1=Mitch| title=Dan Gilbert tells how he and LeBron James mended fences| date=July 13, 2014| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/cavaliers/2014/07/13/dan-gilbert-lebron-james-buried-the-hatchet/12596623/| work=[[USA Today]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>Four years later when James opted out of his contract with Miami, Gilbert and James met privately. Gilbert apologized to LeBron for the open letter, stating "LeBron, we had five good years together and one bad night, Like a marriage that's good and then one bad thing happens and you never talk to each other again." James also expressed his regret to Gilbert about ''[[The Decision (TV special)|The Decision]]''. The two embraced, and James subsequently returned to Cleveland in free agency days later.<ref name="USA Today"/> James explained his homecoming to Cleveland in his ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' announcement writing “I’ve met with Dan, face-to-face, man-to-man. We’ve talked it out. Everybody makes mistakes. I’ve made mistakes as well. Who am I to hold a grudge?”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2014/07/lebron_james_cleveland_his_2014_announcement_was_everything_his_2010_decision.html|title=Nice Rebound!|first=Josh|last=Levin|date=July 11, 2014|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref>==Other businesses and investments==Gilbert is a founding partner in private equity group Rockbridge Growth Equity LLC (RBE). The partnership invests in growing businesses in the financial services, Internet technology, consumer-direct marketing, and the sports and entertainment industries. RBE has significant investments in Gas Station TV,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henderson|first1=Tom|title=Rockbridge to buy owner of Gas Station TV|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20150910/NEWS/150919983/detroit-city-football-club-moves-ahead-with-plans-to-move-from-cass|accessdate=September 10, 2015|work=Crain's Detroit Business|publisher=Crain's Communications Inc|date=June 6, 2014}}</ref> [[Robb Report]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Keith|title=Cavaliers owner Gilbert seals deal for Robb Report|url=https://nypost.com/2014/12/03/cavaliers-owner-gilbert-seals-deal-for-robb-report/|website=New York Post|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref> [[RapidAdvance]],<ref name=Rockbridge>{{cite press release| title=Detroit-based Rockbridge Growth Equity Acquires RapidAdvance| url=http://www.thestreet.com/story/12038625/1/detroit-based-rockbridge-growth-equity-acquires-rapidadvance.html| date=September 16, 2013| publisher=Rockbridge Growth Equity| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> [[Northcentral University]], [[Protect America]], [[AccountNow]], [[Purchasing Power]], [[Triad Retail Media]], [[One on One Marketing]], and [[Connect America]].<ref>{{cite web| title=About Us: The Nationwide Medical Alert System Company| url=http://www.medicalalert.com/about-connect-america-medical-alert.html| publisher=Connect America| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="RBEquity.com">{{cite web| publisher=Rockbridge Growth Equity Website| title=Portfolio| url=http://www.rbequity.com/portfolio-companies/| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>Gilbert is an investor in Courtside Ventures,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/11/business/dealbook/bruin-sports-to-team-up-with-others-as-investor.html|title=Bruin Sports to Team Up With Others as Investor|last=de la Merced|first=Michael|date=January 11, 2016|work=|access-date=May 2, 2016|via=}}</ref> a venture capital fund investing across early stage technology and media companies with a focus on sports and a founding partner of Detroit Venture Partners (DVP), a venture capital firm that funds start-up and early-stage technology companies based primarily in&nbsp;[[Detroit]].<sup>[23]</sup> Some of the companies DVP has invested in includes, LevelEleven,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20140815/NEWS/140819875/detroit-startup-leveleleven-raises-2m-in-vc-funding|title=Detroit startup LevelEleven raises $2M in VC funding|last=Pinho|first=Kirk|date=August 15, 2014|work=|access-date=May 2, 2016|via=}}</ref> iRule<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20150104/NEWS/301049979/irule-to-reveal-2-5m-in-vc-electronics-investor-key|title=IRule to reveal $2.5M in VC; electronics investor key|last=Henderson|first=Tom|date=January 4, 2015|work=|access-date=May 2, 2016|via=}}</ref> and Marxent Labs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xconomy.com/detroit-ann-arbor/2011/12/12/dvp-backed-marxent-labs-wants-to-augment-your-shopping-experience/|title=DVP-Backed Marxent Labs Wants to Augment Your Shopping&nbsp;Experience {{!}} Xconomy|date=December 12, 2011|website=Xconomy|language=en-US|access-date=May 3, 2016}}</ref><ref name="DVP DNA">{{cite web| title=Portfolio| publisher=Detroit Venture Partners| url=http://www.detroitventurepartners.com/portfolio.html| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>In addition, Gilbert recently cofounded StockX, a stock market of things for high-demand, limited edition products such as sneakers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://solecollector.com/news/2016/02/campless-stockx-dan-gilbert|title=Why Cavs Owner Dan Gilbert Is Investing in Sneaker Resellers|access-date=August 3, 2016}}</ref> Gilbert is also invested and involved in the operation of several consumer-based technology-centered businesses, including [[Fathead (brand)|Fathead]], [[Veritix]], [[Xenith]], [[StyleCaster]] and [[Quizzle]].<ref name="QLProfiles"/>Gilbert launched Bizdom in 2007. Today, this non-profit promotes both tech and brick-and-mortar entrepreneurship in Detroit and Cleveland by supporting on-the-ground service providers, as well as leveraging its connections with Quicken Loans and the Rock Ventures Family of Companies to accelerate the growth and development of small businesses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bizdom.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Bizdom-Press-Release_11.6.153.pdf|title=Bizdom press release|date=November 6, 2015|website=Bizdom|publisher=Bizdom|access-date=March 16, 2016}}</ref>In November 2009, Gilbert and a group of partners successfully backed a statewide referendum to bring [[casino]] gaming to [[Ohio]]’s four largest cities. Through a joint venture with [[Caesars Entertainment Corporation]], the groups operate urban-based casinos in both [[Cleveland]] and [[Cincinnati]].  The first of the casinos, [[Horseshoe Cleveland]], opened in May 2012.<ref name="QLProfiles"/>  In 2013, Rock Ventures, the umbrella entity for Gilbert's investments and real estate holdings, announced it had formed Athens Acquisition LLC, an affiliate of Rock Gaming, and acquired the majority interest in Greektown Superholdings Inc., owner of the Greektown Casino-Hotel located in downtown Detroit.<ref name=ReindlFP>{{cite news| title=Dan Gilbert-owned company to acquire controlling interest in Greektown Casino| url=http://www.freep.com/article/20130116/NEWS01/130116070/Dan-Gilbert-Greektown-casino-detroit| last=Reindl| first=J.C.| date=January 13, 2013| work=[[Detroit Free Press]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>According to professional [[Call of Duty]] player [[Nadeshot|Matthew "Nadeshot" Haag]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Nadeshot|title=My Team, 100 Thieves, is BACK! (HUGE ANNOUNCEMENT)|date=2017-11-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRa7XWbMxEo&t=306s|accessdate=2017-11-21}}</ref> Gilbert has made a multi-million dollar investment into Nadeshot's [[eSports]] team called [[100 Thieves|100Thieves]].==Detroit initiatives==[[Quicken Loans]] moved its headquarters and 1,700 of its team members to downtown [[Detroit]] in August 2010, where Gilbert and the company are helping lead a revitalization of Detroit’s urban core.<ref name="QLProfiles" />  Today, Gilbert-owned businesses employ  more than 17,000 people in the city.<ref>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=R.J.|title=Quicken Loans Family of Companies Surpasses 17K Employees in Detroit, More to Come|url=http://www.dbusiness.com/daily-news/Annual-2017/Quicken-Loans-Family-of-Companies-Surpasses-17K-Employees-in-Detroit-More-to-Come/|accessdate=September 21, 2017|work=D Business|publisher=Hour Media|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref>In 2011, Gilbert's Bedrock Detroit purchased several buildings in downtown [[Detroit]], including the historic Madison Theatre Building,<ref name="Madison Building">{{cite press release| title=Quicken Loans Group Buys Madison Theatre Building| publisher=QuickenLoans.com | url=http://www.quickenloans.com/press-room/2011/quicken-loans-group-buys-madison-theatre-building/| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> [[Chase Tower (Detroit)|Chase Tower]] and Two Detroit Center (parking garage),<ref name=Chase2Detroit>{{cite web | title=Dan Gilbert completes purchase of Chase Tower downtown, nearby parking garage| first=Corey| last=Williams| work=Crain's Detroit Business| url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20110407/FREE/110409928/dan-gilbert-completes-purchase-of-chase-tower-downtown-nearby-parking-garage| agency=[[Associated Press]]| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> [[Dime Building]] (renamed Chrysler House),<ref name=Dime>{{cite news| title=Dan Gilbert to Buy Yet Another Building| work=Crain's Detroit Business| date=June 21, 2011| url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20110621/STAFFBLOG08/110629981/dan-gilbert-to-buy-yet-another-building| last=Duggan| first=Daniel| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> [[First National Building]]<ref name=1stNat>{{cite web| title=Dan Gilbert Closes on First National Building| work=Crain's Detroit Business| url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20110830/FREE/110839991/dan-gilbert-closes-on-first-national-building| last=Duggan| first=Daniel| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> and three smaller buildings on Woodward Avenue.<ref name="Woodward Properties">{{cite web| title=Bedrock Properties| publisher=Bedrock Real Estate Services| url=http://www.bedrockmgt.com/properties/| accessdate=February 13, 2012}}</ref> In 2012, Bedrock Detroit purchased the former [[Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago Detroit Branch Building]],<ref name=FRB>{{cite web| title=Dan Gilbert buys Federal Reserve building in Detroit| last=Gallagher| first=John| url=http://www.freep.com/article/20120130/BUSINESS06/120130030/Rock-Financial-Dan-Gilbert-Federal-Reserve-building-Detroit| work=Detroit Free Press| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> [[One Woodward Avenue]], 1201 Woodward (Kresge Building), and five smaller buildings on Woodward Avenue and Broadway Street, totaling 630,000 square feet of commercial space in downtown [[Detroit]].<ref name=5more>{{cite news| title=Dan Gilbert buys 5 more downtown buildings as part of 'Detroit 2.0' vision| url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20121218/BUSINESS/121218067/dan-gilbert-buys-up-5-downtown-detroit-buildings| last=Gallagher| first=John| work=Detroit Free Press| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>  In 2013, Bedrock Detroit purchased the [[1001 Woodward]] office tower, several smaller buildings in the downtown area and announced, along with The Downtown Detroit Partnership and the Detroit Economic Growth Group, a [[placemaking]] plan for revitalizing Detroit's urban core.Bedrock Detroit's downtown Detroit real estate investments include more than 90 properties (buildings and/or store fronts)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2016/08/25/the-david-stott-building-like-a-treasure-hunt-for-dan-gilberts-renovators/|title=The David Stott Building Like A Treasure Hunt For Dan Gilbert's Renovators|access-date=August 31, 2016}}</ref> totaling 15 million square feet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bedrockdetroit.com/about/|title=Bedrock - About|website=www.bedrockdetroit.com|access-date=August 31, 2016}}</ref>In 2015, he purchased [[Book Tower]] in Detroit, MI.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Aguilar|first1=Lewis|title=Gilbert expands west, buys Book Tower|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/real-estate/2015/08/28/bedrock-book-tower-building/71308862/|website=The Detroit Free Press|publisher=The Detroit Free Press|accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref>In September 2013, Gilbert was named co-chair of the Blight Removal Task Force. The group, appointed by the Obama Administration, published a detailed plan in May 2014 to remove all blighted structures and lots in the City of Detroit.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walsh|first1=Tom|title=Quicken Loans founder Dan Gilbert leading fight against Detroit blight|url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20131112/COL06/311120141/Tom-Walsh-Dan-Gilbert-Quicken-Loans|website=The Detroit Free Press|publisher=The Detroit Free Press|accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref>In September 2017, Detroit Mayor [[Mike Duggan]] appointed Gilbert to lead a committee to make a Super Bowl-like bid for online retail giant Amazon to bring its second North American headquarters to Detroit.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Livengood|first1=Chad|title=Dan Gilbert to lead Detroit's Super Bowl-type bid for Amazon HQ2|url=http://www.crainscleveland.com/article/20170914/news/135516/dan-gilbert-lead-detroits-super-bowl-type-bid-amazon-hq2|accessdate=September 21, 2017|work=Crain's Cleveland Business|publisher=Crain Communications|date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>== Philanthropy and political donations ==In September 2012, Gilbert and his wife Jennifer joined [[The Giving Pledge]], committing to give half of their wealth to philanthropy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carlyle|first1=Erin|title=Meet the Eight Forbes 400 Billionaires Who Just Signed the Giving Pledge|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2012/09/18/forbes-400-billionaires-whove-signed-the-giving-pledge/|website=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref> Initiated by [[Warren Buffett]] and [[Bill Gates]] in 2010, the Giving Pledge is a campaign to encourage the wealthiest people in the world to make a commitment to give most of their wealth to philanthropic causes.Gilbert's eldest son was born with [[Neurofibromatosis]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cleveland.com/cavs/index.ssf/2011/10/neurofibromatosis_cant_change.html| title=Neurofibromatosis can't change Nick Gilbert's attitude: 'Look at the bright side of everything'| first=Mary Schmitt| last=Boyer| date=October 30, 2011| work=The Plain Dealer| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref> Gilbert established two Neurofibromatosis research clinics at the [[Children's National Medical Center]] (CNMC) in [[Washington, D.C.]] and at the Dana Children’s Hospital at the [[Sourasky Medical Center]] in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]].  Gilbert also serves on the boards of the Children’s Tumor Foundation, the [[Cleveland Clinic]], and the Children’s Hospital Foundation (an affiliate of CNMC); and is the vice chairman of the not-for-profit ''M-1 RAIL initiative'' which is dedicated to promoting light-rail transportation in downtown Detroit.<ref name=CTF>{{cite web| url=http://www.ctf.org/Board-of-Directors/Daniel-B.-Gilbert.html| publisher=Children's Tumour Foundation| title=Daniel B. Gilbert| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>In 2015, Gilbert donated $750,000 to the presidential candidacy of [[Chris Christie]].<ref name=gomez>{{cite news|last1=Gomez|first1=Henry J.|title=Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert places a big bet on Chris Christie, but what about John Kasich? Ohio Politics Roundup|url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2015/08/cleveland_cavaliers_owner_dan.html|accessdate=October 18, 2015|publisher=Cleveland.com|date=August 12, 2015}}</ref>In September 2016, Gilbert donated $5 million to Wayne State University Law School, representing the largest donation in the law school’s history. In October of that year,  Gilbert also donated $15 million toward the planned $50-million Breslin Center renovation project at Michigan State University.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/spartans/index.ssf/2016/10/breslin_center_dan_gilbert.html|title=Dan Gilbert pledges $15 million to Michigan State and Breslin Center renovation|newspaper=MLive.com|access-date=October 29, 2016}}</ref>== Personal life ==Gilbert resides in [[Franklin, Michigan]] with his wife Jennifer Gilbert and their five children.<ref name=ForbesBillionaires /> His wife serves on the Gilbert Family Neurofibromatosis Institute at [[Children's National Medical Center]] in Washington, D.C. and also serves on the boards of [[World ORT|ORT America]] and the Israeli and Overseas Committee of the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit.<ref name=JewishNews>{{cite news| url=http://www.thejewishnews.com/digital-doodle| work=[[The Detroit Jewish News]]| title=Jennifer Gilbert is poised to revolutionize the residential interior design industry| date=February 9, 2012| first=Lynne| last=Konstantin| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release| title=Children’s National Health System Dedicates Gilbert Family Professorships in Neurofibromatosis| url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2014/01/prweb11493453.htm| publisher=Children's National Medical Center| date=January 15, 2014| accessdate=December 19, 2014}}</ref>== Awards and honors ==Gilbert's companies have achieved the following accolades under his watch:===Quicken Loans===* 11-time winner: [[J.D. Power and Associates|JD Power]] Highest Customer Satisfaction Award (seven for Primary Mortgage Origination, four for Mortgage Servicing)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quickenloans.com/press-room/2016/07/28/jdp-servicing-2016/|title=Quicken Loans Ranks Highest in J.D. Power Study of Mortgage Servicing Client Satisfaction in Third Consecutive Year of Eligibility {{!}} Quicken Loans Pressroom|date=July 28, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=August 3, 2016}}</ref>* 13-time [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] [[100 Best Companies to Work For]] (2005-2017)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quickenloans.com/about|title=About Us - Quicken Loans|website=www.quickenloans.com}}</ref>===Cleveland Cavaliers===* [[List of NBA Champions|2016 NBA Champion]]* 2016 [[Best Team ESPY Award]]===Cleveland Monsters===* 2016 [[Calder Cup]] Champion== References =={{reflist|3}}== External links ==* [http://www.choosethinking.com Dan Gilbert's Blog: Choose Thinking]{{Cleveland Cavaliers}}{{NBAOwners}}{{Wealthiest people in the United States}}{{Authority control}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Gilbert, Dan}}[[Category:1962 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:American businesspeople]][[Category:Cleveland Cavaliers owners]][[Category:Giving Pledgers]][[Category:Jewish American sportspeople]][[Category:Cleveland Monsters]][[Category:Arena Football League executives]][[Category:Michigan State University alumni]][[Category:People from Southfield, Michigan]][[Category:Wayne State University Law School alumni]][[Category:American billionaires]][[Category:Rock Ventures]][[Category:People from Franklin, Michigan]])
(1	Jimmy Casper	{{Infobox cyclist| name          = Jimmy Casper| image         = Jimmy Casper 2008.jpg| caption       = Casper at the 2008 [[Four Days of Dunkirk]]| fullname      = Jimmy Casper| nickname      =| birth_date    = {{birth date and age|1978|5|28}}| birth_place   = [[Montdidier, Somme]], [[France]]| height        = {{convert|1.75|m|abbr=on}}| weight        = {{convert|69|kg|abbr=on}}| currentteam   = Retired| discipline    = Road| role          = Rider| ridertype     = Sprinter| amateuryears1 =| amateurteam1  =| proyears1     = 1998–2003| proteam1      = {{ct|FDJ|1998}}| proyears2     = 2004–2006| proteam2      = {{ct|COF|2004}}| proyears3     = 2007| proteam3      = [[Unibet.com]]| proyears4     = 2008| proteam4      = {{ct|AGR|2008}}| proyears5     = 2009–2011| proteam5      = {{ct|SAU|2009}}| proyears6     = 2012| proteam6      = {{ct|ALM|2012}}| majorwins     = '''[[Grand Tours]]''': [[Tour de France]]::1 stage ([[2006 Tour de France|2006]])| updated = 1 January 2013}}'''Jimmy Casper''' (born May 28, 1978 in [[Montdidier, Somme]]) is a [[France|French]] retired [[road bicycle racer]], who competed as a professional between 1998 and 2012. He is best known for winning stage 1 of [[2006 Tour de France]].==Career==He has on two occasions finished in last place in the [[General classification]] of the [[Tour de France]], thereby 'winning' the [[lanterne rouge|red lantern]].<ref>[http://www.byjamesraia.com/articles/8/1/Lanterne-Rouge-The-Honor-Of-Being-Last-In-The-Tour-de-France/Page1.html Lanterne Rouge] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070727011122/http://www.byjamesraia.com/articles/8/1/Lanterne-Rouge-The-Honor-Of-Being-Last-In-The-Tour-de-France/Page1.html |date=2007-07-27 }}</ref>[[File:Jimmy Casper.jpg|thumb|left|Casper at the [[2006 Tour de France]].]]Casper was suspended from his team, [[Agritubel]] because he tested positive for [[corticosteroid]], an asthma drug that is banned unless the user has a medical exemption for its use, during the [[2008 Tour de France]] by the [[Agence Française de Lutte contre le Dopage]]. The exemption had been renewed but with a previous asthma medication than the one prescribed and used during the Tour de France.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/cycling/7551944.stm | work=BBC News | title=Fifth Tour rider fails drugs test | date=9 August 2008}}</ref> He has been cleared of any charges during the hearing held by the Federation Francaise de Cyclisme. For 2009 he signed with the {{ct|SAU|2009}} team, with whom he enjoyed success, winning two stages at the [[Étoile de Bessèges]], a stage of the [[Critérium International]], the [[Paris–Camembert]], and the [[Grand Prix de Denain]]. Casper joined the {{ct|ALM|2012}} team for the 2012 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2011/08/news/jimmy-casper-joins-ag2r-la-mondiale-for-one-year-deal_187678|title=Jimmy Casper joins Ag2r-La Mondiale for one-year deal|date=10 August 2011|accessdate=1 January 2012|work=VeloNews|publisher=Competitor Group, Inc.|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]}}</ref>In December 2012, Casper announced his retirement as a professional cyclist. He had a total of 61 victories and stated that he would like to remain in the cycling environment with a coaching job.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/casper-retires-from-professional-cycling|title=Casper retires from professional cycling|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=21 December 2012|accessdate=22 December 2012}}</ref>==Major results=={{colbegin|2}};1999 – {{ct|FDJ|1999}}: 1st, Stages 1, 3, 4 & 8, [[Deutschland Tour]]: 1st, Stage 4a, [[Four Days of Dunkirk]]: 1st, Stage 1a, (1	Robert Lipsyte	{{Infobox person|name          = Robert Lipsyte|image         = Robert Lipsyte.jpg|image_size    = 200px|caption       = Lipsyte <!-- prefer more specific -->|birth_name    =Robert Michael Lipsyte|birth_date    = {{Birth date and age|1938|1|16|mf=y}}|birth_place   = [[New York City]], New York, USA|death_date    =|death_place   =|death_cause   =|resting_place =|resting_place_coordinates =|residence     = [[New York City]] and [[Shelter Island, New York]]|nationality   = American|other_names   =|known_for     =|education     =|alma_mater    =|employer      = New York Times, ESPN, CBS, NBC, various publishers|occupation    = [[Sports journalist]], [[author]]|home_town     = [[Rego Park, Queens|Rego Park]], New York City|title         =|salary        =|networth      =|height        =|weight        =|religion      =|spouse        =|partner       =|children      = 2 children|relations     =|signature     =|website       = http://robertlipsyte.com/|footnotes     =}}'''Robert Michael Lipsyte''' (born January 5, 1938) is an [[American people|American]] [[sports journalism|sports journalist]] and [[author]] and former [[Ombudsman]] for [[ESPN]]. He is a member of the Board of Contributors for ''[[USA Today]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s Forum Page, part of the newspaper's Opinion section. He received the [[Margaret Edwards Award]] from the [[American Library Association]] in 2001 for his contribution in writing for teens.<ref name=edwards/>==Personal background==Lipsyte was born on January 16, 1938, in [[New York City]], the son of Fanny (Finston) and Sidney I. Lipsyte. He grew up in [[Rego Park, Queens|Rego Park]], a neighborhood in the [[New York city]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Queens]].<ref>Lipsyte, Robert. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE7DD1231F931A15753C1A963958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2 "COPING; My Bullied Days: A Smart Fat Kid's Story"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 22, 1995. Accessed October 11, 2007. "Rego Park was predominately Jewish, and most of the bullying had no ethnic edge."</ref> Lipsyte’s father was a school principal, his mother a teacher. Young Robert devoted his childhood to books rather than sports. Instead of sharing a game of catch with his father, the two often visited the library. Robert's son, [[Michael Jackson]], is also an author and teacher at [[Columbia University]] in New York.In the first chapter of his 1976 book ''SportsWorld'', which considers the role of sports in American culture, Lipsyte points out that he did not even attend his first major league baseball game until he was thirteen years old, despite the fact that there were three major league teams in New York: the Yankees, the Giants, and the Dodgers. Lipsyte says he was “profoundly disappointed” with his experience at the game and so went to only one more game “as a paying customer.” His third major league game was as a sports reporter for ''[[The New York Times]]''.As a boy, Lipsyte did play [[Chinese handball]] against the sides of brick buildings and participated in street games such as [[stickball]], but he felt acute pressure to excel at sports which discouraged his interest. This experience later developed into a major theme in some of Lipsyte’s nonfiction works such as ''SportsWorld'' and novels like ''Jock and Jill'' (1982) and his trilogy beginning with ''One Fat Summer'' (1977). The protagonist of ''One Fat Summer'', Bobby Marks, is similar to Lipsyte: Bobby is an adolescent in the 1950s, suffering from a weight problem, who does something about it. In 1952, Lipsyte took a summer job as a lawn boy and lost forty pounds, ridding himself of the youthful stigma of excess weight.==Television==Lipsyte has done work as a correspondent for both CBS and NBC, in addition to an Emmy-winning stint as host of WNET/Thirteen's "The Eleventh Hour" in the late 1980s.<ref>Lipsyte, Robert. [http://www.robertlipsyte.com/bio.htm "Biography"], Personal Website, Accessed June 2, 2011. "I've been a correspondent for CBS and NBC and had a nightly public affairs show on the PBS station in New York, WNET Channel 13 for which I won an Emmy."</ref>==Works of nonfiction==Much of Lipsyte’s nonfiction deals with sports, but here again he rarely takes a conventional approach. He is especially concerned that children are subjected to sports in negative ways. Sports should be fun and entertaining; winning need not be the only goal. Although he is not anti-sport, he is disillusioned by a culture of champions that he calls “Sportsworld.” SportsWorld, as Lipsyte points out in the book by that name, “is a grotesque distortion of sports.” It honors the winner more than the race. As illustrated in ''[[The Contender (Robert Lipsyte novel)|The Contender]]'', Lipsyte values the process more than the result; competing well is more important than winning itself.Lipsyte was among the first to accept and respect the [[heavyweight (boxing)|heavyweight]] [[boxing]] champ [[Muhammad Ali]]. His agreement that Ali should be allowed to be himself is echoed in the title of his 1978 book on the complicated man: "Free to Be Muhammad Ali".He co-authored comedian and social activist [[Dick Gregory]]'s 1964 autobiography, ''[[Nigger (1964 book)|Nigger]]''.In 1978, Robert Lipsyte was diagnosed with [[testicular cancer]]. Despite his eventual recovery from that first bout, he was diagnosed with [[cancer]] a second time in 1991. His experience with the illness led to another novel for young adults, The Chemo Kid (1992). In it, the [[protagonist]], Fred Bauer, an ordinary high school junior in almost every way, discovers he has cancer and undergoes a series of experimental hormone treatments. Miraculously, Fred acquires superpowers, apparently due to the treatments, and becomes “The Chemo Kid,” fighting for the environment and against drug dealers.An adult consideration of cancer, and sickness in general, is Lipsyte’s 1998 nonfiction work, "In the Country of Illness". Here, he speaks of infirmity as if it is a foreign land, a place he calls “Malady . . . another country, scary and strange.” Basing his accounts on his own experiences, as well as those of other family members, he comforts, advises, warns, and informs the reader with tenderness, insight, and wit. Lipsyte’s second wife, Margie, learned that she had [[breast cancer]] after their divorce. Especially moving is the account of Lipsyte’s second wife Margie’s failing health, after being diagnosed with breast cancer, and the strength shown by Margie and their two young adult children.In a 2009 interview with SportsMediaGuide, Lipsyte said that he has come to realize "that most jocks are sissies&nbsp;...".<ref>http://sportsmediaguide.com/interviews/robert-lipsyte/. SportsMediaGuide.  or subscription required {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421021216/http://sportsmediaguide.com/interviews/robert-lipsyte/ |date=April 21, 2012 }}</ref>Lipsyte's 2011 autobiography, "An Accidental Sportswriter," looks back at his long, unconventional career as a sports journalist at [[The New York Times]] and other outlets.<ref>[http://allsportsbooks.blogspot.com/2011/04/review-accidental-sportswriter-2011.html "Review: ''An Accidental Sportswriter'' (2011)"]. Budd Bailey. ''Sports Book Review Center''. April 24, 2011.</ref>In addition to the Emmy, Lipsyte's honors and awards include the Dutton Best Sports Stories Award, [[E. P. Dutton]], 1964, 1965, 1967, 1971, and 1976; the Mike Berger Award, Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, 1966 and 1996; Wel-Met Children’s Book Award, 1967; New York Times outstanding children’s book of the year citation, 1977; [[American Library Association]] best young adult book citation, 1977; and New Jersey Author citation, 1978.Lipsyte has been a resident of [[Closter, New Jersey]]. He was inducted into the New Jersey Literary Hall of Fame in 1993.<ref>Horner, Shirley. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE5DD1031F930A35753C1A965958260 "ABOUT BOOKS"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 3, 1993. Accessed December 19, 2007. "The other inductees are&nbsp;... Robert Lipsyte of Closter, a sports columnist for The New York Times and the author of ''The Contender'' a young-adult novel published by Harper in 1967 and still in print&nbsp;...".</ref>The ALA [[Margaret A. Edwards Award]] recognizes one writer and a particular body of work for "significant and lasting contribution to young adult literature". Lipsyte won the annual award in 2001, citing four books published from 1967 to 1993. According to the citation, "''The Contender'' and its sequels, ''The Brave'' and ''The Chief'' transformed the sports novel to authentic literature with their gritty depiction of the boxing world. An ongoing theme is the struggle of their protagonists to seek personal victory by their continuing efforts towards a better life despite defeats. The same theme appears in the humorous ''One Fat Summer'', in which an overweight boy deals with the timeless angst of body image. Lipsyte's books focus on the search for self-definition by young adults."<ref name=edwards/>At one point, ''One Fat Summer'' was removed from the syllabus of the [[Levittown, New York]] public school system after complaints were made about its depiction of its teenage protagonist's sexual fantasies. The decision was criticized by educators, civil libertarians, and the author [[Judy Blume]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/08/nyregion/a-1977-comes-under-scrutiny.html?pagewanted=1</ref>==See also=={{Portal bar |Children's literature |Sports }} <!-- delete "bar" if/when there are enough ordinary See also -->==References=={{Reflist |25em |refs=<ref name=edwards>[http://www.ala.org/yalsa/booklistsawards/bookawards/margaretaedwards/maeprevious/2001awardwinner "2001 Margaret A. Edwards Award Winner"]. [[Young Adult Library Services Association]] (YALSA). American Library Association (ALA).<br>&nbsp; [http://www.ala.org/yalsa/edwards-award "Edwards Award"]. YALSA. ALA. Retrieved 2013-10-13.</ref>}}==External links==* {{official website |robertlipsyte.com/ }}* [http://www.lib.usm.edu/legacy/degrum/public_html/html/research/findaids/lipsyte.htm Robert Lipsyte Paper] in the [[de Grummond Children's Literature Collection]] —with biographical sketch* [http://bloggingheads.tv/?s=lipsyte Robert Lipsyte] on [[Bloggingheads.tv]] —four 2008–2009 appearances with Bryan Curtis* [http://lccn.loc.gov/n50051353 Roberty Lipsyte] at [[Library of Congress]] Authorities —with 31 catalog records{{Closter}}{{Authority control}} <!-- |GND=111605172 is only a nameholder that links some of his works, perhaps among others (VIAF=294131415) -->{{DEFAULTSORT:Lipsyte, Robert}}[[Category:1938 births]][[Category:American Jews]][[Category:American sports novelists]][[Category:American sportswriters]][[Category:Columbia University alumni]][[Category:Margaret A. Edwards Award winners]][[Category:People from Closter, New Jersey]][[Category:People from Queens, New York]][[Category:Sportspeople from Queens, New York]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:20th-century American novelists]][[Category:American male novelists]][[Category:Journalists from New York City]][[Category:20th-century male writers]])
(1	Category:Sport in Prince Edward Island	{{Prince Edward Island Sports|state=collapsed}}{{Commons category|Sports in Prince Edward Island}}[[Category:Prince Edward Island|Sports]][[Category:Sport in Canada by province or territory|Prince Edward Island]][[Category:Sport in the Maritimes| Prince Edward Island]])
(1	UFC 19	{{Infobox MMA event| name = UFC 19: Ultimate Young Guns| image = UFC19.jpg| promotion = [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]]| date = March 5, 1999| venue = [[Casino Magic Bay St. Louis]]| city = [[Bay St. Louis, Mississippi|Bay St. Louis]], [[Mississippi]]| attendance =| gate =| buyrate =| purse =| previousevent = [[UFC 18|UFC 18: The Road To The Heavyweight Title]]| followingevent = [[UFC 20|UFC 20: Battle for the Gold]]}}'''''UFC 19: Ultimate Young Guns''''' was a [[mixed martial arts]] event held by the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] on March 5, 1999 at the [[Casino Magic Bay St. Louis|Casino Magic]] in [[Bay St. Louis]], [[Mississippi]]. The event was seen live on [[pay-per-view]] in the [[United States]], and later released on [[home video]].==History==UFC 19 featured the first appearance of collegiate wrestler [[Kevin Randleman]], as well as the first televised appearance of former [[UFC Light Heavyweight Championship|UFC Light Heavyweight Champion]] and [[UFC Hall of Fame|Hall of Famer]] [[Chuck Liddell]], who had fought at [[UFC 17]] in an alternate untelevised bout. Future referee Dan Miragliotta makes his debut as [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] judge for the event.In the main event, [[Guy Mezger]] fought [[Tito Ortiz]] in a rematch of their first fight in the finals of [[UFC 13]], which Mezger won by submission. Ortiz was a late replacement for [[Vitor Belfort]], who was scheduled to face Mezger but was forced to withdraw. The post-fight disrespect shown by [[Tito Ortiz]] to [[Guy Mezger]] and the [[Lion's Den (mixed martial arts)|Lion's Den]] led to the long-running rivalry between Ortiz and Lion's Den leader [[Ken Shamrock]].UFC 19 was part three of what the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] called "The Road To The Heavyweight Title", a four-part tournament of sorts, held to determine the [[UFC Heavyweight Championship|Heavyweight Champion]] after the title was vacated by [[Randy Couture]]. It was determined that the winner of [[Kevin Randleman]] vs. [[Maurice Smith (kickboxer)|Maurice Smith]] would face [[Bas Rutten]] at [[UFC 20]] for the Undisputed [[UFC Heavyweight Championship]] Title.==Results=={{MMAevent}}{{MMAevent card|Main Card}}{{MMAevent bout|Middleweight|[[Tito Ortiz]]|def.|[[Guy Mezger]]|TKO (punches)||9:55|}}{{MMAevent bout|Heavyweight|[[Gary Goodridge]]|def.|[[Andre Roberts (Mixed martial artist)|Andre Roberts]]|Submission (punches)||0:42|}}{{MMAevent bout|Middleweight|[[Jeremy Horn]]|def.|[[Chuck Liddell]]|Technical Submission (arm-triangle choke)||12:00|}}{{MMAevent bout|Heavyweight|[[Kevin Randleman]]|def.|[[Maurice Smith (kickboxer)|Maurice Smith]]|Decision (unanimous)||15:00|}}{{MMAevent bout|Middleweight|[[Evan Tanner]]|def.|Valeri Ignatov|TKO (punches and elbows)||2:57|}}{{MMAevent bout|Heavyweight|[[Pete Williams (mixed martial artist)|Pete Williams]]|def.|Jason Godsey|Submission (kneebar)||1:54|}}{{MMAevent bout|Middleweight|Sione Latu|def.|Joey Roberts|TKO (doctor stoppage)||10:01|}}{{MMAevent end|notes = yes}}== See also =={{portal|MMA}}* [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]]* [[List of UFC champions]]* [[List of UFC events]]* [[1999 in UFC]]==External links==*[http://www.sherdog.com/events/UFC-19-Ultimate-Young-Guns-29 UFC19 results at Sherdog.com]*[http://www.411mania.com/MMA/video_reviews/61855/HIstory-of-the-UFC-10.22.07:-UFC-XIX:-Ultimate-Young-Guns.htm UFC19 fights reviews]*[http://www.ufc.com/event/UFC-19-Young-Guns UFC Official Website]*[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0483514/ IMDB Page]{{UFC Events}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Ufc 019}}[[Category:Ultimate Fighting Championship events]][[Category:1999 in mixed martial arts]][[Category:Mixed martial arts in Mississippi]][[Category:Sports in Bay St. Louis, Mississippi]][[Category:1999 in sports in Mississippi]])
(1	Golden Bear Stadium	{{Notability|Companies|date=March 2009}}{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name      = Golden Bear Stadium|image = |location          = 1215 Wilbraham Road<br>Springfield, MA 01119 |opened            = September 2002 |closed            = |demolished        = |owner             = Western New England University |operator          = Western New England University |tenants           = Western New England University (NCAA) 2002-Present |seating_capacity  = 1,500|}}[[File:WNECFootball22.jpg|thumb|Golden Bear Stadium]]'''Golden Bear Stadium''' is a multipurpose outdoor sports facility on the campus of [[Western New England University]] in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]]. It features a synthetic turf field. The 1,500-seat stadium serves as the home field for Western New England University's [[American football|football]], [[field hockey]], and men’s and women’s [[lacrosse]] teams.Western New England University's football and lacrosse teams previously played their contests on the game field located near the St. Germain Campus Center. The field hockey team played its events on a grass surface at [[Suprenant Field]].==Memorable moments==* October 31, 2006 - Field hockey team defeats [[Simmons College (Massachusetts)|Simmons College]], 2-1, in a semifinal match of the [[North Atlantic Conference]] (NAC) Tournament. It was the final varsity athletic event held at Golden Bear Stadium for Western New England under the auspices of the NAC. [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2006/10/31/2615054250.aspx?path=fhockey]*May 5, 2007 - Women's lacrosse defeats [[Worcester State College]], 14-10, in the championship game of the [[New England Women's Lacrosse Alliance]] (NEWLA) Tournament. It was the final varsity athletic event held at Golden Bear Stadium for Western New England under the auspices of the NEWLA. [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2007/5/5/7400193810.aspx?path=wlax]*May 5, 2007 - Men's lacrosse defeats [[Springfield College]], 8-6, in the championship game of the [[Pilgrim League]] Tournament. It was the final varsity athletic event held at Golden Bear Stadium for Western New England under the auspices of the Pilgrim League. [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2007/5/5/2167950869.aspx?path=mlax]* May 12, 2007 - The Western New England men's lacrosse team hosts a second-round game of the NCAA Division III Tournament at Golden Bear Stadium, defeating [[Keene State College|Keene State]] 13-5. This is the first NCAA Tournament event in any sport to be held at Western New England University. [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2007/5/12/8282768130.aspx?path=mlax]* May 16, 2007 - The Western New England men's lacrosse team hosts a quarterfinal game of the NCAA Division III Tournament at Golden Bear Stadium, losing to [[Cortland State]] 12-10. [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2007/5/16/7024844289.aspx?path=mlax]*September 26, 2007 - Field hockey team defeats [[Endicott College]], 3-2, in the first varsity athletic event held at Golden Bear Stadium for Western New England under the auspices of The [[Commonwealth Coast Conference]] (TCCC).[http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2007/9/26/8584582210.aspx?path=fhockey]*May 7, 2008 - Men's lacrosse team defeats [[Western Connecticut State University]], 14-4, in the first round of the 2008 NCAA Division III Men's Lacrosse Championship.[http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2008/5/7/7762461901.aspx?path=mlax]*May 2, 2009 - Men's lacrosse team defeats Endicott College, 12-7, to win TCCC Championship and earn an automatic berth to the 2009 NCAA Division III Men's Lacrosse Championship.[http://www.wnecgoldenbears.com/news/2009/5/2/5067629218.aspx?path=mlax]*November 7, 2009 - Football team ends it most successful season ever with a 31-10 victory over [[Nichols College]]. The Football team ended the year with a 6-4 mark, setting a school record for wins in a season to date.[http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2009/11/7/FB_1107092209.aspx?path=football]*August 10, 2010 - New FieldTurf installed at Golden Bear Stadium [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2010/8/10/GEN_0810101201.aspx]*November 20, 2010 - Football team participates in and wins the program's first postseason contest with a 66-41 victory over Maine Maritime in the Eastern College Athletic Conference (ECAC) North Central Bowl Championship. The win caps the most successful in program history as the Golden Bears finished with a school record 9-2 mark and tied for first in the New England Football Conference  Boyd Division with a 6-1 conference record. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120320232658/http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2010/11/20/FB_1120100340.aspx]* August 2011 - New LED Scoreboard and Play Clock systems installed at Stadium.* November 12, 2011 - Football team defeats [[Framingham State University]] 20-13 (OT) to win the program's first ever New England Football Conference championship. With the victory, the football team qualified for the [[NCAA Division III Football Championship]] for the first time in school history.[http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/news/2011/11/13/FB_1113113546.aspx]==External links==* [http://www.wnegoldenbears.com/ Western New England University athletics]{{Massachusetts college football venues}}{{coord|42.112718|-72.513384|type:landmark|display=title}}[[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]][[Category:College football venues]][[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]][[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]][[Category:College field hockey venues in the United States]][[Category:Sports venues in Springfield, Massachusetts]][[Category:Western New England University]][[Category:2002 establishments in Massachusetts]][[Category:American football venues in Massachusetts]])
(1	1979 BDO World Darts Championship	{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}}{{Use British English|date=February 2012}}{{Infobox individual darts tournament|tournament_name = Embassy World Darts Championship|image =|dates = 2&ndash;9 February 1979|venue = [[Jollees Cabaret Club]]<ref name="hickoksports1">{{cite web|author=Ralph Hickok |url=http://www.hickoksports.com/history/wdartschampions.shtml |title=History - World Darts Champions |publisher=HickokSports.com |date=16 January 2010 |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>|location = [[Stoke-on-Trent]]|country = [[England]]|organisation = [[British Darts Organisation|BDO]]|format = [[Set (darts)|Sets]]<br>Final &ndash; best of 9|prize_fund = £15,000|winners_share = £4,500|nine_dart =|high_checkout = '''161''' {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Tony Brown (darts player)|Tony Brown]]<br>{{0|'''161''' }}{{flagicon|WAL}} [[Ronnie Davies]]|winner = {{Flagicon|ENG}} '''[[John Lowe]]'''|prev = [[1978 BDO World Darts Championship|1978]]|next = [[1980 BDO World Darts Championship|1980]]}}The '''1979 Embassy World Darts Championship''' was the second World Professional Championships. Having been held the previous year at the [[Rock City (club)|Heart of the Midlands Club]] in [[Nottingham]], the event moved to [[Jollees Cabaret Club]] in [[Stoke-on-Trent]] where it was to remain until 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.learnaboutdarts.com/world-championship-of-darts.htm |title=The World Championship of Darts |publisher=Learnaboutdarts.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>The tournament was held between 2 February and 9 February and had been expanded from 16 players to 24. The eight seeded players each received a bye into the second round. The format also changed from a straight matchplay (legs) to sets. Each set was the best of 5 legs. - For matches in the opening rounds the matches were best of three sets, - best of five for the quarter-finals and semi-finals, with the final being best of 9 sets, split over an afternoon and evening session with the play-off for third held in between.Defending champion, [[Leighton Rees]] of Wales again progressed to the final where he met [[John Lowe]] in a repeat of the inaugural championship. This time, Lowe was the top seed and came out on top in the final by 5 sets to 0.<ref name="hickoksports1"/>==New players==With the expansion from 16 to 24 players in the finals, 11 players made their championship debuts, the most notable being John Wilson of Scotland, - no doubt to be soon known as Jocky. Wilson's performances over 1978 had enabled him to be seeded 8th for the tournament, and thus ensure a place in round 2 straight away.==Seeds==Wilson entering the seeds meant he would replace Rab Smith, the Scot having to play the first round before moving into the later stages. England's John Lowe had risen to be number 1 seed, with Eric Bristow dropping to 2nd seed after his first round defeat a year earlier. Leighton Rees remained seeded 3, with Tony Brown moving up to number 4. The Semi-Finalist from 1978 Nicky Virachkul was seeded 5th with the other Last 4 man, Stefan Lord seeded 6th. Alan Evans was the 7th seed along with Wilson as 8th.# {{flagicon|ENG}} [[John Lowe]]# {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Eric Bristow]]# {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Leighton Rees]]# {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Tony Brown (darts player)|Tony Brown]]# {{flagicon|USA}} [[Nicky Virachkul]]# {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Stefan Lord]]# {{flagicon|WAL}} [[Alan Evans]]# {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Jocky Wilson]]==First round - Friday 2 and Saturday 3 February==The second Embassy World Championship opened up with the first surprise, Doug McCarthy's 2-1 win over Charlie Ellix. - McCarthy would meet Lowe in the last 16 later on in the event. Jim McQuillian, following Patrick Clifford as only the second Irishman to pay in the World Championship, looked comfortable in his 2-0 win over Murray Smith, whose long trek to Stoke from New Zealand was over before it had begun.==Prize money==Total Prize fund was £15,000 (plus a £12,000 bonus for a [[nine-dart finish]] - not won)*Champion £4,500*Runner-up £2,000*Third Place £1,500*Fourth Place £1,000*Quarter finalists £500*2nd round losers £300*1st round losers £200==The results=={{24TeamBracket-Byes|RD1=Round 1<br/>Best of 3 sets|RD2=Round 2<br>Best of 3 sets|RD3=Quarter-finals<br/>Best of (1	Everett Arena	[[Image:DouglasEverettArena.jpg|thumb|right|Douglas N. Everett Arena]]The '''Douglas N. Everett Arena''' is an indoor [[arena]] in [[Concord, New Hampshire|Concord]], [[New Hampshire]], United States. It hosted the [[Northeastern Hockey League]]'s [[Cape Cod Freedoms|New Hampshire Freedoms]] in 1979. The arena holds 3,000 people.The arena is owned by the City of Concord and operated by the city's General Services Department. The arena was built in 1965 and taken over by the City in the mid 1980s. The arena's mission is to provide a modern, safe, attractive, and well-operated multipurpose facility for the Concord community at rates which are competitive with other facilities in the region.From mid-September to mid-March the arena holds [[ice skating]] activities such as public skating, stick practice, and hockey games. From mid-March to mid-September the arena hosts shows and events. [[Roller skating]] is offered June-July.== Skating =='''Public Ice Skating:''' Occurs from mid-September through mid-March. Hours are Monday through Saturday from 11:30AM to 1PM and Sundays 5:30PM to 7:30PM. Admission is $5 (kids 3 and under are free) and skate rentals are available at the Pro Shop for $5. Skating lessons are available through Concord Parks and Recreation.<ref name=Skating>{{Cite web|title = Concord, NH - Official Website - Skating|url = http://www.concordnh.gov/skating|website = www.concordnh.gov|access-date = 2016-01-21}}</ref>'''Adult Stick Practice (Ages 14+):''' Occurs from mid-September through mid-March. Hours are Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 10:00AM to 11:20PM. Extended hours occur from the beginning of the program through mid-November for Monday through Thursday from 3:30PM to 4:45PM. Admission is $10 (goalies are free). Helmet and gloves are required, although full equipment is recommended.<ref name=Skating/>'''Youth Stick Practice (Ages 13-):''' Occurs from mid-September through mid-March. Hours are Fridays from 3:30PM to 4:45PM. Admission is $8 (goalies are free). Full equipment is required.<ref name=Skating/>== Hockey =='''Adult Men's Hockey:''' Competitive A-level men's hockey plays on Monday and Tuesday evenings, while B-level men's hockey play on Sunday evenings and Tuesday and Wednesday mornings. Leagues are run by independent groups.<ref name="Adult Leagues">{{Cite web|title = Concord, NH - Official Website - Adult Leagues|url = http://www.concordnh.gov/index.aspx?NID=924|website = www.concordnh.gov|access-date = 2016-01-21}}</ref>'''Adult Women's Hockey:''' The Nor'easters play Fridays at 9:30PM. The Helicats play Wednesdays at 9:30PM. Leagues are run by independent groups.<ref name="Adult Leagues"/>'''High School Hockey:''' The Everett Arena hosts five high school teams: [[Concord High School (New Hampshire)|Concord High School]] "[http://www.leaguelineup.com/welcome.asp?sid=435589863&url=chshockey Crimson Tide" Boys Hockey], Concord High School [http://www.leaguelineup.com/welcome.asp?url=girlschshockey "Crimson Tide" Girls Hockey], [[Bishop Brady High School|Bishop Brady]] [http://www.bishopbradyathletics.com/main/team/id/3620078 "Giants" Boys Hockey], Bishop Brady [http://www.bishopbradyathletics.com/main/team/id/3620118 "Giants" Girls Hockey], and [[Bow High School]] [http://bowhighschoolathletics.org/main/teamhome/id/3612619/ "Falcons" Boys Hockey]. On average, teams typically play 10 home games at the arena during the winter season in addition to playoff games at the end of February and the beginning of March. The Everett Arena also hosts the [[New Hampshire Interscholastic Athletic Association|NHIAA]] Semi-Final Tournaments for both the girls and boys division.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Concord, NH - Official Website - High School Hockey|url = http://www.concordnh.gov/index.aspx?NID=923|website = www.concordnh.gov|access-date = 2016-01-21}}</ref>'''Youth Hockey:''' The Concord Youth Hockey Association (CYHA) runs youth hockey at the Everett Arena. CYHA offers learn-to-play hockey programs and travel programs for children ages 4 to 18. Programs run from September to March.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Concord, NH - Official Website - Youth Hockey|url = http://www.concordnh.gov/index.aspx?NID=922|website = www.concordnh.gov|access-date = 2016-01-21}}</ref>== Spring and summer shows ==When the arena is not an ice rink, dry floor shows and events occur during the spring and summer. The arena is located just east of [[Interstate 93]] at Exit 14. There are {{convert|18000|sqft}} of exhibit space with a {{convert|12|x|12|ft|adj=on}} load-in door and {{convert|45|ft|m|adj=mid|-high}} ceilings. Power and water are available on site for exhibitors. A variety of shows and events are hosted at the arena, including book shows, craft fairs, flea markets, gun shows, home shows, and the Kiwanis Spring Fair.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Concord, NH - Official Website - Spring & Summer Shows|url = http://www.concordnh.gov/index.aspx?NID=925|website = www.concordnh.gov|access-date = 2016-01-21}}</ref>==References=={{Reflist}}==External links==* [http://www.concordnh.gov/arena Everett Arena official website]* [http://nh-concord.civicplus.com/Index.aspx?NID=666 Concord Parks and Recreation Department]* [http://www.concordnh.gov/generalservices Concord General Services Department]* [http://capitals.concordyouthhockey.org/ Concord Youth Hockey Association]* [http://www.concordkiwanis.org/Page/11101 Kiwanis Spring Fair]{{coord|43|12|34|N|71|31|37|W|type:landmark|display=title}}[[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]][[Category:Indoor arenas in New Hampshire]][[Category:Sports venues in New Hampshire]][[Category:Buildings and structures in Concord, New Hampshire]])
(1	O. J. Simpson	{{redirect|The Juice||Juice (disambiguation)}}{{pp-blp|expiry=indef|small=yes}}{{pp-move-indef}}{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}}{{stack|{{Infobox NFL biography|name            = O. J. Simpson|image           = O.J. Simpson 1990 · DN-ST-91-03444 crop.JPEG{{!}}border|image_size      = 220|caption         = Simpson in 1990|position        = [[Running back]]|number          = 32|birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1947|7|9}}|birth_place     = [[San Francisco, California]]|death_date      = <!-- {{Death date and age|20YY|MM|DD|1947|7|9}} -->|death_place     =|height_ft       = 6|height_in       = 1|weight_lbs      = 210|draftyear       = 1969|draftround      = 1|draftpick       = 1|high_school     = [[San Francisco (CA) Galileo]]|college         = [[USC Trojans football|USC]]|teams           =* [[Buffalo Bills]] ([[1969 American Football League season|1969]]–{{NFL Year|1977}})* [[San Francisco 49ers]] ({{NFL Year|1978}}–{{NFL Year|1979}})|highlights      =* 5× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[1973 Pro Bowl|1972]]–[[1977 Pro Bowl|1976]])* 5× First-team [[All-Pro]] ([[1972 All-Pro Team|1972]]–[[1976 All-Pro Team|1976]])* [[NFL Most Valuable Player]] (1973)* [[NFL Offensive Player of the Year]]
