(1	2001 Tampa Bay Devil Rays season	{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}}{{Infobox MLB yearly| name = Tampa Bay Devil Rays| season = 2001| misc =| logo = TampaBayDevilRays_100.png| current league = American League| y1 =  1998| division = [[American League East|Eastern Division]]| y2 =  1998| Uniform logo = ALE-Uniform-TB.PNG| ballpark = [[Tropicana Field]]| y4 = 1998| city = [[St. Petersburg, Florida]]| y5 = 1998| record = 62–100 (.383)| divisional place = 5th| owners = [[Vince Naimoli]]| general managers = [[Chuck LaMar]]| managers = [[Larry Rothschild]], [[Hal McRae]]| television = [[Fox Sports Net|FSN Florida]]<br>[[WMOR-TV]]<br>[[WTSP]]<br>[[WTVT]]<br>([[Joe Magrane]], [[Dewayne Staats]])| radio =  [[WFLA (AM)|WFLA]]<br>(Paul Olden, [[Charlie Slowes]])<br>[[WLCC]]<br>(Ricardo Tavares, Enrique Oliu)|}}The '''2001 [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] season''' was their fourth since the franchise was created. This season, they finished last in the [[American League East|AL East]] division, and managed to finish the season with a record of 62-100. Their [[Manager (baseball)|manager]] were [[Larry Rothschild]] and [[Hal McRae]], the latter whom replaced Rothschild shortly after the season began.==Offseason==*November 2, 2000: Bill Pulsipher was Signed as a Free Agent with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/p/pulsibi01.shtml Bill Pulsipher Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>*November 27, 2000: Quinton McCracken was released by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/m/mccraqu01.shtml Quinton McCracken Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>*November 27, 2000: [[Jim Morris]] was released by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.<ref>http://www.baseball-reference.com/m/morrija03.shtml</ref>* January 8, 2001: [[Johnny Damon]] was traded as part of a 3-team trade by the Kansas City Royals with Mark Ellis to the Oakland Athletics. The Oakland Athletics sent Ben Grieve to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. The Oakland Athletics sent Ángel Berroa and A. J. Hinch to the Kansas City Royals. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays sent Cory Lidle to the Oakland Athletics. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays sent Roberto Hernandez to the Kansas City Royals.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/d/damonjo01.shtml Johnny Damon Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>*March 23, 2001: Bill Pulsipher was Released by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.<ref name=autogenerated1 />==Regular season=====Opening Day starters===*Vinny Castilla*Steve Cox*John Flaherty*Ben Grieve*Albie Lopez*Felix Martinez*Fred McGriff*Bob Smith*Greg Vaughn*Gerald Williams<ref>[http://www.baseball-almanac.com/teamstats/roster.php?y=2001&t=TBA 2001 Tampa Bay Devil Rays Roster by Baseball Almanac<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>===Season standings==={{MLBBioRet|Image  = RaysRetired12.PNG|Name   = Wade Boggs|Number = 12|Team   = Tampa Bay Rays|Year   = 2001|}}{{2001 AL East standings|highlight=Tampa Bay Devil Rays}}=== Record vs. opponents ==={{2001 AL Record vs. opponents|team=TB}}===Transactions===*April 4, 2001: Kenny Kely was purchased by the Seattle Mariners from the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/k/kellyke01.shtml Kenny Kelly Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>*June 5, 2001: Dewon Brazelton was drafted by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in the 1st round (3rd pick) of the 2001 amateur draft. Player signed August 25, 2001.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/b/brazede01.shtml Dewon Brazelton Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>* June 5, 2001: Jon Switzer was drafted by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in the 2nd round of the 2001 amateur draft. Player signed August 13, 2001.<ref>[http://www.baseball-reference.com/s/switzjo01.shtml Jon Switzer Statistics] Baseball-Reference.com</ref>===Citrus Series===The annual [[Interleague play|interleague]] games between the Florida Marlins and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays were played in June and July. They are known as the [[Citrus Series]]. The Marlins won the series 4-2.*June 15- @ Marlins 7- Devil Rays 4 <ref>http://baseball-almanac.com/box-scores/boxscore.php?boxid=200106150FLO</ref>*June 16- @ Marlins 11- Devil Rays 0 <ref>http://baseball-almanac.com/box-scores/boxscore.php?boxid=200106170FLO</ref>*July 6- @ Devil Rays 5- Marlins 4 (11 innings) <ref>http://baseball-almanac.com/box-scores/boxscore.php?boxid=200107080TBA</ref>===Roster==={| class="toccolours" style="font-size: 95%;"|-! colspan="10" style="background-color: #00285D; color: (1	Armanti Edwards	{{Infobox NFL player|name= Armanti Edwards|image= Armanti Edwards Bears.jpg|image_size= 250px|caption= Edwards at Bears training camp in 2014.|current_team=Toronto Argonauts|number= 10|position= [[Wide receiver]]|birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1988|3|8|mf=y}}|birth_place= [[Greenwood, South Carolina]]|height_ft =  5|height_in =  11|weight_lbs =  190|high_school= [[Greenwood High School (South Carolina)|Greenwood (SC)]]|college= [[Appalachian State Mountaineers football|Appalachian State]]|draftyear= 2010|draftround= 3|draftpick= 89|pastteams=*[[Carolina Panthers]] ({{NFL Year|2010}}–{{NFL Year|2013}})*[[Cleveland Browns]] ({{NFL Year|2013}})*[[Chicago Bears]] ({{NFL Year|2014}})**[[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] ({{CFL Year|2016}})*[[Toronto Argonauts]] ({{CFL Year|2017}}–present)|pastteamsnote = yes|status=Active|cflstatus=International|highlights=* 2× [[NCAA Division I Football Championship|NCAA FCS national champion]] (2006, 2007)*[[Grey Cup]] champion ([[105th Grey Cup|2017]])* 2× [[Walter Payton Award]] (2008, 2009)* 2× [[SoCon]] Offensive Player of the Year (2008, 2009)* 3× First Team All-SoCon (2006, 2008, 2009)* Second Team All-SoCon (2007)|statweek=|statseason=2013|statlabel1=Receptions|statvalue1=6|statlabel2=Receiving Yards|statvalue2=131|statlabel3=Touchdowns|statvalue3=0|nfl=EDW112351|cfl=armanti-edwards/138082}}'''Armanti Fredrico Edwards, Sr.''' (born March 8, 1988) is an American [[gridiron football]] [[wide receiver]] for the [[Toronto Argonauts]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL). He was drafted by the [[Carolina Panthers]] in the third round of the [[2010 NFL Draft]].<ref>{{cite news|title=After QB, Panthers target targets |author=Andrew Mason |publisher=Panthers.com |date=2010-04-23 |accessdate=2010-04-24 |url=http://www.panthers.com/news/article-1/After-QB-Panthers-target-targets/ff6fd4fd-4ee9-4ea2-be7d-ec0b077b551e| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100428205659/http://www.panthers.com/news/article-1/After-QB-Panthers-target-targets/ff6fd4fd-4ee9-4ea2-be7d-ec0b077b551e| archivedate= 28 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He was the starting [[quarterback]] for the [[Appalachian State Mountaineers football]] team from 2006–09.In addition to leading the [[Appalachian State Mountaineers|Mountaineers]] to consecutive [[NCAA Division I Football Championship]]s (FCS) in [[2006 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|2006]] and [[2007 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|2007]], Edwards became the first quarterback in [[Southern Conference]] history to lead his team to four straight conference [[List of Southern Conference football champions|championships]].<ref name="5Titles">{{cite news |title=Mountaineers Clinch Fifth-Straight SoCon Title |author=Appalachian Sports Information |publisher=GoASU |date=2009-11-14 |accessdate=2009-11-19 |url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104460&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=204833726}}</ref> He became the first quarterback in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] history to throw for 9,000 and rush for 4,000 yards in a career, accomplishing the feat against [[Furman Paladins football|Furman]] on October 31, 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mountaineers Rout Furman, 52-27 |author=Appalachian Sports Information |publisher=GoASU |date=2009-10-31 |accessdate=2009-11-19 |url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104460&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=204824766}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Did He Just Do That? |author=Jason Gilmer |publisher=High Country Press |date=2009-11-19 |accessdate=2009-11-19 |url=http://www.highcountrypress.com/weekly/2009/11-19-09/did-he-just-do-that.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711165601/http://www.highcountrypress.com/weekly/2009/11-19-09/did-he-just-do-that.htm |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }}</ref> Later in the [[2009 NCAA Division I FCS football season|season]], he would become the first quarterback to pass for over 10,000 yards and rush for an additional 4,000 yards in a career.<ref>{{cite news |title=Edwards takes it: ASU quarterback wins the Walter Payton Award for the second time |publisher=Winston-Salem Journal |date=2009-12-18 |accessdate=2010-04-04 |url=http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2009/dec/18/edwards-takes-it/ }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=Red Director |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In the same week that Adrian Peterson set the NFL single game rushing record at 296, Armanti rushed for 313 on 31 attempts against Richmond in the playoffs at Kidd Brewer Stadium (12/7/2007). He is also the first back-to-back and two-time [[Walter Payton Award]] winner, given to the [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Championship Subdivision|Football Championship Subdivision]]'s most outstanding offensive player, receiving the award in 2008 and 2009.<ref name="AEPayton2">{{cite news|title=Armanti Edwards wins 2009 Walter Payton Award |publisher=The Sports Network |accessdate=2009-12-17 |url=http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=cfoot2/misc/2009payton_edwards_900.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404060532/http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=cfoot2%2Fmisc%2F2009payton_edwards_900.htm |archivedate=2011-04-04 |df= }}</ref><ref name="AEPayton3">{{cite news|title=Edwards wins second Payton Award|author=Associated Press|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-12-17|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=4753204}}</ref>{{TOClimit|limit=4}}==Early life==Armanti is the son of Deborah Anderson and Freddie Edwards. At birth, Edwards weighed 4 pounds 11 ounces and was delivered 10 days late.<ref name="Evans">{{cite news|title=A Father’s Prediction Becomes a Son’s Tribute|author=Thayer Evans|publisher=New York Times|date=2008-08-29|accessdate=2008-12-04|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/30/sports/ncaafootball/30edwards.html?ref=sports}}</ref> In September 2006, his father, Freddie, was convicted of a 2005 murder and sentenced to 30 years in prison.<ref name="Evans"/>==High school career==At [[Greenwood High School (South Carolina)|Greenwood High]], under coach Shell Dula, he was named to the Greenwood Touchdown Club/Index-Journal All-Lakelands Team. Edwards originally played wide receiver, but in his senior year, he moved under center. The transition occurred late in the recruiting process, and he drew some interest from [[New Mexico State Aggies football|New Mexico State]], [[Memphis Tigers football|Memphis]], [[South Carolina Gamecocks football|South Carolina]], and [[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]]. After only receiving an offer from [[New Mexico State Aggies football|New Mexico State]], he decided to honor his commitment to Appalachian State, in part because they would let him stay a quarterback. Armanti Edwards graduated with a 3.3 [[Grade (education)#United States|GPA]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Is Appalachian State's Armanti Edwards a true Heisman candidate?|url=http://www.scoresreport.com/2008/08/20/is-appalachian-state%E2%80%99s-armanti-edwards-a-true-heisman-candidate/|author=Anthony Stalter|publisher=The Scores Report|date=2008-08-20|accessdate=2008-11-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206153649/http://www.scoresreport.com/2008/08/20/is-appalachian-state%E2%80%99s-armanti-edwards-a-true-heisman-candidate/| archivedate= 6 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>==College career=====2006 season===Armanti Edwards led the Mountaineers to the FCS (formerly Division I-AA) [[NCAA Division I Football Championship|National Championship]] in [[2006 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|2006]] as a [[true freshman]], beating the [[UMass Minutemen football|Minutemen]] of [[University of Massachusetts Amherst|UMass]] 28–17. He finished the 2006 season with 2,251 yards and 15 touchdowns passing, and 1,153 yards and 15 touchdowns rushing. Edwards joined a select list as the fifth [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] player (Missouri's [[Brad Smith (American football)|Brad Smith]] and Texas's [[Vince Young]] are among the others), and second freshman, to accomplish the feat of 2000 passing yards and 1000 rushing yards in one season.<ref name="Schlabach">{{cite web|title=Undersized and overlooked, Edwards shines at Big House|author=Mark Schlabach|publisher=ESPN|date=2007-09-20|accessdate=2008-12-04|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/notebook?page=gamedayFinal071}}</ref> Edwards was named the [[Southern Conference]] Freshman of the Year at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mountaineers Clean Up as SoCon Awards, All-Conference Teams are Announced |author=Appalachian Sports Information|publisher=GoASU|date=2006-11-22|accessdate=2008-12-04|url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104458&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=1543817}}</ref>===2007 season===Edwards started the [[2007 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|2007]] season by guiding Appalachian State to a [[2007 Appalachian State vs. Michigan football game|34–32 upset victory]] over [[2007 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings|fifth-ranked]] [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] of the Football Bowl Subdivision on September 1, in a game that was named the "Biggest Upset of 2007" by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.<ref name="si121307">{{cite news|title=Biggest Upsets of 2007: #1 Appalachian State 34, No. 5 Michigan 32 |publisher=Sports Illustrated |date=2007-12-13 |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/0712/cfb.upsets/content.10.html}}</ref> In the game, Edwards threw for 227 yards and three touchdowns while also totaling 62 yards and a touchdown on the ground. On December 7, in a semifinal playoff game against [[Richmond Spiders football|Richmond]], Edwards set the single game FCS rushing record for a quarterback, rushing for 313 yards and 4 touchdowns on 31 carries.<ref>{{cite web |title=Edwards' dominating night puts Appalachian State in title game, 55-35 over Richmond |author=Associated Press |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date =2007-12-08 |accessdate=2008-12-04|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/12/08/sports/FBC-Richmond-Appalachian-St.php}}</ref> He also completed 14-of-16 passes for 192 yards and 3 touchdowns. Edwards had been mentioned as a possible candidate for the [[Heisman Trophy]] in the 2008 season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Edwards for Heisman? |author=Stewart Mandel |publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=2008-12-13 |accessdate=2008-12-04|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/writers/stewart_mandel/12/13/armanti.edwards/index.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081206111104/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/writers/stewart_mandel/12/13/armanti.edwards/index.html| archivedate= 6 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Edwards established himself as a threat through the air and along the ground, and garnered elite status within the division. He and the Mountaineers won a third consecutive national championship, beating the [[University of Delaware|Delaware]] [[Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens football|Fightin' Blue Hens]] 49–21 on December 14. He outplayed future Ravens quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] in that game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104458&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=1545029|title=Thrice is Nice: Apps Rout Delaware For Third-Straight National Title|author=Appalachian Sports Information|publisher=GoASU |date=2007-12-14 |accessdate=2008-01-04}}</ref>[[Image:Armanti Edwards Throw.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Edwards warms up prior to a game against [[Jacksonville University]] in 2008.]]===2008 season===[[Image:Armanti Edwards 20081004.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Edwards (#14) with Pierre Banks (#31) in 2008.]]The Mountaineers began the [[2008 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|2008]] campaign against the [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]], the first time defending FBS and FCS champions have met to open the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Edwards runs for 160 yards as Appalachian St. overwhelms No. 7 LSU |author=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN |date=2008-08-30 |accessdate=2008-09-22 |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=282430099| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080912092818/http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=282430099| archivedate= 12 September 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, LSU prevailed 41-13, with Edwards accounting for 216 of Appalachian State's 472 total yards. Edwards accounted for 440 yards of total offense, becoming the Southern Conference's all-time leader in yards with a 70–24 victory over the [[Wofford Terriers]] on October 31.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.soconsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=21895&SPID=1781&DB_OEM_ID=4000&ATCLID=1615697|title=Appalachian State Tops Wofford in Halloween Showdown |publisher=Southern Conference |date=2008-10-31 |accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> On November 15, the Mountaineers clinched the [[List of Southern Conference football champions|Southern Conference championship]], joining [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]] (1953–56), [[Furman Paladins|Furman]] (1980–83) and [[Georgia Southern Eagles football|Georgia Southern]] (1997–2002) as the only programs to win four straight titles, with a 24–16 victory over the [[Elon Phoenix football|Elon Phoenix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soconsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=21895&SPID=1781&DB_OEM_ID=4000&ATCLID=1625955 |title=Appalachian State Clinches Fourth Straight SoCon Title |publisher=Southern Conference |date=2008-11-15 |accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> In his 36th career start, he became the 26th FCS player in history to surpass 10,000 yards of career total offense in Appalachian's win over [[South Carolina State University|South Carolina State]] in the First Round of the 2008 [[2008 NCAA Division I FCS football season#NCAA FCS Playoff bracket|playoffs]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Edwards' Record Day Propels Appalachian Into NCAA Quarterfinals |author=Appalachian Sports Information |publisher=GoASU |date=2008-11-29 |accessdate=2008-11-29 |url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=3624987| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081204032351/http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=3624987| archivedate= 4 December 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He was named the 2008 Southern Conference Offensive Player of the Year,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104458&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=3623077|title=Mountaineers Sweep SoCon's Major Awards, Place 14 on All-Conference Teams|author=Appalachian Sports Information|publisher=GoASU|date=2007-11-25 |accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref> and was the winner of the 2008 [[Walter Payton Award]], given to the top FCS offensive player.<ref name="AEPayton1">{{cite news|url=http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=cfoot2/news/news.aspx?id=4198285 |title=Armanti Edwards wins 2008 Walter Payton Award |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2007-12-18 |accessdate=2008-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525225529/http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=cfoot2%2Fnews%2Fnews.aspx%3Fid%3D4198285 |archivedate=2011-05-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wataugademocrat.com/2008/1215/1219armanitwinspayton.php|archive-url=https://archive.is/20081223142154/http://www.wataugademocrat.com/2008/1215/1219armanitwinspayton.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-12-23|title=Armanti Edwards wins Walter Payton Award|publisher=The Watauga Democrat|author=Steve Behr|date=2007-12-19|accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref> Edwards threw a career-worst 5 interceptions in a quarterfinal loss to eventual tournament winner, Richmond, denying Appalachian State their 4th consecutive FCS championship.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/2008-12-06-playoff-roundup_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Playoff roundup: Richmond dethrones Appalachian State | date=2008-12-07}}</ref>===2009 season===Before the start of the [[2009 Appalachian State Mountaineers football team|season]], Edwards was involved in a [[Lawn mower|lawn mowing]] accident, resulting in a trip to the hospital where he was treated and released.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2009/aug/07/injury-to-right-foot-sidelines-edwards/ |title=Injury to right foot sidelines Edwards |publisher=Winston-Salem Journal |author=Tommy Bowman |date=2009-08-07 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The injury sidelined him for the season opener against the [[East Carolina Pirates football|East Carolina Pirates]], a game which the Mountaineers would lose 29–24. With a 27–10 victory over Elon on November 14, Edwards became the only quarterback in conference history to win four consecutive championships.<ref name="5Titles"/> Edwards's college football career ended on December 12 in a [[2009 NCAA Division I FCS football season#Postseason|playoff semifinal]] game against the [[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana Grizzlies]]. The 24–17 loss was the highest rated FCS postseason game ever broadcast according to [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen]] and the NCAA.<ref>{{cite news |title=ASU-Montana the Highest-Rated FCS Broadcast Ever |author=Appalachian Sports Information |publisher=GoASU |date=2009-12-15 |accessdate=2010-04-24 |url=http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104458&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=204858434}}</ref> The following day, Edwards graduated after just three and a half years with a degree in [[Graphic design|graphic arts]]. On December 17, in a landslide victory, Edwards received the [[Walter Payton Award]] making him the first ever two-time recipient of the award.<ref name="AEPayton2"/>===Statistics==={| border=0 cellspacing=2 cellpadding=4 style="text-align:center;"|- style="background-color: #E0E0E0;"! rowspan=2 | Season !! colspan=9 align=center| Passing !! !! colspan=5 align=center| Rushing|- style="background-color: #E0E0E0;"! 139*ASU and Southern – 250-Yard Total Offense Games: 35*ASU and Southern – 300-Yard Total Offense Games: 24*ASU – 400-Yard Total Offense Games: 8*ASU – Wins By a Starting Quarterback: 42==Professional career=====Carolina Panthers===Edwards was selected in the third round, pick #89, of the 2010 draft by the [[Carolina Panthers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.catscratchreader.com/2017/9/19/16324762/interview-with-former-appalachian-state-qb-carolina-panthers-wr-wide-receiver-armanti-edwards|title=CSR exclusive interview with former Panthers receiver Armanti Edwards|date=September 19, 2017|agency=''Cat Scratch Reader''|author=Sommers, Erik|accessdate=September 22, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6tf4SYyvs|archivedate=September 22, 2017}}</ref> Edwards could see the field at a variety of positions including [[wide receiver]], [[kickoff returner]], and quarterback in the [[wildcat formation]]. He was first activated in the 2010 season for the October 10 game against the [[Chicago Bears]]. After a 34-3 loss against New Orleans and the loss of [[Matt Moore (American football)|Matt Moore]] to the injured reserve list, Coach [[John Fox (American football)|John Fox]] hinted that Edwards would see more snaps at quarterback in practice. Edwards was named the emergency/third quarterback for the first time before the November 14 game at [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay]], but did not see any game action. On December 12, Edwards featured at quarterback for one snap against the [[Atlanta Falcons]] completing a pass to fellow rookie [[David Gettis]] for no gain.The Panthers released Edwards on October 8, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000259331/article/armanti-edwards-to-be-released-by-carolina-panthers|title=Armanti Edwards to be released by Carolina Panthers|work=NFL.com|first=Chris|last=Wesseling|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=2014-08-17}}</ref>===Cleveland Browns===The [[Cleveland Browns]] signed Edwards on October 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawgsbynature.com/2013/10/31/5050154/browns-sign-wr-armanti-edwards-may-get-chance-to-spark-teammates|title=Browns Sign WR Armanti Edwards; Big Plays to Come?|publisher=}}</ref> He was placed on the team's [[injured reserve]] on November 20.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawgsbynature.com/2013/11/20/5125664/browns-sign-wr-josh-cooper-place-wr-armanti-edwards-on-ir|title=Browns Sign WR Josh Cooper; Armanti Edwards to IR|publisher=}}</ref> On December 23, Edwards was released by the team with an injury settlement.<ref>{{cite web|work=HCPress.com|url=http://www.hcpress.com/sports/browns-waive-armanti-edwards-off-ir.html|title=Cleveland Browns Waive Armanti Edwards|first=Jesse|last=Wood|date=December 23, 2013|accessdate=2014-08-17}}</ref>===Chicago Bears===Edwards signed with the [[Chicago Bears]] on June 3, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|work=NBCSports.com|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/06/03/bears-sign-armanti-edwards-micheal-spurlock/|title=Bears sign Armanti Edwards, Micheal Spurlock|first=Josh|last=Alper|date=June 3, 2014|accessdate=2014-08-17}}</ref> He was released by the team during final cuts on August 29, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gantt|first1=Darin|title=Bears part ways with receiver Armanti Edwards|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/08/29/bears-part-ways-with-receiver-armanti-edwards/|publisher=Pro Football Talk|accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref>===Saskatchewan Roughriders===On February 24, 2016, it was announced that Edwards had signed with the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]] of the [[Canadian Football League]].<ref>[http://www.riderville.com/2016/02/24/riders-add-four-to-roster-3/ Riders add four to roster] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160707003654/http://www.riderville.com/2016/02/24/riders-add-four-to-roster-3/ |date=July 7, 2016 }}</ref>===Toronto Argonauts===On May 27, 2017, Edwards was traded from the Roughriders to the [[Toronto Argonauts]] in exchange for offensive lineman, [[Peter Dyakowski]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argonauts.ca/2017/05/27/argos-acquire-wr-edwards-trade-riders/|title=Argos acquire WR Edwards in trade with Riders - Toronto Argonauts|date=27 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Edwards had a breakout season in [[2017 CFL season|2017]] for the Argos, playing in all but one regular season game, catching 83 passes for 962 yards with four touchdowns. In the playoffs he caught seven passes for 56 yards en-route to winning the [[105th Grey Cup]]. In January 2018 Edwards and the Argos agreed to a new two-year contract.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tsn.ca/argos-re-sign-wr-edwards-to-2-year-deal-1.968458|title=Argos re-sign WR Edwards to 2-year deal - Article - TSN|date=2018-01-15|work=TSN|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref>===Career statistics=======NFL statistics===={| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"|-! rowspan="2"|Year !! rowspan="2"|Team !! rowspan="2"|GP !! rowspan="2"|GS !! colspan="9" |Passing !! colspan="5" |Receiving !! colspan="5" |Rushing !! colspan="5" |Kickoff returns !! colspan="5" |Punt returns|-! CFL.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref>==References=={{reflist|30em}}==External links=={{commonscat}}*{{Twitter}}*[http://www.chicagobears.com/team/roster/armanti-edwards/af12faad-09bd-4e1c-b1a3-f99496e2db26/ Armanti Edwards at Chicago Bears]*[http://www.panthers.com/team/roster/Armanti-Edwards/5caab71b-b7d2-4f4f-bc7e-465ed6b3ab12 Armanti Edwards at Carolina Panthers]*[http://www.goasu.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=104461&SPID=12811&DB_OEM_ID=21500&ATCLID=1546162&Q_SEASON=2009 Armanti Edwards bio at GoASU]*[http://www.goasu.com//pdf8/689186.pdf Career Recap at GoASU (PDF)]{{Toronto Argonauts roster navbox}}{{Appalachian State Mountaineers quarterback navbox |state=collapsed}}{{2006 Appalachian State Mountaineers football navbox}}{{2007 Appalachian State Mountaineers football navbox}}{{Walter Payton Award}}{{Panthers2010DraftPicks}}{{105th Grey Cup}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Edwards, Armanti}}[[Category:1988 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:American football quarterbacks]][[Category:American football wide receivers]][[Category:American players of Canadian football]][[Category:Appalachian State Mountaineers football players]][[Category:Canadian football wide receivers]][[Category:Carolina Panthers players]][[Category:Cleveland Browns players]][[Category:Chicago Bears players]][[Category:Walter Payton Award winners]][[Category:People from Greenwood County, South Carolina]][[Category:Sportspeople from Charlotte, North Carolina]][[Category:Players of American football from South Carolina]][[Category:Saskatchewan Roughriders players]][[Category:Grey Cup champions]])
(1	Bill Greenwood (baseball)	{{Infobox baseball biography|name=Bill Greenwood|position=[[Second baseman]]|image=Bill Greenwood (1888 baseball card).jpg|bats=Both|throws=Left|birth_date= April 19, 1857|birth_place=[[Philadelphia]]|death_date= {{death date and age|1902|5|2|1857|4|19}}|death_place=[[Philadelphia]]|debutleague = MLB|debutdate= September 16|debutyear= 1882|debutteam= [[Philadelphia Athletics (American Association)|Philadelphia Athletics]]|finalleague = MLB|finaldate= October 15|finalyear= 1890|finalteam= [[Rochester Broncos]]|statleague = MLB|stat1label=[[Batting average]]|stat1value=.226|stat2label=[[Home run]]s|stat2value=8|stat3label=[[Runs batted in]]|stat3value=185|teams=* [[Philadelphia Athletics (American Association)|Philadelphia Athletics]] ({{mlby|1882}})* [[Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn Atlantics]] ({{mlby|1884}})* [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] ({{mlby|1887}}&ndash;{{mlby|1888}})* [[Columbus Solons]] ({{mlby|1889}})* [[Rochester Broncos]] ({{mlby|1890}})|highlights=*Played 538 games in the infield, most in history by a left-handed player}}'''William F. Greenwood''' (April 19, 1857 &ndash; May 2, 1902) was an American [[Major League Baseball]] player (mostly a second baseman) for six seasons from {{baseball year|1882}} to {{baseball year|1890}}.<ref name="reference">{{cite web| title = Bill Greenwood's career statistics | work = baseball-reference.com | url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/g/greenbi01.shtml | accessdate = 2007-12-03 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071212045903/http://www.baseball-reference.com/g/greenbi01.shtml| archivedate= 12 December 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> He played more games at second base than any other left-handed player.==Career==Greenwood was fast and was often among the league leaders in stolen bases, but he usually hit for a mediocre batting average. He was a left-handed infielder, not entirely uncommon in the 19th century, and he is the all-time leader in games played at second base by a left-hander with 538.<ref name="recondite">{{cite web| title = Labor Day Lefties | work = reconditebaseball.blogspot.com | url=http://reconditebaseball.blogspot.com/2007/09/labor-day-lefties.html | accessdate = 2007-12-03 }}</ref> He also played 30 games at [[shortstop]].<ref name="reference"/>For the {{baseball year|1883}} season, he signed and was playing for the Merrits of [[Camden, New Jersey]], when [[Charlie Byrne (baseball)|Charlie Byrne]] of a fellow league team, the [[Brooklyn Grays]], bought his contract, along with other Merrits [[Sam Kimber]], [[Charlie Householder]], [[Frank Fennelly]], and [[Jack Corcoran]].  He finished out the year and transitioned with the team over to the [[American Association (19th century)|American Association]], where they would be known as the Atlantics.<ref name="longbefore">{{Cite book| title = Long Before the Dodgers: Baseball in Brooklyn, 1855–1884 By James L. Terry, pg. 128 | work = books.google.com | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H4qOXgcdTaUC&pg=PA128&lpg=PA128&dq=%22charlie+householder%22+baseball&source=web&ots=Lgjo8j0wnY&sig=T_sS05RUXi-dbapiSJctK4W13C0 | accessdate = 2007-12-03 }}</ref>Playing in the AA until 1890, Greenwood changed teams every year, except for 1887-88, when he played two seasons for the [[Baltimore Orioles (1882–99)|Baltimore Orioles]]. His 1887 season with Baltimore was one of his best; he hit .263, recorded 65 RBI, and stole 71 bases. During an 1887 home game, Greenwood was on the receiving end of a collision at second base from [[St. Louis Browns]] outfielder [[Curt Welch]]. The collision angered Baltimore fans, and St. Louis players had to run off the field to avoid the irate fans.<ref name=Nemec/>The next year, his batting average fell to .191 and he did not hit above .225 again in the major leagues.<ref name="reference"/>Greenwood thought that his biggest struggle as a left-handed middle infielder was fielding ground balls, but he also had a problem that would be expected of a left-hander: making quick, accurate throws to first base. Compounding his problems was the fact that he liked to drink to excess, so he sometimes got on the bad side of a manager with his behavior.<ref name=Nemec/>==Post-career==Greenwood died in his hometown of [[Philadelphia]] at the age of 45. He had a heart attack while discussing the Athletics game that had been played that day.<ref name="Nemec">{{cite book|last1=Nemec|first1=David|title=Major League Baseball Profiles, 1871-1900, Volume 1: The Ballplayers Who Built the Game|date=2011|publisher=[[University of Nebraska Press]]|isbn=9780803230248|page=360|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3BUqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA360|language=en}}</ref> He is interred at the [[Mount Moriah Cemetery (Philadelphia)|Mount Moriah Cemetery]] in Philadelphia.<ref name="retrosheet">{{cite web| title = Bill Greenwood's career information | work = retrosheet.org | url=http://retrosheet.org/boxesetc/G/Pgreeb102.htm | accessdate = 2007-12-03 }}</ref>==See also=={{Portal|Biography}}* [[List of Major League Baseball career stolen bases leaders]]==References=={{reflist|30em}}==External links==*{{Find a Grave|13264527}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Greenwood, Bill}}[[Category:1857 births]][[Category:1902 deaths]][[Category:Major League Baseball second basemen]][[Category:19th-century baseball players]][[Category:Baseball players from Pennsylvania]][[Category:Philadelphia Athletics (AA) players]][[Category:Brooklyn Atlantics (AA) players]][[Category:Baltimore Orioles (AA) players]][[Category:Columbus Solons players]][[Category:Rochester Broncos players]][[Category:Sportspeople from Philadelphia]][[Category:Brooklyn Grays (Interstate Association) players]][[Category:Camden Merritts players]][[Category:Newark Domestics players]][[Category:Richmond Virginians (minor league) players]][[Category:Newark Little Giants players]][[Category:Lebanon Cedars players]][[Category:Jamestown (minor league baseball) players]])
(1	Solomon Page	{{Infobox NFL player|image      =|position   = [[Guard (American football)|Guard]] / [[Offensive tackle|Tackle]]|number     = 77, 79|birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|2|27}}|birth_place=[[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]|death_date =|height_ft  = 6|height_in  = 4|weight_lbs = 325|draftyear  = 1999|draftround = 2|draftpick  = 55|high_school= [[Brashear High School|Brashear (PA)]]|college    = [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]]|teams      =* [[Dallas Cowboys]] ({{NFL Year|1999}}–{{NFL Year|2002}})* [[San Diego Chargers]] ({{NFL Year|2003}})* [[Detroit Lions]] ({{NFL Year|2004}})** [[New York Giants]] ({{NFL Year|2004}})*|pastteamsnote = yes|statlabel1  = Games played|statvalue1  = 67|statlabel2  = Games started|statvalue2  = 58|statlabel3  =|statvalue3  =|highlights  =* 2× [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|All-Big East]] (1997, 1998)|nfl         = PAG357732|pfr         = PageSo20}}'''Solomon Page''' (born February 27, 1976) is a former [[American football]] [[offensive line]]man in the [[National Football League]] for the [[Dallas Cowboys]] and [[San Diego Chargers]]. He was drafted by the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in the second round of the [[1999 NFL Draft]]. He played [[college football]] at [[West Virginia University]].==Early years==Page was born in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] where he played football at [[Brashear High School]] and was an All-city selection at [[defensive tackle]]. After graduating from high school, he spent a year at [[Hargrave Military Academy]] improving his grades.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19961230&id=1-QxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mW8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3467,8893082&hl=en | title=West Vigirginia's Logan a grabber | accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref>==College career==He accepted a football scholarship from [[West Virginia University]]. After being [[Red-shirt (college sports)|red-shirted]] for his first season, he became a three-year start at [[left tackle]]. As a redshirt freshman, he graded out at 84% consistency, becoming just the 11th freshman since 1980 to earn a spot in the Mountaineer Club for players who grade at least 80 percent. As a sophomore, he earned [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|All-Big East]] honors for an offense that amassed 4,602 yards. As a junior, he was an [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|All-Big East]] selection while grading out at 89% consistency for an offense that generated 5,546 total yards.During his career at West Virginia, Page helped to anchor an [[offensive line]] that helped the offense produced at least 300 yards in each of his final 21 career games. He contributed to [[All-American]] [[Running back (American football)|running back]] [[Amos Zereoué]] becoming the school and Big East's all-time leading rusher (4,054) yards, [[quarterback]] [[Marc Bulger]] becoming the school's career passing yards leader (5,995) and [[wide receiver]] [[David Saunders (American football)|David Saunders]] becoming the school's career leader in receiving yards. Page was an athletic coaching education major. He declared as a junior for the [[NFL Draft]].==Professional career=====Dallas Cowboys===Page was selected by the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in the [[1999 NFL Draft#Round two|second-round (55th overall)]] of the [[1999 NFL Draft]]. During training camp he was moved to [[offensive guard]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19990801&id=jZtHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YH8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=1625,7445798&hl=en | title=Rookie doesn't mind adjustment| accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref>He made his [[NFL]] debut against the [[Arizona Cardinals]] on October 3, which was also his first professional start, as a right tackle replacement for injured starter [[Erik Williams]]. Beginning on November 21, Page started five consecutive games at left guard replacing injured starter [[Larry Allen]]. As a [[rookie]], he contributed to the Cowboys offensive line allowing just 24 sacks, the second fewest in the [[NFL]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?yr=1999&lg=nfl |title=1999 NFL Standings, Stats and Awards |work=databasefootball.com |accessdate=February 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108055407/http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?lg=NFL&yr=1999 |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref> while allowing one or fewer sacks in nine-of-16 games. In addition, the offensive line helped running back [[Emmitt Smith]] to his highest single-season rushing total (1,397) since [[1995 Dallas Cowboys season|1995]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=SMITHEMM01 |title=Emmitt Smith |work=databasefootball.com |accessdate=February 27, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108121754/http://www.databasefootball.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=SMITHEMM01 |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref>In [[2000 Dallas Cowboys season|2000]], Page began the season as the starting right guard and was part of an offensive line that surrendered 35 sacks, with only 12 teams allowing fewer on the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?yr=2000&lg=nfl |title=2000 NFL Standings, Stats and Awards |work=databasefootball.com |accessdate=February 27, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105004836/http://databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?yr=2000&lg=nfl |archivedate=January 5, 2010 |df= }}</ref> In the opener against Philadelphia, he started the game at right guard but was shifted to [[right tackle]] after start Williams was ejected. Later in the season on December 10, against the [[Washington Redskins]] Page started at guard but moved to [[right tackle]] again when Williams suffered a [[neck]] injury early in the second half.In [[2001 Dallas Cowboys season|2001]], he was moved to [[right tackle]] to replace Williams who had left via [free agency]] to play for the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. He was part of an offensive line that helped the Cowboys finish third in the league in rushing with 136.5 yards-per-game. The offensive line also helped Emmitt Smith rush for a league record 11th consecutive 1,000-yard season, while he also moved into second place on the NFL's all-time career rushing list with 16,187 career yards. The offensive line also allowed just 34 sacks in 447 pass plays on the season.<ref name="2001 season">{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?yr=2001&lg=nfl |title=2001 NFL Standings, Stats and Awards |work=databasefootball.com |accessdate=February 27, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108034323/http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?lg=NFL&yr=2001 |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref> Just 12 teams allowed fewer sacks for the year and only eight teams lost fewer yards due to sacks than the 190 lost by the Cowboys.<ref name="2001 season" />It is believed [[2002 NFL season|2002]] was the first time a [[NFL]] franchise had five African American starters on their [[offensive line]], when the Cowboys lined up rookie [[Center (American and Canadian football)|center]] [[Andre Gurode]], [[Tackle (American and Canadian football)|tackle]]s [[Flozell Adams]] and Page, [[Guard (American and Canadian football)|guard]]s [[Larry Allen]] and [[Kelvin Garmon]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://a.espncdn.com/nfl/columns/pasquarelli_len/1417470.html | title=Color barrier on offensive line disappearing | accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref> That season, he started in 15 games (10 at right tackle and 5 at right guard). He also became part of history as the starting [[Guard (American and Canadian football)|guard]] on the Cowboys [[offensive line]] that helped [[Emmitt Smith]] eclipse [[Walter Payton]] as the [[NFL]]'s all-time leading rusher, playing against the [[Seattle Seahawks]] on October 27.===San Diego Chargers===On June 5, [[2003 NFL season|2003]], he was signed by the [[San Diego Chargers]] as a [[free agent]], reuniting with [[Hudson Houck]] who was his [[offensive line]] coach with the Cowboys.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2245&dat=20030606&id=CdkzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HiEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4216,4205086&hl=en | title=Chargers sign Page | accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref> In his one season with the Chargers, he played in eight games (missed eight with a sprained left ankle injury), with seven starts at right guard, helping the team rush for 2,146 and pass for 3,226, sixth and 22nd in the league respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?yr=2003&lg=nfl |title=2003 NFL Standings, Stats and Awards |work=databasefootball.com |accessdate=February 27, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108052113/http://www.databasefootball.com/leagues/leagueyear.htm?lg=NFL&yr=2003 |archivedate=January 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref>===Detroit Lions===On July 27, [[2004 NFL season|2004]], he was signed as a [[free agent]] by the [[Detroit Lions]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1988&dat=20040728&id=mwgoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CAUGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3097,2333537&hl=en | title=Lions sign Butler, Page | accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref> He was waived on August 23.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/24/sports/transactions-733113.html |title=Transactions | work=New York Times |date=August 24, 2004 |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref>===New York Giants===On August 25, [[2004 NFL season|2004]], he signed with the [[New York Giants]] as a [[free agent]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/26/sports/transactions-757560.html |title=Transactions | work=New York Times |date=August 26, 2004 |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> He was released on September 5.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=980DE7D91E31F935A3575AC0A9629C8B63 |title=Transactions |work=New York Times |date=September 6, 2004 |accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref>==Personal life==Page is currently an [[offensive line]] coach at Carrollton Christian Academy in [[Carrollton, Texas]].==References=={{Reflist|30em}}{{Cowboys1999DraftPicks}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Page, Solomon}}[[Category:1976 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Sportspeople from Pittsburgh]][[Category:Players of American football from Pennsylvania]][[Category:American football offensive guards]][[Category:American football offensive tackles]][[Category:West Virginia Mountaineers football players]][[Category:Dallas Cowboys players]][[Category:San Diego Chargers players]][[Category:High school football coaches in the United States]])
(1	2008 Houston Cougars football team	{{Infobox NCAA team season|Year=2008|Team=Houston Cougars|Image=Houston Cougars Logo (1999-2012).svg|ImageSize=150|Conference=Conference USA|Division=West|ShortConference=C-USA|CoachRank=|APRank=|Record=8–5|ConfRecord=6–2|HeadCoach=[[Kevin Sumlin]]|OffCoach=[[Dana Holgorsen]]|OScheme=[[Spread offense|Spread]]|DefCoach=[[John Skladany]]|DScheme=[[4–3 defense|4–3]]|StadiumArena=[[Robertson Stadium]]<br>(Capacity: 32,000)|Champion =Armed Forces Bowl champion|BowlTourney=[[2008 Armed Forces Bowl|Armed Forces Bowl]]|BowlTourneyResult=  W 34–28 vs. [[2008 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force]]}}{{2008 Conference USA football standings}}The '''2008 Houston Cougars football team''', also known as the '''Houston Cougars''', '''Houston''', or '''UH''', represented the [[University of Houston]] in the [[2008 NCAA Division I FBS football season]].  It was the 63rd year of season play for Houston.  The team was coached by first-year head football coach, [[Kevin Sumlin]] whose previous position was as co-offensive coordinator for the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]].  He replaced [[Art Briles]].  The team played its home games at [[Robertson Stadium]], a 32,000-person capacity stadium on-campus in [[Houston]].  Competing against the [[Air Force Falcons]] in the [[2008 Armed Forces Bowl]], the Cougars won their first bowl game since 1980, and broke the longest current bowl game losing streak in Division I FBS football at that time.  In addition, Houston defeated two nationally ranked opponents, which the Cougars hadn't achieved since their 1984 season.==Previous season==In the 2007 season, the Cougars earned an 8-5 (.615) overall season record and a 6-2 (.750) conference record in C-USA.<ref name="2007 schedule">{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/hou-m-footbl-sched-2007.html |title=2007 Archive: 2007-2008 Schedule |publisher=University of Houston athletics |accessdate=March 23, 2008}}</ref>  The 2007 season would be the last for head coach [[Art Briles]] with the Cougars.  Two days after Houston was invited to the [[2007 Texas Bowl]], Briles immediately departed for the [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor Bears]] head coach position in [[Waco, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/112507aaa.html|title=Outstanding Season Nets Cougars A Texas Bowl Appearance|publisher=University of Houston athletics|date=November 25, 2007|accessdate=March 23, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://baylorbears.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/112807aam.html|title=Art Briles Named Baylor's 25th Head Football Coach |publisher=Baylor University athletics |date=November 28, 2007|accessdate=March 23, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080506104058/http://baylorbears.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/112807aam.html| archivedate= May 6, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  Cornerbacks coach, [[Chris Thurmond]] was soon appointed interim head coach, and led the Cougars to the Texas Bowl against the [[TCU Horned Frogs football|TCU Horned Frogs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.click2houston.com/cfoot509/14720440/detail.html|work=[[KPRC-TV|Houston NBC KPRC 2]]|title=Houston Names Thurmond Interim Football Coach|accessdate=March 23, 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080309181400/http://www.click2houston.com/cfoot509/14720440/detail.html| archivedate= March 9, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= yes}}</ref> The Cougars lost to the Horned Frogs 20-13.<ref name="2007 schedule" />In December 2007, the University of Houston hired [[Kevin Sumlin]], a co-offensive coordinator for the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] as the Houston Cougars head coach.<ref name="Sumlin hire">{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3153106 |author=Schad, Joe |title=Houston hires Sumlin, eighth minority coach in FBS |publisher=ESPN.com |date=December 13, 2007|accessdate=March 23, 2008}}</ref>==Preseason=====Recruiting===Twenty players were recruited for the 2008 season.  Several higher-ranking recruits were lost when Art Briles left, as they followed the coach to [[Baylor University|Baylor]].  Due to Houston's head coach change, Sumlin's ability to recruit before [[National Signing Day]] was shorter than usual, as he was finishing his duties with the Oklahoma Sooners.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/sports/5517013.html |author=Campbell, Steve |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=February 6, 2008|title=UH head coach Sumlin has way of seizing on chances |accessdate=April 8, 2008}}</ref>  In early April, it was announced that the Cougars had two other junior college commitments.  Kyle Thomas and Nick Thurston, both from [[California]], came from the [[City College of San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=32&url_article_id=1836&change_well_id=2 |title=Verbal Pledges '09: New Braunfels LB Tom Wort off to OU |publisher=Dave Campbell's Texas Football'' |work=texasfootball.com |date=April 18, 2008|accessdate=April 19, 2008}}</ref>  Two other junior college (JUCO) commitments, Clint Leal and Kierrie Johnson, were recruited from [[Blinn College]].  Thomas is expected to join the roster in the Spring, as he still had some coursework to finish in California.{{College athlete recruit start|40=yes|collapse=yes|year=2008}}{{College Athlete Recruit Austin HS| feet   = 5| inches = 10| weight = 194| 40 = N/A| commitdate = 2008-01-20| scout stars  = 2| rivals stars = 2| espn grade =}}{{College Athlete Recruit End| 40               = yes| year             = 2008| rivals ref title = Houston Commit List for 2008| scout ref title  = Houston: Commits| espn ref title   =| rivals school    =| scout s          =| espn schoolid    =| scout overall    = 77| rivals overall   = 100| accessdate       = March 22, 2008| bball            =| collapse         = yes}}===Coaching staff and changes===[[File:Kevin Sumlin Close-up.jpg|thumb|[[Kevin Sumlin]], Cougars head coach]]During the off-season, the Cougars went through a large amount of notable coaching staff changes.  Former co-offensive coordinator for the [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]], [[Kevin Sumlin]] replaced [[Art Briles]] as head coach.  Sumlin became the first [[African-American]] head coach in Cougar history, and the eighth in the NCAA's [[Football Bowl Subdivision]].<ref name="Sumlin hire" />  In his [[2007 Oklahoma Sooners football team|final year]] with the Sooners, his [[Offense (sports)|offense]] was one of the best in the country, averaging 44 points per game.<ref name="ESPN121707">Schlabach, Mark [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=schlabach_mark&id=3158996 Yellow Jackets, Wolverines, Midshipmen earn high marks], ESPN.com, December 17, 2007.</ref>[[Dana Holgorsen]] came to Houston from the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech Red Raiders]], where he spent eight years as offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/holgorsen_dana00.html |title=Player Bio: Dana Holgorsen|publisher=University of Houston athletics|accessdate=March 24, 2008}}</ref>  He serves the Cougars in the same capacity.[[John Skladany]] replaced [[Alan Weddell]] as defensive coordinator.  Skladany came from the [[UCF Knights football|UCF Knights]], a fellow C-USA team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/skladany_john00.html |title=Player Bio: John Skladany |publisher=University of Houston athletics|accessdate=March 24, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304150740/http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/skladany_john00.html|archivedate=March 4, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  Prior to coaching for UCF, Skladany spent ten years with the [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State Cyclones]].  Sumlin and Skladany followed through with plans to change the Cougars defensive strategy from a [[3–4 defense|3-4]] defense to a [[4–3 defense|4-3]] one.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kubat, Tom |url=http://www.jconline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080218/SPORTS020101/802180338/1046/SPORTS020101|title=Now and Then: Kevin Sumlin|date=February 18, 2008|accessdate=April 8, 2008|newspaper=[[Journal & Courier]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>[[Leon Burtnett]] came from the [[Washington State Cougars football|Washington State Cougars]] as linebackers coach.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/burtnett_leon00.html |title=Player Bio: Leon Burtnett |publisher=University of Houston athletics |accessdate=March 24, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080304150723/http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/burtnett_leon00.html| archivedate= March 4, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  New defensive line coach, [[Jim Jeffcoat]] spent his last four seasons as defensive ends coach for the NFL's [[Dallas Cowboys]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/jeffcoat_jim00.html |title=Player Bio: Jim Jeffcoat |publisher=University of Houston athletics |accessdate=March 24, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080312072719/http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/jeffcoat_jim00.html| archivedate= March 12, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  Another new addition to the staff with NFL coaching experience was special teams coordinator and tight ends coach [[Tony Levine]], who spent his previous two seasons with the [[Carolina Panthers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.collegesports.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/levine_tony00.html |title=Player Bio: Tony Levine |publisher=University of Houston athletics |accessdate=March 24, 2008}}</ref>====Staff===={| class="wikitable"|-! Name !! Position || Alma mater (Year)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Kevin Sumlin]] || Head coach || [[Purdue University|Purdue]] (1986)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Dana Holgorsen]] || [[Offensive coordinator]] || [[Iowa Wesleyan College|Iowa Wesleyan]] (1992)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[John Skladany]] || [[Defensive coordinator]] || [[Central Connecticut State University|Central Connecticut State]] (1972)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Jason Phillips (wide receiver)|Jason Phillips]] || Co-Offensive coordinator || [[University of Houston|Houston]] (1988)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Leon Burtnett]] || [[Linebacker]]s || [[Southwestern College (Kansas)|Southwestern College]] (1965)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Jim Jeffcoat]] || [[Defensive line]] || [[Arizona State University|Arizona State]] (1982)|- style="text-align:center;"| Joe Gilbert || [[Offensive line]] || [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton]] (1987)|- style="text-align:center;"| [[Tony Levine]] || [[Special teams]] || [[University of Minnesota|Minnesota]] (1996)|- style="text-align:center;"| Clarence McKinney || [[Running backs]] || [[University of Mary|Mary]] (1994)|- style="text-align:center;"| Charles McMillian || Defensive backs || [[Utah State University|Utah State]] (1995)|- style="text-align:center;"| Zac Spavital || [[Cornerbacks]]  || [[Murray State University|Murray State]] (2004)|}===Spring practices===From March 8 to April 12, 2008, the Cougars held Spring practices.  In addition to the fourteen practices held throughout this period, the Cougars held two [[Exhibition game|scrimmages]], and concluded with the annual "Red-White Game".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/08-spring-football-dates.html |title=2008 Spring Football Dates |publisher=University of Houston athletics |accessdate=April 13, 2008}}</ref>  The Red-White Game, a home exhibition game between the offensive and defensive players of the Cougars, was a part of festivities held for the University of Houston's "Cougar Fest".  A skydive by the [[United States Army Parachute Team|U.S. Army Golden Knights]] to present the game ball was planned, but was cancelled due to high winds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uh.edu/uhtoday/2008/04april/040808cougarfest.html |title=Cougar Fest 2008 Offers Fun-Filled Day of Football, Interactive Activities |publisher=UH Office of Internal Communications|work=UH Today News|date=April 8, 2008|accessdate=April 13, 2008}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>==Schedule=={{CFB Schedule Start|rank=no|ranklink=no|rankyear=no|tv=yes|time=|attend=yes}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| w/l          = w| date         = August 30| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| time         = 6:00 PM| rank         = no| away         =| neutral      =| opprank      =| opponent     = {{cfb link|year=2008|team=Southern Jaguars|school=Southern University|title=Southern}}| site_stadium = [[Robertson Stadium]]| site_cityst  = [[Houston|Houston, TX]]| gamename     =| tv           =| score        = 55-3| overtime     =| attend       = 26,555}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| w/l          = l| date         = September 6| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| time         = 6:05 PM| rank         = no| away         = yes| neutral      =| opprank      =| opponent     = [[2008 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team|Oklahoma State]]| site_stadium = [[Boone Pickens Stadium]]| site_cityst  = [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater, OK]]| gamename     =| tv           =| score        = 37-56| overtime     =| attend       = 45,001}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| w/l          = l| date         = September 13| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| time         = 2:30 PM| rank         = no| away         =| neutral      = yes| opprank      =| opponent     = [[2008 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force]]| site_stadium = [[Gerald J.
