G. Carter Stadium]]| site_cityst  = [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth, TX]]| gamename     = [[2008 Armed Forces Bowl|Armed Forces Bowl]]| tv           = [[ESPN]]| score        = 34-28| overtime     =| attend       = 41,127}}{{CFB Schedule End|rank=|poll=[[AP Poll]]|timezone=[[Central Time Zone (North America)|Central Time]]|hc=|ncg=}}==Games notes=====Southern===[[File:2008 Houston Cougars vs Southern Jaguars at Robertson Stadium.jpg|thumb|2008 opening season game against the [[Southern Jaguars]] at Robertson Stadium]]{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Southern|R1=0|R2=3|R3=0|R4=0|Home='''Houston'''|H1=7|H2=31|H3=10|H4=7}}The 2008 game marked the first meeting between the Houston Cougars and the [[Southern Jaguars]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://media.www.southerndigest.com/media/storage/paper950/news/2008/04/22/Schedules/Su.Releases.Football.Schedule-3341901.shtml |author=Young, Larry |title=SU releases football schedule |date=April 22, 2008 |accessdate=May 3, 2008 |work=The Southern Digest| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080502004504/http://media.www.southerndigest.com/media/storage/paper950/news/2008/04/22/Schedules/Su.Releases.Football.Schedule-3341901.shtml| archivedate= May 2, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>  The team plays in the [[Southwestern Athletic Conference]] (SWAC) as a member of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Football Championship Subdivision]].  The [[Grambling Tigers]], the Jaguars' main rival, fell to the Cougars as part of their 2006 season schedule 42-22.<ref name="2006 schedule">{{cite web|url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/hou-m-footbl-sched-2006.html |title=Houston Football Archive: 2006 Schedule |accessdate=May 3, 2008|publisher=Houston Cougars athletics}}</ref>  In 2007, the Cougars finished their regular season by defeating another SWAC opponent, crosstown [[Texas Southern Tigers]].<ref name="2007 schedule" />{{Clear}}===Oklahoma State==={{See also|2008 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Houston|R1=7|R2=9|R3=7|R4=14|Home='''Oklahoma State'''|H1=7|H2=7|H3=28|H4=14}}[[File:2008 UH Cougars vs Oklahoma State Cowboys.jpg|thumb|left|The Cougars and Cowboys face off at [[Boone Pickens Stadium]] on September 8, 2008]]This marked the nineteenth game between the Cougars and the [[2008 Oklahoma State Cowboys football team|Oklahoma State Cowboys]] who were a member of the [[Big 12 Conference]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=665 |title=University of Houston VS Oklahoma State University - All Time |publisher=College Football Reference |accessdate=May 3, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303210316/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=665 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  Playing against each other since 1951, the Cougars held a 9-8-1 all-time record against the Cowboys, and the last meeting between the two teams was during the 2006 season.  During that meeting, the Cowboys fell to the Cougars 34-25.<ref name="2006 schedule" />  The Cougars traveled to [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]] for the first time since 1986 to compete.  Despite leading the Cowboys during the first half of the game, the Cougars eventually lost 56-37.  The Cowboys went on to be consistently ranked this season as one of the top 25 teams in the nation.{{Clear}}===Air Force===[[File:2008 UH Cougars vs Air Force Falcons.jpg|thumb|The Cougars versus the Air Force Falcons at [[Gerald J. Ford Stadium]]]]{{Linescore Amfootball||Road='''Air Force'''|R1=3|R2=14|R3=14|R4=0|Home=Houston|H1=7|H2=0|H3=7|H4=14}}Another first meeting on the Cougars' schedule was with the [[2008 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force Falcons]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thedailycougar.com/media/storage/paper1206/news/2008/03/04/Sports/Houston.Football.Schedule.Looks.To.Be.A.Good.Trial.For.Sumlin-3249973.shtml |title=Houston football schedule looks to be a good trial for Sumlin |author=Lee, Jong |date=March 4, 2008 |accessdate=May 3, 2008 |newspaper=[[The Daily Cougar]] }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>  A member of the [[Mountain West Conference]], the Falcons played football since 1955.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost_historical/access/288937262.html?dids=288937262:288937262&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Nov+23%2C+1955&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post+and+Times+Herald++(1954-1959)&edition=&startpage=31&desc=Air+Force+Academy%27s+4-3+Football+Team+Ends+First+Season+With+Oklahoma+Frosh|title=Air Force Academy's 4-3 Football Team Ends First Season With Oklahoma Frosh|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=November 23, 1955|accessdate=May 3, 2008}} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>  The previous season, the Falcons finished with a 9-4 record, while losing to the [[2007 California Golden Bears football team|California Golden Bears]] in the [[2007 Armed Forces Bowl]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/mwest/airforce.htm|title=Air Force: Inside Slant|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=2008-05-03}}</ref>  The game was scheduled to be televised on the [[CBS Sports Network|CBS College Sports Network]] as the first of the four nationally televised games for the Cougars season, but was cancelled.  The game was originally scheduled to be played at Robertson Stadium in Houston, but due to [[Hurricane Ike]], the game was played at [[Southern Methodist University|SMU's]] [[Ford Stadium]].  The Cougars fell to the Falcons 31-28.{{Clear}}===Colorado State==={{See also|2008 Colorado State Rams football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Houston|R1=0|R2=3|R3=14|R4=8|Home='''Colorado State'''|H1=7|H2=14|H3=0|H4=7}}With a 3-0 all-time record against the [[Colorado State Rams football|Colorado State Rams]], the Cougars faced them for the fourth time on the road at [[Sonny Lubick Field at Hughes Stadium|Hughes Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=346|title=University of Houston VS Colorado State University - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference|accessdate=May 3, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303171401/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=346 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  The most recent meeting between the teams had been the season before, where the Rams lost to the Cougars 38-27 in Houston.  [[Steve Fairchild]], a former player for the Rams, and the former offensive coordinator and under previous head coach [[Sonny Lubick]], had taken over as head coach during this season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3154046|title=Fairchild, Rams seek return to college football's national scene|agency=Associated Press|publisher=ESPN|work=ESPN.com|date=December 13, 2008|accessdate=May 3, 2008}}</ref> With a third consecutive loss, the Cougars fell to the Rams 28-25.{{Clear}}===East Carolina==={{See also|2008 East Carolina Pirates football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road='''Houston'''|R1=14|R2=7|R3=3|R4=17|Home=#23 East Carolina|H1=7|H2=3|H3=7|H4=7}}This game was the ninth meeting between the Cougars and fellow [[Conference USA]] team, the [[2008 East Carolina Pirates football team|East Carolina Pirates]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1053|title=University of Houston VS East Carolina University - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference|accessdate=May 3, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303220936/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1053 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  Last season, after defeating the Cougars 37-35, the Pirates went on to finish with an 8-5 record including a win against #24 [[2007 Boise State Broncos football team|Boise State]] in the [[2007 Hawaii Bowl]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273570151 |title=ECU edges No. 24 Boise St. for first postseason win since 2000|agency=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN |work=ESPN.com |date=December 23, 2007|accessdate=May 3, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080508055128/http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273570151|archivedate=May 8, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref>  The Pirates led the series between the Cougars 8-5.  The game was broadcast on the [[CBS College Sports Network]], and was played at East Carolina's [[Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium]].  After beating the #17 [[2008 Virginia Tech Hokies football team|Virginia Tech Hokies]] during their 2008 season opener, the Pirates gained national attention.  This continued in their next week of play, as they defeated the #8 [[2008 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia Mountaineers]] 24-3, and became ranked by the AP Poll as #14.  Despite an upset by the [[2008 NC State Wolfpack football team|North Carolina State Wolfpack]] the week before, the Pirates were ranked at #23 by the AP Poll when the Cougars arrived in Greenville.  Despite predictions that ECU would win the game, the Cougars managed an upset with a large margin of victory.  This was the Cougars' first win over a ranked team since 1996, and the first against a ranked team in a road game since 1984.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/cusa/houston.htm |title=Houston: Season Recap |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=October 20, 2008}}</ref>{{Clear}}===UAB==={{See also|2008 UAB Blazers football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=UAB|R1=3|R2=17|R3=0|R4=0|Home='''Houston'''|H1=0|H2=3|H3=21|H4=21}}The third home game was the seventh meeting between the Cougars and the [[UAB Blazers football|UAB Blazers]].  With the most recent game between the two teams being last season, the Blazers led the series 4-2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1079 |title=University of Houston VS University of Alabama at Birmingham - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference |accessdate=May 4, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303185805/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1079 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> However, the team was defeated by the Cougars, and finished their 2007 season with a 2-10 record, the worst in the school's history.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/cusa/uab.htm |title=UAB: Inside Slant|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=May 4, 2008}}</ref>  This followed the departure of [[Watson Brown]] to the [[Tennessee Tech|Tennessee Tech Golden Eagles]], and the appointment of former [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia Bulldogs]] and Houston Cougars assistant [[Neil Callaway]] as head coach.  The game was televised by the [[CBS College Sports Network]].{{Clear}}===SMU==={{Linescore Amfootball||Road='''Houston'''|R1=0|R2=14|R3=9|R4=21|Home=SMU|H1=14|H2=7|H3=14|H4=3}}Former [[Southwest Conference]] and current [[Conference USA]] members, the [[SMU Mustangs football|SMU Mustangs]] faced the Cougars in their twenty-fourth meeting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=727|title=University of Houston VS Southern Methodist University - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference|accessdate=May 4, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303215436/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=727 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  The first game between the two teams took place during the 1975 season when Houston joined the Southwest Conference, and the teams have regularly played each other since.  The Cougars led the series 13-9-1, including a 38-28 win against the Mustangs last season.  This season, [[June Jones]], former [[Hawaii Warriors football|Hawaii Warriors]] head coach took the same position at SMU.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/topstories/stories/010808dnsposmulede.1b8fc462.html|title=SMU's search ends with hiring of Jones|author=Hairopoulos, Kate|date=January 8, 2008|accessdate=May 4, 2008|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110093347/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/topstories/stories/010808dnsposmulede.1b8fc462.html|archivedate=January 10, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>  At Hawaii, Jones had gained national attention after the Warriors went undefeated, and were invited to the [[2008 Sugar Bowl]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Dec/03/br/br7964813250.html |title=Warriors to play Georgia in Sugar Bowl|author=Tsai, Stephen|newspaper=[[Honolulu Advertiser]]|date=December 3, 2007|accessdate=March 3, 2008}}</ref>  After the win, the Cougars moved up in the Conference USA standings to tie for first with an undefeated [[2008 Tulsa Golden Hurricane football team|Tulsa]] in their division.{{Clear}}===Marshall==={{See also|2008 Marshall Thundering Herd football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Houston|R1=0|R2=3|R3=6|R4=14|Home='''Marshall'''|H1=3|H2=13|H3=14|H4=7}}[[File:UH at Marshall CIMG0316.JPG|left|thumb|On October 28th, the Cougars and Thundering Herd met for the first time ever at [[Joan C. Edwards Stadium]] in [[Huntington, West Virginia]]]]The [[2008 Marshall Thundering Herd football team|Marshall Thundering Herd]] played the Cougars for the second time in history during this season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=690|title=University of Houston VS Marshall University - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference|accessdate=May 4, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201541/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=690 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  Their last game against each other was played during the 2007 season, where the Thundering Herd was defeated 35-28 in Houston at [[Robertson Stadium]].  This time, Marshall played Houston at home, and won.  This marked the first loss for the Cougars in conference play, and dropped them down in conference standings from 1st to 3rd (after Tulsa and Rice). [[ESPN]] broadcast the game. Houston wide receiver [[Patrick Edwards]] suffered a gruesome broken leg when he collided with an equipment cart at the back of the end zone, though he would return [[2009 Houston Cougars football team|the next season]] in a starting role.{{Clear}}===Tulane==={{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Tulane|R1=0|R2=7|R3=0|R4=7|Home='''Houston'''|H1=7|H2=14|H3=21|H4=0}}In another conference game, the [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane Green Wave]] traveled to Houston to play the Cougars for the fourteenth time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=342|title=University of Houston VS Tulane University - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference |accessdate=2008-05-04|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222718/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=342 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  Playing their first game together in 1968, the Cougars led the series 9-4.  The teams had competed against each other each consecutive season since 2002, although Tulane hadn't achieved a win against Houston since that same year.  Tulane's head coach [[Bob Toledo]] returned for his second year with the Green Wave.  Although not originally scheduled, the game was televised on [[CBS College Sports]], presumably because Houston's TV appearance against Air Force earlier in the season was cancelled.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tulanegreenwave.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/102308aaa.html|title=Tulane Football Game at Houston to be Televised on CBS College Sports|publisher=Tulane University athletics|date=October 23, 2008|accessdate=November 23, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026092842/http://tulanegreenwave.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/102308aaa.html|archivedate=October 26, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref>  This marked Houston's homecoming game, and was one of the largest attendances for the regular season at Robertson Stadium.{{Clear}}===Tulsa==={{See also|2008 Tulsa Golden Hurricane football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=#25 Tulsa|R1=0|R2=17|R3=13|R4=0|Home='''Houston'''|H1=14|H2=28|H3=21|H4=7}}The [[Tulsa Golden Hurricane football|Tulsa Golden Hurricane]] and Houston Cougars faced-off for their thirty-third all-time meeting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=712 |title=University of Houston VS University of Tulsa - All Time |publisher=College Football Reference |accessdate=2008-05-10|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070306195102/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=712 |archivedate = March 6, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>  Playing together since 1950, Houston had a 17-16 advantage over the Golden Hurricane.  In their 2007 season meeting, new coach [[Todd Graham]] led the Golden Hurricane to a 56-7 win over the Cougars.  It was the Cougars' largest margin of defeat for the season.  Tulsa went on to a 10-4 record in the previous season including a 63-7 [[GMAC Bowl]] game win against the [[2007 Bowling Green Falcons football team|Bowling Green Falcons]].  The team held the record for scoring the largest margin in bowl game history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ncaafootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=34&url_article_id=11934&change_well_id=2|title=Tulsa Runs Away With GMAC Bowl|author=Zenor, John|publisher=Associate Press|work=ncaafootball.com|date=January 6, 2008|accessdate=May 10, 2008}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>  The win was considered an [[upset]] by the nation, as Tulsa was ranked as #24 in the [[Coaches' Poll]] and #25 in the [[AP Poll]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/recap?gid=200811150080&prov=ap|title=Keenum’s leads Houston over No. 25 Tulsa |agency=Associated Press|author=Rieken, Kristie|date=November 16, 2008|accessdate=November 23, 2008}}</ref>  This marked the second time that the Cougars had beaten a nationally ranked opponent in the season (the other being East Carolina); something Houston hadn't done since its 1984 season under [[College Football Hall of Fame]] coach [[Bill Yeoman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_11028312?source=most_viewed |title=Houston Cougars rain praise on UTEP Miners |author=Bloomquist, Bret |newspaper=[[El Paso Times]] |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=November 22, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>After the win, the Cougars were again ranked as first in conference play as Tulsa (5-1) had beaten Rice (5-1), and Houston (5-1) had beaten Tulsa.  This made Houston's other two regular season games on the schedule much more significant because if they won both games from this point, they would be allowed to compete in and host the [[Conference USA Football Championship]].{{Clear}}===UTEP===[[File:Houston Cougars football vs UTEP Miners 2008.jpg|thumb|[[2008 UTEP Miners football team|UTEP Miners]] at Robertson Stadium]]{{See also|2008 UTEP Miners football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=UTEP|R1=7|R2=14|R3=7|R4=9|Home='''Houston'''|H1=0|H2=9|H3=7|H4=26}}Although meeting for the first time during the Cougars' inaugural season in 1946, the [[UTEP Miners football|UTEP Miners]] had only met with the Cougars five times in history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1028|title=University of Houston VS University of Texas at El Paso - All Time|publisher=College Football Reference|accessdate=May 10, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175917/http://cfreference.net/cfr/all_time_schedule/1049?vs_id=1028 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>  As Conference USA foes, the Cougars held a 2-3 all-time record against the Miners, whereas both wins came consecutively during the 2006 and 2007 meetings of the teams.  [[Mike Price]] returned as the Miners' head coach this season.  After a close game, where Houston lagged behind, the Cougars made a fourth quarter comeback to win the game.{{Clear}}===Rice==={{See also|Bayou Bucket Classic|2008 Rice Owls football team}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road=Houston|R1=7|R2=14|R3=7|R4=14|Home='''Rice'''|H1=14|H2=21|H3=14|H4=7}}In the 2008 [[Bayou Bucket Classic]], the Cougars will meet with Rice at [[Rice Stadium (Rice University)|Rice Stadium]] as part of the [[Houston-Rice rivalry]].  It will be the 33rd meeting between the two teams, where Houston leads the series 24-9 and have won the last three meetings.  During this season, the outcome of the game will have significant influence for the Conference USA West Division title.  While Houston remains first in the division, a loss to Rice, and a win for [[2008 Tulsa Golden Hurricane football team|Tulsa]] (9-2) against [[Marshall Thundering Herd football|Marshall]] (4-7) would mean Tulsa, not Houston would be headed to compete against the East Division champion [[2008 East Carolina Pirates football team|East Carolina]] in the [[Conference USA Football Championship]].  If Rice wins its game against the Cougars, and Marshall wins its game against the Golden Hurricane, then Rice would be the West Division champion.  The game was picked up by [[CBS Sports Network|CBS College Sports]] after Houston's 70-30 blowout victory against Tulsa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conferenceusa.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111708aac.html |title=CBS College Sports Announces November 29&nbsp;C-USA Game|publisher=Conference USA|date=November 17, 2008|accessdate=November 23, 2008}}</ref>{{Clear}}===Armed Forces Bowl==={{main article|2008 Armed Forces Bowl}}{{See also|Air Force Falcons football}}{{Linescore Amfootball||Road='''Houston'''|R1=17|R2=0|R3=7|R4=10|Home=Air Force|H1=7|H2=10|H3=3|H4=8}}[[File:Carson Blackmon and Spencer Armstrong 2008 Armed Forces Bowl.jpg|thumb|left|Houston's Carson Blackmon tackles Air Force's Spencer Armstrong after a reception]]With seven regular season wins, the Cougars secured [[Bowl eligible|bowl eligibility]].  On December 7, 2008, the Houston Cougars announced that they had been selected to play in the [[2008 Armed Forces Bowl]] game against [[2008 Air Force Falcons football team|Air Force]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120708aaa.html|title=Cougars To Armed Forces Bowl, Rematch With Air Force|publisher=Houston Cougars athletics|date=December 7, 2008|accessdate=December 12, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211100432/http://uhcougars.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120708aaa.html|archivedate=December 11, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref>  This marked the Cougars' fourth consecutive bowl game invitation, and the fifth in six years.  The game was a rematch, as the Falcons and the Cougars faced off earlier during the regular season, where the Cougars were defeated.  This was the second time in history the Cougars had played a bowl game in Fort Worth; in 2005 the team appeared in the Fort Worth Bowl.The Cougars defeated the Falcons to win their first bowl game since 1980, and broke the longest current bowl game losing streak in Division I FBS football at that time.  The score was 34-28.  The game was televised on [[ESPN]].{{Clear}}==References=={{Reflist|2}}==External links=={{Commons category|2008 Houston Cougars football team}}{{Houston Cougars football navbox}}[[Category:2008 Conference USA football season|Houston Cougars]][[Category:Houston Cougars football seasons]][[Category:Armed Forces Bowl champion seasons]][[Category:2008 in sports in Texas|Houston Cougars football]])
(1	Trinidad and Tobago at the 2007 Pan American Games	{{Infobox country at games| NOC            = TRI| NOCname        = [[Trinidad and Tobago Olympic Committee]]| year           = 2007| date           = 13–29 July 2007| games          = Pan American Games| location       = [[2007 Pan American Games|Rio de Janeiro]]| competitors    = 75| sports         = 11| flagbearer     = [[Kwadwane Brown]]| officials      =| gold           = 0| silver         = 1| bronze         = 3| rank           = 21| appearances    = {{Team appearances list|competition=Pan American Games|team=Trinidad and Tobago|1959}}| app_begin_year =| seealso        =| website        =}}The '''[[2007 Pan American Games|15th Pan American Games]]''' were held in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] from 13 July 2007 to 29 July 2007.==Medals=====[[Image:Silver medal america.svg|20px]] Silver==={{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Cycling pictogram.svg|event=Cycling}}*Men's Individual Road Race: [[Emile Abraham]]===[[Image:Bronze medal america.svg|20px]] Bronze==={{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Athletics pictogram.svg|event=Athletics}}*Women's Shot Put: [[Cleopatra Borel-Brown]]{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Swimming pictogram.svg|event=Swimming}}*Men's 50m Freestyle: [[George Bovell]]{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Taekwondo pictogram.svg|event=Taekwondo}}*Men's &ndash; 80&nbsp;kg: [[Chinedum Osuji]]==External links==*[http://www.rio2007.org.br/ Rio 2007 Official website]*[http://200.58.120.7/comunidad-arquitectos.net/Records.aspx T&T Olympic Committee]{{NOCin2007PanAmericanGames}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Trinidad And Tobago At The 2007 Pan American Games}}[[Category:Nations at the 2007 Pan American Games]][[Category:2007 in Trinidad and Tobago sport|P]][[Category:Trinidad and Tobago at the Pan American Games|2007]])
(1	1997 DFB-Pokal Final	{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}}{{Infobox football match| title        = 1997 DFB-Pokal Final| image        = [[File:1997 DFB-Pokal Final programme.jpg|frameless]]| caption      = Match programme cover| event        = [[1996–97 DFB-Pokal]]| team1        = [[VfB Stuttgart]]| team1score   = 2| team2        = [[FC Energie Cottbus|Energie Cottbus]]| team2score   = 0| details      =| date         = {{Start date|1997|6|14|df=y}}| stadium      = [[Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]]| city         = [[Berlin]]| referee      = [[Edgar Steinborn]] ([[Sinzig]])<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://archive.org/details/DFBPokalFinalReferees |title=Schiedsrichter: Der erste war Berliner |magazine=DFB-Pokal: Das offizielle Stadionmagazin des Deutschen Fußball-Bundes |publisher=[[German Football Association]] |year=2015 |access-date=29 April 2017}}</ref>| attendance   = 76,400| weather      = Partly cloudy<br>{{convert|21|°C|°F|abbr=on}}<br>64% [[humidity]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/EDDT/1997/6/14/DailyHistory.html |title=Weather History for Berlin Tegel, DE |website=[[Weather Underground (weather service)|Weather Underground]] |publisher=[[The Weather Company]] |date=14 June 1997 |access-date=29 April 2017}}</ref>| previous     = [[1996 DFB-Pokal Final|1996]]| next         = [[1998 DFB-Pokal Final|1998]]}}The '''1997 DFB-Pokal Final''' decided the winner of the [[1996–97 DFB-Pokal]], the 54th season of Germany's premier knockout [[Association football|football]] cup competition. It was played on 14 June 1997 at the [[Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]] in [[Berlin]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dfb.de/dfb-pokal/statistik/bisherige-sieger/ |title=Alle DFB-Pokalsieger |trans-title=All DFB-Pokal winners |website=dfb.de |publisher=[[German Football Association]] |access-date=6 June 2016 |language=German}}</ref> [[VfB Stuttgart]] won the match 2–0 against third-division [[FC Energie Cottbus|Energie Cottbus]] to claim their third cup title.==Route to the final==The DFB-Pokal began with 64 teams in a [[single-elimination tournament|single-elimination]] knockout cup competition. There were a total of five rounds leading up to the final. Teams were drawn against each other, and the winner after 90 minutes would advance. If still tied, 30 minutes of [[Overtime (sports)#Association football|extra time]] was played. If the score was still level, a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] was used to determine the winner.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dfb.de/dfb-pokal/modus/ |title=Modus |trans-title=Mode |website=dfb.de |publisher=[[German Football Association]] |date=15 August 2012 |access-date=11 June 2015 |language=German}}</ref>''Note: In all results below, the score of the finalist is given first (H: home; A: away).''{| style="width:80%; text-align:center;"|- style="vertical-align:top; background:#99CCFF;"! colspan="2" | [[VfB Stuttgart]]! style="width:20%" | Round! (1	Warde Manuel	{{BLP sources|date=February 2012}}{{Infobox college coach| name = Warde Manuel| image =| alt =| caption =| sport =| current_title = [[Athletic director]]| current_team = [[Michigan Wolverines|Michigan]]| current_conference = [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]]| birth_date = {{birth year and age|1968}}| birth_place =| death_date =| death_place =| alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]]| player_years1 = 1986–1989| player_team1 = [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]]| player_positions = [[Defensive tackle]]| admin_years1 = 2005–2012| admin_team1 = [[Buffalo Bulls|Buffalo]]| admin_years2 = 2012–2016| admin_team2 = [[Connecticut Huskies|Connecticut]]| admin_years3 = 2016–present| admin_team3 = [[Michigan Wolverines|Michigan]]| overall_record =| bowl_record =| tournament_record =| championships =| awards =| coaching_records =}}'''Warde Joseph Manuel'''<reF>http://www.umsalary.info/index.php?FName=warde&LName=manuel&Year=12&Campus=0</reF> (born c. 1968) is an American college athletics administrator, former [[American football]] player.   On January 29th, 2016, he was named the 13th Director of Athletics at his alma mater, the [[University of Michigan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/story/money/business/columnists/carol-cain/2017/08/27/michigan-athletic-director-warde-manuel/601297001/|title=How fate led Warde Manuel to Michigan athletic director job|date=August 27, 2017|agency=''[[Detroit Free Press]]''|author=Cain, Carol|accessdate=August 29, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6t4qAm9Hz|archivedate=August 29, 2017}}</ref> He was named the Director of Athletics at the [[University of Connecticut]] on February 12, 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tests for New Athletic Director at UConn |first=Mark |last=Viera |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/14/sports/ncaabasketball/warde-j-manuel-uconns-new-athletic-director-faces-immediate-challenges.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 13, 2012 |accessdate=February 15, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Warde Manuel Named Director of Athletics|url=http://www.uconnhuskies.com/genrel/021212aad.html|publisher=uconnhuskies.com|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>  From August 29, 2005 to February 12, 2012, Manuel was the [[athletic director]] at the [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York]].  Prior to arriving at Buffalo, Manuel was an associate athletic director at the [[University of Michigan]].==Early life and playing career==Manuel played high school football at Brother Martin High School in New Orleans.<ref name=Roster/> He was a first team high school All-American.  He was recruited and enrolled at the [[University of Michigan]] where he played [[defensive tackle]] for the [[Michigan Wolverines football|Wolverines]] from 1986 to 1989, for coach [[Bo Schembechler]], before suffering a career-ending neck injury.<ref name=Roster>{{cite web|title=University of Michigan Football Rosters|publisher=Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan|url=http://141.211.39.65/allroster/fbsearch.htm}}</ref>==Administrative career==Manuel developed his management skills as assistant athletic director and then associate AD at the University of Michigan.  He credits Michigan coaches and staff for his success, including Bo Schembechler, Stephen Ross, and [[Greg Harden]], now Director of Athletic Counseling at U-M.<ref name=CarolCain>[http://archive.freep.com/article/20140427/COL24/304270098/Carol-Cain-Warde-Manuel-credits-U-M-showing-him-what-do-UConn "Warde Manuel credits U-M for showing him what to do at UConn"], by Carol Cain, April 27, 2014.</ref>Manuel was responsible for the hiring of [[Turner Gill]] as the head coach of [[Buffalo Bulls football|Buffalo's football team]]. Under Gill the team achieved its first winning season and first invitation to a post season bowl game since the program joined [[NCAA Division I]] athletics in 1999.  Manuel has helped change Buffalo's image and marketing strategy. Immediately after he took office, Manuel replaced the old "Bull Head" logo with a sleeker, more modern bull.  Manuel also increased the athletics budget from $11 million to $25 million within three years of his hiring.==References=={{Reflist}}===Additional sources===* [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=1257AF69B6B1A1F8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Manuel's can-do attitude does plenty (Buffalo News Archives)]* [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/2006-02-28-buffalo_x.htm New Buffalo trifecta busting racial barriers (USAToday)]==External links==* [http://www.mgoblue.com/genrel/warde_manuel_1000490.html Michigan profile]* [http://www.uconnhuskies.com/genrel/manuel_warde00.html Connecticut profile]{{Buffalo Bulls athletic director navbox}}{{Connecticut Huskies athletic director navbox}}{{Michigan Wolverines athletic directors navbox}}{{Big Ten Conference athletic director navbox}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Manuel, Warde}}[[Category:1960s births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:American football defensive ends]][[Category:Buffalo Bulls athletic directors]][[Category:Connecticut Huskies athletic directors]][[Category:Michigan Wolverines athletic directors]][[Category:Michigan Wolverines football players]][[Category:Michigan Wolverines track and field athletes]][[Category:Ross School of Business alumni]][[Category:Wayne State University faculty]][[Category:Sportspeople from New Orleans]][[Category:Players of American football from Louisiana]])
(1	Mauricio Villardo	{{Orphan|date=June 2014}}{{Infobox martial artist| image           =| name            = Mauricio Villardo|| image_size      = 175px| caption         = Mauricio Villardo.| residence       = [[Wellington, Florida|Wellington]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]| birth_date      =| birth_place     = {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]| martial_art     = [[Gracie Jiu-Jitsu]]| teacher         = [[Royler Gracie]],| rank            = 4th Degree Black Belt| students        =| website         = http://www.brjj.com| footnotes       =}}'''Mauricio Villardo Reis''' (born January 14, 1975) best known as '''Mauricio Villardo''' is a fourth-degree black belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu under [[Royler Gracie]],<ref name="Royler_WIki">[[Royler Gracie]]</ref> head instructor of [[Gracie Humaitá]] and he is also a former World Champion of the [[World Jiu-Jitsu Championship]]<ref name="World Championship">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibjjf.org/worlds.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303002442/http://www.ibjjf.org/worlds.htm |archivedate=2009-03-03 |df= }} World Championship, {{cite web|url=http://www.ibjjf.org/results.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090918103809/http://www.ibjjf.org/results.htm |archivedate=2009-09-18 |df= }} Results</ref> of the [[International Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Federation]] ([[IBJJF]]). Living close to the beautiful beaches in Brazil, Mauricio's hobby was [[surfing]], but once he experienced [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu|Jiu-Jitsu]], he fell in love with the sport. Mauricio’s first experience with the [[martial arts]] was not Jiu-Jitsu. When he was seven,he began practicing [[Judo]] at Clube do Flamengo,in Rio de Janeiro.At the age of fifteen, Mauricio began to practice [[Muay Thai]]. A few months later, a friend invited him to visit a Brazilian jiu-jitsu academy and for Mauricio, it began a lifelong journey studying the worlds most effective fighting and self-defense system.Almost immediately after becoming a Jiu-Jitsu student, Mauricio began to compete at local and regional tournaments in Brazil. Later, he began to assist Professor [[Royler Gracie]] with classes, developing his passion for teaching. He won many major tournaments including the 1996 [[World Jiu-Jitsu Championship]]. In 1997, Mauricio accomplished a lifelong dream receiving his black belt from the hands of his professor [[Royler Gracie]].In 2002 Mauricio moved to south [[Florida]]. Recognizing the opportunity to build a small business in the  [[United States]],  he decided to continue teaching his style of jiu-Jitsu in the [[Palm Beach County, Florida]] area. Since 2002, Mauricio has been developing and expanding [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]] in the [[West Palm Beach]] area where he lives and operates an academy in [[Wellington, Florida|Wellington]].WIth an expanding academy Professor Villardo has also continued his success in competition.  In 2009 he won a silver medal at the [[IBJJF]] PAN Championships in California.  He also won gold medals at the [[IBJJF]] 2009 and 2010 PAN No-Gi championships in New York City.== Instructor lineage ==[[Mitsuyo Maeda|Mitsuo "Count Koma" Maeda]] → [[Carlos Gracie|Carlos Gracie Sr.]] → [[Hélio Gracie]] → [[Royler Gracie]]== See also ==* [[Gracie Humaitá]]== References ==<!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically -->{{Reflist}}==External links==*[http://www.brjj.com/ The Mauricio Villardo Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu web site]*[https://web.archive.org/web/20090210023427/http://academiagracie.com.br/ Academia Gracie Jiu-Jitsu]*[http://www.Riliongracie.com/ Rilion Gracie Jiu-Jitsu Academy]{{DEFAULTSORT:Villardo, Mauricio}}[[Category:1975 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Brazilian practitioners of Brazilian jiu-jitsu]][[Category:Brazilian expatriate sportspeople in the United States]][[Category:Sportspeople from Rio de Janeiro (city)]][[Category:People from Wellington, Florida]])

(1	1963 Men's European Volleyball Championship	The '''[[Men's European Volleyball Championship|1963 Men's European Volleyball Championship]]''' was the sixth edition of the event,  organized by Europe's governing volleyball body, the [[Confédération Européenne de Volleyball]]. It was hosted in various cities in [[Romania]] from October 21 to November 2, 1963, with the final taking place in [[Bucharest]].==Teams=={| table width=90%| width=30% valign="top" |* {{flag|Austria}}* {{flag|Belgium}}* {{flag|Bulgaria}}* {{flag|Czechoslovakia}}* {{flag|Denmark}}* {{flag|Finland}}* {{flag|France}}| width=30% valign="top" |* {{flag|East Germany}}* {{flag|West Germany}}* {{flag|Italy}}* {{flag|Yugoslavia}}* {{flag|Netherlands}}* {{flag|Poland}}* {{flag|Romania}}| width=30% valign="top" |* {{flag|Turkey}}* {{flag|Hungary}}* {{flag|USSR}}|}==Final ranking==# [[Romania]]# [[Hungary]]# [[Soviet Union]]# [[Bulgaria]]# [[Czechoslovakia]]# [[Poland]]# [[Yugoslavia]]# [[France]]# [[East Germany]]# [[Italy]]# [[Turkey]]# [[Netherlands]]# [[Belgium]]# [[Finland]]# [[West Germany]]# [[Austria]]# [[Denmark]]==References==* [https://web.archive.org/web/20150421165446/http://todor66.com/volleyball/Europe/Men_1963.html Results]{{Volleyball}}{{Volleyball European Championship}}[[Category:Men's European Volleyball Championships]][[Category:1963 in volleyball|European Championship]][[Category:1963 in Romanian sport|Mens European Volleyball Championship, 1963]][[Category:International volleyball competitions hosted by Romania]][[Category:Sports competitions in Bucharest]][[Category:1960s in Bucharest]][[Category:October 1963 sports events]][[Category:November 1963 sports events]])
(1	2003 WGC-NEC Invitational	{{Infobox individual golf tournament| name          = 2003 WGC-NEC Invitational| image         =| dates         = August 21–24, 2003| location      = [[Akron, Ohio]], U.S.| course        = [[Firestone Country Club]]| tour          = [[PGA Tour]]<br>[[European Tour]]| par           = 70| yardage       = 7,283| field         = 85 players| cut           = None| purse         = [[United States dollar|$]]6,000,000| winners_share = $1,050,000| champion      = {{flagicon|NIR}} [[Darren Clarke]]| score         = 268 (–12)| previous      = [[2002 WGC-NEC Invitational|2002]]| next          = [[2004 WGC-NEC Invitational|2004]]}}The '''2003 WGC-NEC Invitational''' was a [[golf]] tournament that was contested from August 21–24, 2003 over the South Course at [[Firestone Country Club]] in [[Akron, Ohio]]. It was the fifth [[WGC-NEC Invitational]] tournament, and the second of four [[World Golf Championships]] events held in 2003.[[Darren Clarke]] won the tournament to capture his first WGC-NEC Invitational and his second World Golf Championships title.==Field==;1. (1	Manly Yacht Club	{{Refimprove|date=January 2011}}{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 15em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;"|+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Manly Yacht Club'''|-| colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" |[[Image:Myc-burgee.png|200px|]]<br>Burgee|-! Founded| 1950|-! Clubhouse| East Esplanade, Manly, NSW, 2095|-! Country| {{AUS}}|-! Website| http://www.myc.org.au|-|}'''Manly Yacht Club''' (MYC) is a [[sailing club]] in the [[suburb]] of [[Manly, New South Wales|Manly]] on the [[Northern Beaches (Sydney)|Northern Beaches]] of [[Sydney]], in the state of [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]].== History ==Manly Yacht Club was formed in 1950 as the Manly 14&nbsp;ft Skiff Club. In the late 50's a training boat called the [[Manly Junior]] was introduced.The 60's was a busy decade with the formulation of the Yachting Division and the Manly Graduate division. The club's name was subsequently changed to the ManlyYacht Club. In the early 80's the club moved into the present building which was the site of the former Gentlemen's Baths, 'the largest and most efficiently equipped gentlemen's swimming baths in the state', opened in 1892. In October 1926, a new Olympic pool with a grandstand to seat 1400 people was opened at a cost of £11,000.The Baths suffered severe storm damage in May 1974[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/northern-beaches/the-year-our-coastline-was-battered/story-fngr8hax-1226946127690] and were closed in April 1976[http://manlydiggers.org.au/history/]. The Harbord Diggers swimming club held a ceremony with special guests Sir Robert Askin and Fitz Lough, who had swum at the baths for seventy years. At the last race a wreath was floated in the pool. It was said that since the first race had been held in 1890 the pool had `seen more Olympic champions in action than any other swimming centre in this country.' Early in 1977 the Manly Yacht Club submitted plans to convert the remaining buildings for boat storage, and has been in residence ever since.==External links==* [http://www.myc.org.au Manly Yacht Club]* [http://www.manlysailability.com.au/ Manly Sailability]{{Coord|-33.80315|151.2854|format=dms|type:landmark_region:AU-NSW|display=title}}[[Category:Yacht clubs in Australia]][[Category:Sports clubs established in 1950]][[Category:1950 establishments in Australia]][[Category:Sporting clubs in Sydney]][[Category:Manly, New South Wales]])

World Championships 2012 – Women's relay|4 × 6 km relay]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2013|2013 Nové Město]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2013 – Mixed relay|Mixed relay]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2015|2015 Kontiolahti]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2015 – Mixed relay|Mixed relay]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2015|2015 Kontiolahti]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2015 – Women's relay|4 × 6 km relay]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016|2016 Oslo]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016 – Women's sprint|7.5 km sprint]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016|2016 Oslo]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016 – Women's relay|4 × 6 km relay]]}}{{MedalSilver|[[Biathlon World Championships 2017|2017 Hochfilzen]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2017 – Mixed relay|Mixed relay]]}}{{MedalBronze|[[Biathlon World Championships 2009|2009 Pyeongchang]]|4 × 6 km relay}}{{MedalBronze|{{nowrap|[[Biathlon World Championships 2011|2011 Khanty-Mansiysk]]}}|[[Biathlon World Championships 2011 – Mixed relay|Mixed relay]]}}{{MedalBronze|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016|2016 Oslo]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2016 – Women's pursuit|10 km pursuit]]}}{{MedalBronze|[[Biathlon World Championships 2017|2017 Hochfilzen]]|[[Biathlon World Championships 2017 – Women's relay|4 x 6 km relay]]}}}}'''Marie Dorin Habert''' (born 19 June 1986<ref>[http://familledorin.free.fr/english/monprofil.htm Profile of Marie Dorin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720221354/http://familledorin.free.fr/english/monprofil.htm |date=2011-07-20 }} – Le site de Marie Dorin – biathlete</ref>) is a French [[Biathlon|biathlete]].==Career==She represented [[France at the 2010 Winter Olympics]].<ref>[http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-biathlon/athletes/marie-dorin_ath1030953SD.html Vancouver 2010 Profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206173445/http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-biathlon/athletes/marie-dorin_ath1030953SD.html |date=2010-02-06 }}</ref> She was also on the bronze medal winning French relay team at the [[Biathlon World Championships 2009]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/amateur/story/2009/02/21/landertinger-biathlon-worlds.html CBC]</ref><ref name="IBUprofile">{{cite web |url=http://services.biathlonresults.com/athletes.aspx?IbuId=BTFRA21906198601 |title=Marie Dorin Habert |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=IBU Datacenter |publisher=International Biathlon Union |access-date=17 May 2015}}</ref>Dorin won a bronze in the women's 7.5&nbsp;km sprint on 13 February 2010 and a silver in the relay. She won her first individual world cup victory at the 2015 world championships in Kontiolahti, Finland, in the sprint event, which was her first World Champion title as well. The next day she won the world championships pursuit, making it her second individual world cup victory and second gold medal in the world championships.==Personal life==Dorin is married to retired French biathlete Lois Habert. She gave birth to their daughter Adele in September 2014 and returned to the Biathlon World Cup in January 2015.==Biathlon results==All results are sourced from the [[International Biathlon Union]].<ref name="IBUprofile"/>===Olympic Games===''2 medals (1 silver, 1 bronze)''{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"|- "!Event!style="text-align:center; (1	Hamid Ezzine	{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}}{{Infobox sportsperson| name           =| image          = Hamid Ezzine 2013.jpg| image_size     =| caption        = Ezzine at the 2013 World Championships| birth_name     =| fullname       =| nationality    =| residence      =| birth_date     = {{birth-date and age|5 October 1983}}| birth_place    = [[Aït Ali]], [[Morocco]]<ref name=sr/>| death_date     =| death_place    =| height         = 174 cm<ref name=rio/>| weight         = 62 kg| country        =| sport          = Athletics| event = [[steeplechase]]| pb = 3000 mS – 8:09.72 (2007)<ref name=iaaf/>| club           =FATH Union Sports, Rabat<ref name=london/><ref name=nbc/>| coach = Ayachi Amekdouf<ref name=london/><br>Ahmed Ettanani<br>Abdellah Boukraa<br>Lahlou Benyounes<br>Mohamed Nouami<ref name=nbc/>| education = [[Al Akhawayn University]]<ref name=nbc/>| retired        =| olympics       =| highestranking =| show-medals    = yes| medaltemplates ={{MedalCountry|{{MAR}}}}{{MedalCompetition|[[IAAF World Cross Country Championships|World Cross Country Championships]]}}{{MedalBronze |[[2006 IAAF World Cross Country Championships|Fukuoka 2006]]|Short race – Team}}{{MedalCompetition|[[Mediterranean Games]]}}{{MedalBronze|[[2013 Mediterranean Games|Mersin 2013]]|[[Athletics at the 2013 Mediterranean Games|3000 m steeplechase]]}}}}'''Hamid Ezzine''' (born 5 October 1983) is a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] [[long-distance track event|long-distance runner]] who specialized in the [[3000 metres steeplechase]]. He is a younger brother of the Olympic runner [[Ali Ezzine]].<ref name=sr/> He finished twelfth in the 5000 metres at the [[2002 World Junior Championships in Athletics|2002 World Junior Championships]], but then turned to the steeplechase. He finished fourth at the [[2004 African Championships in Athletics|2004 African Championships]],<ref name=iaaf/> won the gold medal at the [[Athletics at the 2005 Jeux de la Francophonie|2005 Jeux de la Francophonie]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/fg.htm|title=Francophone Games|work=GBR Athletics|publisher=Athletics Weekly|accessdate=4 March 2010}}</ref> finished fifth at the [[2006 African Championships in Athletics|2006 African Championships]] and eleventh at the [[2007 IAAF World Athletics Final|2007 World Athletics Final]]. He also competed at the [[2005 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 3000 metres steeplechase|2005 World Championships]], the [[2007 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 3000 metres steeplechase|2007 World Championships]] and the [[Athletics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's 3000 metre steeplechase|2008 Olympic Games]] without reaching the final.<ref name=iaaf/>His personal best time in the steeplechase is 8:09.72 minutes, achieved in July 2007 in [[Athens]]' [[Olympic Stadium (Athens)|Olympic Stadium]]. Up until then he had improved steadily from 8:47.67 minutes in 2003 (August, [[Casablanca]]) to 8:25.10 in 2004 (June, [[Rabat]]), 8:21.38 in 2005 (June, Rabat) and 8:19.37 in 2006 (June, Rabat).<ref name=iaaf/> In late 2007 Ezzine was described in the official [[IAAF]] season reviews as one of that year's major beakthroughs statistically.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iaaf.org/news/Kind=2/newsId=42728.html|title=2007 – End of year Reviews – LONG DISTANCE RUNNING|last=Julin|first=A. Lennart|author2=Jalava, Mirko|date=29 December 2007|publisher=[[IAAF]]|accessdate=4 March 2010}}</ref> His personal best in the 5000 metres is 14:00.6 minutes, achieved in June 2002 in Rabat.<ref name=iaaf/>Ezzine also finished 30th at the [[2004 IAAF World Cross Country Championships|2004 World Cross Country Championships]], 41st at the [[2005 IAAF World Cross Country Championships|2005 World Cross Country Championships]] and 21st at the [[2006 IAAF World Cross Country Championships|2006 World Cross Country Championships]], all in the ''short race''.<ref name=iaaf/> This earned him a fifth place in the team competition of 2004 and a bronze medal in the team competition of 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mypage.bluewin.ch/tomtytom/iccu/wxc_iaaf/wxc_SM2004C.html|title=IAAF World Cross Country Championships – 4.0km CC Men – Bruxelles Ossegem Park Date: Saturday, March 20, 2004 |publisher=Athchamps|accessdate=4 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016110714/http://mypage.bluewin.ch/tomtytom/iccu/wxc_iaaf/wxc_SM2004C.html|archivedate=16 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mypage.bluewin.ch/tomtytom/iccu/wxc_iaaf/wxc_SM2006C.html|title=IAAF World Cross Country Championships – 4.0km CC Men – Fukuoka Date: Saturday, April 1, 2006|publisher=Athchamps|accessdate=4 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016110734/http://mypage.bluewin.ch/tomtytom/iccu/wxc_iaaf/wxc_SM2006C.html|archivedate=16 October 2007}}</ref>In 2009 he was found guilty of refusal to submit to [[doping (sport)|doping control]] and tampering with a doping control. For this he received a two-year suspension from the sport, lasting from March 2009 to March 2011.<ref name=nbc/> He returned to competition in late 2011 to win the silver medal in  3000 m steeplechase at the [[Athletics at the 2011 Pan Arab Games|2011 Pan Arab Games]].  That year he also competed at the [[2011 World Championships in Athletics|World Championships]] in Daegu, finishing 9th in the final. He reached the [[Athletics at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's 3000 metres steeplechase|Olympic final in 2012]], finishing in seventh place.  At the [[2013 World Championships in Athletics|2013 World Championships]], he again finished 9th.<ref name=iaaf/>==References=={{Commons category|Hamid Ezzine}}{{reflist|refs=<ref name=iaaf>{{iaaf name|190250}}</ref><ref name=rio>[https://www.rio2016.com/en/athlete/hamid-ezzine Hamid Ezzine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806071346/https://www.rio2016.com/en/athlete/hamid-ezzine |date=6 August 2016 }}. rio2016.com</ref><ref name=nbc>[http://results.nbcolympics.com/athletes/athlete=ezzine-hamid-1149575/index.html Hamid Ezzine]. nbcolympics.com</ref><ref name=london>[http://results.nbcolympics.com/athletes/athlete=hesselbjerg-ole-1136387/index. Hamid Ezzine]. nbcolympics.com</ref><ref name=sr>[http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ez/hamid-ezzine-1.html Hamid Ezzine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025134707/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ez/hamid-ezzine-1.html |date=25 October 2012 }}. sports-reference.com</ref>}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Ezzine, Hamid}}[[Category:1983 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Moroccan male long-distance runners]][[Category:Moroccan male steeplechase runners]][[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 2008 Summer Olympics]][[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 2012 Summer Olympics]][[Category:Athletes (track and field) at the 2016 Summer Olympics]][[Category:Olympic athletes of Morocco]][[Category:Doping cases in athletics]][[Category:Moroccan sportspeople in doping cases]][[Category:People from Ain Taoujdate]][[Category:World Championships in Athletics athletes for Morocco]][[Category:Mediterranean Games bronze medalists for Morocco]])
(1	Gary Jones (footballer, born 1969)	{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}}{{Use British English|date=May 2013}}{{Infobox football biography| name        = Gary Jones| image       =| fullname    =| height      = {{height|ft=6|in=0}}| birth_date  = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1969|4|06}}| birth_place = [[Huddersfield]], England| position    = [[Centre forward]]| youthyears1 =| youthclubs1 =| years1 =| years2 = 1988–1990| years3 =| years4 =| years5 = 1991–1993| years6 = 1993–1996| years7 = 1993–1994| years8 = 1995–1999| years9 = 1996–1997| years10 = 1998–2000| years11 = 1999–2000| years12 = 2000–2002| years13 = 2002–2003| years14 = 2002–2003| years15 = 2002–2003| years16 = 2003–2007| years17 = 2006–2008| years18 = 2007–2009| years19 = 2009–2010| years20 = 2016–2017| clubs1 = [[Rossington Main F.C.|Rossington Main]]| clubs2 = [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]]| clubs3 = [[Grantham Town F.C.|Grantham Town]]| clubs4 = [[Kettering Town F.C.|Kettering Town]]| clubs5 = [[Boston United F.C.|Boston United]]| clubs6 = [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]]| clubs7 = → [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] (loan)| clubs8 = [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]]| clubs9 = → [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] (loan)| clubs10 = [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]]| clubs11 = → [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]] (loan)| clubs12 = [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]]| clubs13 = [[Nuneaton Town F.C.|Nuneaton Borough]]| clubs14 = [[Hucknall Town F.C.|Hucknall Town]]| clubs15 = [[Gainsborough Trinity F.C.|Gainsborough Trinity]]| clubs16 = [[Armthorpe Welfare F.C.|Armthorpe Welfare]]| clubs17 = [[Selby Town F.C.|Selby Town]]| clubs18 = [[Armthorpe Welfare F.C.|Armthorpe Welfare]]| clubs19 = [[Winterton Rangers F.C.|Winterton Rangers]]| clubs20 = [[Fairway F.C.|Fairway]]| caps1 =| caps2 = 20| caps3 =| caps4 =| caps5 =| caps6 = 70| caps7 = 4| caps8 = 117| caps9 = 11| caps10 = 45| caps11 = 8| caps12 = 68| goals1 =| goals2 = 2| goals3 =| goals4 =| goals5 =| goals6 = 16| goals7 = 2| goals8 = 38| goals9 = 5| goals10 = 7| goals11 = 1| goals12 = 9}}'''Gary Jones''' (born 6 April 1969) is an English former [[Association football|footballer]] who played for over three hundred times in [[the Football League]] principally for [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]], [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] and [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]].==Playing career=====Return to non-league===He joined [[Nuneaton Town F.C.|Nuneaton Borough]] ahead of the 2002–2003 season before moving on to [[Hucknall Town F.C.|Hucknall Town]] and [[Gainsborough Trinity F.C.|Gainsborough Trinity]]. In the summer of 2003 he linked up with [[Armthorpe Welfare F.C.|Armthorpe Welfare]]. In November 2006 he joined [[Selby Town F.C.|Selby Town]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport1/Joy-as-inform-Hallam-take.1886968.jp|title=Joy as in-form Hallam take scalp of leaders|date=20 November 2006|publisher=[[Sheffield Star|The Star]]|accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref> before returning to [[Armthorpe Welfare F.C.|Armthorpe Welfare]] the following season. In July 2009 he joined [[Winterton Rangers F.C.|Winterton Rangers]], scoring twice on his [[Northern Counties East League]] debut for the club in the 4–0 victory at [[Rainworth Miners Welfare F.C.|Rainworth Miners Welfare]] on 8 August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisscunthorpe.co.uk/brigg/news/sparkle-Rangers-make-midable-start/article-1236583-detail/article.html|title=Front two sparkle as Rangers make four-midable start|date=10 August 2009|publisher=Scunthorpe Telegraph|accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>He retired from playing in November 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisscunthorpe.co.uk/brigg/news/Winterton-boss-eager-bring-stability-team/article-1510252-detail/article.html|title=Winterton boss eager to bring stability to his team|date=13 November 2009|publisher=Scunthorpe Telegraph|accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref>==References=={{reflist|30em}}==External links==*{{Soccerbase}}*[http://www.redimps.com/archive3/index.mv?cat=players&drop=playerdetsdrop&play=jone03 Lincoln City F.C. Official Archive Profile]{{Navboxes colour|title=Awards|bg=gold|fg=navy|list1={{English Third Division top scorers}}{{Boston United F.C. Player of the Year}}{{Notts County F.C. Player of the Year}}}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Jones, Gary}}[[Category:1969 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Sportspeople from Huddersfield]][[Category:English footballers]][[Category:Association football forwards]][[Category:Rossington Main F.C. players]][[Category:Doncaster Rovers F.C. players]][[Category:Grantham Town F.C. players]][[Category:Kettering Town F.C. players]][[Category:Boston United F.C. players]][[Category:Southend United F.C. players]][[Category:Lincoln City F.C. players]][[Category:Notts County F.C. players]][[Category:Scunthorpe United F.C. players]][[Category:Hartlepool United F.C. players]][[Category:Halifax Town A.F.C. players]][[Category:Nuneaton Town F.C. players]][[Category:Hucknall Town F.C. players]][[Category:Gainsborough Trinity F.C. players]][[Category:Armthorpe Welfare F.C. players]][[Category:Selby Town F.C. players]][[Category:Winterton Rangers F.C. players]][[Category:English Football League players]])

(1	Poor and Stupid	{{Infobox Television episode| title        = Poor and Stupid| series       = South Park| image        =<!-- Deleted image removed:  [[File:KennyNearDeath.png|250px]] -->| caption      = Kenny jumps atop Cartman's car in an attempt to stop the race and restore dignity to racing.| season       = 14| episode      = 8| airdate      = October 6, 2010| production   = 1408| writer       = Trey Parker| director     = [[Trey Parker]]| guests       =| season_article = South Park (season 14)| episode_list = List of South Park episodes| season_list  =| prev         = [[Crippled Summer]]| next         = [[It's a Jersey Thing]]}}"'''Poor and Stupid'''" is the eighth episode and mid-season premiere of the [[South Park (season 14)|fourteenth season]] of the American animated television series ''[[South Park]]'', and the 203rd overall episode of the series. It aired on [[Comedy Central]] in the United States on October 6, 2010. In the episode, [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]] wants to become a [[NASCAR]] racer, but he feels that he cannot because he is not "poor and stupid enough" to fulfill his dream. After some experiments, his dream comes true, and he receives his own race car after his consumption of [[Vagisil]] brings massive attention to the product, much to the dismay of his friend [[Kenny McCormick|Kenny]], who tries to stop Cartman from giving his favorite event a bad reputation."Poor and Stupid" received a mixed reception. 3.139 million viewers watched the episode, according to [[Nielsen Media Research]], making it the second most watched cable television show of its airdate, losing the number one spot to the [[baseball]] game between the [[New York Yankees]] and the [[Minnesota Twins]] during the [[2010 American League Division Series]].==Plot==<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:South-park-poor-stupid.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Cartman's dream comes true when he races for NASCAR.{{deletable image-caption|Tuesday, 8 March 2011}}]] -->When [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] and [[Kyle Broflovski|Kyle]] find [[Eric Cartman|Cartman]] crying in front of his locker at school, he explains that he's upset about the essay [[Mr. Garrison]] assigned, "What I Want to Be When I Grow Up." He wails that he dreams of being a [[NASCAR]] driver, but "a person like him" could never be that–he's nowhere near poor and stupid enough to be a NASCAR driver or fan. Immediately he turns to [[Kenny McCormick|Kenny]], who innocently confirms that he is a huge NASCAR fan. Dismayed at Cartman's views of NASCAR, Kenny, and himself, Stan and Kyle effectively convince him that he's actually very poor and very stupid. Cartman immediately turns to [[Butters Stotch|Butters]] for help in becoming as poor and stupid as possible: he gives Butters all his money and orders him to spend it all and never give it back. Then, while watching what he hopes is brain-cell-killing TV programming, he sees a commercial for [[Combe Incorporated|Vagisil]] that lists [[Anterograde amnesia|short-term memory loss]] as a possible side effect, so he shoplifts some and consumes it (quite literally, as he eats the cream meant for topical use). On race day, Butters convinces a driver to abandon his car because his wife has been raped, and Cartman hops into his car, but his total lack of knowledge causes an accident that lands him in the hospital. The doctor comments to Cartman, who's disappointed that he is not more seriously injured than he is, that his accident was the stupidest he has ever seen, which restores Cartman's hope. His antics cause the news media to wonder if all NASCAR fans are as stupid as he seems to be.An angered Kenny storms to Cartman's house just in time for a visit from Vagisil founder Jeff Hamill and his wife Patty. Since Cartman's determination has brought considerable attention to Vagisil, Hamill rewards him with his own Vagisil-sponsored racecar, further galling Kenny. Before his first race, Cartman posts bigoted and ignorant statements on his podcast and the media concludes that "NASCAR really is just for the poor and stupid". Kenny decides that he must put a stop to Cartman. He tries to smuggle a hunting rifle into the racetrack, but it gets confiscated. He is however reassured that he can buy another in the gift shop.At Cartman's first race in his Vagisil car, he drives badly, crashing into other drivers, pulling [[Danica Patrick]] under the wheel, and mowing down spectators. When Kenny tries to interrupt, he's knocked onto the track; 2 cars crash to avoid him, leaving Cartman's the only car remaining in the race. Suddenly, Patty Hamill, fed up of her husband's disrespectful and condescending remarks toward her, gets onto the track and takes [[Jimmie Johnson]]'s damaged car. She beats Cartman and wins the race, much to Hamill's sheer disappointment, now that his company is ruined. Cartman apologizes to Kenny (who, surprisingly is still alive) for trying to become a NASCAR driver, and gives his future up, still believing that he is too smart for NASCAR. He demands that Butters give back his money, then yells at him for having done what he was told and gotten rid of it. Kenny watches in disbelief and confusion.== Production and theme  {{anchor|Production|ThemeCultural references}} ==[[File:TreyParkerHWOFApr2013.jpg|thumb|upright|Series co-creator [[Trey Parker]] wrote and directed "Poor and Stupid".|alt=A brown-haired man wearing a lime shirt and grown jacket smiles and looks at something off-screen.]]"Poor and Stupid" was written and directed by series co-founder [[Trey Parker]], and was rated TV-MA-L-V in the United States. It first aired on October 6, 2010 in the United States on Comedy Central.The episode satirizes stereotypes associated with the NASCAR community.<ref name="avclub" /><ref name="ign" /> In the episode, Cartman claims that all NASCAR drivers and fans are poor and stupid, and that he too must become so in order to become a NASCAR driver.<ref name="avclub" /> The NASCAR drivers are portrayed as well-spoken and the NASCAR fans are depicted as being fairly smart;<ref name="ew">{{cite news| date = October 6, 2010| first = Ken| last = Tucker| title = 'South Park' season premiere review: NASCAR and Vagisil| url = http://watching-tv.ew.com/2010/10/06/south-park-nascar/|newspaper = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | publisher = Ray Chelstowski }}</ref> it is only Cartman's stereotypical impersonation of the NASCAR community that casts them in a negative light.<ref name="ign" />==Reception===== Ratings ===In its original American broadcast on October 6, 2010, "Poor and Stupid" was watched by 3.139 million viewers, according to [[Nielsen Media Research]], making it the second most watched cable television show of the night, losing the number one spot to the [[baseball]] match between the [[New York Yankees]] and the [[Minnesota Twins]] during the [[2010 American League Division Series]]. The episode received a 2.0 rating/4 share, meaning it was seen by 2 percent of the population and 4 percent of the people watching television at the time of its broadcast. Among adult viewers between ages 18 and 49, the episode scored a 1.8 rating/5 share and among male viewers between ages 18 and 34, the episode received a 3.8 rating/12 share.<ref>{{cite web| date = October 7, 2010| first1 = Robert |last1 =Seidman| title= Wednesday Cable: Yankees/Twins Tops Night; South Park Top Scripted; Terriers Falls & More| url= http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/10/07/wednesday-cable-yankeestwins-tops-night-south-park-top-scripted-terriers-falls-more/67170 | work = TV by the Numbers | accessdate = November 25, 2010}}</ref>=== Critical response ==="Poor and Stupid" received mixed reviews. [[The A.V. Club]] gave the episode a B− rating.<ref name="avclub">{{cite web| date = October 7, 2010| author = Brett Singer| title = South Park: Poor and Stupid| url = http://www.avclub.com/articles/poor-and-stupid,45959/| work = [[The A.V. Club]]| publisher = [[The Onion]]}}</ref>  [[IGN]] gave the episode a score of 7 out of 10. Reviewer Ramsey Isler described the episode as "docile" by South Park standards and asserted that the episode lacks the show's "signature style of biting ridicule". Despite some winning one-liners and sight gags he considered the episode among the weaker episodes of the season so far and hoped for more in future episodes.<ref name="ign">{{cite web| date = October 7, 2010| author = Ramsey Isler| title = South Park: "Poor and Stupid" Review. Cartman gets a taste of NASCAR...and Vagisil.| url = http://tv.ign.com/articles/112/1126308p1.html| work = [[IGN]]| publisher = [[News Corporation]]}}</ref>Brad Trechak of ''[[TV Squad]]'' said that, while the episode had some humorous moments, the episode "doesn't feel like Matt [Stone] and Trey [Parker] at their best", and criticized the satire as "not [being] the sort of sharp social satire we would expect from ''South Park''."<ref name="tvsquad">{{cite web| date = October 7, 2010| author = Brad Trechak| title = 'South Park' Season 14, Episode 8 Recap| url = http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/10/07/south-park-season-14-episode-8-recap/| work = [[TV Squad]]| publisher = Aol}}</ref>Writing for ''[[The Yorker]]'', Simon Cocks wrote that the episode turned out to be "reliable yet ultimately disappointing".<ref name="yorker">{{cite web| date = October 11, 2010| author = Simon Cocks| title = Returning season: South Park| url = http://www.theyorker.co.uk/news/film/5471| work = The Yorker| publisher =}}</ref>Merrill Barr of ''[[Film School Rejects]]'' was more positive, calling "Poor and Stupid" a "fine episode of ''South Park''".<ref name="filmschoolrejects">{{cite web| date = October 7, 2010| author = Merrill Barr| title = Review: South Park – Poor and Stupid| url = http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/tv/review-south-park-%E2%80%93-poor-and-stupid.php| work = Film School Rejects| publisher = Neil Miller}}</ref>None of the NASCAR drivers lampooned in "Poor and Stupid" were reported to be offended by their depiction in the episode. Driver [[Jeff Gordon]] said that he thought, although the episode was making fun of NASCAR, it was still good publicity for the sport.<ref name="b-hamnews">{{cite web| date = October 9, 2010| author = Doug Demmons| title = Drivers approve of South Park's 'Poor and Stupid' spoof of NASCAR| url = http://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2010/10/drivers_says_south_parks_poor.html| work = The Birmingham News| publisher =}} Jeff Gorden</ref>==Home release=="Poor and Stupid", along with the thirteen other episodes from ''South Park'''s fourteenth season, were released on a three-disc [[DVD]] set and two-disc [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] set in the United States on April 26, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/South-Park-Season-14/14998|title=''South Park - 'The Complete 14th Season' Formally Announced; Seems it Really IS Complete!|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com |date=2011-07-02 |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>==References=={{Reflist}}==External links=={{wikiquote}}* [http://www.southparkstudios.com/full-episodes/s14e08-poor-and-stupid "Poor and Stupid"] Full episode at South Park Studios* [http://www.southparkstudios.com/guide/episodes/s14e08-poor-and-stupid "Poor and Stupid"] Episode guide at South Park Studios* {{imdb episode|1708917}}* {{tv.com episode|south-park/poor-and-stupid-1344696}}{{South Park episodes|14}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Poor And Stupid}}[[Category:South Park (season 14) episodes]][[Category:Motorsports in fiction]][[Category:NASCAR on television]][[Category:Sports animation]])

(1	Matt Miller (left-handed pitcher)	{{other people||Matthew Miller (disambiguation)}}{{distinguish|Matt Miller (right-handed pitcher)}}{{Infobox baseball biography| image =<!-- only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people. Non-free and "fair use" images, promo photos, etc., will be deleted - see [[WP:NONFREE]] -->|name=Matt Miller|position=[[Pitcher]]|bats=Left|throws=Left|birth_date={{Birth date and age|1974|08|2|mf=y}}|birth_place=[[Lubbock, Texas]]|debutleague = MLB|debutdate=May 8|debutyear={{Baseball year|2001}}|debutteam=[[Detroit Tigers]]|finalleague = MLB|finaldate=April 4|finalyear={{Baseball year|2002}}|finalteam=Detroit Tigers|statleague = MLB|stat1label=[[Win (baseball)|Win-Loss]]|stat1value=0-0|stat2label=[[Earned run average]]|stat2value=7.84|stat3label=[[Strikeout]]s|stat3value=7|teams=*Detroit Tigers ({{Baseball year|2001}}–{{Baseball year|2002}})}}'''Matthew "Matt" Lincoln Miller ''' (born August 2, 1974 in [[Lubbock, Texas]]) is a former [[left-handed]] [[Major League Baseball]] [[pitcher]] who played for the [[Detroit Tigers]].Miller attended [[Monterey High School (Lubbock)|Monterey High School]] before attending [[Texas Tech University]], both in Lubbock, Texas. In the 1996 draft, Miller was drafted in the 2nd round by the [[Detroit Tigers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/players/m/millema01.shtml |title=Matt Miller Statistics and History |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-02}}</ref> Miller played collegiately with the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders baseball|Texas Tech Red Raiders baseball team]]. He made his debut May 8, 2001 for the Tigers against the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/boxes/DET/DET200105080.shtml |title=May 8, 2001 Texas Rangers at Detroit Tigers Box Score and Play by Play |publisher=Baseball-Reference.com |date=2001-05-08 |accessdate=2013-09-02}}</ref>==References=={{Reflist}}==External links=={{Baseballstats|br=m/millema01}}*[http://mlb.mlb.com/team/player.jsp?player_id=400078 MLB.com player info page]{{DEFAULTSORT:Miller, Matt}}[[Category:1974 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Major League Baseball pitchers]][[Category:Baseball players from Texas]][[Category:Detroit Tigers players]][[Category:Texas Tech Red Raiders baseball players]][[Category:Sportspeople from Lubbock, Texas]])
(1	Ivan Allen Jr. Braves Museum and Hall of Fame	[[File:1995 World Series trophy.JPG|thumb|right|175px|The [[1995 World Series]] [[Commissioner's Trophy (MLB)|Commissioner's Trophy]] on display in the museum]]The '''Ivan Allen Jr. Braves Museum and Hall of Fame''' (BMHF) was founded in 1999,<ref name=Museum&HOF>{{cite web|title=Museum and HOF|work=atlantabraves.mlb.com|url=http://atlanta.braves.mlb.com/atl/ballpark/information/index.jsp?content=museum|accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref> to honor various players, managers, coaches, executives, and others who have been a part of the [[Atlanta Braves]] professional-baseball franchise during its years in Boston (1871–1952), Milwaukee (1953–1965), and/or Atlanta (1966–present).<ref name=Museum&HOF/> The Museum and [[Hall of Fame]], named after former [[Atlanta]] mayor [[Ivan Allen Jr.]], was located in [[Turner Field]] on the northwest side at Aisle 134.<ref name=Museum&HOF/>==Exhibits====="Braves Hall of Fame"===[[File:Hank aaron jersey.jpg|thumb|175px|The jersey [[Hank Aaron]] wore when he broke [[Babe Ruth]]'s [[500 home run club#Members|home run record]] on display in the museum's "Atlanta" exhibit]]The Braves Hall of Fame consists of 24 members who contributed to the franchise during its 138 seasons, whether they were players, managers, broadcasters, or owners.====Braves Hall of Fame members===={| class="wikitable"|+Key!scope="row" |Year|Year inducted|-!scope="row" style="background:#ffb;"|  '''Bold'''|Member of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Baseball Hall of Fame]]|-!scope="row" style="background:#ffb;"| {{center|{{dagger}}}}|Member of the Baseball Hall of Fame as a Brave|-!scope="row" style="background:#cfc;"|  '''Bold'''|Recipient of the Hall of Fame's [[Ford C. Jones]] || [[Center fielder|CF]] || 1996–2007|-| — || style="background:#ffb;"|'''[[John Schuerholz]]''' || Executive || 1990–present|}==="City" Exhibits===[[File:Braves Museum.JPG|right|thumb|250px|Individual exhibits for the Braves' NL championship seasons as seen in the "Atlanta" exhibit]]The museum featured three "city" exhibits (for Boston, Milwaukee, and Atlanta) that each featured items and information for the Braves from their times in that respective city. Included in these exhibits were "Babe Ruth as a Brave" and the [[1914 World Series]] exhibit from Boston, a section of an original [[Baltimore and Ohio Railroad]] Car and the [[1957 World Series]] exhibit from Milwaukee, and [[Hank Aaron]]'s 715th home run exhibit and the [[1995 World Series]] exhibit with replica rings and the [[Commissioner's Trophy (MLB)|Commissioner's Trophy]] from Atlanta.==="Braves in Cooperstown"===This exhibit featured photos of all who played for the Braves franchise who are members of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|National Baseball Hall of Fame]].====Braves in National Baseball Hall of Fame===={{Baseball hall of fame list| Current Team Name = Atlanta Braves| All Team Names = Braves| ColorA# = 13274F| ColorB# = FFFFFF| ColorC# =
