Schuerholz' plaque will not bear a cap because he was elected as an executive.|}}==="The Transformation of Turner Field"===This exhibit showed how [[Centennial Olympic Stadium]] was transformed into [[Turner Field]] following the [[1996 Summer Olympics]].==="Braves Leaderboard"===This exhibit featured a large scoreboard that tracked current players' progress into breaking Braves franchise pitching and hitting records.==Move to SunTrust Park==The Braves decided against building a museum into [[SunTrust Park]], instead preferring to have the memorabilia throughout the new park.<ref>https://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/news/2017/03/13/atlanta-braves-suntrust-park-won-t-have-a-museum.html</ref>==See also==*{{section link|Atlanta Braves award winners and league leaders|Braves Hall of Fame}}*[[Ty Cobb Museum]]*[[Georgia Sports Hall of Fame]]*[[List of museums in Georgia (U.S. state)]]==References=={{Reflist}}==External links==*[http://atlanta.braves.mlb.com/atl/ballpark/information/index.jsp?content=museum Braves Museum and Hall of Fame] official webpage{{Atlanta Braves}}[[Category:Atlanta Braves]][[Category:Major League Baseball museums and halls of fame|Atl]][[Category:Halls of fame in Georgia (U.S. state)]][[Category:Sports museums in Georgia (U.S. state)]][[Category:Baseball in Georgia (U.S. state)]][[Category:Sports in Atlanta]][[Category:Museums in Atlanta]][[Category:Defunct museums in Georgia (U.S. state)]][[Category:Museums established in 1999]][[Category:Museums disestablished in 2016]][[Category:1999 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]][[Category:2016 disestablishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]])
(1	Tracey Cross	{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}}{{Use Australian English|date=September 2015}}{{Infobox sportsperson|| name = Tracey Cross| image = 201000 - Opening Ceremony Athletes Oath swimmer Tracey Cross - 3b - 2000 Sydney opening ceremony photo.jpg| imagesize =| caption = Cross takes the official Athletes Oath at the 2000 Summer Paralympics Opening Ceremony| fullname = Tracey Nicole Cross| nicknames =| nationality = {{AUS}}| club =| collegeteam =| birth_date = 4 December 1972| birth_place = [[Bunbury, Western Australia]]| death_date =| death_place =| height =| weight =| medaltemplates={{MedalSport |Swimming}}{{MedalCompetition|[[Paralympic Games]]}}{{MedalGold | [[1992 Summer Paralympics|1992 Barcelona]] |Women's 100&nbsp;m Freestyle B1}}{{MedalGold | [[1992 Summer Paralympics|1992 Barcelona]] |Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle B1}}{{MedalGold | [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Atlanta]] |Women's 100&nbsp;m Butterfly B1}}{{MedalGold | [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Atlanta]] |Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley B1}}{{MedalSilver | [[1992 Summer Paralympics|1992 Barcelona]] |Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke B1}}{{MedalSilver | [[1992 Summer Paralympics|1992 Barcelona]] |Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley B1}}{{MedalSilver | [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Atlanta]] |Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle B1}}{{MedalSilver | [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney]] |Women's 100&nbsp;m Freestyle S11}}{{MedalSilver | [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney]] |Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle S11}}{{MedalBronze | [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney]] |Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle S11}}{{MedalCompetition | World Championships and Games for the Disabled}}{{MedalGold | 1990 Assen|Women's 100&nbsp;m Freestyle B1}}}}'''Tracey Nicole Cross''', [[Order of Australia|OAM]]<ref name="oam">{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=886365&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=Cross, Tracey Nicole: Medal of the Order of Australia|publisher=It's an Honour|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> (born 4 December 1972)<ref name=dob-loc>{{cite web|archiveurl=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/nph-arch/2000/Z2000-Jan-20/http://www.ausport.gov.au/olym96/paraswim.html|url=http://www.ausport.gov.au/olym96/paraswim.html |title=Australians at the 1996 Atlanta Paralympics: Swimmers|archivedate=20 January 2000|publisher=[[Australian Sports Commission]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> is an Australian visually impaired swimmer.  She won ten medals at three Paralympics, from 1992 to 2000.==Personal==Cross was born in the Western Australian city of [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]] on 4 December 1972.<ref name="dob-loc"/> She has been blind since birth; in a 2000 interview, she said that the light perception that she had in one eye was "almost useless".<ref name="smh">{{cite news|title=Why every stroke counts for Cross|publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|first=Philip|last=Derriman|date=11 October 2000|page=40|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news001011_0126_5327|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref> She was left out of sporting activities at school, and started swimming at the age of 15.<ref name="smh"/> She took the sport casually at first, but took it more seriously when she found that she had a natural aptitude for swimming.<ref name="smh"/>In 1994, she obtained a law degree from [[Murdoch University]]. After working in that field for some years, she became a [[massage|massage therapist]]; she works in a natural health clinic in [[West Perth, Western Australia|West Perth]]. Cross developed her passion for massage after she sustained a neck and shoulder injury while training for the [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney Paralympics]].<ref name="smh"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.centrohealth.com.au/practitioners-at-centro-health/remedial-massage-therapist-tracey-cross/|title=Tracey Cross – Remedial Massage Therapist|publisher=Centro Health|accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>==Swimming career==[[File:221000 - Swimming Tracey Cross action - 3b - 2000 Sydney event photo.jpg|thumb|left|Action shot of Cross in the pool during competition at the 2000 Summer Paralympics]]Cross won her first international gold medal in the women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 at the 1990 World Championships and Games for the Disabled in [[Assen]], Netherlands.<ref name="profile">{{cite web|archiveurl=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/nph-arch/2000/S2000-Dec-5/http://www.paralympic.org.au/athletes/athleteprofile695f.html|url=http://www.paralympic.org.au/athletes/athleteprofile695f.html|archivedate=5 December 2000|title=Athlete's Profile: Tracey Cross|publisher=[[Australian Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=World Championships and Games for the Disabled – Athletics Results|year=1990|publisher=Organising Committee|location=Netherlands}}</ref>At the [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Barcelona Games]], she won two gold medals in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 and Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 events, and two silver medals in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke B1 and Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley B1 events;<ref name=IPC>{{cite web|title=Athlete Search Results|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/search.php?sport=all&games=all&medal=all&npc=all&name=Cross&fname=Tracey&gender=all|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> she also came fourth in both the Women's 100&nbsp;m Butterfly B1<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=B1&sport=swimming&competition=1992PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=100%20m%20Butterfly|title=1992 Women's 100&nbsp;m Butterfly Results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> and Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=B1&sport=swimming&competition=1992PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=50%20m%20Freestyle|title=1992 Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref>She won two gold medals at the [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Atlanta Games]] in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Butterfly B1 and the Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley B1 events, and a silver medal in the Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle B1 event;<ref name="IPC"/> she also came fifth in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke B1 event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=B1&sport=swimming&competition=1996PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=100%20m%20Backstroke|title=1996 Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke B1 –  Results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> and came seventh in the heats of the Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle B2 event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=B2&sport=swimming&competition=1996PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=400%20m%20Freestyle|title=1996 Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle B2 – Results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref>She spoke the [[Paralympic symbols|Paralympic oath]] at the opening ceremony of the [[2000 Summer Paralympics|2000 Sydney Paralympics]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Honour for swimmer|publisher=[[Illawarra Mercury]]|date=16 October 2000|page=7|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?docID=news001017_0166_0030|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref> In the competition, she received two silver medals in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Freestyle S11 and the Women's 400&nbsp;m Freestyle S11 events, and a bronze medal in the Women's 50&nbsp;m Freestyle S11 event;<ref name="IPC"/> she also came fifth in the Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley SM11 event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=SM11&sport=swimming&competition=2000PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=200%20m%20Medley|title=2000 Women's 200&nbsp;m Medley SM11 – results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> and eighth in the Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke S11 event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org/ipc_results/results.php?eclass=S11&sport=swimming&competition=2000PG&gender=f&discipline=&event=100%20m%20Backstroke|title=2000 Women's 100&nbsp;m Backstroke S11 – Results|publisher=[[International Paralympic Committee]]|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref>==Recognition==In 1993, Cross received a [[Order of Australia|Medal of the Order of Australia]] for her 1992 Paralympic gold medals.<ref name="oam"/> In that year, she also received the [[Western Australian Citizen of the Year Award]] in the Youth category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebratewa.com.au/61/sport|title=WA Citizen of the Year Awards|publisher=Celebrate WA|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> On 14 November 2000, she received an [[Australian Sports Medal]] "For Service to Sport as a gold Medallist at the Paralympic Games".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=972131&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=Cross, Tracey Nicole: Australian Sports Medal|publisher=It's an Honour|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> She received a [[Centenary Medal]] on 1 January 2001 "For service to the community through Paralympic swimming".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1123287&search_type=quick&showInd=true|title=Cross, Tracey: Centenary Medal|publisher=It's an Honour|accessdate=9 January 2012}}</ref> In 2009, she was inducted into the Swimming Western Australia Hall of Fame.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wa.swimming.org.au/hall-of-fame.html|title=Hall of Fame|publisher=Swimming Western Australia|accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>==References=={{reflist|2}}{{Paralympic Oath}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Cross, Tracey}}[[Category:Female Paralympic swimmers of Australia]][[Category:Swimmers at the 1992 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Swimmers at the 1996 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Swimmers at the 2000 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Medalists at the 1992 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Medalists at the 1996 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Medalists at the 2000 Summer Paralympics]][[Category:Paralympic gold medalists for Australia]][[Category:Paralympic silver medalists for Australia]][[Category:Paralympic bronze medalists for Australia]][[Category:Recipients of the Medal of the Order of Australia]][[Category:Recipients of the Australian Sports Medal]][[Category:Recipients of the Centenary Medal]][[Category:People from Bunbury, Western Australia]][[Category:Sportswomen from Western Australia]][[Category:Murdoch University alumni]][[Category:Visually Impaired category Paralympic competitors]][[Category:Blind people from Australia]][[Category:1972 births]][[Category:Living people]])
(1	2001 CARIFTA Games	{{Infobox Athletics Championships|Name = XXX CARIFTA Games|Logo =|Size =  200px|Colour =|Optional caption =|Host city = [[Bridgetown]], [[Barbados]] {{flagicon|Barbados}}|Dates = April 14–16|Stadium =|Nations participating =  about 23|Athletes participating =  about 382 <br> (220 junior, 162 youth)|Events = 62 <br> (35 junior (incl. 4 open), 27 youth)|Records set = 7 games records|Level = Junior and Youth|Previous = [[2000 CARIFTA Games|2000 St. George's]]|Next = [[2002 CARIFTA Games|2002 Nassau]]}}The 30th '''[[CARIFTA Games]]''' was held in [[Bridgetown]], [[Barbados]], on April 14–16, 2001.    An appraisal of the results has been given on the occasion of 40th anniversary of the games,<ref name=nevisaaa>{{ Citation| last = Clarke| first = Clayton| date =| title = 40 years of Carifta…… Ten years ago…………Bridgetown, Barbados| url = http://sites.google.com/site/nevisaaa/40-years-of-carifta| publisher = Nevis Amateur Athletic Association| accessdate = January 26, 2012}}</ref> and on the [[IAAF]] website.<ref name=iaaf>{{ Citation| last = Francis| first = Amadeo| date = Apr 19, 2001| title =  Jamaicans dominate the Carifta Games| url =  http://www.iaaf.org/news/printer,newsid=13573.htmx| publisher =  [[IAAF]]| accessdate = Feb 1, 2012}}</ref>==Participation (unofficial)==Detailed result lists can be found both on the CFPI<ref name=cfpi/> and on the "World Junior Athletics History" website.<ref name=wjah/>  An unofficial count yields the number of about 382 athletes (220 junior (under-20) and 162 youth (under-17)) from about 23 countries:  Antigua and Barbuda (7), Aruba (4), Bahamas (39), Barbados (54), Bermuda (11), British Virgin Islands (4), Cayman Islands (14), Dominica (7), French Guiana (1), Grenada (32), Guadeloupe (20), Guyana (6), Haiti (1), Jamaica (61), Martinique (36), Netherlands Antilles (5), Saint Kitts and Nevis (3), Saint Lucia (10), Saint Vincent and the Grenadines (4), Suriname (3), Trinidad and Tobago (47), Turks and Caicos Islands (7), US Virgin Islands (6).==Records==It is reported that a total of 9 games records were set.<ref name=iaaf/>  However, the reporting for the two relay records might be disputable.<ref name=cfpi/>In his first year as a junior. [[Darrel Brown]] from Trinidad and Tobago finished the 100 metres in 10.24s (wind: 0.0&nbsp;m/s).  Further records in the boys' U-20 category were established by [[Damion Barry]], also from Trinidad and Tobago, in 46.51s over 400 metres, and [[Damon Thompson]] from Barbados jumping 2.20m high.  It is stated<ref name=iaaf/> that the Trinidad and Tobago 4 × 100 metres relay team winning in 40.19s also set a new games record, but this is not marked as a record in the published results.<ref name=cfpi/>Moreover, two other sources<ref name=gbr1/><ref name=wjah1>{{ Citation| last = World Junior Athletics History| first =| date =| title = WORLD JUNIOR ATHLETICS HISTORY ("WJAH") CARIFTA Games 1997| url = http://www.wjah.co.uk/wojc/CAJG/CAJG1997.html| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref> list faster times of 39.87s for Jamaica at the [[1997 CARIFTA Games]], and 40.03s at the [[1998 CARIFTA Games]].<ref name=gbr1/><ref name=wjah2>{{ Citation| last = World Junior Athletics History| first =| date =| title = WORLD JUNIOR ATHLETICS HISTORY ("WJAH") CARIFTA Games 1998| url = http://www.wjah.co.uk/wojc/CAJG/CAJG1998.html| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref>In the girls' U-20 category, [[Veronica Campbell]] from Jamaica improved her own mark for 200 metres from the year before to 22.93 seconds (wind: -1.6&nbsp;m/s). [[Melaine Walker]] from Jamaica achieved 56.90s in 400 metres hurdles.In the boys' U-17 category, two new records were set: by [[Kern Harripersad]] from Trinidad and Tobago in 1:55.20 for 800 metres, and by Jamaican [[Patrick Lee (athlete)|Patrick Lee]] finishing the 100 metres hurdles in 13.20s (wind: -2.3&nbsp;m/s).Finally, in the girls' U-20 category, it is also stated<ref name=iaaf/> that the Jamaican 4 × 100 metres relay team winning in 45.44s set a new games record. Again, this is not marked as a record in the published results,<ref name=cfpi/> and two other sources<ref name=gbr4/><ref name=wjah3>{{ Citation| last = World Junior Athletics History| first =| date =| title = WORLD JUNIOR ATHLETICS HISTORY ("WJAH") CARIFTA Games 1999| url = http://www.wjah.co.uk/wojc/CAJG/CAJG1999.html| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref> list a faster time of 45.16s for Jamaica at the [[1999 CARIFTA Games]],==Austin Sealy Award==The [[CARIFTA Games#Austin Sealy Award Winners|Austin Sealy Trophy]] for the most outstanding athlete of the games was awarded to [[Veronica Campbell]] from Jamaica.<ref name=carifta1>{{ Citation| last =| first =| date =| title = Carifta Games Magazine, Part 2| url = http://www.cariftagames2011.herobo.com/web_documents/carifta_magazine_sm_part2.pdf| publisher = Carifta Games 2011| accessdate = Oct 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{ Citation| last =| first =| date =| title = Carifta Games Magazine, Part 3| url = http://www.cariftagames2011.herobo.com/web_documents/carifta_magazine_sm_part3.pdf| publisher = Carifta Games 2011| accessdate = Oct 12, 2011}}</ref>  She won 3 gold medals (100m, 200m, and 4 × 100m relay) in the junior (U-20) category.==Medal summary==Medal winners are published by category: Boys under 20 (Junior),<ref name=gbr1>{{ Citation| last = Athletics Weekly| first =| date =| title = CARIFTA GAMES (UNDER 20 MEN)| url = http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cfg.htm| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref> Girls under 20 (Junior),<ref name=gbr2>{{ Citation| last = Athletics Weekly| first =| date =| title = CARIFTA GAMES (UNDER 20 WOMEN)| url = http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cfgw.htm| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref> Boys under 17 (Youth),<ref name=gbr3>{{ Citation| last = Athletics Weekly| first =| date =| title = CARIFTA GAMES (UNDER 17 BOYS)| url = http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cfgy.htm| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref> and Girls under 17 (Youth).<ref name=gbr4>{{ Citation| last = Athletics Weekly| first =| date =| title = CARIFTA GAMES (UNDER 17 GIRLS)| url = http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cfgyw.htm| publisher =| accessdate = October 8, 2011}}</ref>Complete results can be found on the CFPI<ref name=cfpi>{{ Citation| last =| first =| date =| title = 30TH CARIFTA GAMES 2001, BRIDGETOWN, BARBADOS – Saturday April 14, 2001 to Monday April 16, 2001, COMPLETE RESULTS – ALL ROUNDS| url = http://www.cfpitiming.com/2001%20track%20season/Carifta_2001_results.htm| publisher =  C.F.P.I. Timing & Data| accessdate = October 15, 2011}}</ref> and the "World Junior Athletics History"website.<ref name=wjah>{{ Citation| last = World Junior Athletics History| first =| date =| title = WORLD (1	2011–12 Harvard Crimson men's basketball team	{{Good article}}{{Infobox NCAA team season|Mode=Basketball|Year=2011–12|Prev year=2010–11|Next year=2012–13|Team=Harvard Crimson| Logo =Harvard Crimson logo.svg| LogoSize = 200| LogoAlt =|Image=|ImageSize=|ImageAlt =|Conference=Ivy League|Division=|ShortConference=Ivy League|CoachRank=|APRank=|Record=26–5|ConfRecord=12–2|HeadCoach=[[Tommy Amaker]]|AsstCoach1=Brian Adams|AsstCoach2=Brian DeStefano|AsstCoach3=[[Yanni Hufnagel]]|Captain=Oliver McNally|Captain2=[[Keith Wright (basketball)|Keith Wright]]|StadiumArena=[[Lavietes Pavilion]]|Champion=[[Ivy League]] Champion<br>2011 [[Battle 4 Atlantis]] Champion|BowlTourney=[[2012 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2012 NCAA Division I Tournament]]|BowlTourneyResult=Second Round}}{{2011–12 Ivy League men's basketball standings}}The '''2011–12 Harvard Crimson men's basketball team''' represented [[Harvard University]] in the [[Ivy League]] athletic conference during the [[2011–12 NCAA Division I men's basketball season]]. The team played its home games in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] at the [[Lavietes Pavilion]], located across the [[Charles River]] from the university's main campus in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] with a capacity of 2,195.  The team was led by fifth-year [[head coach]] [[Tommy Amaker]] and senior co-[[captain (sports)|captains]] [[Keith Wright (basketball)|Keith Wright]] and Oliver McNally.<ref name=HMBMDI>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/videos/20111011|title=Harvard Men's Basketball Media Day Interviews|accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-10-11|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com}}</ref><ref name=MBAMD>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/releases/20111011_media_day|title=Men's Basketball Attends Media Day|accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-10-11|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com}}</ref>Harvard began the season 8–0, the best start by an Ivy League team since {{cbb link|1969|sex=men|team=Columbia Lions|school=Columbia University|title=Columbia}} won its first ten games to begin the [[1969–70 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|1969-70 season]].<ref name=ILMBW17>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_17.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: Week 17 • February 27, 2012|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2012-02-27|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=6}}</ref> On December 5, 2011, Harvard made its first-ever appearances in the [[AP Poll]] and the [[Coaches' Poll]], ranking 25th and 24th, respectively.<ref name="ESPN">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/7319295/duke-blue-devils-north-carolina-tar-heels-stand-ground-top-losses|title=Duke, UNC don't cede much in Top 25|accessdate=2011-12-05|date=2011-12-05|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> The season included two wins against teams in the powerhouse [[2011–12 Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball season|Atlantic Coast Conference]] (ACC).Harvard set a school record with 26 wins during the season and tied a school record for conference wins with 12. Its 14 non-conference wins also tied an Ivy League record previously held by the [[2009–10 Cornell Big Red men's basketball team|2009-10 Cornell Big Red]].<ref name=ILMBPW2p7>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Postseason_Release_2.pdf|title=2011-12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: Postseason - Week 2 • March 18, 2012|accessdate=2012-03-21|date=2012-03-18|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=7}}</ref> The season culminated in an invitation to the [[2012 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]], where Harvard lost in the second round. It was Harvard's first NCAA tournament appearance since 1946 and third consecutive appearance in a postseason tournament.<ref name=H2MBPG3>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/NotesGame_31_NCAA_Second_Round.pdf|title=Harvard 2011-12 Men's Basketball Postseason Guide|accessdate=2012-03-19|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com|page=3|format=.pdf}}</ref> Junior [[Kyle Casey]] was a first-team All-Ivy selection, while junior [[Brandyn Curry]] and senior Keith Wright earned second-team recognition.==Preseason==Harvard came into the 2011-12 season off of its first Ivy League championship and two school record-setting years in terms of total wins.<ref name=ANFFJA>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2009-10/releases/100310_Amaker_Jobe_Finalist|title=Amaker Named Finalist For Jobe Award|accessdate=2010-03-31|date=2010-03-10|publisher=Harvard University}}</ref><ref name=PaHKP>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/26/sports/ncaabasketball/26hoops.html|title=Princeton and Harvard Keep Pace|accessdate=2011-03-17|date=2011-02-25|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The [[2010–11 Harvard Crimson men's basketball team|2010–11 team]] that won the league championship during the [[2010–11 Ivy League men's basketball season]] had no seniors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/series/basketball-10-11/article/2010/11/11/basketball-supp-wright-111210/|title=Finding Mister Wright |accessdate=2011-03-06|date=2010-11-11|work=[[Harvard Crimson]]|author=Walsh, Timothy J.}}</ref> [[Ivy League Men's Basketball Player of the Year]] Keith Wright returned to the team as a senior, as did All-Ivy League juniors Kyle Casey, Brandyn Curry and Christian Webster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2010-11/releases/Mens_Basketball_All-Ivy_--_2010-11|title=Men's Basketball All-Ivy – 2010–11|accessdate=2011-03-12|date=2011-03-09|website=IvyLeagueSports.com}}</ref> Harvard entered the season with a 17-game home winning streak, the 10th-longest in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2010-11/weeklyreleases/2010-11_MBB_Final_Release.pdf|title=2010–11 Highlights|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=5}}</ref> Senior co-captain Oliver McNally entered the season with a 32-shot [[free throw]] streak,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/player/gamelog/_/id/41640/year/2011/oliver-mcnally|title=Oliver McNally Game-by-Game Stats (2010–11)|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> having finished second in the nation in [[free throw percentage]] the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/statistics/player/_/stat/free-throws/sort/freeThrowPct/year/2011|title=NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Player Free-Throw Shooting Statistics – 2010–11|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>The upperclassmen on the team came from the first top-25 recruiting class in Ivy League history.<ref name=IaNEaHNQoS>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/02/sports/ncaabasketball/02harvard.html?|title=In a New Era at Harvard, New Questions of Standards|accessdate=2010-04-02|date=2008-03-02|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Thamel, Pete}}</ref><ref name=TAHBio>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/coaches/amaker_tommy|title=Tommy Amaker|accessdate=2010-03-31|publisher=Harvard University}}</ref> Harvard and Wright won numerous preseason honors.  Wright was a preseason [[John R. Wooden Award]] Top 50 Watchlist honoree as well as a Lou Henson Preseason All-America team selection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_1.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: November 7, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-07|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=4}}</ref> Harvard was selected as the conference preseason favorite for the first time in school history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_1.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: November 7, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-07|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=6}}</ref> In addition, Harvard received preseason votes in the AP Poll, marking the fourth straight season it received votes at some point in the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_1.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: November 7, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-07|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=5}}</ref>The team's schedule included power conference opponents [[2011–12 Boston College Eagles men's basketball team|Boston College]] ([[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]]), [[2011–12 Utah Utes men's basketball team|Utah]] ([[Pac-12 Conference|Pac-12]]) and [[2011–12 Connecticut Huskies men's basketball team|Connecticut]] ([[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|Big East]]) as well as a possible second-round [[Battle 4 Atlantis]] match against [[2011–12 Florida State Seminoles men's basketball team|Florida State]] (ACC).  Expectations were high for Harvard, and a December 8 contest against Connecticut was the only Ivy League game scheduled for broadcast on [[ESPN2]] during the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_1.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: November 7, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-07|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=7}}</ref>==Schedule=={{CBB schedule start|attend=yes}}|-!colspan=9 style="background:#991111; color:#FFFFFF;"| Regular 67–63| overtime      =| attend       = 4,027| record        = 26–4 (12–2)}}|-!colspan=9 style="background:#991111; color:#FFFFFF;"| [[2012 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|<span style="color:#FFFFFF;">2012 NCAA Tournament</span>]]{{CBB schedule entry| date         = Mar. 15, 2012| time         = 4:45 p.m.| w/l          = l| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| away         =| neutral      = yes| rank         = (12)| opponent     = [[2011–12 Vanderbilt Commodores men's basketball team|Vanderbilt]]| opprank      = (5)| site_stadium = [[The Pit (arena)|The Pit]]| site_cityst  = [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]]| gamename     = East Regional Second round| tv           = [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]]| score        =  70–79| overtime     =| attend       = 10,774| record       = 26–5}}{{CBB schedule end| timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]]}}==Rankings=={{main|2011–12 NCAA Division I men's basketball rankings}}On December 5, 2011, Harvard made its first-ever appearance in either the [[AP Poll|AP]] (25th) or [[Coaches' Poll]] (24th).<ref name="ESPN"/> That left [[Brown Bears men's basketball|Brown]] as the only [[Ivy League]] school never to have been ranked in the AP Poll and left only seven Division I schools active since the poll began that have never been ranked in it.<ref name=HARVARD25>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/collegebasketballnation/post/_/id/41106/harvard-shakes-one-monkey-off-its-back|title=Harvard shakes one monkey off its back|author=Brennan, Eamonn|accessdate=December 5, 2011|date=December 5, 2011|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Harvard was the first Ivy League team ranked in the Coaches' Poll since the [[2009–10 Cornell Big Red men's basketball team|2009–10 Cornell Big Red]] and the first Ivy League team ranked in the AP Poll since the [[1997–98 Princeton Tigers men's basketball team|1997–98 Princeton Tigers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/releases/Harvard_Mens_Basketball_Appears_In_National_Polls|title=Harvard Men's Basketball Appears In National Polls|accessdate=2011-12-05|date=2011-12-05|website=IvyLeagueSports.com}}</ref> By January 2, the team achieved rankings of 22nd in the AP Poll and 21st in the Coaches' Poll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/rankings/_/year/2012/week/9/seasontype/2|title=2012 NCAA Men's Basketball Rankings – Week 9 (Jan. 2)|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2012-01-02|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> On February 6, the team again attained the ranking of 21st in the Coaches' Poll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/rankings/_/year/2012/week/14/seasontype/2|title=2012 NCAA Men's Basketball Rankings – Week 14 (Feb. 6)|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2012-02-06|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>{{Ranking Movements| poll1title     = [[AP Poll]]<ref name=rankings>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/rankings |title=2011–12 NCAA Men's Basketball Rankings |accessdate=October 21, 2011 |work=[[ESPN]] |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113173644/http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/rankings |archivedate=November 13, 2009 |df= }}</ref>| poll1firstweek = 0| poll1lastweek  =19| poll1_0=RV| poll1_1=RV| poll1_2=RV| poll1_3=RV| poll1_4=25| poll1_5=RV| poll1_6=RV| poll1_7=24| poll1_8=22| poll1_9=RV| poll1_10=RV| poll1_11=RV| poll1_12=RV| poll1_13=25| poll1_14=RV| poll1_15=RV| poll1_16=RV| poll1_17=RV| poll1_18=RV| poll1_19=| poll1_20=| poll2title     = [[Coaches Poll]]<ref name="rankings"/>| poll2firstweek = 0| poll2lastweek  =19| poll2_0=| poll2_1=| poll2_2=RV| poll2_3=RV| poll2_4=24| poll2_5=RV| poll2_6=25| poll2_7=23| poll2_8=21| poll2_9=25| poll2_10=24| poll2_11=23| poll2_12=23| poll2_13=21| poll2_14=RV| poll2_15=RV| poll2_16=RV| poll2_17=RV| poll2_18=RV| poll2_19=| poll2_20=| poll3title     = <!-- [[The Poll]] -->| poll3firstweek =| poll3lastweek  =| poll3_0=| poll3_1=| poll3_2=| poll3_3=| poll3_4=| poll3_5=| poll3_6=| poll3_7=| poll3_8=| poll3_9=| poll3_10=| poll3_11=| poll3_12=| poll3_13=| poll3_14=| poll3_15=| poll3_16=| poll3_17=| poll3_18=| poll3_19=| poll3_20=| poll4title     = <!-- [[The Poll]] -->| poll4firstweek =| poll4lastweek  =| poll4_0=| poll4_1=| poll4_2=| poll4_3=| poll4_4=| poll4_5=| poll4_6=| poll4_7=| poll4_8=| poll4_9=| poll4_10=| poll4_11=| poll4_12=| poll4_13=| poll4_14=| poll4_15=| poll4_16=| poll4_17=| poll4_18=| poll4_19=| poll4_20=| poll5title     = <!-- [[The Poll]] -->| poll5firstweek =| poll5lastweek  =| poll5_0=| poll5_1=| poll5_2=| poll5_3=| poll5_4=| poll5_5=| poll5_6=| poll5_7=| poll5_8=| poll5_9=| poll5_10=| poll5_11=| poll5_12=| poll5_13=| poll5_14=| poll5_15=| poll5_16=| poll5_17=| poll5_18=| poll5_19=| poll5_20=}}==Season==Harvard's season began with a Crimson [[Midnight Madness (basketball)|Madness]] event on October 15 where the team raised a 2010–11 Ivy League Championship banner and held an intrasquad scrimmage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/videos/20111015-arxgyz1o|title=Highlights: Harvard Men's Basketball Hosts Crimson Madness|accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-11-15|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/releases/20111015brzxi5|title=Men's Basketball Unveils Ivy Championship Banner at Crimson Madness|accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-11-15|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com}}</ref> The team opened the season with a victory over {{cbb link|2011|sex=men|team= MIT Engineers|school=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|title= MIT}} on November 11 that extended Harvard's win streak against MIT to nine games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313150108|title=Harvard 76, MIT 49|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2011-11-11|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>Following the victory over MIT, Harvard took part in the 2011 [[Battle 4 Atlantis]] Tournament. The team beat [[2011–12 Utah Utes men's basketball team|Utah]] 75–47 in the first game of the tournament,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313280254|title=Harvard 75, Utah 47|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-24|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> its first-ever win against a [[Pac-12 Conference]] opponent.<ref name=H2MBPG9/> On November 25, Harvard faced [[2011–12 Florida State Seminoles men's basketball team|Florida State]], which was then ranked 22nd in the AP poll and 20th in the Coaches' Poll. Harvard won that game 46–41 for the second-ever defeat of a ranked opponent in team history.<ref name=HucFStrtf>{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313290108|title=Harvard upsets cold-shooting Florida State to reach tourney final|accessdate=2011-11-28|date=2011-11-25|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> Harvard then matched up against [[2011–12 UCF Knights men's basketball team|UCF]] in the tournament final, winning 59–49.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313302116|title=Unbeaten Harvard wins Battle 4 Atlantis crown|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-26|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> Wright earned Ivy League player of the week for his performance in the Battle 4 Atlantis tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/2011-12_MBB_Release_Week_4.pdf|title=2011–12 Ivy League Men's Basketball: Week 4 • November 28, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-06|date=2011-11-28|website=IvyLeagueSports.com|page=5}}</ref> McNally extended his free-throw streak to 51 in the Florida State victory,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/player/gamelog/_/id/41640/year/2012/oliver-mcnally|title=Oliver McNally Game-by-Game Stats (2011–12)|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>  but his run ended in the final minutes of the UCF game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/playbyplay?gameId=313302116|title=Harvard 59 (6–0, 2–0 away); UCF 49 (4–2, 2–0 home); Complete Play-By-Play|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>The [[2008–09 Harvard Crimson men's basketball team|2008–09 team]] had previously defeated then-[[2008–09 NCAA Division I men's basketball rankings|ranked]] [[2008-09 Boston College Eagles men's basketball team|Boston College]] (17th in the AP Poll and 24th in the Coaches' Poll) for the first win over a ranked team in the program's history,<ref name=LphtruoN2B>{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=290070103|title=Lin powers Harvard to rare upset over No. 24 BC|accessdate=2010-04-02|date=2009-01-07|work=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> but lost to all ranked opponents in the 2009-10 and 2010-11 seasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/schedule/_/id/108/year/2010/harvard-crimson|title=Harvard Crimson Schedule – 2009–10|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/schedule/_/id/108/year/2011/harvard-crimson|title=Harvard Crimson Schedule – 2010–11|accessdate=2011-12-07|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> The win against Boston College was the 1000th in school history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/releases/20111229_BC_Recap|title=No. 23/24 Harvard Extends Win Streak Over BC to Four Games, Tops Eagles, 67-46|accessdate=2012-07-05|date=2011-12-29|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref> The Florida State victory was the school's second over a ranked team in its history and the highest-ranked opponent in the Coaches' Poll that Harvard has ever defeated. Florida State went on to win the [[2012 ACC Men's Basketball Tournament]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-baskbl/recaps/031112aaa.html|title=Florida State Wins the #ACCTRNY 85–82 over North Carolina: This is Florida State's first ACC Championship|accessdate=2012-03-14|date=2012-03-11|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|author=TheACC.com}}</ref>Harvard began the season 8–0, the best start by an Ivy League team since {{cbb link|1969|sex=men|team=Columbia Lions|school=Columbia University|title=Columbia}} won its first ten games to begin the [[1969–70 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|1969-70 season]].<ref name=ILMBW17/> Harvard, then ranked 25th in the AP poll and 24th in the Coaches' poll, next faced its most formidable challenge yet: [[2009-10 Connecticut Huskies men's basketball team|Connectucut]], which then had a 7–1 record and was ranked 9th in both polls. Harvard had the better record against common foes, Florida State and UCF (2–0 versus 1–1).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313300041|title=Shabazz Napier, Ryan Boatwright have big parts in UConn's OT win |accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-11-26|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313290041|title=UCF, trailing by 17, storms back to upset No. 4 UConn|accessdate=2011-12-07|date=2011-11-25|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Connecticut won the teams' previous meeting at [[Harry A. Gampel Pavilion]] in 2009 by a score of 79–73 as the [[2009-10 Connecticut Huskies men's basketball team|2009-10 Huskies]] (then ranked 14th in the AP Poll and 13th in the Coaches' Poll) survived a 30-point, 9-rebound effort by [[Jeremy Lin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=293410041|title=Dyson's 24 points, 14 boards help UConn fend off Harvard|accessdate=2011-12-09|date=2009-12-06|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Harvard lost the 2011 meeting 67–53.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313420041|title=No. 9 UConn spoils No. 24 Harvard's 1st game as a ranked team|accessdate=2011-12-09|date=2009-12-08|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>Harvard won its next four games, including victories over {{cbb link|2010|sex=men|team=Boston Terriers|school=Boston University|title=Boston University}} and [[2011–12 Boston College Eagles men's basketball team|Boston College]] for a season sweep of city rivals after beating MIT in November.<ref name=N2HrfUlwroBU>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313440104|title=No. 24 Harvard returns from UConn loss with romp over Boston U|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2011-12-10|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref name=N2HbBCffss>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=313630103|title=No. 23 Harvard beats Boston College for fourth straight season|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2011-12-29|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Harvard's victory over Boston College was its fourth in a row against the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] team,<ref name=N2HbBCffss/> giving it five consecutive wins overall against ACC teams, including its only two wins against ranked opponents.<ref name=HucFStrtf/><ref name=LphtruoN2B/><ref name=N2HbBCffss/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/history/yrbyyrresults|title=Harvard Men's Basketball All-Time Results|accessdate=2012-07-07|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/history/seriesrecords|title=Harvard Men's Basketball All-Time Series Records|accessdate=2012-07-07|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=293430103|title=Harvard 74, Boston College 67|accessdate=2012-07-07|date=2009-12-09|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=310050103|title=Harvard 78, Boston College 69|accessdate=2012-07-07|date=2011-01-05|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> After rising to 21st in the Coaches' Poll and 22nd in the AP Poll, [[2011–12 Fordham Rams men's basketball team|Fordham]] upset Harvard 60&ndash;54 in January.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=320032230|title=Bryan Smith, Chris Gaston lead Fordham by No. 21 Harvard|accessdate=2012-06-30|date=2012-01-03|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> A 65&ndash;35 win over [[2011–12 Yale Bulldogs men's basketball team|Yale]] three weeks later was Harvard's widest margin of victory against its Ivy League rival in 183 meetings.<ref name=H2MBPG/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=320270043|title=Laurent Rivard, Harvard rout Yale for 5th straight win|accessdate=2012-03-19|date=2012-01-27|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Harvard lost its third Ivy League game of the season, falling to [[2011–12 Princeton Tigers men's basketball team|Princeton]] on February 11, but avenged the loss in a home win on February 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=320550108|title=Harvard rallies from 10 down to edge Princeton|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2012-02-24|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> That victory gave Harvard a new school record for single-season wins as well as single-season non-league wins and tied the record for conference game wins.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/GameNotes29.pdf|title=Harvard Basketball Game Notes (HARVARD (24–4, 10–2) vs.COLUMBIA (14–14, 3–9))|accessdate=2012-03-05|date=2012-03-02|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref> A day after beating Princeton, however, Harvard lost to [[2011–12 Penn Quakers men's basketball team|Penn]], snapping a 28-game home winning streak dating to February 20, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=320560108|title=Penn tops Harvard to throw Ivy League race wide open|accessdate=2012-03-04|date=2012-02-25|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/schedule/_/id/108/year/2010/harvard-crimson|title=Harvard Crimson Schedule – 2009–10|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/schedule/_/id/108/year/2011/harvard-crimson|title=Harvard Crimson Schedule – 2010–11|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/schedule/_/id/108/year/2012/harvard-crimson|title=Harvard Crimson Schedule – 2011–12|accessdate=2012-03-05|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref> Nonetheless, Harvard finished the season with a 26–4 overall record. The team won [[2011–12 Ivy League men's basketball season|Ivy League regular-season title]] and earned its first invitation to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA tournament]] since 1946. Harvard entered the tournament with a 2–1 record against teams in the field and was seeded 12th in the East Region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/releases/20120312_Vanderbilt_Preview|title=Going Dancing: No. 12 Seed Harvard Readies for Fifth-Seeded Vanderbilt; Thursday's Game Shown Live on TNT|accessdate=2012-03-19|date=2012-03-12|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref> Harvard lost in the second round of the [[2012 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|tournament]] to fifth-seeded [[2011–12 Vanderbilt Commodores men's basketball team|Vanderbilt]] on March 15 by a score of 79&ndash;70.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/Game_Notes_-_Vanderbilt_vs._Harvard.pdf|title=NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament Notes: Game No. 2 – (5) Vanderbilt vs. (12) Harvard Thursday, March 15, 2012 • "The Pit" • Albuquerque, NM|accessdate=2012-03-19|date=2012-03-15|publisher=GoCrimson.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=320750238|title=Vanderbilt overcomes Harvard's late charge to advance|accessdate=2012-03-19|date=2012-03-15|publisher=[[ESPN]]}}</ref>Harvard set a school record by selling out 10 of 12 home games at Lavietes Pavilion (the sellouts came in all seven Ivy League matchups, as well as versus MIT, [[2011–12 Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball team|Saint Joseph's]], and [[2011–12 George Washington Colonials men's basketball team|George Washington]]).<ref name=H2MBPG>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/NotesGame_31_NCAA_Second_Round.pdf|title=Harvard 2011-12 Men's Basketball Postseason Guide|accessdate=2012-03-19|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com|page=7|format=.pdf}}</ref> All five of Harvard's starters and 12 total players returned from the previous year's championship team, but freshmen accounted for over 22% of minutes played in the 2011-12 season.<ref name=H2MBPG/> By sweeping its four games against Massachusetts rivals, Harvard extended an in-state winning streak to 14 games.<ref name=H2MBPG/> The program also defeated teams from a record-setting 11 conferences, plus an independent.<ref name=H2MBPG/> Other school records set during the season included best Ivy League start and most road wins, with 12.<ref name=H2MBPG9>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/NotesGame_31_NCAA_Second_Round.pdf|title=Harvard 2011-12 Men's Basketball Postseason Guide|accessdate=2012-03-19|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|website=GoCrimson.com|page=9|format=.pdf}}</ref> Harvard's 14 non-conference wins in the regular season tied an Ivy-League record.<ref name=ILMBPW2p7/>==Honors=====In-season===Each week the Ivy League selected a player of the week and a rookie of the week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivyleaguesports.com/sports/mbkb/2011-12/weeklyreleases/index|title=2011–12 Men's Basketball Weekly Releases|accessdate=2011-12-06|website=IvyLeagueSports.com}}</ref>{| the [[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]] to its 10-man All-District I (ME, VT, NH, RI, MA, CT) team, while [[Tommy Amaker]] was named the All-District I Coach of the Year.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.sportswriters.net/usbwa/news/2012/alldistrict120306.html| work=| publisher=[[United States Basketball Writers Association|U.S. Basketball Writers Association]]| title=USBWA Names 2011–12 Men's All-District Teams| accessdate=2012-03-06|date=2012-03-06}}</ref> The [[National Association of Basketball Coaches]] announced its Division&nbsp;I All‐District 13 team on March 14, recognizing the nation’s best men’s collegiate basketball [[student-athlete]]s. Keith Wright was a first-team selection, while Kyle Casey was a second-team selection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nabc.com/NABC_Releases/releases/2011-12_NABC_Releases/2012_NABC_Division_I_All-District_teams.pdf|format=PDF| work=| publisher=[[National Association of Basketball Coaches]]| title=National Association of Basketball Coaches Announces 2012 Division I All-District Teams| accessdate=2012-03-14|date=2012-03-14}}</ref> Wright was also selected to participate in the NABC 2012 [[Reese's College All-Star Game|Reese's Division I All-Star Game]] at the 2012 NCAA Tournament [[final four]].<ref>{{cite Division I All-Star Game|accessdate=2012-04-14|date=2012-03-26|website=IvyLeagueSports.com}}</ref>The following players earned Ivy League postseason recognition:<ref>{{cite 2011–12|accessdate=2012-03-12|date=2012-03-07|website=IvyLeagueSports.com}}</ref>;First Team All-Ivy*Kyle Casey, (Jr., F, [[Medway, Massachusetts|Medway, Mass.]]);Second Team All-Ivy*[[Brandyn Curry]], (Jr., G, [[Huntersville, North Carolina|Huntersville, N.C.]])*Keith Wright, (Sr., F, [[Suffolk, Virginia|Suffolk, Va.]])==Notes=={{reflist|colwidth=30em}}==External [[ESPN.com]]*[http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/team/stats/_/id/108/year/2012/harvard-crimson Season stats] at [[ESPN.com]]{{Harvard Crimson men's basketball navbox}}{{DEFAULTSORT:2011-12 (1	Tony Levine	{{Infobox college coach| name = Tony Levine| image = Tony_Levine.jpg| alt =| caption =| sport = [[American football|Football]]| birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|10|28}}<ref name="Pike">{{cite web |url=http://www.arenafan.com/players/Tony_Levine-957 |title=Tony Levine |publisher=ArenaFan |accessdate=2012-10-16}}</ref>| birth_place = [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]]| death_date =| death_place =| alma_mater =| player_years1 = 1992–1995| player_team1 = [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota]]| player_years2 = 1996| player_team2 = [[Minnesota Fighting Pike]]| player_positions = [[Wide receiver]]| coach_years1 = 1996| coach_team1 = [[Highland Park High School (Minnesota)|Highland Park HS (MN)]] (freshman)| coach_years2 = 1997–1999| coach_team2 = [[Texas State Bobcats football|Texas State]] (WR/TE)| coach_years3 = 2000–2001| coach_team3 = [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]] ([[Graduate assistant|GA]])| coach_years4 = 2002| coach_team4 = [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|Louisiana Tech]] (ST/TE)| coach_years5 = 2003| coach_team5 = [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville]] (football ops)| coach_years6 = 2004–2005| coach_team6 = [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville]] (ST/OLB)| coach_years7 = 2006–2007| coach_team7 = [[Carolina Panthers]] ([[Strength and conditioning coach|asst. S&C]]/asst. ST)| coach_years8 = 2008–2011| coach_team8 = [[Houston Cougars football|Houston]] (ST/TE/outside WR)| coach_years9 = 2011–2014| coach_team9 = [[Houston Cougars football|Houston]]| coach_years10 = 2016| coach_team10 = [[Western Kentucky Hilltoppers football|Western Kentucky]] (ST/TE)| coach_years11 = 2017| coach_team11 = [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] (ST/Co-OC/TE)| overall_record = 21–17| bowl_record = 1–1| tournament_record =| championships =| awards =| coaching_records =}}'''Anthony Michael "Tony" Levine''' (born October 28, 1972) is a former [[American football]] who last coached at [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] as the special teams coordinator, co-offensive coordinator, and tight ends coach. He is a former head coach for the [[Houston Cougars football]] team.A walk-on [[wide receiver]] for the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] under [[Jim Wacker]], Levine became a three-year starter and was twice named to the Academic All-[[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] team. After his graduation from Minnesota, Levine played [[arena football]] for the [[Minnesota Fighting Pike]] in 1996.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mndaily.com/1996/05/10/levine-extends-football-career-minnesota-fighting-pike |title=Levine extends football career with Minnesota Fighting Pike |date= May 10, 1996 |author=Todd Zolecki |newspaper=Minnesota Daily |accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Before coming to Houston, the St. Paul native coached at [[Texas State Bobcats football|Texas State]], [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]], [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|Louisiana Tech]], [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville]] and the NFL's [[Carolina Panthers]].==Early and personal life==Tony Levine was born in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]], to Marvin and Harriet Levine, and is Jewish.<ref name="PennLive">{{cite web |url=http://blog.pennlive.com/davidjones/2011/12/penn_state_will_face_jazzy_hou.html |title=Penn State will face jazzy Houston Cougars offense and their jazz-loving new coach Tony Levine |author=Jones, David |publisher=''[[The Patriot-News]]'' |date=2011-12-30 |accessdate=2012-10-17}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>[http://jhvonline.com/uh-coach-takes-pride-in-family-football-p13573-102.htm UH coach takes pride in family, football<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated3>[http://jhvonline.com/levine-joins-jewish-exodus-of-houston-sports-scene-p18363-256.htm Levine joins Jewish exodus of Houston sports scene<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  His father, Marvin Levine, worked as a [[certified public accountant]] and played big-band trumpet.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/158213/tony-levine-the-most-popular-football-coach-in-houston Meet Tony Levine: The Most Popular Football Coach in Houston – Tablet Magazine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated4>[http://thedailycougar.com/2013/10/18/levine-travels-lengthy-path-to-uhs-top-job/ Levine travels lengthy path to UH's top job - The Daily Cougar<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>  His mother, Harriet, was a high school [[guidance counselor]].<ref name=autogenerated1 />  His brother, Jeffrey Levine is now an amazing band and orchestra director at [[Bloomington Jefferson High School|Jefferson High School]] in [[Bloomington, Minnesota]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jeffersonbandboosterclub.com/leadership|title=Leadership - Jefferson Band Booster Club|website=www.jeffersonbandboosterclub.com|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> Both maternal and paternal grandmothers of Tony Levine were pianists.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> Levine said his parents stressed to him the significance of family among Jewish traditions, and that it impacts his approach to coaching football.<ref name=autogenerated2 />He and his wife Erin have four children (Ben, Asher, Willa, and Eli).<ref name=autogenerated2 />==High school and college==Attending [[Highland Park High School (Minnesota)|Highland Park High School]] in Saint Paul, Levine was a member of the marching band, where he excelled at saxophone.  He became a two-time musical high school All-American at saxophone.<ref name="PennLive" /><ref name=autogenerated4 />As a high school junior, he joined the football team for the first time, and played [[wide receiver]].  His senior year, Levine was chosen for the Minnesota All-State team.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> He graduated in 1991.  While offered musical scholarships to the [[University of Rochester]], [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana University]], [[University of North Texas]] and [[University of Wisconsin–Eau Claire]], he did not pursue a musical degree.<ref name="PennLive" />In football, Levine was recruited by [[South Dakota State Jackrabbits football|South Dakota State]] and [[Hamline Pipers|Hamline]], but did not receive any [[Division I FBS|Division I-A]] scholarships.<ref name="PennLive" />  However, he received a call from a [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota]] assistant, Dave Spiegler, to invite him to [[Walk-on (sports)|walk-on]] as a receiver, which he accepted.<ref name="PennLive" /><ref name="Daily">{{cite news |url=http://thedailycougar.com/2013/10/18/levine-travels-lengthy-path-to-uhs-top-job |title=Levine travels lengthy path to UH's top job |author=Valderas, Andrew |publisher=''[[The Daily Cougar]]'' |date=October 18, 2013 |accessdate=October 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2 />  Levine paid for his first two years at Minnesota independently.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_20349129/charley-walters-notre-dames-harrison-smith-fits-vikings |title=Charley Walters: Notre Dame's Harrison Smith fits Vikings' needs |author=Walters, Charley |publisher=''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]'' |date=2012-04-07 |accessdate=2012-10-15}}</ref>  During the second game of the [[1993 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|1993 season]] against [[Indiana State Sycamores football|Indiana State]], Levine substituted for injured teammate Omar Douglas.  In that game, he caught seven passes for 121 yards.  Head coach [[Jim Wacker]] then offered Levine a scholarship, and eventually made Levine a starter for the team in the 1994 and 1995 seasons. In his three years playing for the team, he was a two-time Academic All-[[Big Ten]] Team member.<ref name=autogenerated2 />He earned two [[masters degree]]s, one in [[physical education]] from [[Texas State]] in 1999 and one as an [[educational specialist]] in adult education from [[Auburn University|Auburn]] in 2003.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[http://www.purduesports.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/tony_levine_1034693.html PURDUESPORTS.COM - Tony Levine Bio - Purdue University Official Athletic Site<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>==Professional playing career==After finishing his career at Minnesota, Levine joined the [[Minnesota Fighting Pike]] of the [[Arena Football League]].  However, his professional career only lasted the [[1996 Minnesota Fighting Pike season|1996 season]], as the team folded thereafter.  In his season with the Fighting Pike, he received 8 passes for a total of 83 yards and 1 touchdown.<ref name="Pike" />==Coaching career=====Early coaching career===In 1996 Levine began his career as a coach, when he returned to his high school alma mater, Highland Park High School. He served as head coach of the freshmen team before he departed for Texas for a position at [[Texas State Bobcats football|Texas State]]. During his time there, Levine rented an apartment at Pennington Funeral Home in Downtown San Marcos upon learning of the location from head coach [[Bob DeBesse]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/sports/cougars/article/UH-coach-Levine-s-old-home-was-deathly-quiet-3822600.php |title=UH coach Levine's old home was deathly quiet |author=Duarte, Joseph |publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' |date=2012-08-28 |accessdate=2012-10-30}}</ref>  His monthly salary consisted of $976.00, and he did not own an automobile.  Levine walked approximately one mile to campus each day.  He simultaneously attended classes as a student, and earned a master's degree in physical education from the university in 1999.  One of Levine's pupils at Texas State was [[Travis Bush]] whom he would later hire as an assistant when he became head coach at Houston.<ref name="Daily" />His next career move was to move to [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]].  Similar to his time spent at Texas State, Levine attended classes at the university, and eventually earned a degree at Auburn as an [[Educational specialist]] in adult education in 2003.He later held coaching positions at [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|Louisiana Tech]], [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville]] and the NFL's [[Carolina Panthers]].===Houston===Tony Levine was hired by Houston head coach [[Kevin Sumlin]] to be the special teams coordinator in 2008.  During his time in this position, Houston achieved great success, and finished the [[2011 Houston Cougars football team|2011&nbsp;season]] undefeated in regular season play.He was named interim head football coach of the Cougars after Sumlin left for Texas&nbsp;A&M; however, on December 21—eleven days before the Cougars were due to play in the [[2012 TicketCity Bowl]]—Houston dropped the "interim" from Levine's title and formally named him as the school's 12th head coach partly because of Levine's commitment to continuity. The Cougars then defeated No.&nbsp;22 [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] in the TicketCity Bowl.<ref name=Fox26>Berman, Mark. [http://www.myfoxhouston.com/dpp/sports/ncaa_football/111210-kevin-sumlin-is-leaving-the-university-of-houston Kevin Sumlin is Leaving the University of Houston]. [[KRIV (TV)|KRIV]], 2011-12-10.</ref><ref>Khan, Sam Jr. [http://www.chron.com/sports/cougars/article/Sumlin-leaves-post-as-UH-head-coach-2394351.php Sumlin leaves post as UH head coach].  [[Houston Chronicle]], 2011-12-10.</ref><ref>[http://espn.go.com/dallas/story/_/id/7337943/texas-aggies-hire-houston-cougar-kevin-sumlin-source-says Source: Kevin Sumlin to coach A&M]. [[ESPN]], 2011-12-10.</ref>  Houston finished No.&nbsp;14 in the Coaches Poll for 2011.Levine was relieved after three seasons at Houston on December 8, 2014, with an overall record of 21-17, and three bowl appearances.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Levine was let go because his Cougars struggled to win games in which they were heavily favored. On what seemed to be a promising year, the Cougars lost their inaugural game in [[TDECU Stadium]] to UTSA 27-7--a disappointment compounded by the loss in the opening game to Texas State 30-13 two years prior.<ref>[https://www.si.com/college-football/2014/12/06/tony-levine-fired-houston-cougars "Houston coach Tony Levine fired after Cougars' 7-5 campaign"]</ref>===Western Kentucky===Levine was hired by [[Jeff Brohm]] to be the Co-offensive Coordinator, Special Teams Coordinator and Tight Ends Coach at [[Western Kentucky Hilltoppers football|Western Kentucky]].===Purdue===On December 31, 2016, Levine was hired by new [[Purdue Boilermakers football]] head coach, Jeff Brohm, as the team's Special Teams Coordinator, Co-Offensive Coordinator and tight ends coach.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/college-football/story/purdue-boilermakers-tony-levine-hire-jeff-brohm-coordinator-123116 |title=Purdue's Jeff Brohm adds former Houston head coach Tony Levine to his staff |author=Bruce Feldman |date=December 31, 2016 |publisher=Fox Sports |work=www.foxsports.com |accessdate=December 31, 2016}}</ref>==Head coaching record=={{CFB Yearly Record (1	Khaled Gahwji	{{Infobox football biography| name      = Khaled Gahwji| image =| fullname = Khaled Gahwji| birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1975|07|07}}| birth_place = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]]| height = {{height|meters=1.70}}| position = [[midfielder]]| years1 =   1994–2004| years2 =   2004–2007| years3 =   2007–2010| clubs1 = [[Al-Ahli (Jeddah)|Al-Ahli]]| clubs2 = [[Al-Ittihad (Jeddah)|Al-Ittihad]]| clubs3 = [[Jeddah Club]]| caps1 =  200| goals1 = 37| caps2 =  15| goals2 = 3| caps3 =  50| goals3 = 4| nationalyears1 = 1999| nationalteam1 = [[Saudi Arabia national football team|Saudi Arabia]]| nationalcaps1 = 2| nationalgoals1 = 0}}'''Khaled Gahwji''' [خالد قهوجي in Arabic] (born 1975) is a Saudi [[association football|football]] player.==Career=={{Cleanup-rewrite|it consists of poor English which does not make sense|section|date=August 2016}}"Khaled Gahwji" Saudi player [[Al-Ahli (Jeddah)|Al-Ahli]] already in 2004 moved to [[Al-Ittihad (Jeddah)|Al-Ittihad]] 3 million riyals has to ensure that the President (Mansour Balawi), and now he plays in [[Al-Rabee]] in Saudi Arabia. Of the best players [[Midfielder]] in Saudi Arabia, one of the players who have a mass as large as the star [[Yousuf Al-Thunayan]] and [[Sami Al-Jaber]] and legendary [[Majed Abdullah]] and the stars [[Fahad Al-Bishi]] and [[Fahad Al-Ghesheyan]] and [[Mohammed Noor]] has the skills high and finishes in a which was like the team, but always excluded and is expected to be hands hidden excluded repeated it was the most beautiful epochs in the club [[Al-Ahli (Jeddah)|Al-Ahli]] emerged as remarkably even his nicknamed [[Arabian]] [[Diego Maradona|Maradona]]. Stories of the famous Khaled Gahwji story mentions that he was assaulted from the nearest of his friends after the conspiracy and was able to Khalid to escape from a small window, fell from the top floor on the ground of what the cause of his concussion and a broken jaw, but returned after a story about a month to play again for Al-Ahli. It was in addition to technical excellence was also a distinctive moral was to a large degree of good morals.==Honours=====Club===*'''[[Al-Ahli (Jeddah)]]''':*[[Crown Prince Cup]]: 1997, 2003.:*[[Saudi Federation Cup]]: 2001, 2002.:*[[Gulf Club Champions Cup]]: 2002.:*[[Arab Champions League]]: 2003.===National Team===*'''Saudi Arabia football National team''':*[[1999 FIFA Confederations Cup]]: 4th Place==References=={{reflist}}*{{FIFA player|70090}}{{Saudi Arabia Squad 1999 FIFA Confederations Cup}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Gahwji, Khaled}}[[Category:1975 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Saudi Arabian footballers]][[Category:Al-Ahli Saudi FC players]][[Category:Ittihad FC players]][[Category:Jeddah Club players]][[Category:Sportspeople from Jeddah]][[Category:Saudi First Division players]][[Category:Saudi Professional League players]])

(1	Steve Slattery	{{Infobox athlete|name = Steve Slattery|image =|imagesize =|caption =| sport = [[Track and field#Running|Track]]| event = [[1500 meters]], [[3000 meters]], [[5000 metres|5000 meters]], [[3000 meters steeplechase]]| nationality = [[Americans|American]]|alias =|club =|birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|8|14}}|birth_place = [[Flanders, New Jersey]]|collegeteam = [[University of Colorado at Boulder|Colorado]]|height =|weight =|turnedpro =|retired =|pb = '''[[Mile run|Mile]]''': 3:56.75<ref name="All-Athletics">{{cite web|url=http://www.all-athletics.com/node/97870|author=All-Athletics|title=Profile of Steve Slattery}}</ref> <br> '''[[3000 meters]]''': 7:50.76<ref name="All-Athletics"/> <br> '''[[Two miles|2-mile]]''': 8:37.95<ref name="All-Athletics"/> <br> '''[[5000 meters]]''': 13:36.03<ref name="All-Athletics"/>|olympics =|worlds =|highestranking =|coaching =|updated =|medaltemplates =}}'''Steve Slattery''' (born August 14, 1980) is an American [[track and field]] athlete who is a [[steeplechase (athletics)|steeplechase]] specialist. He has a personal record 8:15.69 minutes for the event and was the 2003 American outdoor champion. He has represented the United States at the [[World Championships in Athletics]] on two occasions (2003, 2005) and has also competed at the [[2006 IAAF World Indoor Championships]] and the [[2006 IAAF World Cup]].==Running career=====High school===Raised in the [[Flanders, New Jersey|Flanders]] section of [[Mount Olive Township, New Jersey]], he attended [[Mount Olive High School (New Jersey)|Mount Olive High School]] and established himself as a distance runner while there, receiving four high school [[All-America]] honors before graduating in 1998.<ref>Lambert, Jim. [http://www.nj.com/hssports/blog/boyscrosscountry/index.ssf/2012/09/steve_slattery_one_of_njs_distance_runners_ever_is_headed_into_the_mount_olive_hall_of_fame.html "Steve Slattery, a NJ distance running legend, is headed into the Mount Olive Hall of Fame"], NJ Advance Media for [[NJ.com]], September 24, 2012. Accessed November 6, 2017. "I haven't covered many runners blessed with the kind of talent or who ran with the kind of heart that Steve Slattery showed during his days at Mount Olive High.... After graduating from Mount Olive in 1998, Slattery took that same drive and passion to Colorado with him where he flourished under Jersey native Mark Wetmore, especially in the grueling steeplechase."</ref> He made his international debut that year at the [[1998 IAAF World Cross Country Championships]], finishing 40th in the junior race.===Collegiate===He went on to attend the [[University of Colorado]] from 1998 to 2002. During that time he was the 2001 [[Big 12 Conference]] champion in the steeplechase and came tenth at the [[Athletics at the 2001 Summer Universiade|2001 World Student Games]]. He was the runner-up at the [[NCAA Men's Outdoor Track and Field Championship]] as well as the [[USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships]] in 2002. While at the University of Colorado he met his future wife, [[Sara Slattery|Sara Gorton]], another distance runner.<ref name=USATFBio>[http://www.usatf.org/athletes/bios/TrackAndFieldArchive/2008/Slattery_Steve.asp Steve Slattery]. USATF. Retrieved on 2012-05-28.</ref>===Professional===After college he signed a contract with [[Nike, Inc|Nike]] and won his first national title at the 2003 USA Outdoor Championships.<ref>[http://www.usatf.org/statistics/champions/USAOutdoorTF/men/m3000mSC.aspUSA Outdoor Track & Field Champions Men's 3,000 m Steeplechase]. USATF. Retrieved on 2012-05-28.</ref> Slattery made his senior international debut at the [[2003 World Championships in Athletics]] and ran a personal record time of 8:22.32 minutes in the heats.<ref name=IAAFBio>[http://www.iaaf.org/athletes/biographies/country=usa/athcode=138477/index.html Slattery Steve]. [[IAAF]]. Retrieved on 2012-05-28.</ref> He failed to build on this success the following year and missed a spot on the Olympic team after finishing fifth at the [[United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|United States Olympic Trials]]. In 2005 he set a personal record time of 8:17.87 minutes at the [[FBK Games]], the fastest by an American that year. A third-place finish at the USA Outdoors brought him his second world championship appearance,<ref name=USATFBio/> although he was again eliminated in the heats at the [[2005 World Championships in Athletics|2005 World Championships]].<ref name=USATFBio/> In 2006 he represented the United States in the [[3000 meters]] flat at the [[2006 IAAF World Indoor Championships – Men's 3000 metres]] and in the steeplechase at the [[2006 IAAF World Cup]]. He was the runner-up at the usatf national championships that year and his season's best time of 8:22.70 minutes was second in the American rankings.<ref name=USATFBio/>Slattery set a new best of 8:15.69 minutes at the 2007 [[Memorial Van Damme]] meeting (second fastest American that year) and was third in the steeplechase at the [[Prefontaine Classic]]. Despite this form, he failed to finish at the USA Outdoor Championships.<ref name=USATFBio/> As one of the fastest performers on the circuit, he was invited to the [[2007 IAAF World Athletics Final]] in [[Stuttgart]], where he finished eighth.<ref name=IAAFBio/> He came second at the 2008 [[Reebok Grand Prix]] in [[New York City]] with a run of 8:28.21 minutes, but failed to finish at the Olympic Trials final. After a low-key 2009, he returned to form on the [[2010 IAAF Diamond League]] circuit and came third at the [[2010 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships|2010 USA Outdoor Nationals]]. In 2011 he ran a season's best of 8:28.52 minutes at the [[Shanghai Golden Grand Prix]], but pulled out of the steeplechase heats at the national championships.<ref name=IAAFBio/>==References=={{reflist|30em}}==External links==*{{IAAF name|138477}}{{Footer US NC Steeplechase Men}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Slattery, Steve}}[[Category:Living people]][[Category:1980 births]][[Category:American male long-distance runners]][[Category:American male steeplechase runners]][[Category:Colorado Buffaloes track and field athletes]][[Category:People from Mount Olive Township, New Jersey]][[Category:Sportspeople from Morris County, New Jersey]][[Category:Track and field people from New Jersey)

(1	Acht van Chaam	{{Infobox cycling race| name        = Acht van Chaam| image       = Anefo 911-3332 "Acht van Chaam".jpg| date        = End of July| region      = [[Chaam]], Netherlands| english     = Eight of Chaam| localnames  = Acht van Chaam {{nl icon}}| nickname    =| discipline  = [[Road bicycle racing|Road]] race| competition =| type        = [[Criterium]]| organiser   =| director    =| first       = '''Men''': {{start date|1932}}<br />'''Women''': {{start date|2001}}| number      = '''Men''': 75 (as of 2013)<br />'''Women''': 12 (as of 2012)| last        =| firstwinner = '''Men'''<br />{{flagathlete|[[Matthijs van Oers]]|NED}}<br />'''Women'''<br />{{flagathlete|[[Monique Knol]]|NED}}| mostwins    = '''Men'''<br />{{nowrap|{{flagathlete|[[Karel Kaers]]|BEL}}}}<br />{{nowrap|{{flagathlete|[[Rik Van Steenbergen]]|BEL}}}}<br />{{nowrap|{{flagathlete|[[Jo de Roo]]|NED}}:''3 wins''}}'''Women'''<br />{{nowrap|{{flagathlete|[[Leontien van Moorsel]]|NED}}}}<br />{{nowrap|{{flagathlete|[[Marianne Vos]]|NED}}:''3 wins''}}| mostrecent  = '''Men'''<br />{{flagathlete|[[Marcel Kittel]]|GER}}<br />'''Women'''<br />{{flagathlete|[[Nina Kessler]]|NED}}}}'''Acht van Chaam''' ({{lang-en|Eight of Chaam}}) is an elite men's and women's professional [[road bicycle racing]] event held annually in [[Chaam]], [[Netherlands]]. The first edition was in 1932 and since 1992 the event also includes a women's race.<ref name="men">{{cite web|title=Acht van Chaam|url=http://www.cyclingarchives.com/wedstrijdfiche.php?wedstrijdid=5|publisher=cyclingarchives.com|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref><ref name="women">{{cite web|title=Acht van Chaam (F)|url=http://www.cyclingarchives.com/wedstrijdfiche.php?wedstrijdid=14704|publisher=cyclingarchives.com|accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref>== Results ===== Men ===Source:<ref name="men" />{| class="wikitable"! (1	1991 IAAF World Cross Country Championships – Junior women's race	{{Infobox XC Championships|Name       = Junior women's race at the 1991 IAAF World Cross Country Championships|Logo       =|Size       =|Caption    =|Organisers = [[IAAF]]|Edition    = 19th|Date       = March 24|Host city  = [[Antwerpen]], [[Antwerp (province)|Antwerpen province]], [[Belgium]] {{flagicon|Belgium}}|Location   = [[Linkeroever]] Racecourse|Nations participating  = 30|Athletes participating = 127|Races      = 1|Distances  = 4.435 km – Junior women|Website    =|Previous   = [[1990 IAAF World Cross Country Championships – Junior women's race|1990 Aix-les-Bains]]|Next       = [[1992 IAAF World Cross Country Championships – Junior women's race|1992 Boston]]}}The '''Junior women's race''' at the '''[[1991 IAAF World Cross Country Championships]]''' was held in [[Antwerpen]], [[Belgium]], at the [[Linkeroever]] Racecourse on March 24, 1991.   A report on the event was given in the [[New York Times]].<ref name=times_01>{{ Citation| last = Bloom| first =  Marc| date = March 25, 1991| title = CROSS COUNTRY; Jennings Retains World Title| url = team result</small>==Participation==An unofficial count yields the participation of 127 athletes from 30 countries in the Junior women's race. (1	Wrestling at the 2015 European Games	{{Infobox FILA wrestling event|Name = Wrestling at the 2015 European Games|Logo =|Size = 150|Host city = {{flagicon|AZE}} [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]]|dates = June 13–18|Stadium = [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex|Heydar Aliyev Sports Arena]]|Freestyle =|Greco-Roman =|Women =}}{{Wrestling at the 2015 European Games}}The '''[[Wrestling]]''' events for the '''[[2015 European Games]]''' will be held at the [[Heydar Aliyev Sports and Exhibition Complex|Heydar Aliyev Arena]], [[Baku]] from 13 to 20 June 2015. 24 events will be held, 16 in [[freestyle wrestling|Freestyle]] across both sexes, and 8 in the [[Greco-Roman wrestling|Greco-Roman]] style, for men only.<ref>[http://www.uec.ch/documents/news/2013/baku_2015_newsletter_eu_v2.pdf Newsletter]</ref>==Medalists=====Men's freestyle==={| {{MedalistTable|type=Event}}|-|rowspan=2|57&nbsp;kg<br/>{{DetailsLink|Wrestling at the 2015 European Games – Men's freestyle 57
