(1	Yvette Vaucher	'''Yvette Vaucher''' (née Pilliard; born 1929) is a Swiss [[mountaineer]] and [[parachutist]]. Credited as Switzerland's first female parachutist, she was also the first woman to climb the [[Matterhorn]]'s north face.==Biography==Vaucher was born in 1929 in [[Vallorbe]], Switzerland. She took up rock climbing in 1951 and climbed mainly on the [[Salève]] in the [[French Prealps]] near [[Geneva]], where she joined a group of women climbers who were regulars on the Salève.<ref name=women/><ref name=berg>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeitlupe.ch/uploads/media/1206_beg_alpinistin.pdf|title=Ein Leben am Berg|language=German|first=Usch|last=Vollenwyder|work=Zeitlupe|volume=6|year=2012|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> In 1955, she moved to [[Neuchâtel]], where she began free fall parachuting.<ref name=women/> She is credited as Switzerland's first female parachutist.<ref name=presse>{{cite web|url=http://www.la-salevienne.org/presseX.php?X=jn2012|work=Le Messager|title=Yvette Vaucher, une belle marraine pour Orjobet|date=August 2, 2012|first=Dominique|last=Ernst|accessdate=May 3, 2012|language=French}}</ref> She had made over 100 mountain descents via parachute before she formed a climbing team with [[Michel Vaucher]], a mountaineer whom she married in 1962.<ref name=women>{{cite book|title=Women Climbing: 200 Years of Achievement|year=1990|publisher=[[The Mountaineers Books]]|last=Birkett|first=Bill|last2=Peascod|first2=Bill}}</ref>One of Vaucher's most famous climbs was the [[Matterhorn]] in July 1965. When she reached the summit on July 14, she became the first woman to have climbed the Matterhorn's north face.<ref name=times>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19650715&id=svZRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H3QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7215,2416845|title=Swiss Housewife Steals Matterhorn Show|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=July 15, 1965|page=16-A|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> She made the ascent with her husband on the 100th anniversary of the first successful ascent of the mountain, and their "surprise climb" was noted to have "stole[n] the spotlight" from two other climbing teams who were planning to climb the Matterhorn at the same time with film crews to broadcast their ascent on live television.<ref name=times/> An article in the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' about the Vauchers' success was titled "Swiss Housewife Steals Matterhorn Show", and when interviewed about her plans after the descent, Yvette answered, "to go have a hair-do – fast."<ref name=times/>Yvette and Michel Vaucher made numerous significant climbs in the Alps throughout the 1960s and 1970s, including [[Piz Badile]], the [[Aiguille de Triolet]], the [[Aiguille du Dru]], the [[Eiger]], the [[Große Zinne]] and the [[Grandes Jorasses]]. In 1966, they made the first direct ascent of the north face of the [[Dent Blanche]].<ref name=women/> They climbed frequently with [[Loulou Boulaz]] and her partner [[Michel Darbellay]].<ref name=berg/>Vaucher and her husband joined an international expedition to [[Mount Everest]] headed by [[Norman Dyhrenfurth]] in 1971; she intended to become the first woman to reach the summit of Everest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Defeat on Everest|work=[[Life (magazine)|Life]]|pages=22–29|date=July 2, 1971|first=Murray|last=Sayle}}</ref> Tensions and conflict were rife within the team, however, and the expedition was ultimately unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Mountain: My Time on Everest|first=Ed|last=Viesturs|authorlink=Ed Viesturs|pages=235–245|year=2013|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]}}</ref> Vaucher, upset with Dyhrenfurth's leadership, is said to have thrown snowballs at him before leaving the expedition.<ref name=women/>Vaucher was denied membership of the [[Swiss Alpine Club]] until 1979, when she became one of the first women to be made an honorary member.<ref name=berg/><ref name=presse/> As of 2012, she continues to hike regularly in the Alps, despite having hip and knee replacements.<ref name=berg/>==References=={{reflist|30em}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Vaucher, Yvette}}[[Category:1929 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:Swiss mountain climbers]][[Category:Swiss skydivers]][[Category:Female climbers]][[Category:Sportspeople from Geneva]][[Category:People associated with the Matterhorn]])
(1	2014–15 Missouri Mavericks season	{{Infobox IcehockeyTeamSeason|Season = 2014–15|year = 2014|Team = Missouri Mavericks|League = ECHL|LeagueRank =|Conference = Western<ref name="ECHL Announces Home-and-Away Standings" />|GoalsFor = 192<ref name="ECHL 2014-15 Regular Season Conference Standings" /><ref name="ECHL 2014-15 Regular Season Division Standings" />|GoalsAgainst = 231<ref name="ECHL Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|PointsLeader = [[Sébastien Thinel]] (70)<ref name="Missouri Mavericks 2014-15 Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|PlusMinusLeader = [[Brett Stovin]] (+5)<ref name="Missouri Mavericks 2014-15 Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|PIMLeader = [[Ryley Grantham]] (116)<ref name="Missouri Mavericks 2014-15 Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|WinsLeader = [[Mike Clemente]] (13)<ref name="Missouri Mavericks 2014-15 Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|GAALeader = [[Mike Clemente]] (2.83)<ref name="Missouri Mavericks 2014-15 Regular Season Individual Statistics" />|prev_season = [[2013-14 Missouri Mavericks season|2013-14]]|next_season =}}The '''[[2014–15 ECHL season|2014–15]] [[Missouri Mavericks]] season''' is the 6th [[season (sports)|season]] of the [[ECHL]] franchise in [[Independence, Missouri]], a suburb of [[Kansas City, Missouri]].{{TOC limit|limit=4}}==Off-season==On May 21, 2014, Head Coach [[Scott Hillman]] announced his resignation from the Mavericks because he is "pursuing other hockey opportunities and wants to move to a community where he and wife Dalyn's sons can compete at the highest level."<ref name="Head Coach Scott Hillman Resigns from Mavericks (Kansas City Star)" /><ref name="Head Coach Scott Hillman Resigns from Mavericks (The Examiner)" />  On May 27, 2014, Hillman was named as the first Head Coach for the expansion [[Indy Fuel]] of the [[ECHL]].<ref name="Scott Hillman Named Head Coach of Indy Fuel" />On June 12, 2014 [[Richard Matvichuk]], a 14-year veteran [[Defenseman]] in the [[National Hockey League]], was announced as the new Head Coach for the Mavericks.<ref name="Richard Matvichuk Named Missouri Mavericks Head Coach" />  Matvichuk had spent the previous two seasons as the Assistant General Manager and Defensive Assistant for the [[Allen Americans]], also of the [[Central Hockey League]], during which time the team won two consecutive ''[[Ray Miron President's Cup]]'' league championships.<ref name="Richard Matvichuk Named Missouri Mavericks Head Coach" />On June 26, 2014, the Mavericks renewed their affiliation agreement for the 2014-15 season with the [[Chicago Wolves]] of the [[American Hockey League]].<ref name="Mavericks Announce Renewal of Affiliation Agreement with Chicago Wolves for 2014-15 Season" />Between July 1 and July 11, 2014, Mavericks fans voted for the [[Missouri Mavericks#Top-10 Missouri Mavericks Players Of All Time|Top-10 Mavericks players from the first 5 years of the team's existence]].  Beginning on July 15, 2014, ''[[The Examiner (Missouri)|The Examiner]]'' newspaper revealed the players one-per-day.<ref name="Missouri Mavericks Top-10 All-Time Players Named (2014) (Article 1)" /><ref name="Missouri Mavericks Top-10 All-Time Players Named (2014) (Article 2)" />On October 7, 2014, soon before the 2014&ndash;15 Central Hockey League season was set to begin, it was announced that the Central Hockey League ceased operations and the Mavericks, along with the [[Allen Americans]], [[Brampton Beast]], [[Quad City Mallards]], [[Rapid City Rush]], [[Tulsa Oilers]], and [[Wichita Thunder]], were all admitted to the [[ECHL]] for the [[2014–15 ECHL season]].<ref name="Central Hockey League Folds, Missouri Mavericks Join ECHL" />  All [[Central Hockey League]] contracts which had already been signed by players for the [[2014–15 ECHL season|2014-15 Central Hockey League season]] were immediately nullified, which forced the team to hastily attempt to re-sign as many players as possible to [[ECHL]] contracts.<ref name="Central Hockey League Folds, Missouri Mavericks Join ECHL (Article 2)" />  For the 2014-15 ECHL season, the Mavericks were designated to play in the Midwest Division of the Western Conference in the ECHL.<ref name="ECHL Announces Conference and Division Alignment and Playoff Format for 2014-15 Season" />In February 2015, [[Lamar Hunt Jr.]], son of former [[Kansas City Chiefs]] owner [[Lamar Hunt]], purchased the Mavericks outright from majority owner [[Matt Adams (ice hockey)|Matt Adams]], partners [[Mark Adams (ice hockey)|Mark Adams]] and [[Mike Carper]], and General Manager [[Brent Thiessen]], who had a minority stake in the organization.<ref name="Lamar Hunt Jr. Buys Missouri Mavericks" />  Hunt Jr. will own the team through his company [[Loretto Sports Ventures, LLC]].<ref name="Lamar Hunt Jr. Buys Missouri Mavericks" /><ref name="Lamar Hunt Jr. Buys Missouri Mavericks (Article 2)" />==Regular season=={{#section:2014–15 ECHL season|2014-15 ECHL Western Conference Regular Season Standings}}==Awards, records, and milestones=={|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;"|- align="center" bgcolor="dddddd"| '''Player/Team''' (1	Diving at the 2014 Commonwealth Games – Women's 10 metre platform	{{Infobox Commonwealth Games event|event = Women's 10 metre platform|games = 2014|image = [[Image:Diving pictogram.svg|50px]]|caption =|venue = [[Strathclyde Country Park]]|date = July 31|competitors = 12|nations = 4|gold = [[Meaghan Benfeito]]|goldCGA =CAN|silver = [[Pandelela Rinong]]|silverCGA = MAS|bronze = [[Roseline Filion]]|bronzeCGA=CAN|win_label = Winning points|win_value = 372.65|prev = [[Diving at the 2010 Commonwealth Games – Women's 10 metre platform|2010]]|next = [[Diving at the 2018 Commonwealth Games – Women's 10 metre platform|2018]]}}{{DivingAt2014CommonwealthGames}}The '''women's 10 metre platform''' was part of the [[Diving at the 2014 Commonwealth Games]] program. The competition was held on 31 July 2014 at [[Royal Commonwealth Pool]] in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Aquatics|url=https://www.glasgow2014.com/games/sports/aquatics|publisher=Glasgow 2014|accessdate=13 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413140856/https://www.glasgow2014.com/games/sports/aquatics|archivedate=13 April 2014|df=}}</ref>==Schedule==<small>All times are [[British Summer Time]] (UTC+1)</small>{| class="wikitable"! (1	Konstantin Tereshchenko	{{Eastern Slavic name|Alekseyevich|Tereshchenko}}{{Infobox racing driver| name              = Konstantin Tereshchenko| image             =| imagesize         = 290 px| caption           = Tereshchenko Konstantin.| nationality       = {{flagicon|RUS}} Russian| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1994|06|17|df=y}}| birth_place       = [[Moscow]], Russia| current series    = [[Euroformula Open Championship|Euroformula Open]]| first year        = [[2014 Euroformula Open season|2014]]| current team      = [[Campos Racing]]| car number        = 6| former teams      =| starts            = 32| wins              = 6| poles             = 8| fastest laps      = 6| best finish       = 2nd| year              = [[2015 Euroformula Open season|2015]]| prev series       = [[GP3 Series]]<br/>[[Formula Renault 2.0 Alps]]<br/>[[Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0]]<br>Formula Russia| prev series years = [[2014 GP3 Series season|2014]]-[[2015 GP3 Series season|15]]<br/>[[2012 Formula Renault 2.0 Alps season|2012]]–[[2013 Formula Renault 2.0 Alps season|13]]<br/>[[2012 Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 season|2012]]–[[2013 Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 season|13]]<br>2012–13| titles            = [[Spanish Formula Three]]<br>Formula Russia| title years       = [[2015 Euroformula Open season#Spanish Formula Three Championship|2015]]<br>2012| awards            =| award years       =}}'''Konstantin Alekseyevich Tereshchenko''' ({{lang-rus|Константи́н Алексе́евич Тере́щенко|p=kənstɐnʲˈtʲin ɐlʲɪˈksʲejɪvʲɪtɕ tʲɪrʲɛˈɕːinkə}}; born 17 June 1994) is a [[Russia]]n [[auto racing|racing]] driver.==Career=====Karting===Born in Moscow, Tereshchenko began [[karting]] in 2009 in the Junior class of the German karting championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://openracing.ru/pilots/tereshchenko_konstantin|title=Tereshchenko Konstantin|publisher=OpenRacing.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> For the next two years he competed in the [[KF2]] category, racing in various European karting championships.===Formula Renault===In [[2012 Formula Renault 2.0 Alps season|2012]], Tereshchenko moved into [[Open-wheel car|open-wheel racing]], competing in [[Formula Renault 2.0 Alps]] with the [[Interwetten Racing|Interwetten.com Racing Team]].<ref>{{cite news|date=10 March 2012|title=Nuovi volti nella F.Renault 2.0 Alps: Al via anche il figlio di Panis|work=[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]|publisher=[[RCS MediaGroup]]|page=36|url=http://www.renaultsportitalia.it/upload/renaultsport/20120310/La-Gazzetta-dello-Sport-20120310-pag-36.pdf|accessdate=15 March 2012|language=Italian|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|trans-title=New faces in the Alps Formula Renault 2.0: Starts the son of Panis}}</ref> He ended the season 32nd, without scoring a point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.driverdb.com/championships/standings/formula-renault-20-alps/2012/|title=Formula Renault 2.0 Alps 2012 standings|work=driverdb.com|publisher=Driver Database|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> He also had a part-time campaign in [[2012 Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 season|Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0]].Tereshchenko stayed with the team for the [[2013 Formula Renault 2.0 Alps season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.renaultsportitalia.it/en/art/news_20130304_alps_eng.html|title=Interwetten 2013 line-up will include Abogado, Mora and Tereshchenko|date=4 March 2013|work=Renault Sport Italia|publisher=Fast Lane Promotion|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> He improved to fifteenth position in the final series standings with four point-scoring positions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.driverdb.com/championships/standings/formula-renault-20-alps/2014/|title=Formula Renault 2.0 Alps 2014 standings|work=driverdb.com|publisher=Driver Database|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> He also competed in three rounds of the [[2013 Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0 season|Eurocup Formula Renault 2.0]].===Euroformula Open===Tereshchenko stepped up to the [[Euroformula Open Championship]], with [[Campos Racing]], in [[2014 Euroformula Open season|2014]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paddockscout.com/tereshchenko-joins-campos-for-debut-f3-open-season/|title=Tereshchenko joins Campos for debut F3 Open season|last=Khorounzhiy|first=Valentin|date=21 January 2014|publisher=Paddock Scout|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref>  He will remain with Campos Racing for a second season in 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thecheckeredflag.co.uk/2015/01/tereschenko-returns-campos-racing-2015/|title=Tereschenko returns to Campos Racing for 2015|first=Paul|last=Hensby|work=thecheckeredflag.co.uk|publisher=The Checkered Flag|date=27 January 2015|accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref>===GP3 Series===In [[2014 GP3 Series season|2014]], Tereshchenko will début in the [[GP3 Series]] with [[Trident Racing|Trident]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gp3series.com/News/2014/August/2014-GP3-Series-Round-6-Preview-Spa-Francorchamps-Belgium/ |title=2014 GP3 Series Round 6 Preview: Spa-Francorchamps, Belgium |date=21 August 2014 |work=[[GP3 Series]] |publisher=GP2 Motorsport Limited |accessdate=21 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140821230620/http://www.gp3series.com/News/2014/August/2014-GP3-Series-Round-6-Preview-Spa-Francorchamps-Belgium/ |archivedate=21 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> He suffered a spectacular rollover in his first free practice session at [[Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps|Spa]]; from which, according to commentators on American network [[NBCSN]], he acquired the nickname 'Cosmonaut'.===World Series===Tereshchenko made his debut with Spain's [[Teo Martín Motorsport]] at the opening round of the [[World Series Formula V8 3.5]] in [[2017 World Series Formula V8 3.5|2017]], where he is currently 8th in the championship, with a best result of 4th.==Racing record=====Career summary==={| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; text-align:center"! (1	2015 Missouri Tigers football team	{{Infobox NCAA team season|Year=2015|Prev year =2014|Team=Missouri Tigers|sport=football|Image=Mizzou Athletics wordmark.svg|ImageSize=250|Conference=Southeastern Conference|Division= Eastern Division|ShortConference=SEC|CoachRank=|APRank=|CFPRank=|Record= 5–7|ConfRecord= 1–7|HeadCoach= [[Gary Pinkel]]|HCYear= 15th|OffCoach= Josh Henson|OScheme=[[Spread offense|Spread]]|OCYear=3rd|DefCoach= [[Barry Odom]]|DCYear=1st|DScheme=[[4–3 defense|4–3]]|Captain=|Captain2=|Captain3=|Captain4=|StadiumArena=[[Faurot Field]]<br>(Capacity: 71,168)|Champion=|ConfChamp=|ConfChampResult=|BowlTourney=|BowlTourneyResult=}}{{2015 SEC football standings}}The '''2015 Missouri Tigers football team''' (also called "Mizzou") represented the [[University of Missouri]] in the [[2015 NCAA Division I FBS football season]]. It marked the Tigers' fourth season as a member of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) in the [[Southeastern Conference#Current members|Eastern Division]]. The team played its home games at [[Faurot Field]] in [[Columbia, Missouri]]. They were led by 15th year head coach [[Gary Pinkel]], in what would be his last season as the team's head coach.==Recruits=={{College athlete recruit start|40=yes|collapse=yes|year=2015}}{{College The 2015 schedule consist of 6 home games, 5 away games and 1 neutral game in the regular season. The Tigers will host SEC foes [[Florida Gators football|Florida]], [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State]], [[South Carolina Gamecocks football|South Carolina]], and [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]], and will travel to [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]], [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia]], [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]], and [[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]].<ref name="Mizzou15">{{cite press release |title=Mizzou Football 2015 Schedule Announced|url=http://www.mutigers.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/101414aab.html|publisher=University of Missouri Department of Athletics|date=October 14, 2014|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref>Missouri will host Mississippi State for the first time since 1984, when the Tigers were playing in the [[Big Eight Conference]], before joining the SEC 28 years later. That match–up against the Bulldogs will be the third Thursday night game hosted by Missouri in Tiger history. This will be the Tigers' first year without [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M]] on their schedule since 2009, and the first year without any team from [[Texas]] on its schedule since 1984.At the release of the 2015 schedule, Missouri was the only member in the SEC to not complete their entire schedule as the Tigers were still finalizing the game to be played on November 14. One month later after releasing of their schedule, Missouri announced that the game on November 14 would be played against [[BYU Cougars football|BYU]] at [[Arrowhead Stadium]] in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]].<ref name="BYU">{{cite press release |title=Arrowhead Stadium to Host Mizzou-BYU in 2015|url=http://www.mutigers.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111314aaa.html|publisher=University of Missouri Department of Athletics|date=November 13, 2014|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref>{{CFB Schedule Start|time=|rank=yes|ranklink=|rankyear=2015|tv=yes|attend=yes}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| date Reynolds Razorback Stadium]]| site_cityst  = [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville, AR]]| gamename = [[Battle Line Rivalry]]| tv           = [[SEC on CBS|CBS]]| score        = 3–28| attend       = 65,228}}{{CFB Schedule End|rank=|poll=[[2015 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings#AP Poll|AP Poll]] released prior to game|timezone=[[Central Time Zone (North America)|Central Time]]}}:'''Schedule Source:'''<ref>{{cite web |title=2015 Missouri Tigers Football Schedule|url=http://www.fbschedules.com/ncaa-15/sec/2015-missouri-tigers-football-schedule.php|publisher=FB Schedules|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref>==Rankings=={{Further|2015 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings}}{{NCAA Division I FBS CFP ranking movements| year            = {{2015}}| finalpollweek   = 15| cfpfirstweek    = 9| AP_pre          = 24| coaches_pre     = 23| AP_1            = 21| coaches_1       = 21| AP_2            = 22| coaches_2       = 20| AP_3            = 25| coaches_3       = 23| AP_4            = NR| coaches_4       = RV| AP_5            = RV| coaches_5       = RV| AP_6            = NR| coaches_6       = NR| AP_7            = NR| coaches_7       = NR| AP_8            = NR| coaches_8       = NR| AP_9            = NR| coaches_9       = NR| cfp_9           = NR| AP_10           = NR| coaches_10      = NR| cfp_10          = NR| AP_11           = NR| coaches_11      = NR| cfp_11          = NR| AP_12           = NR| coaches_12      = NR| cfp_12          = NR| AP_13           = NR| coaches_13      = NR| cfp_13          = NR| AP_14           = NR| coaches_14      = NR| cfp_14          = NR| AP_15           = NR| coaches_15      = NR}}==Campus protests and resignation of Tim Wolfe=={{main|2015 University of Missouri protests}}In the fall of 2015 there were a number of racially charged incidents at the University of Missouri campus.  Some students held protests, and some called for the resignation of university system president Tim Wolfe, who they said had not provided a sufficient response to the incidents.  On November 7 some members of the Missouri Tigers football team said that they would boycott all football-related activities until Wolfe resigned. Coach Pinkel stated that he supported the players. On November 9 Wolfe resigned as president.<ref>{{cite news |title=Black Football Players Lend Heft to Protests at Missouri|first1=Marc|last1=Tracy|first2=Ashley|last2=Southall|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/09/us/missouri-football-players-boycott-in-protest-of-university-president.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 8, 2015|accessdate=November 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Why Missouri's Football Team Joined a Protest Against School Administration|first1=Rohan|last1=Nadkarni|first2=Alex|last2=Nieves|url=https://www.si.com/college-football/2015/11/09/missouri-football-protest-racism-tim-wolfe|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=November 9, 2015|accessdate=November 9, 2015}}</ref>==References=={{Reflist|2}}{{Missouri Tigers football navbox}}[[Category:2015 Southeastern Conference football season|Missouri]][[Category:Missouri Tigers football seasons]][[Category:2015 in sports in Missouri|Missouri Tigers football]])
(1	Larry Nance Jr.	{{Infobox basketball biography| name            = Larry Nance Jr.| image           = Larry Nance Jr.jpg| image_size      =| caption         = Nance dunks in 2014| position        = [[Power forward (basketball)|Power forward]]| height_ft       = 6| height_in       = 9| weight_lb       = 230| league          = [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]| team            = Los Angeles Lakers| number          = 7| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1993|1|1}}| birth_place     = [[Akron, Ohio]]| nationality     = American| high_school     = [[Revere High School (Ohio)|Revere]] ([[Richfield, Ohio]])| college         = [[Wyoming Cowboys basketball|Wyoming]] (2011–2015)| draft_year      = 2015| draft_round     = 1| draft_pick      = 27| draft_team      = [[Los Angeles Lakers]]| career_start    = 2015| career_end      =| years1          = {{nbay|2015|start}}–present| team1           = [[Los Angeles Lakers]]| highlights      =* 2× First-team All-[[Mountain West Conference|MWC]] (2014, 2015)* MWC Defensive Player of the Year (2015)* 2× MWC All-Defensive Team (2014, 2015)| nba_profile = larry_nance| bbr         = nancela02}}'''Larry Donnell Nance Jr.''' (born January 1, 1993) is an American professional [[basketball]] player for the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). He played college basketball for [[Wyoming Cowboys men's basketball|Wyoming]],<ref name=realgm>{{cite web|title=Larry Nance Jr. Player Profile|url=http://basketball.realgm.com/player/Larry-Nance-Jr/Summary/30624|website=''[[RealGM]]''|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref> where he was considered one of the best big men in the [[Mountain West Conference]]<ref name=bio>{{cite web|title=Larry Nance Jr. Bio|url=http://www.gowyo.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/larry_nance_jr_765297.html|website=''GoWyo.com''|accessdate=17 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316203630/http://www.gowyo.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/larry_nance_jr_765297.html|archivedate=16 March 2015|df=}}</ref> after leading the 2014–15 Wyoming Cowboys to their first NCAA Tournament appearance since 2002.==High school and college career==Nance attended [[Revere High School (Ohio)|Revere High School]] near Akron, Ohio, growing into a then-6'7" body by his senior year after playing point guard for the freshman team standing at 5'11". He averaged 18.2 points, 9.5 rebounds and 3.0 blocks per game as a senior for the Minutemen.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pluto|first1=Terry|title=Larry Nance Jr. happy to continue his long, winding basketball road to Wyoming: Terry Pluto|url=http://www.cleveland.com/pluto/blog/index.ssf/2011/05/larry_nance_jr_happy_to_contin.html|accessdate=26 June 2015|agency=The Plain Dealer|issue=9 May 2011|publisher=Plain Dealer Publishing Co.}}</ref>In his four-year college career at [[Wyoming Cowboys basketball|Wyoming]], Nance averaged 11.3 points, 6.6 rebounds, 1.4 assists, 1.1 steals, and 1.1 blocks in 123 games.<ref>{{cite web|title=Larry Nance Stats|url=http://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/larry-nance-2.html|work=Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=June 26, 2015}}</ref>===College statistics==={{NBA player statistics start}}|-| style="text-align:left;"| [[2011–12 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2011–12]]| style="text-align:left;"| [[2011–12 Wyoming Cowboys basketball team|Wyoming]]| '''33''' || 0 || 17.9 || .462 || .333 || '''.814''' || 4.0 || .4 || .8 || .6 || 4.1|-| style="text-align:left;"| [[2012–13 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2012–13]]| style="text-align:left;"| [[2012–13 Wyoming Cowboys basketball team|Wyoming]]| '''33''' || '''33''' || 32.0 || .533 || '''.345''' || .750 || 6.9 || 1.2 || 1.3 || .7 || 10.7|-| .243 || .758 || '''8.6''' || 1.6 || '''1.4''' || '''2.1''' || 15.4|-| style="text-align:left;"| [[2014–15 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2014–15]]| style="text-align:left;"| [[2014–15 Wyoming Cowboys basketball team|Wyoming]]| 31 || 31 || '''34.9''' || .514 || .333 || .786 || 7.2 || '''2.5''' || 1.2 || 1.2 || '''16.1'''|- class="sortbottom"| style="text-align:center;" colspan=2| Career| 123 || 90 || 29.5 || .521 || .308 || .771 || 6.6 || 1.4 || 1.1 || 1.1 || 11.3{{S-end}}==Professional career=====Los Angeles Lakers (2015–present)===On June 25, 2015, Nance was selected with the 27th overall pick in the [[2015 NBA draft]] by the [[Los Angeles Lakers]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/150625_nancedraft | title=Lakers Select Larry Nance in First Round | work=NBA.com | date=June 25, 2015 | accessdate=June 27, 2015}}</ref> On July 10, he signed his rookie scale contract with the Lakers.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/150710_nanceSigns | title=Lakers Sign Larry Nance, Jr. | work=NBA.com | date=July 10, 2015 | accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> He made his NBA debut on November 6 against the [[Brooklyn Nets]], recording six points and five rebounds in a 104–98 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20151106/LALBKN/gameinfo.html|title=Bryant, Lakers beat winless Nets for 1st victory|work=NBA.com|date=November 6, 2015|accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref> On December 7, he made his first start for the Lakers after replacing [[Julius Randle]] at the starting power forward spot against the [[Toronto Raptors]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/n/nancela02/gamelog/2016/|title=Larry Nance Jr. 2015-16 Game Log|work=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> On December 27, he recorded his first career double-double with 17 points and 11 rebounds in a 112–96 loss to the [[Memphis Grizzlies]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20151227/LALMEM/gameinfo.html|title=Conley, Green lead Grizzlies past Lakers, 112-96|work=NBA.com|date=December 27, 2015|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref>On November 20, 2016, Nance scored a career-high 18 points in a 118–110 loss to the [[Chicago Bulls]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400899648|title=Jimmy Butler's 40 points boost Bulls past Lakers, 118-110|work=ESPN.com|date=November 20, 2016|accessdate=November 20, 2016}}</ref> On December 25, 2016, he was ruled out for four weeks after suffering an injury to his left knee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/161225-nance-jr-injury-update|title=Larry Nance Jr. Injury Update|work=NBA.com|date=December 25, 2016|accessdate=December 26, 2016}}</ref>On November 3, 2017, Nance was ruled out for four to six weeks after fracturing the second metacarpal on his left hand the previous night against the [[Portland Trail Blazers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/releases/171103-larry-nance-injury-report|title=Larry Nance Jr. Medical Update|work=NBA.com|date=November 3, 2017|accessdate=November 3, 2017}}</ref> He missed 11 games as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=400975048|title=Clippers hang on to beat Lakers 120-115 for 3rd win in row|work=ESPN.com|date=November 27, 2017|accessdate=November 28, 2017}}</ref>On December 18, 2017, Nance garnered significant media attention for performing a "slam-dunk" on Kevin Durant in a 116-114 loss to the [[Golden State Warriors]]. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/larry-nance-jr-posterizes-kevin-durant-dunk-of-the-year-2017-12|title=Lakers forward Larry Nance Jr. destroyed Kevin Durant with what is being called the Dunk of the Year|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en}}</ref>==NBA career statistics=={{NBA player statistics legend}}===Regular season==={{NBA player statistics start}}|-| style="text-align:left;"| {{nbay|2015}}| style="text-align:left;"| [[2015–16 Los Angeles Lakers season|L.A. Lakers]]| '''63''' || '''22''' || 20.1 || '''.527''' || .100 || .681 || 5.0 || .7 || .9 || .4 || 5.5|-| style="text-align:left;"| {{nbay|2016}}| style="text-align:left;"| [[2016–17 Los Angeles Lakers season|L.A. Lakers]]| '''63''' || 7 || '''22.9''' || .526 || '''.278''' || '''.738''' || '''5.9''' || '''1.5''' || '''1.3''' || '''.6''' || '''7.1'''|- class="sortbottom"| style="text-align:center;" colspan=2| Career| 126 || 29 || 21.5 || .526 || .239 || .717 || 5.4 || 1.1 || 1.1 || .5 || 6.3{{S-end}}==Personal life==Nance is the son of [[Larry Nance]], a former professional [[basketball]] player for the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] and [[Phoenix Suns]]. Nance Sr. was a three-time [[List of NBA All-Stars|NBA All-Star]] and won the league's first [[Slam Dunk Contest]]. He also has been diagnosed with [[Crohn's disease]].<ref name=bio /><ref>Darby, Luke (October 26, 2017). "[https://www.gq.com/story/real-life-diet-larry-nance-jr The Real-Life Diet of Larry Nance Jr., the NBA Player with Crohn's Disease]". ''[[GQ Magazine|GQ]]''.</ref>==References=={{Reflist}}==External links=={{Portal|National Basketball Association}}{{Commons}}{{basketballstats|bbr=n/nancela02|nba=larry_nance}}* [https://web.archive.org/web/20150316203630/http://www.gowyo.com/sports/m-baskbl/mtt/larry_nance_jr_765297.html Larry Nance Jr.] at gowyo.com* [http://www.draftexpress.com/profile/Larry-Nance-42170/ Larry Nance Jr.] at draftexpress.com* {{instagram|larrydn7}}* {{Twitter}}{{Los Angeles Lakers current roster}}{{2015 NBA Draft}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Nance, Larry Jr.}}[[Category:1993 births]][[Category:Living people]][[Category:African-American basketball players]][[Category:Basketball players from Ohio]][[Category:Los Angeles Lakers draft picks]][[Category:Los Angeles Lakers players]][[Category:Power forwards (basketball)]][[Category:Sportspeople from Akron, Ohio]][[Category:Wyoming Cowboys basketball players]])
(1	Category:1995 in Kyrgyzstani sport	{{Portal|Kyrgyzstan|Sport}}{{Year by category|m=1|c=9|d=9|y=5|cat=in Kyrgyzstani sport|sortkey=Kyrgyzstan|parent=Kyrgyzstani sport by year|subcat=1995 in Kyrgyzstan}}[[Category:1995 in sports by country|Kyrgyzstan]][[Category:1995 in Asian sport|Kyrgyzstan]])

(1	Batang Pinoy	{{Infobox Sporting Event Organization|name         = Philippine Youth Games – Batang Pinoy|image        = Batang Pinoy Logo.png|size         = 220px|caption      =|abbreviation = PYG-Batang Pinoy|motto        =|formation    = [[Manila]], [[Philippines]]<ref name=executiveord/>|recurrence   = Annually|last         = [[2016 Batang Pinoy|2016]] in [[Tagum]], [[Davao del Norte]]|purpose      = National games for athletes under 15 years old|headquarters =|leader_title =|Department   = Department of Education|website      =|remarks      =}}The '''Philippine Youth Games – Batang Pinoy''' or simply '''Batang Pinoy''' ({{literal translation|Filipino Youth}}) is the national [[Youth sports|youth]] sports competition of the [[Philippines]] for athletes under 15 years old. Unlike the [[Palarong Pambansa]] a competition for student athletes, the Batang Pinoy also includes the out-of-school youth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Batang Pinoy! Yes!|url=http://bp2012.psc.gov.ph/index.php/about|website=Batang Pinoy 2011|publisher=Philippine Sports Commission|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref>==History==The Batang Pinoy was established through the Executive Order No. 44 which was signed by then President [[Joseph Estrada]] in December 2, 1998.<ref name=executiveord>{{cite web|last1=Estrada|first1=Joseph|title=EXECUTIVE ORDER NO. 44|url=http://www.web.psc.gov.ph/Legal%20%20Mandates_/Executive%20Order%20No.44.pdf|website=Philippine Sports Commission|publisher=The President Of The Philippines|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> The first edition was held in [[Bacolod]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vanzi|first1=Sol Jose|title=Laguna Takes Overall Batang Pinoy Games Lead|url=http://www.newsflash.org/1999/12/sp/sp000924.htm|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Philippine Headline News Online|date=6 December 1999|location=Bacolod}}</ref> From then, the games were held annually with Santa Cruz, Laguna<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorandum Circular 2000-108 - 2000 Philippine National Youth Games - Batang Pinoy Program|url=http://www.dilgx.org/Memorandum%20Circulars/MemoCircs/2000-108%202000%20Philippine%20National%20Youth%20Games%20-%20Batang%20Pinoy%20Program.pdf|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Department of Interior and Local Government|date=23 August 2000}}</ref> (2000), [[Bacolod]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Over 4,000 athletes compete in Batang Pinoy Games|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/140855/over-4000-athletes-compete-batang-pinoy-games|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=21 November 2001}}</ref> (2001) [[Puerto Princesa]]<ref name=puerto>{{cite news|last1=Vanzi|first1=Sol Jose|title='Batang Pinoy' Unfolds in Puerto Princesa|url=http://www.newsflash.org/1999/12/sp/sp000924.htm|accessdate=1 December 2015|work=Philippine Headline News Online|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=2 December 2002|location=Bacolod}}</ref> (2002) hosting the next three editions. The 2002 and prior editions, were for athletes of 12 years and below.<ref name=puerto/>In 2003, the [[Philippine Sports Commission]] decided to put the competition, along with its other national competitions, on hold so the sports body could reallocate funds to the national teams' stint at the [[Southeast Asian Games]].<ref name=postponed>{{cite news|last1=Cruz|first1=Agnes|title=PSC Sacrifices Pet Projects for Vietnam SEA Games|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/235760?quicktabs_stat2=0|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=Arab News|date=15 August 2003}}</ref> The Batang Pinoy was held again in 2011, and is held annually since then.<ref name=revive>{{cite news|title=PSC revives Batang Pinoy competition|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/psc-revives-batang-pinoy-competition|accessdate=1 December 2015|publisher=InterAKTV|date=6 September 2011}}</ref> It is set to be discontinued in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tribune.net.ph/sports/psc-set-to-scrap-batang-pinoy|title=PSC set to scrap Batang Pinoy|publisher=The Daily Tribune|last=Manicad|first=Julius|date=September 30, 2017|accessdate=October 9, 2017}}</ref>==Editions==Host of the Batang Pinoy National Championships.{{Location map+ |Philippines |width=275 |float=left |caption=Location of the '''Batang Pinoy''' hosts <br>'''Bacolod''': [[1999 Batang Pinoy|1st]],[[2000 Batang Pinoy|3rd]],[[2013 Batang Pinoy|7th]],[[2014 Batang Pinoy|8th]]|places={{Location map~ |Philippines |marksize=5  |lat=10.666667 Batang Pinoy|5th]]|position=right}}{{Location map~ |Philippines |marksize=5  |lat=14.278611    |long=121.415556  |label=[[2000 Batang Pinoy|2nd]]|position=top}}{{Location map~ |Philippines |marksize=5  |lat=9.733333    |long=118.733333  |label=[[2002 Batang Pinoy|4th]]|position=left}}{{Location map~ |Philippines |marksize=5  |lat=7.45    |long=125.8  |label=[[2016 Batang (1	List of New Zealand female boxing champions	This '''list of New Zealand female boxing champions''' is a table showing the female boxers who have won the New Zealand professional championship. The title has been administered by the New Zealand Boxing Association, New Zealand National Boxing Federation, New Zealand Professional Boxing Commission and [[New Zealand Professional Boxing Association]] since 2002. A champion will often voluntarily relinquish the title in order to fight for a higher-ranked championship, such as the world. Where the date on which a champion relinquished the title is unclear.==Heavyweight=={| class="wikitable"! Name! Beginning of Reign! Title! (1	1986 TCU Horned Frogs football team	{{refimprove|date=June 2016}}{{Infobox NCAA team season|Year=1986|Team=TCU Horned Frogs|Image=|Conference=Southwest Conference|Division=|ShortConference=SWC|BCSRank=|CoachRank=|APRank=|Record=3–8|ConfRecord=1–7|HeadCoach=[[Jim Wacker]]|HCYear=4th|OffCoach=|DefCoach=|OScheme=|DScheme=|StadiumArena=[[Amon G. Carter Stadium]]<br>(Capacity: 46,083)|Champion=|BowlTourney=|BowlTourneyResult=}}{{1986 Southwest Conference football standings}}The '''1986 TCU Horned Frogs football team''' represented [[Texas Christian University]] (TCU) in the [[1986 NCAA Division I-A football season]]. The Horned Frogs finished the season 3–8 overall and 1–7 in [[Southwest Conference]]. The team was coached by [[Jim Wacker]], in his fourth year as head coach. The Frogs played their home games in [[Amon G. Carter Stadium]], which is located on campus in [[Fort Worth, Texas]].==Schedule=={{CFB Schedule Start|time=|rank=no|ranklink=|rankyear=1986|tv=|attend=yes}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| date         = September 13| time         =| w/l          = w| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| away         = yes| neutral      =| rank         = no| opponent     = [[1986 Tulane Green Wave football team|Tulane]]| opprank      =| site_stadium = [[Louisiana Superdome]]| site_cityst  = [[New Orleans]]| gamename     =| tv           =| score        = 48–31| overtime     =| attend       = -}}{{CFB Schedule Entry| date         = September 20| time         =| w/l          = w| nonconf      = yes| homecoming   =| away         =| neutral      =| rank         = no| opponent     = [[1986 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]]| opprank      =| site_stadium = [[Amon G. (1	2016–17 Pittsburgh Penguins season	{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}}{{NHLTeamSeason| League = NHL| Season = 2016–17| year = 2016| Team = Pittsburgh Penguins| Division = [[Metropolitan Division|Metropolitan]]| DivisionRank = 2nd| Conference = [[Eastern Conference (NHL)|Eastern]]| ConferenceRank = 2nd| Record = 50–21–11| HomeRecord = 31–6–4| RoadRecord = 19–15–7| GoalsFor = 282| GoalsAgainst = 234| GeneralManager = [[Jim Rutherford]]| Coach = [[Mike Sullivan (ice hockey)|Mike Sullivan]]| Captain = [[Sidney Crosby]]| AltCaptain = [[Chris Kunitz]]<br>[[Evgeni Malkin]]| Arena = [[PPG Paints Arena]]| Attendance = 19,762 (110.2%)<ref>{{cite web|title=2016–2017 NHL Attendance – National Hockey League – ESPN|url=http://espn.go.com/nhl/attendance|publisher=''ESPN''}}</ref><br>(41 games)| MinorLeague = [[Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins|WBS Penguins]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]])<br />[[Wheeling Nailers]] ([[ECHL]])| GoalsLeader = [[Sidney Crosby]] (44)| AssistsLeader = [[Phil Kessel]] (47)| PointsLeader = Sidney Crosby (89)| PlusMinusLeader = [[Justin Schultz]] (+27)| PIMLeader = [[Evgeni Malkin]] (77)| WinsLeader = [[Matt Murray (ice hockey)|Matt Murray]] (32)| GAALeader = Matt Murray (2.41)| DivisionWin =| PresidentsTrophy =| ConferenceWin = yes| StanleyCup = yes*}}The '''[[2016–17 NHL season|2016–17]] [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] [[season (sports)|season]]''' was the [[Pittsburgh Penguins seasons|50th]] season for the [[National Hockey League]] [[ice hockey]] team that was established on June 5, 1967.<ref>https://www.nhl.com/news/a-brief-history-pittsburgh-penguins/c-536264</ref> The Penguins would win the [[Stanley Cup]] championship in back to back years, defeating the Nashville Predators in the [[2017 Stanley Cup Finals|2017]] Finals after winning the Stanley Cup in [[2016 Stanley Cup Finals|2016]].== Off-season ==On the first day of the [[2016 NHL Entry Draft]] the Pittsburgh Penguins announced they will officially change their uniform colors from Black and Vegas Gold, used from 2002–03 through 2015–16, back to the Black and "Pittsburgh Gold" they have used as an alternate jersey for the past two season reveling a new Visitor jersey reflecting the same format used in the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Penguins Make The Move to "Pittsburgh Gold" – Pittsburgh Penguins – News|url=http://penguins.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=887098|publisher=''Pittsburgh Penguins''|accessdate=June 24, 2016|date=June 24, 2016}}</ref>== Pre-season ===== Game log ==={| class="toccolours" Penguins first-round pick went to the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] as the result of a July 1, 2015 trade that sent [[Phil Kessel]], [[Tyler Biggs]], [[Tim Erixon]], a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round two|2016 second-round conditional pick]] and cash to the Penguins in exchange for a [[Scott Harrington (ice hockey)|Scott Harrington]], [[Kasperi Kapanen]], [[Nick Spaling]], [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round three|2016 third-round pick]] and this conditional pick.<ref name=TORTRADE>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=773329 |title=Penguins acquire Kessel from Maple Leafs Draft#Round one|2017 first-round pick]] if Penguins qualify for 2017 playoffs, else [[2017 NHL Entry Draft#Round two|2017 second-round pick]].* {{Note label|Note1|a|a}}The [[Vancouver Canucks]] second-round pick went to the Pittsburgh Penguins as a result of a July 28, 2015 trade that sent [[Brandon Sutter]] and a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round three|2016 third-round pick]] to the Canucks in exchange for [[Nick Bonino]], [[Adam Clendening]] and this pick.<ref name=SUTTER>{{cite web |url=http://penguins.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=775784 |title=Penguins Acquire Forward Nick Bonino, Defenseman [[Kasperi Kapanen]], [[Nick Spaling]], a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round one|2016 first-round conditional pick]] and a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round three|2016 third-round pick]] to the Maple Leafs in exchange for [[Phil Kessel]], [[Tyler Biggs]], [[Tim Erixon]], cash and this conditional pick.<ref name=TORTRADE />**'''Condition(s)''' – [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round one|2016 first-round pick]] if New York Islanders originally Vancouver Canucks) went to the [[Vancouver Canucks]] as the result of a July 28, 2015 trade that sent [[Nick Bonino]], [[Adam Clendening]] and a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round two|2016 second-round pick]] to the Penguins in exchange for a [[Brandon Sutter]] and this pick.<ref name=SUTTER />* The Pittsburgh Penguins third-round pick (originally New Jersey Devils) went to the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] as a result of a July 1, 2015 trade that sent [[Phil Kessel]], [[Tyler Biggs]], [[Tim Erixon]], a [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round two|2016 second-round conditional pick]] and cash to the Penguins in exchange for [[Scott Harrington (ice hockey)|Scott Harrington]], [[Kasperi Kapanen]], [[Nick Spaling]], [[2016 NHL Entry Draft#Round one|2016 first-round conditional pick]] and this pick.<ref name=TORTRADE />* {{Note label|Note1|c|c}}The [[New Jersey Devils]] third-round pick (originally [[Detroit Red Wings]]) went to the Pittsburgh Penguins as a result of a June 25, 2016 trade that sent [[Beau Bennett]] to the Devils in exchange for this pick.<ref name=bennett_trade />* The Pittsburgh Penguins third-round pick went to the [[Edmonton Oilers]] as the result of (1	Maldives International	The '''Maldives International''' is an open international [[badminton]] tournament in [[Maldives]] organized by the Badminton Association of Maldives and sanctioned by the [[Badminton Asia Confederation]] and [[Badminton World Federation]]. This tournament has been an [[BWF International Challenge|International Challenge]] level before it went into hiatus in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Maldives to revive Maldives International after three years in doldrum |url=http://badmintonasia.org/updates/news/maldives-to-revive-maldives-international-after-three-years-in-doldrum |publisher=[[Badminton Asia Confederation]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> This tournament held at the Malé sports complex, and offered [[BWF World Ranking|world ranking points]] with total prize money US$ 15,000.<ref>{{cite web |title=Maldivian International Challenge 2010 |url=http://www.bwfbadminton.org/tournamentcalendar_event.aspx?id=10399 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120808160436/http://www.bwfbadminton.org/tournamentcalendar_event.aspx?id=10399 |deadurl=yes |publisher=[[Wayback Machine]] |archivedate=8 August 2012 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Maldives International Badminton Challenge 2013 |url=http://www.badmintonindia.org/download/tournaments/Maldives%20IC%202013%20-%20Prospectus.doc |publisher=[[Badminton in India]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="pakistan">{{cite news|title=Olympics for Pakistani badminton players |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/899419 |publisher=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>In 2010, India won two titles from the men's and women's singles event. [[Anand Pawar]] won the men's singles title after defeated [[Dinuka Karunaratne]] of Sri Lanka with the score 21–14, 21–18, while his compatriot [[Trupti Murgunde]] won the women's singles title after [[Ann Venice Alcala Malvinne]] of Philippines retired with a hamstring injury at the score 21–10, 11–3.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trupti, Pawar shine in Maldives |url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=TOINEW&BaseHref=TOIBG%2F2010%2F06%2F07&ViewMode=HTML&PageLabel=19&EntityId=Ar01906&AppName=1&FontSize=l1 |publisher=[[The Times of India]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> The men's doubles title goes to Pakistani [[Kashif Ali Sulehri]] and [[Rizwan Azam]]<ref name="pakistan"/>, and the Japanese pair [[Chinami Okui]] and [[Yukie Sumida]] won the women's doubles title. [[Kennevic Asuncion]] and [[Karyn Velez]] won the mixed doubles title outlasted Sri Lanka's Udara Nayanajith and Renu Chandrika Hettiarachchige, 24–22, 17–21, 21–13.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asuncion-Velez bags mixed doubles gold |url=https://www.pressreader.com/philippines/philippine-daily-inquirer/20100531/283506497213096 |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>In 2011, [[Pablo Abián]] of Spain with his fast movement on the court, excellent physics, and speed of strokes managed to win the men's singles title.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vítězem Maldives Badminton Challenge je sympaťák Pablo Abian |url=http://www.badec.cz/vitezem-maldives-badminton-challenge-pablo-abian/ |publisher=Badec.cz|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=Czechs}}</ref> The 15 years old, [[P. V. Sindhu]] produced a stunning performance to win the women's singles title. She beat [[Carolina Marin]] in the third round and [[Agnese Allegrini]] in the semi-final.<ref>{{cite news|title=15 Years Old PV Sindhu Triumphs at Maldives Open |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/badminton/15-years-old-pv-sindhu-triumphs-at-maldives-open |publisher=[[Sportskeeda]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> The men's, women's, and mixed doubles title goes to Singapore ([[Ashton Chen Yong Zhao]] and [[Derek Wong Zi Liang]]), Japan ([[Miki Komori]] and [[Nao Miyoshi]]) and Canada ([[Toby Ng]] and [[Grace Gao]]) respectively.<ref>{{cite news|title=Maldives International: naši uhráli dvě kola |url=http://www.badmintonweb.cz/maldives_international_nasi_uhrali_dve_kola.htm |publisher=Badminton web|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=Czechs}}</ref>In 2012, [[K. Srikanth]] emerged as the title winner by ending the men's singles final set in three games with a margin of 13–21, 21–11 and 21–16 of [[Zulfadli Zulkiffli]].<ref>{{cite news|title=India’s Srikanth K. steals limelight at Maldives International Challenge 2012 |url=http://www.newspakistan.pk/2012/06/04/India-s-Srikanth-K-steals-limelight-at-Maldives-International-Challenge-2012/ |publisher=News Pakistan|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> Japan won three titles from the women's singles, men's doubles and women's doubles event.<ref>{{cite news|title=バドミントン高橋が女子単で優勝／モルディブ国際 |url=https://www.shikoku-np.co.jp/sports/general/20120604000201 |publisher=Shikoku News|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref> [[Raj Popat]] of Wales and [[Devi Tika Permatasari]] of Indonesia emerged as the winner of the mixed doubles title after defeating Sri Lanka’s Hasitha Chanaka and Kavindi Ishandika Sirimannage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Raj Popat and Devi Tika Permatasari grab Mixed Doubles title at Maldives International |url=http://www.senore.com/Raj-Popat-and-Devi-Tika-Permatasari-grab-Mixed-Doubles-title-at-Maldives-International-q352072 |publisher=Senore|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>In 2013, Indonesia managed to put 6 representatives in the final round, and won two titles in the men's singles and women's doubles event after created All Indonesian finals. [[Hanna Ramadini]] lost to [[Michelle Li (badminton)|Michelle Li]] of Canada in the women's singles final and [[Arya Maulana Aldiartama]]/[[Alfian Eko Prasetya]] defeated by the Taiwanese pair [[Tien Tzu-chieh]] and [[Wang Chi-lin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Indonesia raih dua gelar dari Maldives |url=https://sports.sindonews.com/read/747993/47/indonesia-raih-dua-gelar-dari-maldives-1370845777 |publisher=SINDOnews.com |accessdate=11 June 2017 |language=Indonesian}}</ref> Indian pair [[K. Nandagopal]] and [[Maneesha Kukkapalli]] clinched the mixed doubles title after registering a straight-game victory over Kim Dae-sung and Oh Bo-kyung of South Korea.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nandagopal-Maneesha lift mixed doubles title at Maldives International Badminton |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/badminton/Nandagopal-Maneesha-lift-mixed-doubles-title-at-Maldives-International-Badminton/articleshow/20507684.cms |publisher=[[The Times of India]]|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>==Previous winners=={| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%;"!Year!Men's singles!Women's singles!Men's doubles!Women's doubles!Mixed doubles|-|[http://bwf.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/winners.aspx?id=0FB6479D-B618-4178-9A6E-DA9F32CF8DB5 2010]|{{flagicon|IND}} [[Anand Pawar]]|{{flagicon|IND}} [[Trupti Murgunde]]|{{flagicon|PAK}} [[Kashif Ali Sulehri]]<br>{{flagicon|PAK}} [[Rizwan Azam]]|{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Chinami Okui]]<br>{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Yukie Sumida]]|{{flagicon|PHI}} [[Kennevic Asuncion]]<br>{{flagicon|USA}} [[Karyn Velez]]|-|[http://bwf.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/winners.aspx?id=C0731AD9-5BDA-446E-84CC-334DD003D10E 2011]|{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Pablo Abián]]|{{flagicon|IND}} [[P. V. Sindhu]]|{{flagicon|SIN}} [[Ashton Chen Yong Zhao]]<br>{{flagicon|SIN}} [[Derek Wong Zi Liang]]|{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Miki Komori]]<br>{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Nao Miyoshi]]|{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Toby Ng]]<br>{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Grace Gao]]|-|[http://bwf.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/winners.aspx?id=D7913F9C-6450-4225-925A-7C77AE0809C4 2012]|{{flagicon|IND}} [[K. Srikanth]]|{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Sayaka Takahashi]]|{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Kazuya Itani]]<br />{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Tomoya Takashina]]|{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Naoko Fukuman]]<br />{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Kurumi Yonao]]|{{flagicon|WAL}} [[Raj Popat]]<br />{{flagicon|INA}} [[Devi Tika Permatasari]]|-|[http://bwf.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/winners.aspx?id=87CC1F4C-4A34-4356-B7B9-E83B1CA0A349 2013]|{{flagicon|INA}} [[Fikri Ihsandi Hadmadi]]|{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Michelle Li (badminton)|Michelle Li]]|{{flagicon|TPE}} [[Tien Tzu-chieh]]<br />{{flagicon|TPE}} [[Wang Chi-lin]]|{{flagicon|INA}} [[Maretha Dea Giovani]]<br />{{flagicon|INA}} [[Melvira Oklamona]]|{{flagicon|IND}} [[K. Nandagopal]]<br />{{flagicon|IND}} [[Maneesha Kukkapalli]]|-|2014–2016|colspan="5" align="center" |''no competition''|-|[http://bwf.tournamentsoftware.com/sport/tournament.aspx?id=B59B98EC-4CBC-494A-8A69-CA9194084359 2017]||||||}== References =={{reflist|2}}==External links==*[http://badmintonmaldives.org.mv/ Badminton Association of Maldives][[Category:Badminton tournaments]][[Category:Badminton in the Maldives]][[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 2010]])
(1	Rugged Maniac Northern California	{{Infobox sports competition event| event        = Rugged Maniac Northern California| image        =| caption      =| venue        = [[Alameda County Fairgrounds]]| location     = [[Pleasanton, California]]| date         = May 27, 2017. October 14, 2017.| men          = {{flagicon|USA}}  '''Jeff Huxhold'''| women        = {{flagicon|USA}}  '''Emma Overell'''| prev         = May 21, 2016| next         = May 27, 2017}}The '''Northern California [[Rugged Maniac]]''' 5K Obstacle Course event (or '''Rugged Maniac NorCal''') has been held annually in [[Pleasanton, California]] since 2013. The event currently takes place at the [[Alameda County Fairgrounds]].<ref>{{cite web |url =http://yourdailyjournal.com/features/32423/connections-family-support-program-offering-support-group-on-tuesday |title =Rugged Maniac |last = |first = |date =May 9, 2016 |website =YourDailyJournal.com |publisher = |access-date =September 29, 2016 |quote = }}</ref>==History=====2017===The May event was the first Northern California event, where only the Top 3 finishers (male and female) were manually timed by race officials. Beginning January 2017, Rugged Maniac has stopped the use of timing chips due to a lack of demand.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://obstacleracingmedia.com/ocr-news/rugged-maniacs-changes-timing-protocol/ |title =Rugged Maniac’s Changes Its Timing Protocol |last = |first = |date =Jan 10, 2017 |website =obstacleracingmedia.com |publisher = |access-date=June 2, 2017 |quote = }}</ref>===2016===[[Rugged Maniac]] Northern California was held at the [[Alameda County Fairgrounds]] in [[Pleasanton, California]].<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.independentnews.com/sports/sports_notes/rugged-maniacs/article_185b5864-1dc0-11e6-bd19-cbfe6871baac.html |title =Rugged Maniacs |last = |first = |date =May 19, 2016 |website =IndependentNews.com |publisher = |access-date =September 29, 2016 |quote = }}</ref>In 2016, the event featured 25 obstacles over a length of 5 kilometers. The festival area hosted activities such as dance parties, mechanical bulls, bounce houses and exhibition booths.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.pleasantonweekly.com/news/2016/05/20/rugged-maniac-returns-to-fairgrounds-tomorrow |title =Rugged Maniac returns to fairgrounds today |last =Walsh |first =Jeremy |date =May 20, 2016 |website =Pleasantonweekly.com |publisher = |access-date =September 29, 2016 |quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url =http://pleasanton.gate2bay.com/2016/05/20/rugged-maniac-returns-to-fairgrounds-tomorrow/ |title =Rugged Maniac returns to fairgrounds tomorrow |last = |first = |date =May 20, 2016 |website =pleasanton.gate2bay.com |publisher = |access-date =September 29, 2016 |quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url =http://patch.com/california/pleasanton/calendar/event/20160521/1790/rugged-maniac-5k-obstacle-race-returns-to-pleasanton |title ='Rugged Maniac 5K Obstacle Race' Returns to Pleasanton |last =Wilkins |first =Jamie |date =May 21, 2016 |website =patch.com |publisher = |access-date =September 29, 2016 |quote = }}</ref>===2015===2015 saw a battle between two women elite [[obstacle course racing]] athletes, '''Lea Stretch''' and '''Nichole Root'''. Both women have regularly placed in the top 10 for races such as Rugged Maniac, Spartan Race, and Battlefrog.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.auburnjournal.com/article/1/26/15/super-woman-auburn-preschool-teacher-competes-grueling-spartan-races |title =SUPER WOMAN: Auburn preschool teacher competes in grueling Spartan Races |last =Dodson |first =Ike |date =January 26, 2015 |website =AuburnJournal.com |publisher = |access-date =September 30, 2016 |quote = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.sixpackbags.com/blog/athlete-interview-lea-stretch-ocr-ninja/ |title =Sponsored Athlete Interview: Lea Stretch, OCR Ninja Pt. 1 |last = |first = |date =August 2014 |website =sixpackbags.com |publisher = |access-date =September 30, 2016 |quote = }}</ref> Stretch edged out Root by three seconds for the top finisher medal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.athlinks.com/Athletes/222280782 |title=Nichole Root |access-date=September 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.athlinks.com/athletes/157757143 |title=Lea Stretch |access-date=September 30, 2016}}</ref>==Winners=====Men==={|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%"|- align="center"|width="80" bgcolor="efefef"|'''Year'''|width="200" (1	1932 U.S. National Championships – Women's Singles	{{GrandSlamEvents|1932|U.S. National Championships|| champ = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Helen Jacobs]]| runner = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Carolin Babcock]]<ref name=collins/>| score =  6–2, 6–2| before_name = U.S. National Championships – Women's Singles| after_name = U.S. National Championships – Women's Singles}}First-seeded [[Helen Jacobs]] defeated [[Carolin Babcock]] 6–2, 6–2 in the final to win the '''Women's Singles''' [[tennis]] title at the [[1932 U.S. National Championships (tennis)|1932 U.S. National Championships]].<ref name=collins>{{cite book|last=Collins|first=Bud|authorlink=Bud Collins|title=The Bud Collins History of Tennis|year=2010|publisher=New Chapter Press|location=[New York City]|isbn=978-0942257700|edition=2nd|page=469}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Wallis Myers|editor1-first=A.|editorlink=A. Wallis Myers|title=Ayres' Lawn Tennis Almanack and Tournament Guide 1933|date=1933|publisher=F.H. Ayres Limited|location=London|pages=176–177}}</ref>==Seeds==The tournament used two lists of players for seeding the women's singles event; one list of eight U.S. players and a list for three foreign players. (1	2017 Scottish Cup Final	{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}{{infobox football match| title              = 2017 Scottish Cup Final| image              =| caption            = CELTIC 2 - 1 ABERDEEN| event              = 2017 Scottish Cup Final| team1              = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]| team1score         = 2| team2              = [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]]| team2score         = 1| date               = 27 May 2017| stadium            = [[Hampden Park]]| city               = [[Glasgow]]| man_of_the_match1a =| referee            = [[Bobby Madden]]| attendance         = 48,713| previous           = [[2016 Scottish Cup Final|2016]]| next               = 2018}}The '''2017 Scottish Cup Final''' was the 132nd final of the [[Scottish Cup]] and the final of the [[2016–17 Scottish Cup]], the most prestigious knockout [[association football|football]] competition in Scotland. The match took place at [[Hampden Park]] on 27 May 2017 and was contested by [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] and [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]].The fixture was a repeat of the finals in [[1937 Scottish Cup Final|1937]], [[1954 Scottish Cup Final|1954]] and [[1967 Scottish Cup Final|1967]] won by Celtic, and in [[1970 Scottish Cup Final|1970]], [[1984 Scottish Cup Final|1984]] and [[1990 Scottish Cup Final|1990]] won by Aberdeen.Celtic won the game 2-1 to complete a domestic treble without losing a game; they went 47 domestic matches unbeaten during the season.<ref>{{citeweb|url= http://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39984102|title=Celtic 2 Aberdeen 1|date=27 May 2017|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url= http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/competitions/scottish-cup/celtic-2-1-aberdeen-celtic-complete-treble-and-make-history-1-4458979|title= Celtic 2 - 1 Aberdeen: Celtic complete treble and make history|date=27 May 2017|work=The Scotsman|accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref>== Route to the final =====Celtic==={| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left;margin-left:1em;float:right"|-!width=125|Round!width=110|Opposition!width=110|Location!width=80|Score|-!colspan=4|Celtic|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Fourth round|Fourth round]]| [[Albion Rovers F.C.|Albion Rovers]]| [[Excelsior Stadium|Excelsior]]| align=center|3–0|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Fifth round|Fifth round]]| [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness CT]]| [[Celtic Park]]| align=center|6–0|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Quarter-finals|Quarter-final]]| [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]]| [[Celtic Park]]| align=center|4–1|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Semi-finals|Semi-final]]| [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]| [[Hampden Park]]| align=center|2–0|-!colspan=4|Aberdeen|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Fourth round|Fourth round]]| [[Stranraer F.C.|Stranraer]]| [[Pittodrie Stadium|Pittodrie]]| align=center|4–0|-| [[2016–17 Scottish Cup#Fifth round|Fifth round]]| [[Ross County F.C.|Ross County]]| [[Victoria Park, Dingwall|Victoria Park]]| align=center|1–0|-| [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]]| [[Hampden Park]]| align=center|3–2|}===Aberdeen=====Match=====Summary===[[Jonny Hayes]] opened the scoring for Aberdeen in the 9th minute with a low left foot volley from seven yards out after a corner from the right by [[Niall McGinn]].<ref>{{citeweb|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-4548082/Celtic-2-1-Aberdeen-Tom-Rogic-hits-late-winner.html|title= Celtic 2-1 Aberdeen: Tom Rogic hits dramatic stoppage time winner to secure Scottish Cup glory|date=27 May 2017|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref>Two minutes later [[Stuart Armstrong]] made it 1-1 with a left foot shot to the right corner from just outside the penalty area.<ref>{{citeweb|url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/05/27/celtic-2-aberdeen-1tom-rogic-shatters-dons-secure-historic-clean/|title= Celtic 2 Aberdeen 1: Tom Rogic shatters Dons to secure historic clean sweep with Scottish Cup final win|date=27 May 2017|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref>In the 92nd minute, [[Tom Rogic]] got the winning goal when he received the ball 40 yards out and made his way into the right side of the penalty area before clipping the ball with his right foot over the goalkeeper from three yards out from a tight angle.<ref>{{citeweb|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2017/may/27/celtic-v-aberdeen-scottish-cup-final-live|title=Celtic 2 Aberdeen 1: as it happened |date=27 May 2017|work=Guardian|accessdate=31 May 2017}}</ref>===Details==={{football box ||date = 27 May 2017|time = 15:00|team1 = [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]|score = 2 – 1|report = [http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39984102 Report]|team2 = [[Aberdeen (1	Joe Vlasits	{{Infobox football biography|name           = Joe Vlasits|image          = Joe Vlasits1.JPG|image_size     =|alt            =|caption        =|fullname       = Joseph Vlasits|birth_date     = 1921|birth_place    = [[Budapest|Budapest, Hungary]]|death_date     = {{Death date and given age|1985|04|23|64|df=yes}}|death_place    =|height         =|position       = Winger|years1         = 19??–19??|clubs1         = [[Nemzeti SC|Nemzeti]]|caps1          = ?|goals1         = ?|manageryears1  = 1958–1960|managerclubs1  = [[Bankstown Berries FC|Canterbury-Marrickville]]|manageryears2  = 1961|managerclubs2  = [[Sydney FC Prague|Sydney Prague]]|manageryears3  = 1962|managerclubs3  = [[St George FC|Budapest]]|manageryears4  = 1963–1964|managerclubs4  = [[Sydney Olympic FC|Pan-Hellenic]]|manageryears5  = 1965|managerclubs5  = [[Bankstown City FC|Bankstown]]|manageryears6  = 1966|managerclubs6  = [[SSC Yugal]]|manageryears7  = 1967–1968|managerclubs7  = [[Parramatta FC|Melita Eagles-Newtown]]|manageryears8  = 1967–1969|managerclubs8  = [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]]|manageryears9  = 1972|managerclubs9  = [[Sydney Olympic FC|Pan-Hellenic]]|manageryears10  = 1974|managerclubs10  = Northern Districts}}'''Joseph "Uncle Joe" Vlasits''' (1921 – 23 April 1985) was a Hungarian football player and manager who coached the Australian national side from 1967 to 1969.==Early life and playing career==Vlasits was born in 1921 in [[Budapest|Budapest, Hungary]]. He played for Budapest First Division club [[Nemzeti SC|Nemzeti]]  but his career was cut short by injury and he moved to Australia in the late 1940s.==Managerial career==In Australia, Vlasits moved into management, and coached New South Wales Division One side [[Bankstown Berries FC|Canterbury-Marrickville]] from 1958 to 1960, winning titles in 1958 and 1960 and winning the [[Waratah Cup|Ampol Cup]] in '58. He then coached [[Sydney FC Prague|Sydney Prague]] and [[St George FC|Budapest]] in 1961 and '62 respectively, winning the Division One title with both clubs. He then took over at fellow Division One side [[Sydney Olympic FC|Pan-Hellenic]] for 1963 and '64, but could only manage fourth- and sixth-place finishes. He then dropped down a league to Division Two side [[Bankstown City FC|Bankstown]], which placed sixth in his only year of management, 1965. He returned to Division One in 1966 with strugglers [[SSC Yugal]], which came third-last that season. A two-year stint at [[Parramatta FC|Melita Eagles-Newtown]] saw the club finish third-last in both the 1967 and '68 Division One seasons. He coached the Australian national side from 1967 to '69, and coached the team to victory in the [[1967 Quoc Khanh Cup]], winning all five matches they played. It was Australia's first international footballing honour. He coached Australia for a total of 23 games — 13 wins, seven draws, and three losses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socceroos.com.au/article/teams-of-the-decade--mens-1963-1970/15gwe4e644vel111n0jqpnv76v|title=Teams of the Decade <nowiki>|</nowiki> Men's 1963-1970|publisher=[[Australia national football team]]|date=18 December 2013|accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> He returned to Pan-Hellenic for the 1972 season, and the team came seventh in Division One. He then managed Northern Districts to the Division Three title in 1974.==Death==Vlasits died at the age of 64 on 23 April 1965.==Honours=====As a manager=======Canterbury-Marrickville====*[[National Premier Leagues NSW|New South Wales Division One]]: 1958, 1960*[[Waratah Cup|Ampol Cup]]: 1958====Sydney Prague====*[[National Premier Leagues NSW|New South Wales Division One]]: 1961====Budapest====*[[National Premier Leagues NSW|New South Wales Division One]]: 1962====Australia====*[[Quoc Khanh Cup]]: [[1967 Quoc Khanh Cup|1967]]====Northern Districts====*[[National Premier Leagues NSW 3|New South Wales Division Three]]: 1974==Managerial statistics=={| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center"|-!rowspan="2"|Team!rowspan="2"|From!rowspan="2"|To!colspan="5"|Record|-!G!!W!!D!!L!!Win %|-|align=left|[[Australia national football team|Australia]]|align=left|1967|align=left|1969{{WDL|23|13|7|3}}|}==References=={{reflist}}==External links==*[http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Players/V/VE.html Joe Vlasits' profile] on ozfootball.net*[http://www.worldfootball.net/player_summary/joe-vlatsis/ Joe Vlasits' profile] on worldfootball.net{{Australia national football team coaches}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Vlasits, Joe}}[[Category:Australia national soccer team managers]][[Category:1921 births]][[Category:1985 deaths]][[Category:Hungarian expatriate football managers]][[Category:Hungarian footballers]][[Category:Sportspeople from Budapest]])
(1	Palm Beach Hawks	{{Pro hockey team| team       = Palm Beach Hawks| bg_color   = background:#FFFFFF; border-top:red 5px solid; border-bottom:red 5px solid;| text_color = Black| logo       =| city       = [[Lake Worth, Florida]]| league     = [[United States Premier Hockey League|USPHL]]| conference =| division   =| founded    = 2006| arena      = Palm Beach SkateZone| colors     =| owner      = Carlos & Debbie Frietas| GM         = Carlos Frietas| coach      = Don Babineau| website    = [http://www.palmbeachjrhawks.com PalmBeachJrHawks.com]}}The '''Palm Beach Hawks''' are an [[United States|American]] [[junior ice hockey|junior]] [[ice hockey]] organization playing in [[Lake Worth, Florida]]. They field two [[junior ice hockey#Tier III|Tier III teams]] and a number of youth teams.==History==Established in 2006 as the Palm Beach Predators, the organization was renamed Hawks in 2009. The organization were members of the [[Southeast Junior Hockey League]] (which became the [[EJHL South]] in 2011) from 2006 until 2011. A second team was formed for the 2009–10 season which competed in the [[Metropolitan Junior Hockey League]] and then the [[Empire Junior Hockey League]] from 2011 to 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usajuniorhockey.com/palm-beach-hawks-young-simons-impresses-at-training-camp-teams-open-season-this-weekend/ |title=Young Simons impresses at training camp, teams open season this weekend |date=September 13, 2012 |website=USA Junior Hockey Magazine}}</ref> In 2013, many American junior hockey leagues reorganized and both teams joined the [[United States Premier Hockey League]] in the Elite and Empire Divisions, respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usajuniorhockey.com/united-states-premier-hockey-league-elite-a-great-tradition-of-junior-hockey-in-the-east-continues/ |title=United States Premier Hockey League Elite: A great tradition of junior hockey in the East continues |date=October 9, 2013 |website=USA Junior Hockey Magazine}}</ref> In 2015, the Empire Division was rebranded to the USP3. In 2017, the USP3 was disbanded, the USPHL added a higher division, and the Hawks' teams were promoted to the Premier and Elite Divisions.==Season-by-season=={| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center"!
