(0	Temple Israel (Dayton, Ohio)	{{Infobox religious building| building_name         =Temple Israel| image                 =| image_size            =275px| caption               =| map_type              =| map_size              =| map_caption           =| location              =130 Riverside Drive,<br/>[[Dayton, Ohio]],<br/>{{flag|United States}}| geo                   = {{coord|39.768979|-84.189906|display=inline,title}}| religious_affiliation =[[Reform Judaism]]| rite                  =| region                =| province              =| territory             =| prefecture            =| sector                =| district              =| cercle                =| municipality          =| consecration_year     =| status                =| functional_status     =Active| heritage_designation  =| leadership            =Senior Rabbi: Karen Bodney-HalaszRabbi Emeritus: David M. Sofian| website               ={{url|tidayton.org}}| architecture          =yes| architect             =| architecture_type     =| architecture_style    =| general_contractor    =| facade_direction      =| groundbreaking        =| year_completed        =1994<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>| construction_cost     =| specifications        =| capacity              =| length                =| width                 =| width_nave            =| height_max            =| dome_quantity         =| dome_height_outer     =| dome_height_inner     =| dome_dia_outer        =| dome_dia_inner        =| minaret_quantity      =| minaret_height        =| spire_quantity        =| spire_height          =| materials             =| nrhp                  =| added                 =| refnum                =| designated            =}}'''Temple Israel''' is a [[Reform Judaism|Reform]] congregation located at 130 Riverside Drive in [[Dayton, Ohio]]. Formed in 1850, it incorporated as "Kehillah Kodesh B'nai Yeshurun" in 1854.<ref name=Incorporated/> After meeting in rented quarters, the congregation purchased its first [[synagogue]] building, a former Baptist church at 4th and Jefferson, in 1863. Strongly influenced by [[Rabbi]] [[Isaac Mayer Wise]], it rapidly modernized its services, and, in 1873, was a founding member of the [[Union for Reform Judaism]].<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>The congregation sold its existing building in 1893, and constructed a larger one at First and Jefferson,<ref name=FirstJefferson/> later severely damaged by the [[Great Dayton Flood]] of 1913.<ref name=History/> In 1927, the congregation moved to still larger, multi-purpose premises at Salem and Emerson Avenues, outside downtown Dayton, and began to use the name "Temple Israel",<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives195/> adding a new sanctuary to the building in 1953. Temple Israel moved to its current building in 1994.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/>Synagogue membership grew steadily for over 100 years, from 12 families in 1850 to 150 in the early 1900s, 200 by 1927, and 500 by 1945, peaking at 1,100 in the 1960s. By 1995, however, membership was down to 800 families.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>Temple Israel has had a number of long-tenured [[rabbi]]s who were influential both in the congregation and in the larger Dayton community. These have included [[David Lefkowitz]] (1900–1920), Louis Witt (1927–1947), Selwyn Ruslander (1947–1969) and P. Irving Bloom (1973–1997).<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> {{As of|2011}}, the rabbis were David M. Sofian and Karen Bodney-Halasz.<ref name=Staff/>==The early years, at 4th and Jefferson==What was later to become Temple Israel was originally formed as a Hebrew Society in 1850 by twelve Jewish men under the leadership of Joseph Lebensburger, a [[German Jews|German Jew]]<ref name=Olitzky1996p293>[[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293.</ref><ref name=History>[[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website.</ref><ref name=AJArchives616>[[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]].</ref><ref name=Thum2000>[[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]].</ref> and first permanent Jewish resident of Dayton.<ref name=Tedford2009>[[#refTedford2009|Tedford (2009)]].</ref> The Society met daily for [[minyan|prayers]] in rented rooms: first above a shop in the old Dayton Bank Building (which was later the Steele High School, and has since been demolished) near Monument and Main Streets, and later in larger quarters in a building next to the Cooper building, a block south on Main Street.<ref name="Olitzky1996p293"/><ref name=History/><ref name=AJArchives616/><ref name=Thum2000/><ref name=Tedford2009/><ref name=Landman1941v3p493>[[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493.</ref> It also hired its first [[Torah reading|Torah reader]], a "Mr. Wendel",<ref name=Wendel/> and purchased—for $100 (today ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|100|1850|r=-2}}}})—a small piece of land for a cemetery on what is now Rubicon Street.<ref name=FirstCemetery/>The Society incorporated as "Kehillah Kodesh B'nai Yeshurun"<ref>or "B'nai Jeshurun", "B'nai Jeshurim".</ref> in 1854.<ref name=Incorporated/> It moved to larger facilities, first near First and Main Streets in 1860, and then, in 1863,<ref name=4thJeffersonDate/> to the northeast corner of 4th and Jefferson Streets. There Kehillah Kodesh B'nai Yeshurun purchased for $1,500 (today ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|1500|1863|r=-3}}}})<ref name=4thJeffersonPrice/> its first owned premises, the building of a [[Baptist]] church whose congregation was moving to Main Street.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=History/><ref name=Thum2000/>The structure required "extensive remodeling", and Lebensburger, as building chairman, led the campaign to raise the necessary $9,000 (today ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|9000|1863|r=-3}}}}). Funds came not only from the membership but also from non-Jewish members of many local societies, including the [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows|Odd Fellows]] and [[Freemasonry|Masons]].<ref name=Thum2000/> Rabbi [[Isaac Mayer Wise]] assisted B'nai Yeshurun's then–religious leader<ref name=Delbanco/> Rev. Mr. Delbanco with the dedication of what became "the seventh congregation-owned Jewish House of Worship in Ohio."<ref name=AJArchives616/><ref name=Thum2000/>==Move to Reform, and early rabbis==Influenced by Wise, the congregation implemented many reforms in its services. In 1861 they adopted Wise's ''[[Minhag America]]'' [[siddur|prayer book]]. In that same decade they added an [[Pipe organ|organ]], did away with the [[Tallit|prayer shawl]], and started a [[Hebrew school|religious school]]. In the 1870s the congregation removed [[yahrzeit candle]]s from the sanctuary, and added [[Mechitza|family pews]] and a [[Tzniut#Female singing voice|mixed choir]] (men and women together). In 1873 B'nai Yeshurun was one of the first thirteen founding members of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations (UAHC), now [[Union for Reform Judaism]].<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/>By 1889 B'nai Yeshurun had outgrown its original cemetery, and the congregation purchased {{convert|8|acre}} on West Schantz Avenue in [[Oakwood, Montgomery County, Ohio|Oakwood]]. Oakwood was a "restricted community"; Jews were not allowed to reside or own stores there. According to Leonard Spialter, president of the Dayton Jewish Genealogical Society, "if you were dead, you could be buried in Oakwood, but if you were alive, you couldn’t live there". Relatives began moving those buried at the Rubicon cemetery to the new "Riverview Cemetery", including Lebensburger, who had died by this time. This process was not completed until 1967.<ref name=Tedford2009/>In its first forty years the congregation had a series of generally short-tenured religious leaders. These included Delbanco (1862–63), Moses Bauer (1863–64), L. Liebman (1864–67), Abraham Blum (1868–69), Leon Leopold (1870–72), Ben Weil (1872–76), Ephraim Fischer (1876–81), Godfrey/Gottheil Taubenhaus (later rabbi of [[Congregation Beth Elohim (Brooklyn, New York)|Congregation Beth Elohim]] of [[Brooklyn, New York]]) (1881–85), and Israel Saenger (1885–89).<ref name=Landman1941v3p493/>During this period the membership also transformed from immigrant-born to native-born. In 1881 the congregation's "language of record" was changed from German to English, and in 1889 the synagogue hired its first American-trained [[rabbi]], Max Wertheimer.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>A graduate of Wise's [[Hebrew Union College]], Wertheimer had been born in Germany to [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] parents. He was popular with the congregation, and Dayton's Christian community highly respected him. Non-Jews attended his Friday evening sermons, and he in turn was a guest speaker at many Dayton churches.<ref name=Thum2000/>==First and Jefferson building, and David Lefkowitz as rabbi==In 1893 the congregation sold its building at 4th and Jefferson, and constructed a new one at First and Jefferson.<ref name=FirstJefferson/> Wise again assisted with the dedication.<ref name=AJArchives616/>Wertheimer's wife died young, leaving him with two small children.<ref name=Thum2000/> This tragedy made him question his faith;<ref name=Thum2000/> in 1899<ref name=WertheimerResigned/> he resigned from the congregation, resigned his membership in the [[Central Conference of American Rabbis]] (CCAR), and, in 1900, converted to [[Christian Science]];<ref name=Thum2000/><ref name=Umansky2005pp26-27>[[#refUmansky2005|Umansky (2005)]], pp. 26–27.</ref> in 1938 [[David Max Eichhorn]] wrote that "[[Mary Baker Eddy]] herself financed Wertheimer's study".<ref name=Eddy/> Wertheimer later became a [[Baptist]].<ref name=WertheimerBaptist/>David Lefkowitz was hired as rabbi in 1900, when the congregation comprised around 150 families.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> Born in [[Prešov|Eperies]], [[Hungary]] in 1875, he had emigrated to the United States with his widowed mother and two brothers around 1881. Due to financial difficulties, he and one brother grew up in the [[Hebrew Orphan Asylum of New York]], where he later worked to help pay for his schooling. A graduate of both the [[City College of New York|College of the City of New York]] and the [[University of Cincinnati]], he was [[semicha|ordained]] at Hebrew Union College in 1900.<ref name=AJArchives195>[[#refAJArchives195|An Inventory to the David Lefkowitz, Sr. Papers]].</ref> Held in "high regard" by the membership,<ref name=Thum2000/> Lefkowitz was also "an active force in Dayton's civic and interfaith activities" and an "ambassador of the Jewish Community to the Dayton area".<ref name=AJArchives616/> He was the first president of the Dayton chapter of the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] and served on its Executive Board, and also served as president of the [[Humane Society]].<ref name=Guzman2000pp21-22>[[#refGuzman2000|Guzman (2000)]], pp. 21–22.</ref>Later president of the CCAR,<ref name=AJArchives195/><ref name=Guzman2000p52>[[#refGuzman2000|Guzman (2000)]], p. 52.</ref> Lefkowitz was also [[Anti-Zionism|anti-Zionist]].<ref name=Guzman2000p55>[[#refGuzman2000|Guzman (2000)]], p. 55.</ref> He was one of the prominent Jewish signatories of a petition presented in 1919 by [[United States Congress]]man [[Julius Kahn (congressman)|Julius Kahn]] to [[President of the United States]] [[Woodrow Wilson]] who "asserted their wish not to see Palestine 'either now or at any time in the future' become a Jewish state."<ref name=Kolsky1992p31>[[#refKolsky1992|Kolsky (1992)]], p. 31.</ref><ref name=Kolsky1992p78>[[#refKolsky1992|Kolsky (1992)]], p. 78.</ref> In 1942, he was one of the founders of the [[American Council for Judaism]], "the only American Jewish organization ever formed for the specific purpose of fighting Zionism and opposing the establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine."<ref name=Kolsky1992pix>[[#refKolsky1992|Kolsky (1992)]], p. ix.</ref>During Lefkowitz's tenure, the synagogue building was severely damaged by the [[Great Dayton Flood]] of 1913.<ref name=History/> Lefkowitz was "in charge of one of the districts outside the flooded area". There he assisted around 28,000 refugees in finding shelter, and "established a bread line to feed them".<ref name=RedCross/> However, his suggestion that the congregation move to a larger building in a new location outside downtown Dayton, while taken seriously, was not acted on.<ref name=Thum2000/>Membership had grown to 206 families by 1919. The congregational school held classes twice a week, and had 8 classes, 10 teachers, and 140 students. That year the synagogue's total income was $10,000 (today ${{formatnum:{{inflation|US|10000|1919|r=-3}}}}).<ref name=refAJYearBookV21p531>[[#refAJYearBookV21|''American Jewish Year Book'', Vol. 21]], p.&nbsp;531.</ref> In 1920, Lefkowitz moved to [[Temple Emanu-El (Dallas, Texas)|Temple Emanu-El]], Dallas's largest and oldest synagogue.<ref name=AJArchives195/><ref name=Guzman2000piv>[[#refGuzman2000|Guzman (2000)]], p. iv.</ref>==Salem and Emerson building==Samuel S. Mayersberg succeeded Lefkowitz as rabbi. He was "known for his oratorical skills and his crusades formoral and police reforms in Dayton". His major goal during his ministry was to acquire larger premises outside downtown Dayton, which was realized in 1927<ref name=SalemEmerson/> when the congregation moved to a new building at Salem and Emerson Avenues.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives195/><ref name=Thum2000/> Besides the main sanctuary, which had seating for 600 people, the structure included a social hall and kitchen, classrooms, and offices.<ref name=History/> It was at that time that the congregation began to use the name "Temple Israel".<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=History/> Mayersberg left that year, and became the rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jehudah of [[Kansas City, Missouri]].<ref name=Olitzky1996p194>[[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 194.</ref> During his tenure, membership increased to 200 families.<ref name=MaysersbergMembership/>Louis Witt succeeded Mayersberg in 1927. He worked on fostering interfaith relations, and, like his predecessors, was active in community and civic life.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> A tall man who sometimes wore a [[Dress coat#Dress coat|swallow-tail coat]] when conducting services, he was a strong proponent of [[Pittsburgh Platform|"Classical Reform"]] principles, and while he was rabbi, following his preference, no one wore a [[Kippah|skullcap]] in the Temple.<ref name=Thum2000/>In 1929, at the second UAHC convention, Witt had asserted that America "by its very pleasantness and friendliness lures us away from our ancient loyalties. Its secularism is so delightful, its mutuality so penetrative, its universalism so delightful, that by a sort of sheer spiritual osmosis it incorporates us into itself and makes us look and become more and more like itself". Witt argued that Jews had to resist this pull.<ref name=Eisen1995p42>[[#refEisen1995|Eisen (1995)]], p. 42</ref> Ten years later, however, in a 1939 article in ''[[The Christian Century]]'', he argued that Jews should celebrate [[Christmas]]. In his view, Christians were now more liberal and celebrated "the inherent humanness and [[universalism]]" of Christmas, rather than any specifically Christian doctrine. Stating that his children had been deprived of the holiday's pleasures, Witt asserted that [[Judaism]] was already a syncretic religion, and that celebrating the holiday was an ecumenical act which did not indicate that he was "thereby drawn even by the breadth of a hair nearer to the worship of an ecclesiastical [[Christ]]". He concluded by asking "Is it neither treason of Jew nor triumph of Christian but partnership of Jew and Christian in the making of a better world in which the Christ can have part only by energizing and perpetuating and hallowing the partnership?"<ref>See [[#refTime1940|TIME (1940)]], [[#refSarna1990|Sarna (1990)]], p. 158, [[#refRestad1996|Restad (1996)]], pp. 158–159, [[#refShandler2009|Shandler (2009)]], pp. 198–199.</ref>During Witt's tenure, Dayton experienced an influx of Jewish immigration, and the original German-Jewish constituency of the congregation became more diverse. Family membership reached 500 by 1945.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>==New sanctuary during Selwyn Ruslander's tenure==Following Witt's retirement in 1947, Selwyn D. Ruslander succeeded him.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/> Born in Pennsylvania in 1911, Ruslander had graduated from the University of Cincinnati in 1931, and was ordained at Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati in 1935. He worked at a number of non-rabbinic jobs (including as an [[Ordinary Seaman]] in the [[United States Merchant Marine|U.S. Merchant Marine]]), and several rabbinic positions, including both pulpit and non-pulpit roles. In 1939 he was appointed Director of Youth Education for the UAHC, and also became the first director of the National Federation of Temple Youth (now [[North American Federation of Temple Youth]]).<ref name=AJArchives460>[[#refAJArchives460|An Inventory to the Selwyn D. Ruslander Papers]].</ref> In 1942, during [[World War II]], he took a leave of absence from the UAHC to volunteer for the armed forces as a [[United States Navy Chaplain Corps|U.S. Navy chaplain]].<ref name=RuslanderNavy/> From 1943 to 1945 he served with the [[United States Eighth Fleet]] in the [[Mediterranean Sea]], "the first Jewish chaplain in the history of the Navy to serve with a combat fleet", and earned a Combat Star for his participation in [[Operation Shingle]]. He was released from active duty in December 1946, and returned briefly to the UAHC, then went to South Shore Temple in [[Chicago]], before taking the role at Temple Israel.<ref name=AJArchives460/>Ruslander brought some traditionalism back to the congregation; he reinstated the [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] and inaugurated the Bat Mitzvah celebrations, and re-organized the religious school and added Hebrew to its curriculum.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> Like his predecessors, he was very active in Dayton's civic life, serving on the boards of a large number of community organizations.<ref name=RuslanderBoards/> Ruslander was possibly Dayton's then "best known clergyman of any faith", and during his tenure Temple Israel experienced rapid growth. In 1953, Temple Israel constructed a new sanctuary at its Salem and Emerson location, and connected it to the original building. By the end of the 1960s membership increased to 1,100 families, and Temple Israel hired Howard R. Greenstein and Joseph S. Weizenbaum as assistant rabbis. Ruslander died in 1969, and for several years Greenstein and Weisenbaum served as interim spiritual leaders.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> In 1972, Weizenbaum became rabbi of [[Temple Emanu-El (Tucson)|Temple Emanu-El]] of Tucson, Arizona, where he served until 1993.<ref name=Olitzky1996p38>[[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 38.</ref> Greenstein joined Jacksonville, Florida's [[Congregation Ahavath Chesed (Jacksonville, Florida)|Congregation Ahavath Chesed]] as rabbi in 1973, and served there until 1995.<ref name=Greenstein>See [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 100 and [[#refKerr2006|Kerr (2006)]].</ref>==The move to Riverside Drive, led by P. Irving Bloom==P. (Paul) Irving Bloom joined as rabbi in 1973.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/><ref name=AJArchives616/> He had previously been a [[United States Air Force Chaplain Corps|U.S. Air Force chaplain]], then rabbi of [[Congregation Sha'arai Shomayim (Mobile, Alabama)|Congregation Sha'arai Shomayim]] in [[Mobile, Alabama]] from 1960 to 1973.<ref name=BloomMobile/> Bloom introduced a number of innovations to the synagogue, including joint programs with other Dayton synagogues, a new curriculum for the religious school and Jewish studies classes for adults, and enhanced Friday programs and lay-led services in the summer.<ref name=History/> Bloom strongly believed that Temple Israel should relocate to a more central location, as the Jewish community of Dayton had by then spread throughout [[Miami Valley]]. His vision was realized in 1994, when the congregation moved to a new building on Riverside Drive, near downtown Dayton. The building at Salem and Emerson was sold to a Baptist church. As noted by Bloom, the congregation had "come full circle"; it purchased its first building from a Baptist church in downtown Dayton, and had sold its most recent building to a Baptist church in order to return to the area.<ref name=Thum2000/> By 1995, however, membership was only eight hundred families.<ref name=Olitzky1996p293/>Bloom retired in 1997, and was succeeded by Marc Gruber.<ref name=History/> A graduate of [[Brandeis University]], Gruber attended Hebrew Union College in Jerusalem and New York, and was ordained in 1981. A vegetarian, he also wrote a syndicated vegetarian cooking column from 1990 to 1993.<ref name=StaffCSNC>[[#refStaffCSNC|Staff]], Central Synagogue of Nassau County website</ref> At Temple Israel he reformed the services and introduced Bar and Bat Mitzvah classes for adults. During his tenure, in 2000, the congregation celebrated its Sesquicentennial, with a number of "religious, cultural, social and social action programs" throughout the year.<ref name=History/> Gruber also served on the Steering Committee for the UAHC Department of Jewish Family Concerns from 1995 to 2002, working on "the inclusion of people with disabilities and special needs".<ref name=StaffCSNC/> Gruber moved to Central Synagogue of Nassau County in [[Rockville Centre, New York]] in 2002, and Michael Remson served as interim rabbi.<ref name=History/>==Recent events==David M. Sofian joined as Rabbi in 2003. A graduate of Hebrew Union College and the [[University of Missouri]], Sofian had served as assistant rabbi at [[Temple Emanuel Sinai (Worcester, Massachusetts)|Temple Emanuel]] in [[Worcester, Massachusetts]], at Temple Shaarai Shomayim in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]], and at Emanuel Congregation in Chicago, before coming to Temple Israel. Karen Bodney-Halasz, a graduate of [[Northwestern University]], joined as Religious School Director in 2003 and became Director of Education in 2005. After her rabbinic ordination in June 2007, she became Rabbi-Educator.<ref name=Staff>[[#refStaff|Staff]], Temple Israel website.</ref>Sofian retired in 2014, IIlene Bogosian was hired as interim senior rabbi and Bodney-Halasz was elevated to associate rabbi. After an eight-month search process, the temple's search committee unanimously recommended Bodney-Halasz become the next senior rabbi. The temple's board of directors approved that recommendation in January 2016, making Bodney-Halasz Temple Israel's first female senior rabbi. She officially took over July 1.==Notes=={{reflist|colwidth=40em|refs=<ref name=Wendel>[[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]] spells the name "Wendel". [[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493 spells it "Wendell".</ref><ref name=FirstCemetery>Sources differ on the size of the piece of land purchased for a cemetery, and on the date purchased:*[[#refTedford2009|Tedford (2009)]] writes "On July 14, 1851, Joseph Lebensburger purchased a quarter acre of land at Rubicon and Stewart Streets on behalf of The Hebrew Society. This would become the burial site for the society, later to be known as Temple Israel."*[[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]] writes "...Lebensburger, along with his wife Rose paid $100 to Jacob Dietrich for an acre of his land. That transaction, which took place May 5, 1854, assured the newly incorporated KKBY that its congregants would have a cemetery."*[[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]] states "In 1850, a small Jewish community in Dayton, Ohio [...] created a Hebrew Society and began to conduct services [...] in downtown Dayton. The Hebrew Society also purchased a cemetery on the outskirts of Dayton on what is now known as the Rubicon Street  (an alley parallel to Stewart)."</ref><ref name=Incorporated>According to [[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493, [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, [[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]], and [[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website. According to [[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]], the Society was created in 1850, and "Within a year, the Society created a formal synagogue known as K.K. B'nai Yeshurun."</ref><ref name=4thJeffersonDate>According to [[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493, [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, and [[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]]. According to [[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website, the 4th and Jefferson building was purchased in 1860.</ref><ref name=4thJeffersonPrice>According to [[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]]. According to [[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website, the purchase price was $4,500.</ref><ref name=Delbanco>[[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]] and [[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493, describe Delbanco as the congregation's "rabbi". [[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]], describes him as "the Senior Reader".</ref><ref name=FirstJefferson>According to [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, and [[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website. According to [[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]], the First and Jefferson building was constructed in 1891.</ref><ref name=WertheimerResigned>Sources differ on the year Wertheimer resigned. [[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]] writes "In 1898 Wertheimer resigned from Temple Israel". [[#refUmansky2005|Umansky (2005)]], p. 27 writes that he "declined reappointment in 1899". [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, write that "Wertheimer left in 1900", and [[#refLandman1941v3|Landman (1941) Vol. 3]], p. 493 also gives the end of his term as 1900.</ref><ref name=Eddy>[[#refUmansky2005|Umansky (2005)]], p. 27, citing John J. Appel, "Christian Science and the Jews", ''Jewish Social Studies'', 31, 2 (April 1969).</ref><ref name=WertheimerBaptist>[[#refThum2000|Thum (2000)]] writes that Wertheimer "became a Christian; first as a Christian Scientist and later as a Baptist minister." [[#refUmansky2005|Umansky (2005)]], p. 209, footnote 44, writes "According to Eichhorn, Wertheimer later left Christian Science for Baptist fundamentalism", citing John J. Appel, "Christian Science and the Jews", ''Jewish Social Studies'', 31, 2 (April 1969).</ref><ref name=RedCross>According to [[#refGuzman2000|Guzman (2000)]], p. 22. According to [[#refAJArchives195|An Inventory to the David Lefkowitz, Sr. Papers]], "He was president of the American Red Cross during the flood of 1913, dealing with the 30,000 refugees left homeless."</ref><ref name=SalemEmerson>According to [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, and [[#refAJArchives616|An Inventory to the Dayton, Ohio — Temple Israel Records]]. According to [[#refHistory|History of Temple Israel]], Temple Israel website, the new structure was built in 1925.</ref><ref name=MaysersbergMembership>According to [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky & Raphael (1996)]], p. 293, membership was "stable at 150 families" during Lefkowitz's tenure, and "grew to two hundred" before Mayersberg left in 1927. According to [[#refAJArchives195|An Inventory to the David Lefkowitz, Sr. Papers]], "During [Lefkowitz's] tenure the congregation grew from 82 families to over 300 families."</ref><ref name=RuslanderNavy>For more on Ruslander's activities in the navy, see [[#refAJArchives460|An Inventory to the Selwyn D. Ruslander Papers]], [[#refGrobman1994|Grobman (1994)]], p. 18, and [[#refMoore2004|Moore (2004)]], p. 144.</ref><ref name=RuslanderBoards>According to [[#refAJArchives460|An Inventory to the Selwyn D. Ruslander Papers]], these included "the Human Relations Council, the Dayton [[National Urban League|Urban League]], the Board of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]], the County Juvenile Court Advisory Council, the Health and Welfare Planning Council's Casework Study committee, the Ohio Committee on Delinquency and Crime, the Ohio Citizen's Council, and the Ohio Youth Commission."</ref><ref name=BloomMobile>See [[#refOlitzky1996|Olitzky (1996)]], p. 32 and [[#refISJLMobile|Institute for Southern Jewish Life]]. According to the Institute for Southern Jewish Life, Bloom started his tenure at Sha'arai Shomayim in 1958.</ref>}}==References=={{refbegin}}*<span id="refStaffCSNC" class="citation">[https://web.archive.org/web/20100508144019/http://www.centralsy.org/aboutus/staff/ Staff], About Us, Central Synagogue of Nassau County website. ''From Christian Science to Jewish Science: spiritual healing and American Jews'', [[Oxford University Press]], 2005. {{ISBN|978-0-19-504400-3}}</span>{{refend}}==Further reading==* Lubow, Jeffrey Samuel. ''Chronicle of an American Crusader'', [[Bloch Publishing Company]], 1944. {{ISBN|978-1-4067-5881-8}}==External links==*[https://books.google.com/books?id=e2X0JqKvTpoC&pg=PA49false#v=onepage&q=&f=false Picture of the First and Jefferson synagogue in 1893]*[https://books.google.com/books?id=OOLhwFMy1zkC&pg=PA103#v=onepage&q=&f=false Picture of the current sanctuary interior]{{good article}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Israel (Dayton, Ohio)}}[[Category:1850 establishments in Ohio]][[Category:19th-century synagogues]][[Category:Buildings and structures in Dayton, Ohio]][[Category:Culture of Dayton, Ohio]][[Category:Founding members of the Union for Reform Judaism]][[Category:Reform Judaism in Ohio]][[Category:Reform synagogues in Ohio]][[Category:Religious organizations established in 1850]])

      = 5008|pop_est_as_of            = 2016|population_footnotes     = <ref name ="FactFinder"/>|population_total         = 2584|population_density_km2   = 112.0|population_density_sq_mi = 290.0<!-- General information -->|timezone                 = [[North American Central Time Zone|Central (CST)]]|utc_offset               = -6|timezone_DST             = CDT|utc_offset_DST           = -5|elevation_footnotes      = <ref name="GR3">{{cite web|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov|accessdate=2008-01-31|title=US Board on Geographic Names|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|date=2007-10-25}}</ref>|elevation_m              =|elevation_ft             = 778|coordinates              = {{coord|42|33|32|N|88|02|57|W|region:US-WI|display=inline,title}}<!-- Area/postal codes & others -->|postal_code_type         = ZIP Code|postal_code              = 53104|area_code                = [[Area code 262|262]]|blank_name               = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]]|blank_info               = 55-09800|blank1_name              = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID|blank1_info              = 1562217<ref name="GR3" />|website                  =|footnotes                =|pop_est_footnotes = <ref name="USCensusEst2016"/>}}'''Bristol''' is a village in [[Kenosha County, Wisconsin|Kenosha County]], [[Wisconsin]], United States. It was incorporated in 2009 from portions of the [[Bristol, Kenosha County, Wisconsin|Town of Bristol]]. The population was 2,584 at the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]]. The former unincorporated communities of [[Bissell, Wisconsin|Bissell]], [[Cypress, Wisconsin|Cypress]], [[Pikeville, Wisconsin|Pikeville]], and [[Woodworth, Wisconsin|Woodworth]] are located in the village.==History=={{Main|Bristol (town), Kenosha County, Wisconsin}}The Bristol area's first settler was Rollin Tuttle, who arrived in April 1830.<ref>'Racine Journal,' December 22, 1902, pg. 1</ref>  The village was named in 1836 for two brothers, George and Lester Bristol.<ref>{{cite book|author=Chicago and North Western Railway Company|title=A History of the Origin of the Place Names Connected with the Chicago & North Western and Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha Railways|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OspBAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA47|year=1908|page=47}}</ref>The first Barnum circus to play in Wisconsin played in Bristol before the Civil War.<ref>Wisconsin Encyclopedia  By Federal Writers' Project of the Works Progress Administration, Jennifer L. Herman page 271</ref>In November 2009, residents of the Town of Bristol living in the {{convert|9|mi2|km2}} of the northwest corner of the town voted to incorporate as a village.<ref>Deneen Smith "Bristol votes yes to incorporation", November 3, 2009. [http://www.kenoshanews.com/home/bristol_votes_yes_to_incorporation_6679865.html 'Kenosha News'']</ref> The incorporation became official on December 1, 2009, when a certificate of incorporation was issued by the [[Secretary of State of Wisconsin]]. The first elections for village officials took place on January 19, 2010.<ref name="town.bristol.wi.us">[http://www.town.bristol.wi.us/usrDefault.aspx Town of Bristol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529224614/http://www.town.bristol.wi.us/usrDefault.aspx |date=May 29, 2010 }}</ref>In early January 2010, village officials approved filing a petition with the county court to hold a referendum on annexing the remainder of the Town of Bristol.<ref>Bill Guida "New Bristol border battle brewing?", ''[[Kenosha News]]'', January 7, 2010. [http://www.kenoshanews.com/news/new_bristol_border_battle_brewing_7090802.html Kenosha News article]</ref> On June 29, 2010, the village of Bristol voted to annex the remainder of the town of Bristol. The annexation took effect on July 4, 2010. A small section of the town was also annexed by the village of [[Pleasant Prairie, Wisconsin]].<ref name="town.bristol.wi.us"/>== Geography ==According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the village has a total area of {{convert|9.03|sqmi|sqkm|2}}, of which, {{convert|8.91|sqmi|sqkm|2}} of it is land and {{convert|0.12|sqmi|sqkm|2}} is water.<ref name="Gazetteer files">{{cite web |title=US Gazetteer files 2010 |url=https://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/files/Gaz_places_national.txt |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] |accessdate=2012-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64vfLAeJ2?url=http://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/files/Gaz_places_national.txt |archivedate=2012-01-24 |df= }}</ref>Bristol has several residential neighborhoods:=== Bissell ===Bissell is located at the intersection of Kenosha County Highways C (Wilmot Road) and MB, just south of the residential neighborhood of [[Woodworth, Wisconsin|Woodworth]].<ref name="rootsweb.ancestry.com">http://rootsweb.ancestry.com/~wikenosh/placenames.htm</ref> A feed, flour and coal business was a part of community life in 19th-century Bissell, especially after a U.S. post office was established within that building in 1893; however, the post office closed 16 months later.=== Cypress ===Cypress is a neighborhood flanking U.S. Highway 45 at 128th Street (Kenosha County Highway WG), just north of the Wisconsin-Illinois border. At the time it was settled, the village was named [[Hoadley, Wisconsin|Hoadley]], and had its own post office under that name.<ref name="rootsweb.ancestry.com"/>=== Pikeville ===Pikeville is a residential and agricultural community<ref>[http://wisconsin.hometownlocator.com/wi/kenosha/pikeville.cfm Hometown Locator]</ref> (originally named Pikeville Corners) named for three brothers surnamed Pike. It was settled around the one-room Pikeville School (now a restaurant) in the 19th century. It is centered along [[U.S. Route 45]] at 116th Street, approximately one mile north of the Wisconsin-Illinois border, on the eastern shore of Mud Lake.<ref>[http://www.placenames.com/us/p1571400/ Pikeville on Placenames.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225140506/http://www.placenames.com/us/p1571400/ |date=February 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.placenames.com/us/p1569904/ Mud Lake website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225140543/http://www.placenames.com/us/p1569904/ |date=February 25, 2012 }}</ref>=== Woodworth ===Woodworth is located on Kenosha County Highway MB at 82nd Street.<ref>[http://wisconsin.hometownlocator.com/wi/kenosha/woodworth.cfm Hometown Locator: Woodworth]</ref> The [[Kenosha and Rockford Railroad]] (the "KD Line") brought prosperity and activity to Woodworth, and a U.S. post office ([[ZIP Code]] 53194) is located there. By 1920, a large serum laboratory had been built in Woodworth. It provided wartime vaccines for troops and civilians. Woodworth's rural appearance has been featured in at least one on-location television commercial, as well as in the 1999 movie, ''[[The Last Great Ride]]'', starring [[Ernest Borgnine]] and [[Eileen Brennan]].<ref>[http://videoeta.com/movie/42017 Video ETA ''The Last Great Ride'']</ref>==Economy==Bristol has a commercial/industrial/small business incubator park and is home to the [[Bristol Renaissance Faire]] theme park, as well as the [[List of nature centers in the United States#Wisconsin|Pringle Nature Center]].<ref>[http://pringlenc.org/ Pringle Nature Center]</ref>==Demographics=={{US Census population|2010= 2584|estyear=2016|estimate=5008|estref=<ref name="USCensusEst2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/popest/data/tables.2016.html|title=Population and Housing Unit Estimates|accessdate=June 9, 2017}}</ref>|footnote=<center>U.S. Decennial Census<ref name="DecennialCensus">{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|title=Census of Population and Housing|publisher=Census.gov|accessdate=June 4, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YSasqtfX?url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|archivedate=May 12, 2015|df=}}</ref></center>}}===2010 census===As of the [[census]]<ref name ="FactFinder">{{cite web|title=American FactFinder|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/index.xhtml|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|accessdate=2012-11-18}}</ref> of 2010, there were 2,584 people, 934 households, and 716 families residing in the village. The [[population density]] was {{convert|290.0|PD/sqmi|PD/km2|1}}. There were 1,006 housing units at an average density of {{convert|112.9|/sqmi|/km2|1}}. The racial makeup of the village was 94.9% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 1.2% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 0.2% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.5% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 1.4% from [[Race (U.S. Census)|other races]], and 1.7% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 4.6% of the population.There were 934 households of which 39.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 61.6% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 11.5% had a female householder with no husband present, 3.6% had a male householder with no wife present, and 23.3% were non-families. 17.6% of all households were made up of individuals and 5.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.77 and the average family size was 3.15.The median age in the village was 39 years. 26.5% of residents were under the age of 18; 8.8% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 23.8% were from 25 to 44; 32.2% were from 45 to 64; and 8.7% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the village was 49.6% male and 50.4% female.==References=={{reflist|35em}}==External links=={{commonscat}}*[http://www.villageofbristol.org Village of Bristol, Wisconsin website]{{Kenosha County, Wisconsin}}[[Category:Villages in Wisconsin]][[Category:Villages in Kenosha County, Wisconsin]][[Category:2009 establishments in Wisconsin]])
(0	I Just Had to Hear Your Voice	{{Infobox single | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Songs -->| Name           = I Just Had to Hear Your Voice| Cover          = I_Just_Had_to_Hear_Your_Voice_by_Oleta_Adams.jpg| Artist         = [[Oleta Adams]]| from Album     = [[Evolution (Oleta Adams album)|Evolution]]| B-side         = "Get Here", "Think Again", "Don't Look Too Closely"| Released       = January 26, 1994| Format         = {{hlist|[[Single (music)|CD single]]|[[cassette single]]|7" vinyl}}| Recorded       = 1993| Genre          = {{hlist|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[soul music|soul]]}}| Length         = 3:38| Label          =| Writer         = {{hlist|Allan Rich|Jud Friedman}}| Producer       = {{hlist|Oleta Adams|[[Stewart Levine]]|Darren Klein}}| Reviews        =| Certification  =| Last single    =| This single    =| Next single    =| Misc        =}}"'''I Just Had to Hear Your Voice'''" is a 1994 [[R&B]] single by [[Oleta Adams]]. The single earned the singer a [[Soul Train Awards of 1994|Soul Train nomination]] for R&B Single of the Year, Female in 1994.<ref name="Jet">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA34-IA1&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Jet | publisher=Johnson | year=1944 | pages=35–36}}</ref>==Chart positions=={|class="wikitable sortable"!Chart (1993)!Peak<br>position|-|U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]]<ref name="AllMusic">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/oleta-adams-mn0000887806 | title=Oleta Adams: Music Biography, Credits and Discography - AllMusic | publisher=AllMusic | accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>|align="center"|97|}==Covers==The song has been covered by [[Jordan Hill (singer)|Jordan Hill]] and [[Brian Lane Green]]. Mexican singer [[Cristian Castro]] covered the song in Spanish as "El Deseo de Oír Tu Voz" from the [[El Deseo de Oír Tu Voz|album of the same name]].==References=={{reflist}}[[Category:1993 singles]][[Category:Cristian Castro songs]][[Category:1993 songs]])

(0	Calliotropis limbifera	{{Italic title}}{{Taxobox| name = ''Calliotropis limbifera''| image = Calliotropis limbifera 001.jpg| image_caption = Three views of a shell of ''Calliotropis limbifera''| regnum = [[Animal]]ia| phylum = [[Mollusca]]| classis = [[Gastropoda]]| unranked_superfamilia= clade [[Vetigastropoda]]| superfamilia = [[Seguenzioidea]]| familia = [[Calliotropidae]]| subfamilia =| genus = ''[[Calliotropis]]''| species = '''''C. limbifera'''''| binomial = ''Calliotropis limbifera''| binomial_authority = ([[Mattheus Marinus Schepman|Schepman]], 1908)| synonyms_ref =| synonyms =}}'''''Calliotropis limbifera''''' is a [[species]] of [[sea snail]], a marine [[gastropod]] [[mollusk]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Calliotropidae]].<ref name="WoRMS">{{WRMS species|446321|''Calliotropis limbifera'' (Schepman, 1908)||18 April 2010}}</ref>==Description==(Original description by Schepman) The shell reaches a length of 8 mm. The yellowish-white, conical shell is moderately depressed and slightly convex below. It has a very strong, rounded keel, and is widely umbilicate. The [[Spire (mollusc)|spire]] consists of 6½ [[Whorl (mollusc)|whorl]]s. The nucleus is smooth. The upper whorls contain concentric ribs and traces of one or two spiral lirae, producing small tubercles on the ribs. The whorls are flattened near the [[Suture (anatomy)|suture]]. Above the upper row of tubercles, this depression is roughened by small lamellae. The lower part of the whorls is slightly convex. On the lower whorls, the sculptureconsists of a row of rather strong tubercles At some distance from the suture, the flattened space between suture and tubercles is also lamelliferous. A second row of smaller tubercles makes its appearance, and becomes more conspicuous on the [[body whorl]]. At some distance from the lower suture, a spiral rib, with inconspicuous beads, is crossed by irregular, waved lamellae, which spread on the large keel. This keel is flat above, rounded at its periphery, and adorned by sharp, compressed folds, which make it crenulated. The base of the shell is sculptured by five beaded spirals, of which the outer one, placed at some distance from the margin, and the most central one, bordering the umbilicus are double. The whole base is covered by radiating very oblique riblets. The funnel-shaped [[Umbilicus (mollusc)|umbilicus]] is pervious. It has two spiral lirae, of which the lower one is beaded, and radiating riblike striae. Its largest diameter is about 1⅓ of the base. The [[Aperture (mollusc)|aperture]] is rhombic. The convex,outer margin is rather thin, internally lirate, with short folds between the lirae. The convex basal margin is short,  and internally with a few lirae. The broad [[Columella (gastropod)|columella]] is concave, with a conspicuous fold near the base and a small denticle above it. Itsupper part is connected to the outer margin by a conspicuous layer of enamel, with thickened margin, and a free ear-shaped projection, covering part of the umbilicus. <ref> [https://archive.org/details/sibogaexpeditie39sibo Schepman M.M. (1909), The prosobranchia of the Siboga Expedition]  </ref>==Distribution==This species occurs in the [[Sulu Sea]], the Philippines.==References=={{reflist}}* Vilvens C. (2007) ''New records and new species of Calliotropis from Indo-Pacific''. Novapex 8 (Hors Série 5): 1-72==External links==*{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}}{{Taxonbar}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Calliotropis Limbifera}}[[Category:Calliotropis|limbifera]][[Category:Animals described in 1908]])

(0	Du Hong	{{more footnotes|date=December 2013}}'''Du Hong''' (杜洪) (d. 905) was a warlord late in the [[History of China|Chinese]] dynasty [[Tang Dynasty]], who controlled Wuchang Circuit (武昌, headquartered in modern [[Wuhan]], [[Hubei]]) from 886 to 905.  In 905, he was defeated and captured by [[Yang Xingmi]], who executed him.==Background and seizure of Wuchang Circuit==It is not known when Du Hong was born, but it is known that he was from Wuchang's capital E Prefecture (鄂州) and that, in his youth, he was an actor.  Late in the ''Qianfu'' era (874-879) of [[Emperor Xizong of Tang|Emperor Xizong]], when much of the realm was overrun by agrarian rebels, E's prefect Cui Shao (崔紹) organized the people into local militias to defend against attacks, so the prefectural militia became a strong fighting force.  It was during this time that Du became an officer in the prefectural militia.<ref name=NBT190>''[[New Book of Tang]]'', [[:zh:s:新唐書/卷190|vol. 190]].</ref>In 884, Cui died.  The imperial official Lu Shenzhong (路審中), whom the imperial government had commissioned the prefect of Hang Prefecture (杭州, in modern [[Hangzhou]], [[Zhejiang]]), had been refused entry by the warlord [[Qian Liu]], who occupied the region; he therefore took up residence at Wuchang's Huang Prefecture (黃州, in modern Wuhan).  Upon hearing news of Cui's death, he conscripted 3,000 soldiers and entered E Prefecture, taking it over.  Thereafter, Du expelled the prefect of Yue Prefecture (岳州, in modern [[Yueyang]], [[Hunan]]) and took it over himself, claiming the title of prefect.<ref name=ZZTJ255>''[[Zizhi Tongjian]]'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷255|vol. 255]].</ref>In 886, the agrarian rebel Zhou Tong (周通) attacked E Prefecture.  Lu abandoned E and fled.  Du took the chance to enter E and claimed the title of acting military governor of Wuchang, a title that Emperor Xizong thereafter confirmed.<ref name=ZZTJ256>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷256|vol. 256]].</ref>==Rule of Wuchang Circuit==It was said that while Du Hong received the commission from the imperial government, he became an ally of the warlord [[Zhu Wen|Zhu Quanzhong]] the military governor of Xuanwu Circuit (宣武, headquartered in modern [[Kaifeng]], [[Henan]]) and cut off the tribute routes between the southeastern circuits not allied with Zhu and the imperial capital [[Chang'an]].<ref name=NBT190/>In 894, Wu Tao (吳討) the prefect of Huang Prefecture submitted to a chief rival of Zhu's, [[Yang Xingmi]] the military governor of Huainan Circuit (淮南, headquartered in modern [[Yangzhou]], [[Jiangsu]]).  In response, Du attacked Wu, and Wu, while Yang sent his brother-in-law [[Zhu Yanshou]] to aid Wu, was still fearful of Du's attack, and therefore surrendered his post completely to Yang.  Yang sent his officer Qu Zhang (瞿章) to take over Huang Prefecture and defend against Du.<ref name=ZZTJ259>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷259|vol. 259]].</ref>Fearing Yang's expansion, in 896, Du, along with Qian Liu (then the military governor of Zhenhai Circuit (鎮海, headquartered at Hang Prefecture)) and [[Zhong Chuan]] the military governor of Zhennan Circuit (鎮南, headquartered in modern [[Nanchong]], [[Jiangxi]]), all sought aid from Zhu Quanzhong.  Zhu Quanzhong sent his adoptive son Zhu Yougong (朱友恭) south to try to determine what he could do, but Zhu Yougong appeared to not venture far.<ref name=ZZTJ260>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷260|vol. 260]].</ref>In 897, under order by Emperor Xizong's brother and successor [[Emperor Zhaozong of Tang|Emperor Zhaozong]], Yang attacked Du, and Du sought aid from Zhu Quanzhong.  Zhu Quanzhong sent Nie Jin (聶金) to raid Huainan's Si Prefecture (泗州, in modern [[Huai'an]], [[Jiangsu]]) and sent Zhu Yougong to attack Huang Prefecture.  Qu abandoned Huang and took his army and people south to Wuchang Base (武昌寨, in modern [[Ezhou]], [[Hubei]]).  Zhu Yougong subsequently captured Wuchang Base, took Qu captive, and captured Huang Prefecture.  The Huainan forces that Yang sent to aid Qu were all repelled.  A subsequent major attack by Zhu Quanzhong on Huainan was decisively repelled by Yang and his general [[Zhu Jin]], however, and it was said that thereafter Zhu no longer had the strength to consider a major attack on Huainan.<ref name=ZZTJ261>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷261|vol. 261]].</ref>In 903, Yang sent his officer [[Li Shenfu]], with Liu Cun (劉存) as Li's deputy, to again attack Du.  Li first attack E Prefecture's Yongxing County (永興, in modern [[Huanggang]], [[Hubei]]) and captured it.<ref name=ZZTJ263>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷263|vol. 263]].</ref>  He then put E Prefecture under siege, and Du sought aid from Zhu Quanzhong.  Zhu sent his officer Han Qing (韓勍) with 10,000 men to Shekou (灄口, in modern Wuhan), and also sent messengers to [[Cheng Rui]] the military governor of Jingnan Circuit (荊南, headquartered in modern [[Jingzhou]], [[Hubei]]), [[Ma Yin]] the military governor of Wu'an Circuit (武安, headquartered in modern [[Changsha]], [[Hunan]]), and [[Lei Yanwei]] the military governor of Wuzhen Circuit (武貞, headquartered in modern [[Changde]], [[Hunan]]), trying to persuade them to save Du.  Cheng, who feared Zhu's strength and also wanted to expand his own territory, launched a fleet to try to save Du, but after he left his capital Jing Prefecture (荊州), Ma and Lei jointly attacked Jing Prefecture, capturing it and pillaging its wealth and population.  Hearing the news, the morale of Cheng's soldiers failed, and Li subsequently engaged him and decisively defeated him.  Cheng committed suicide by drowning, and Han withdrew, leaving Du with no aid.  Du was only subsequently saved when Li was also forced to withdraw when Yang's subordinates [[Tian Jun]] the military governor of Ningguo Circuit (寧國, headquartered in modern [[Xuancheng]], [[Anhui]]) and An Renyi (安仁義) the military prefect of Run Prefecture (潤州, in modern [[Zhenjiang]], [[Jiangsu]]) rebelled against Yang, requiring Li to engage Tian instead.<ref name=ZZTJ264>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷264|vol. 264]].</ref>==Defeat and death==In 904, with Yang Xingmi's having crushed Tian Jun's rebellion, he again sent Li Shenfu to attack Wuchang.  Zhu Quanzhong, who had then seized control of Emperor Zhaozong and forcibly moved the capital and the emperor from Chang'an to [[Luoyang]], sent messengers to Yang, seeking to intercede on Du Hong's behalf, and Yang responded, "I will do so and rebuild my relationship with you if the Son of Heaven were restored to Chang'an."<ref name=ZZTJ264/>  Later in 904, when Li fell ill (and later died), Yang sent Liu Cun to replace Li and continued the siege.  In spring 905, Zhu sent Cao Yanzuo (曹延祚) to help Du defend the city, but Liu soon captured the city and took Du and Cao captive, delivering them to Yang Xingmi at Huainan's capital Yang Prefecture (揚州).<ref name=ZZTJ265>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷265|vol. 265]].</ref>  When Yang questioned Du why he did not surrender, Du responded, "I could not betray Lord Zhu."  Yang then executed him and Cao.  After Zhu usurped the Tang throne and established [[Later Liang (Five Dynasties)|Later Liang]] as its emperor, he posthumously honored Du.<ref name=NBT190/>==Notes and references=={{reflist}}* ''[[New Book of Tang]]'', [[:zh:s:新唐書/卷190|vol. 190]].* ''[[Old History of the Five Dynasties|History of the Five Dynasties]]'', [[:zh:s:舊五代史/卷17|vol. 17]].* ''[[Zizhi Tongjian]]'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷255|255]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷256|256]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷259|259]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷260|260]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷261|261]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷263|263]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷264|264]], [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷265|265]].{{DEFAULTSORT:Du Hong}}[[Category:9th-century births]][[Category:905 deaths]][[Category:Politicians from Wuhan]][[Category:Tang dynasty jiedushi of Wuchang Circuit]][[Category:Executed Tang dynasty people]][[Category:Executed people from Hubei]][[Category:Executed military personnel]][[Category:People executed by the Tang dynasty by decapitation]][[Category:10th-century executions]][[Category:Tang dynasty generals from Hubei]][[Category:Male actors from Wuhan]][[Category:Tang dynasty politicians from Hubei]])
(0	Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed	{{refimprove|date=March 2011}}{{Infobox television episode| title = Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed| image =| caption =| season = 7| episode = 17| airdate = April 3, 2011| writer = Annie Weisman| director = [[David Warren (director)|David Warren]]| guests = * [[Emily Bergl]] as [[List of Desperate Housewives characters#Beth Young|Beth Young]]* Daniella Baltodano as [[Acquaintances of Gabrielle Solis#Celia Solis|Celia Solis]]* [[Harriet Sansom Harris]] as [[List of Desperate Housewives characters#Felicia Tilman|Felicia Tilman]]* [[Shawn Pyfrom]] as [[Andrew Van de Kamp]]* Todd Grinnell as [[Acquaintances of Bree Van de Kamp#Alex Cominis|Dr. Alex Cominis]]* Michael Kagan as Board Chairman* Ron Melendez as Glenn Morris* [[Josh Clark (actor)|Josh Clark]] as Warden* [[Aaron Lustig]] as Craig Lynwood* Brian Patacca as Car Salesman* [[Tim Ransom]] as Tommy* Karl T. Wright as Dr. Jenkins* Kevin Sifuentes as Jorge* Susan Grace as Edna* Andy Forrest as Chuck* [[Mindy Sterling]] as [[List of Desperate Housewives characters#Mitzi Kinsky|Mitzi Kinsky]]* Brittany Ross as Girl| episode_list = [[List of Desperate Housewives episodes]]| prev = [[Searching (Desperate Housewives)|Searching]]| next = [[Moments in the Woods]]}}"'''Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed'''" is the 151st episode of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[television series]], ''[[Desperate Housewives]]''. It is the seventeenth episode of the show's [[Desperate Housewives (season 7)|seventh season]] and was broadcast on April 3, 2011.==Plot==Beth Young shot herself in the head and is on life support. Her last wish was to donate a kidney to her dear friend Susan Delfino. Beth and Susan weren't really friends. That's probably why a grieving Paul tells his former neighbor that there's no way she's going to strip his wife for spare parts. Mike wants to fight this thing. The law is on their side. But that doesn't matter to Susan. She barely acknowledged Beth in life, so why should she deserve anything from her in death?Paul swings by the prison where Felicia tells him they need to stop hurling hatred at each other. She wants Beth taken off life support so she can rest. Later, Paul lets Susan know that he's alerted the transplant office to move forward with Beth's wishes. When he breaks down in tears, Susan gives him a hug. One can only suspect things will only get worse for Paul once he learns Felicia Tilman is being released from prison.Tom gets a great new job offer, but declines the deal out of loyalty to Carlos. This has Lynette scheming for ways to get him to reconsider. She performs a little bedroom seduction that's typically reserved for corporate hotshots. As sexy as this scene is, Tom won't be swayed. He tells her he will ask Carlos to match the offer, which he doesn't.Lynette swings by the local car dealership to borrow a $70,000 sports car. She parks that it in Carlos' driveway so that Tom can see that his boss certainly can afford to pay him better. The plan works. Tom accepts the new job, but wants to renege once he learns what his wife did. A test drive in the sports car has Tom reconsidering his position.Bree receives a call from Karen McCluskey in the early hours of the morning, telling her that Andrew was on her couch, passed out. Bree goes over to the house with Alex and they collect Andrew. They take him home, and then she and Alex talk about Andrew's problem. Alex mentions that he is thinking of leaving Andrew because of the seriousness of the problem, but Bree pleads with him not to if she could help him.Bree then secretly takes Andrew to an AA meeting (which he was not happy about). When it came to Andrew's turn to talk he instead started to criticize his mother and he mentions some of the bad things she has done throughout his life.Later on at Andrew's house, Bree asks Andrew to come back to another meeting, but he insists that he doesn't have a problem and that he is fine. Bree accepts this at first and leaves but then remembers about Beth and her pain, so she goes back inside and begs Andrew to discuss his problems. Andrew gets emotional as he tells her that Alex had left him due to his addiction. Bree asks Andrew one last time to come to the AA meeting, but he still says no. However, they end up having their own private meeting; just the two of them.Renee and Gaby have been planning a big party. Everyone is invited, but no one feels like going because of the Beth Young situation. That's not going to stop Renee from pressing forward with her fabulous spring fling.The night of the big party arrives and Renee's place is packed with a bunch of strangers. Gaby realizes the reason Renee wouldn't cancel the party is because her mother also committed suicide. This party is her way of dealing with it. Gaby then adds her name to the guest list in a show of support.==Reception==On its original broadcast on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], the episode scored 9.047 million of viewers and achieved a 2.9 rating in the adults 18-49 demographic. This episode was aired against the Country Music Awards on CBS which was watched by 13.05 million viewers and received a 3.3 in the 18-49 demographic. The awards show topped the night both in total viewers and the demographic.<ref>http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/05/sunday-final-ratings-desperate-housewives-secret-millionaire-american-dad-celebrity-apprentice-adjusted-up-cleveland-down/88298/</ref> With the DVR Rating, this episode is up 2.2 in million of viewers (rising to a total of 11.3 million of viewers) and it's up 0.8 in the adults 18-49 demographic (rising to a total of a 3.7 rating).<ref>http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/18/live7-dvr-ratings-greys-anatomy-musical-episode-tops-absolute-gains-the-event-tops-gains/89881/</ref>==Notes==* [[Charlie Carver]] ([[Acquaintances of Lynette Scavo#Preston and Porter Scavo|Porter Scavo]]), Joshua Logan Moore ([[Acquaintances of Lynette Scavo#Parker Scavo|Parker Scavo]]), [[Darcy Rose Byrnes]] ([[Acquaintances of Lynette Scavo#Penny Scavo|Penny Scavo]]) and [[Madison De La Garza]] ([[Acquaintances of Gabrielle Solis#Juanita Solis|Juanita Solis]]) do not appear and are not credited.* The title of this episode comes from lyrics in the song "Sorry Grateful", taken from the [[Stephen Sondheim]] musical ''[[Company (musical)|Company]]''.==International titles==*Arabic: ''نفس'' (Same)*Italiano: ''Cambiamenti'' (Changes)*Македонски : ''Се е различно , ништо не е сменето '' (Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed)*Български : ''Всичко е различно, нищо не се е променило '' (Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed)*ελληνικα: ''ολα ειναι διαφορετικα,τιποτα ομως δεν αλλαζει'' (Greek :Everything's Different, Nothing's changed)*Turkish: Her Şey Farklı, Hiçbir Şey Değişmedi (Everything's Different, Nothing's Changed)*German: ''Alles hat sich verändert, nichts hat sich verändert (Everything's changed, Nothing's changed)*French: ''Le jour du changement'' (The day of change)==References=={{reflist}}{{Desperate Housewives episodes}}[[Category:Desperate Housewives (season 7) episodes]][[Category:2011 American television episodes]])

(0	Miss Nepal 2011	{{COI|date=August 2011}}{{Infobox beauty pageant| winner      = [[Malina Joshi]]| photo       =| caption     =| represented = [[Dharan, Nepal|Dharan]]| date        = August 30, 2011| venue       = Tribhuvan Army Club, [[Kathmandu]]| broadcaster = [[Nepal Television|NTV]]| entrants    = 19| before      = [[Miss Nepal 2010|2010]]| next        = [[Miss Nepal 2012|2012]]}}'''Hidden Treasures Miss Nepal 2011''', the 17th [[Miss Nepal]] beauty pageant was held on the August 30, 2011, at the Tribhuvan Army Club in [[Kathmandu]]. The new main sponsor for the event Dabur Nepal was [[Lux (soap)|Lux]].<ref>http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-07-26/news/29816319_1_dabur-nepal-nepal-unilever-popular-beauty-pageant</ref> This year, 19 young women aged 19 years and above, had been shortlisted for the final from across the country. [[Sadichha Shrestha]] [[Miss Nepal 2010]] winner, crowned her successor in the finale event at Tribhuvan Army Club. The winner, [[Malina Joshi]], represented Nepal in the international pageants of [[Miss World 2011]].  First Runner Up [[Anupama Aura Gurung]] represented Nepal at [[Miss Earth 2011]], and [[Sarina Maskey]] went to the [[Miss International 2011]].<ref name="thehimalayantimes">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Malina+Joshi+stands+tall+as+Miss+Nepal+2011&NewsID=301096|title=The Himalayan Times - Nepal&#039;s No.1 English Daily Newspaper &#124; Nepal News, Latest Politics, Business, World, Sports, Entertainment, Travel, Life Style News|publisher=thehimalayantimes.com|accessdate=2016-07-21}}</ref>==Results=====Placements==={| class="wikitable"|-! (0	Portal:Muppets/Selected article/2	{{Portal:Muppets/Selected article/Layout|image=Jim Henson (1989) headshot.jpg|size=|caption=Henson at the 1989 [[Emmy Awards]]|text='''James Maury''' "'''Jim'''" '''Henson''' (September 24, 1936 – May 16, 1990) was an American [[puppeteer]] best known as the creator of [[The Muppets]]. As a puppeteer, Henson performed in various television programs, such as ''[[Sesame Street]]'' and ''[[The Muppet Show]]'', films such as ''[[The Muppet Movie]]'' and ''[[The Great Muppet Caper]]'', and created advanced puppets for projects like ''[[Fraggle Rock]]'', ''[[The Dark Crystal]]'', and ''[[Labyrinth (film)|Labyrinth]]''. He was also an [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated film director, [[Emmy Award]]-winning television producer, and the founder of [[The Jim Henson Company]], the [[Jim Henson Foundation]], and [[Jim Henson's Creature Shop]]. He died of ''[[Streptococcus pyogenes]]'' on May 16, 1990.Henson, who was born in [[Greenville, Mississippi]], and educated at [[University of Maryland, College Park]], is one of the most widely known puppeteers ever. He created ''[[Sam and Friends]]'' as a freshman in College Park. After suffering struggles with programs that he created, he eventually was selected to participate in ''[[Sesame Street]]''. During this time, he also contributed to ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. The success of ''Sesame Street'' spawned ''The Muppet Show'', which featured Muppets created by Henson. He also co-created with [[Michael Jacobs (producer)|Michael Jacobs]] the television show ''[[Dinosaurs (TV series)|Dinosaurs]]'' during his final years. In 1992, he [[List of prizes, medals, and awards|posthumously]] received the Courage of Conscience Award from The Peace Abbey, and on June 16, 2011, he posthumously received the [[Disney Legends]] Award.|link=Jim Henson}}<noinclude>[[Category:Muppets portal selected articles|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]</noinclude>)

(0	Stephen Hillier	{{use British English|date=August 2017}}{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}}{{Infobox military person|name= Sir Stephen Hillier|image= Air Marshal Stephen Hillier.jpg|caption= Air Chief Marshal Stephen Hillier|birth_date=|death_date=|birth_place=|death_place=|nickname=|allegiance= United Kingdom|branch= [[Royal Air Force]]|serviceyears= 1980 –|rank= [[Air Chief Marshal]]|unit=|commands= [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]]<br/>[[No. 2 Group RAF|No. 2 Group]]<br/>[[RAF Lossiemouth]]<br/>[[No. 2 Squadron RAF|II (AC) Squadron]]|battles= [[Gulf War]]<br/>[[Iraq War]]|awards= [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]]<br/>[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]<br/>[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]<br/>[[Bronze Star Medal]] (United States)|laterwork=}}[[Air Chief Marshal]] '''Sir Stephen John Hillier''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KCB|CBE|DFC|ADC|sep=,|size=100%}} is a senior [[Royal Air Force]] officer, who serves as [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]]. He won the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] for actions in the Gulf in 1999 and was awarded the US [[Bronze Star Medal]] for service in the [[Iraq War]]. He went on to be Air Officer Commanding, [[No. 2 Group RAF|No. 2 Group]], Director Information Superiority at the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] and then [[Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff|Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff (Capability)]]. Hillier succeeded Air Chief Marshal [[Andrew Pulford]] as [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]] on 12 July 2016.==Service career==Hillier was commissioned as an [[acting pilot officer]] on 6 November 1980,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=48460|supp=y|page=17812|date=22 December 1980}}</ref> and regraded to [[pilot officer]] (after Initial Officer Training) on 6 November 1981.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=48796|supp=y|page=14595|date=16 November 1981}}</ref> He was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 6 November 1982.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=49188|supp=y|page=15998|date=7 December 1982}}</ref> He was a pilot – flying the [[Panavia Tornado|Tornado]] aircraft – and served in the 1991 [[Gulf War]].<ref name=ATA_Event>{{cite web|url=http://www.atamuseum.org/events.html |title=ATA Museum Events page (includes photo) |publisher=Air Transport Auxiliary Museum |accessdate=11 July 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110162614/http://www.atamuseum.org/events.html |archivedate=10 November 2012 }}</ref> He was promoted to [[squadron leader]] on 1 July 1991<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=52591|supp=y|pages=10091–10092|date=1 July 1991}}</ref> and [[Wing commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 July 1996,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=54453|page=8919|date=1 July 1996}}</ref> and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his actions commanding [[No. 2 Squadron RAF|II (AC) Squadron]] in the Gulf during [[Operation Southern Watch]] on 29 October 1999.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=55651|supp=y|page=11558|date=29 October 1999}}</ref>Promoted to [[group captain]] on 1 July 2000,<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=55901|supp=y|page=7250|date=4 July 2000}}</ref> Hillier became station commander at [[RAF Lossiemouth]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/fp/news/politics/820248/former-lossiemouth-commander-appointed-to-top-post/|title=Former Lossiemouth commander appointed to top post|publisher=Press and Journal|date=31 January 2016|accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref> He then served in the [[Iraq War]],<ref name=ATA_Event /> where he commanded the Tornado Detachment with aircraft supplied from [[No. 2 Squadron RAF|No. 2]], [[No. 12 Squadron RAF|12]] and [[617 Squadron|617 Squadrons]].<ref>{{cite journal|editor1-last=Wise|editor1-first=Andrew|title=Crews are all heroes|journal=RAF News|date=18 April 2003|issue=1,071|page=11|publisher=RAF|location=Innsworth|issn=0035-8614}}</ref> For this, he was awarded the US [[Bronze Star Medal]] on 31 October 2003.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=57100|supp=y|page=12|date=31 October 2003}}</ref> He was also appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the [[2005 New Year Honours]],<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=57509|supp=y|pages=4–6|date=31 December 2004}}</ref> just prior to his promotion to [[air commodore]] on 1 January 2005 of that year.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=57553|supp=y|page=1518|date=8 February 2005}}</ref>Hillier served as Head of Theatre Airspace Capability in the Ministry of Defence prior to his promotion to [[air vice marshal]] and appointment as Air Officer Commanding [[No. 2 Group RAF|No. 2 Group]] in September 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/E57D7C91_1143_EC82_2EF22AC09F8B7A7B.doc |title=Air Rank Appointments List 03/08 |publisher=Royal Air Force |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> In October 2010 he returned to the Ministry of Defence as Director Information Superiority<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/1796DE51_5056_A318_A84060B07945066F.doc |title=Air Rank Appointments List 03/10 |publisher=Royal Air Force |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> and in June 2012 he was promoted to [[air marshal]] and appointed [[Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff|Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff (Capability)]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafcms/mediafiles/F0E763D0_5056_A318_A891278D1D13AB0D.doc |title=Air Rank Appointments List 03/11 |publisher=Royal Air Force |accessdate=11 July 2012}}</ref> He managed the UK's Carrier Enabled Power Projection Programme, encompassing the [[Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carrier|aircraft carrier]], [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II|F35B Lightning II]] and [[AgustaWestland AW101|Merlin Helicopter]] programmes; his appointment has been criticised by former [[First Sea Lord]] Admiral [[Alan West, Baron West of Spithead|Lord West]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3288413/Officer-charge-Royal-Navy-s-new-6-2bn-aircraft-carriers-RAF-man-never-served-sea.html|title=Officer put in charge of Royal Navy's new £6.2bn aircraft carriers is a top RAF man who has never served at sea|publisher=Daily Mail|date=25 October 2015|accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref> Hillier became [[Air Aide-de-Camp]] (ADC) to [[Queen Elizabeth II]] and succeeded Air Chief Marshal [[Andrew Pulford]] as [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]] on 12 July 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/the-secretary-of-state-announces-new-senior-appointments-in-the-armed-services|title=The Secretary of State announces new Senior Appointments in the Armed Services|publisher=Ministry of Defence|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/organisation/chief-of-the-air-staff.cfm |title=Sir Stephen Hillier |publisher=Royal Air Force |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref><ref name=":0" />Hillier was appointed [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] (KCB) in the [[2014 New Year Honours]].<ref name=":0">{{London Gazette| issue = 61656| date = 26 July 2016| page = 16088| supp = y}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/268848/New_Year_Honours_2014_military_division_list.pdf |title=New Year Honours 2014 Military Division|publisher=UK Government|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref>{{Navbox| title = <small>Decorations| navbar = plain| style = width:315px; float:right| groupstyle = background:white| listclass = hlist| group1 = [[File:Order of the Bath (ribbon).svg|60px]]| list1  = * <small>[[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] (2014)| group2 = [[File:Order of the British Empire (Military) Ribbon.png|60px]]| list2 = * <small>[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (2005)| group3 = [[File:United Kingdom Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon.svg|60px]]| list3  = * <small>[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] (1999)| group4 = [[File:Gulf Medal BAR.svg|60px]]| list4  = * <small>[[Gulf Medal|Gulf War Medal]]| group5 = [[File:General Service Medal 1962 BAR.svg|60px]]| list5  = * <small>[[General Service Medal (1962)|General Service Medal]]| group6 = [[File:Iraq Medal BAR.svg|60px]]| list6  = * <small>[[Iraq Medal (United Kingdom)|Iraq Medal]]| group7 = [[File:Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal ribbon.png|60px]]| list7  = * <small>[[Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal]] (2002)| group8 = [[File:QEII Diamond Jubilee Medal ribbon.png|60px]]| list8  = * <small>[[Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal]] (2012)| group9 = [[File:Bronze Star Medal ribbon.svg|60px]]| list9  = * <small>[[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]] (2003 – United States)}}==References=={{Reflist|30em}}{{s-start}}{{s-mil}}{{s-bef | before = Unknown}}{{s-ttl | title = Head of Theatre Airspace Capability, Ministry of Defence| years = to August 2008}}{{s-aft | [[Paul Lambert (Royal Navy officer)|Paul Lambert]]}}{{s-ttl | title = [[Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff|Deputy Chief of the Defence Staff (Capability)]]| years = June 2012 – January 2016}}{{s-aft | (0	Wangchun Bridge station	{{one source|date=December 2014}}{{Infobox station| name             = Wangchun Bridge| native_name      = 望春桥| native_name_lang = zh-Hans| symbol_location  = ningbo| symbol           = rt| symbol_location2 =| symbol2          =| symbol_location3 =| symbol3          =| symbol_location4 =| symbol4          =| image            = Platform of Wangchun Bridge Station, 2014-07-06.JPG| alt              =| caption          =| mlanguage        = <!-- Template:Infobox Chinese/Chinese -->| other_name       =| address          = [[Haishu District]], [[Ningbo]], [[Zhejiang]]| country          = China| coordinates      =| operator         = Ningbo Rail Transit Co. Ltd.| line             = {{rail color box|system=NingboRT|line=1|inline=yes}}| platforms        = 2 (1 [[island platform]])| connections      =| structure        = Underground| disabled         =| code             =| opened           = 30 May 2014| closed           =| former           = Wangchun| passengers       =| pass_year        =| services         = {{s-rail|title=Ningbo Rail Transit}}{{s-line|system=NingboRT|line=1|previous=Xujiacao Changle|next=Zemin}}}}'''Wangchun Bridge Station''' ({{zh|s=望春桥站}}) is a [[metro station|station]] on Line 1 of the [[Ningbo Rail Transit]] that started operations on 30{{nbsp}}May 2014. It is situated under Wangchun Road ({{zh|c=望春路|lomks=no}}) in the [[Haishu District]] of Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province, eastern China.<ref>[http://www.nbmetro.com/line_info.php Ningbo Rail Transit station information]</ref>==Exits=={| class="wikitable"! style="width:70px" colspan="2" | Exit number! Exit location|-| align="center" colspan="2" | Exit A| Wangchun Road|-| align="center" colspan="2" | Exit C [[File:NingboRT Elevator Logo.svg|25px]]| Wangchun Road, Xiangcheng Avenue|-| align="center" colspan="2" | Exit D| Wangchun Road, Xinyuan Road|}==References=={{reflist}}{{Ningbo Rail Transit Station|line1=yes|line6=yes}}{{coord|29.8843|N|121.5047|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}[[Category:Railway stations in Zhejiang]][[Category:Railway stations opened in 2014]][[Category:2014 establishments in China]][[Category:Ningbo Rail Transit stations]])

(0	Al Thakhira	{{Infobox settlement<!-- See Template:Infobox settlement for additional fields and descriptions -->| name                    = Al Thakhira| native_name             = الذخيره| native_name_lang        = <!-- ISO 639-2 code e.g. "fr" for French. If more than one, use {{lang}} instead --> ar| settlement_type         = Town| image_skyline           =| imagesize               =| image_alt               =| image_caption           =| image_flag              =| flag_alt                =| image_seal              =| seal_alt                =| image_shield            =| shield_alt              =| nickname                =| motto                   =| image_map               =| map_alt                 =| map_caption             =| pushpin_map             = Qatar| pushpin_label_position  =| pushpin_map_alt         =| pushpin_map_caption     =| coordinates             = {{coord|25|44|05|N|51|32|51|E|display=inline,title}}| coor_pinpoint           =| coordinates_footnotes   =| subdivision_type        = Country| subdivision_name        = [[Qatar]]| subdivision_type1       = Municipality| subdivision_name1       = [[Al Khor (municipality)|Al Khor]]| subdivision_type2       =| subdivision_name2       =| area_total_km2          =| population_footnotes    =| population_total        = 13,511| population_as_of        = 2004| population_density_km2  = auto| population_demonym      =| population_note         =| timezone1               =| utc_offset1             =| timezone1_DST           =| utc_offset1_DST         =| postal_code_type        =| postal_code             =| area_code_type          =| area_code               =| iso_code                =| website                 =| footnotes               =}}[[File:AlThakhiraCoastline.jpg|thumb|right|Al Thakhira Beach, Qatar]][[File:Mangrove03-Qatar-Dakhira.jpg|thumb|Mangrove forest in Al Thakhira]][[File:An old masjid at Dhakhira, Qatar.jpg|thumb|right|Old mosque in Al Thakhira]]'''Al Thakhira''' ({{lang-ar|الذخيره}}; also spelled '''Al Dakhira''') is a town on the coast of the [[Al Khor (municipality)|Al Khor municipality]] in [[Qatar]], about {{convert|7|km|mi}} northeast of the city of [[Al Khor (city)|Al Khor]]. The area is home to [[Al Dakhira Nature Reserve]], an island with mangroves, and a beach.<ref>[http://www.qatartourism.gov.qa/en-us/thingstodo/naturallandmarks.aspx Natural Landmarks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703154542/http://www.qatartourism.gov.qa/en-us/thingstodo/naturallandmarks.aspx |date=2015-07-03 }}, Qatar Tourism Authority</ref>==Etymology==Al Thakhira translates to 'ammunition' in English. There are two prevalent theories regarding the origin of this name. The first theory states that its inhabitants used to keep large reserves of food, money and weapons. Another theory alleges that the town was named by a group of sailors who had lost their bearings. After finding and docking at Al Thakhira, they set out to look for food, taking with them their weapons and ammunition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geoportal.gisqatar.org.qa/qmap/index.html|title=GIS Portal|publisher=Ministry of Municipality and Environment|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>==History==[[John Gordon Lorimer (1870-1914)|J.G. Lorimer]]'s ''[[Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf, Oman and Central Arabia|Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf]]'' gives an account of Al Thakhira in 1908:{{quote|A village on the east coast of Qatar, situated on a khor or inlet of the same name about 30 miles north of [[Doha]], and consisting of about 300 houses of the Mahandah ([[Al Muhannadi]]) tribe. The people are all pearl-divers, following no other occupation except fishing and owning no flocks or herds. Fifteen pearl boats [manned by 180 men], two other sea-going boats of the mushuwah type and five fishing boats are owned at Dhakhira. Transport animals are 10 camels. Drinking water is from Lubwairdah, 2 miles to the north-west.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qdl.qa/en/archive/81055/vdc_100023909213.0x00009d|title='Gazetteer of Arabia Vol. I' [525] (556/1050)|publisher=Qatar Digital Library|accessdate=28 July 2015}} ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref>}}==Demographics=={| class="wikitable"|-!
